fields.headline: Sunday round-up
fields.trailText: In the National League Leicestershire tied for the second week in succession when a bye off the last ball gave them a share of the First Division game against Lancashire at Old Trafford.
fields.body:
In the National League Leicestershire tied for the second week in succession when a bye off the last ball gave them a share of the First Division game against Lancashire at Old Trafford.

Jon Dakin, who had just hammered Lancashire's Peter Martin for six, needed to score two off the final delivery, missed with a big swing but put everything into his run.

Anil Kumble, racing to the danger end, looked to be on to a loser as the wicketkeeper Warren Hegg gathered the ball and then rolled it towards the stumps. But it missed by inches, leaving Leicestershire on 177 for nine in reply to Lancashire's 177 for seven.

The visitors' acting captain Ben Smith made 90 off 118 balls; Sourav Ganguly (63) at last made an impression for Lancashire.

 Gloucestershire successfully defended 150 for nine in a rain-affected game against Northamptonshire at Wantage Road. James Averis took five for 20, including three in five balls, to restrict the hosts to 112.

 In the Second Division Nottinghamshire pulled off a three-run victory at Chelmsford. Needing 191, Essex subsided once Nasser Hussain (55) was out. Eight were needed from the last over but the young left-arm seamer David Lucas kept his nerve.

 Shane Warne's three for 33 was not enough to overcome Hampshire's batting deficiencies against Middlesex at Lord's. The visitors struggled to reach 147, Robin Smith's 71 comprising almost half the total, as Middlesex strolled to victory by four wickets.

 At Edgbaston Nick Knight continued his impressive start to the season with an unbeaten 68 from 79 balls as Warwickshire crushed Glamorgan by nine wickets.

webTitle: Schofield's heroics raise hopes of the unthinkable

fields.headline: Schofield's heroics raise hopes of the unthinkable
fields.trailText: Lancashire swept to an innings victory over Leicestershire at Old Trafford, sparking hopes among the county's long-suffering supporters that they are ready to end their 66-year championship drought.
fields.body:
An impressive all-round performance by Chris Schofield swept Lancashire to an innings victory over Leicestershire at Old Trafford, sparking hopes among the county's long-suffering supporters that they are ready to end their 66-year championship drought.

Schofield gave his test prospects a timely boost, following up his unbeaten 66 with four for 82 as Lancashire rose to second place behind Somerset in the first division. The rookie leg-spinner snared three of the last four wickets on Saturday, enticing Vince Wells to edge to slip, bowling Anil Kumble round his legs and having Neil Burns stumped.

Hampshire players have been summoned for extra net practice after they crashed to a nine-wicket defeat by Somerset.

The England pace bowler Andrew Caddick, who took seven for 64, inspired the west country side to victory with a day to spare. Among his victims was Shane Warne, who completed a pair in the match.

Nottinghamshire are the surprise second division leaders despite failing to reach a target of only 198 in 51 overs to beat Essex at Chelmsford. They finished on 150 for six.

Adrian Rollins fell four runs short of a century in each innings as Northamptonshire eventually drew comfortably with Middlesex at Lord's. The Australian Matthew Hayden made 93 from 123 balls.

An 81-run stand between Matthew Maynard and Adrian Shaw helped Glamorgan scramble to a draw against Warwickshire.

fields.headline: McLean shines in record stand
fields.standfirst: Pakistan 288 West Indies 222-7
fields.trailText: Third day report: Pakistan 288 West Indies 222-7
fields.body:
A record sixth-wicket partnership against Pakistan of 74 between Shivnarine Chanderpaul and Nixon McLean rescued the West Indian innings from embarrassment on the third day of the first Test at the Bourda ground here in Guyana yesterday.

Though the West Indian batting still fluctuates between fragile and suspect, the stand between Chanderpaul and McLean reflects the new team spirit under Jimmy Adams's leadership. Not long ago - as recently as the first four days of the first Test against Zimbabwe in Trinidad in January, for example - any slip in the batting could be guaranteed to turn into a slide.

The sight of a West Indian bowler putting his nose to the grindstone and the middle of his bat to good balls brings some comfort to Caribbean cricket fans, if not quite as much as they would take from the same application a bit higher in the batting order. McLean batted solidly for his 46 runs, and even played solid cricket strokes, driving more convincingly than Chanderpaul through mid-on for a couple of his nine boundaries.

After the loss of the entire morning session to rain, until McLean and Chanderpaul came together at 139 for six, West Indies had found batting difficult on a wicket good enough to have allowed Pakistan to recover from 39 for five to 288 all out; and even that rescue act reflected the fragility of the West Indies batting, again exposed by good spin and pace bowling and, on one occasion, even without any bowling at all.

A training-manual communication error between Chanderpaul, taking the strike on his home ground, and the wicketkeeper Ridley Jacobs, the last of the recognised batsmen, had Jacobs run out by such a distance that he did not even attempt to make his ground.

Chanderpaul never took his eyes off the ball as it ran down to short third man until Jacobs was standing right next to him. The first time the batsmen looked at each other was immediately before Jacobs turned to walk back to the pavilion.

A run-out was a luxury West Indies could not afford, far less one that could have shattered the team spirit so carefully nurtured by Adams, and particularly after Adams, batting solidly and confidently on Saturday, was out to a spectacular catch by Younis Khan in the slips in the first over of the day.

The other wicket to go before tea, that of Chris Gayle, also went far more easily than it ought with the score on 130 and with four wickets down. The ball hung in the air long enough for Wasim Akram to brew a cup of tea before taking an easy catch at mid-off.

Chanderpaul, whose last innings on his home ground produced a century, grafted hard for his 46 runs which may have begun to turn the game back towards West Indies. At least the home-town support was solidly behind him.

In Guyana, touring teams from India and Pakistan can also often find strong support among the local Asian population, but Moin Khan's team have managed to alienate the crowd by continuous appealing when batsmen were patently not out.

The umpires Steve Bucknor and Rudi Koertzen may well have developed an immunity to Pakistan appeals and McLean seemed to have developed some resistance as well. When he was out to the first ball of Waqar Younis's spell with the new ball he stood his ground until Bucknor sent him on his way, the last wicket to fall before play was stopped for light.

webTitle: Johnson gets Zimbabwe off the mark

fields.headline: Johnson gets Zimbabwe off the mark
fields.trailText: Top-class cricket returned to Hastings after 11 years yesterday when Neil Johnson's accomplished century helped Zimbabwe to their first win of a troubled tour.
fields.body:
Top-class cricket returned to Hastings after 11 years yesterday when Neil Johnson's accomplished century helped Zimbabwe to their first win of a troubled tour.

Zimbabwe, chasing a target of 265, eased home by eight wickets with three of their 50 overs in hand, the left-handed Johnson remaining unbeaten on 107 after century partnerships with Grant Flower and Murray Goodwin.

In front of a crowd of 2,000 at the smart new Horntye Park, replacing the now defunct Prior Meadow, the Sussex innings revolved around a second-wicket stand of 176 between Richard Montgomerie, who made an undefeated 129, and Tony Cottey with 85.

Chris Adams, the Sussex captain and an England hopeful, fell for just a single. He played a delivery from Bryan Strang on to his stumps attempting to drive him through the offside.

On a superb batting strip, Johnson hit 14 boundaries and a huge six off Michael Yardy in his attractive 134-ball innings. His fine opening stand with Flower ended when Flower, attempting a single off James Kirtley, was brilliantly run out for 53 by a direct hit to the striker's end from Adams at backward point.

Johnson was given further excellent support in the sunshine by Goodwin who had made 63, including eight fours and a six over mid-wicket at Robin Martin-Jenkins' expense, when he skied a catch to Adams at short square-leg from a top edge off Yardy. The former captain Alistair Campbell then joined Johnson to see Zimbabwe home in untroubled fashion.

Sussex earlier made 264 for four after choosing to bat. The former Northamptonshire opener Montgomerie struck 11 fours and a six off 154 balls and his partnership with Cottey took just 34 overs.

After Adams had gone in the fourth over of the day, Montgomerie and Cottey batted with confidence as Zimbabwe got through eight bowlers. Cottey had hit eight fours in his attractive 102-ball innings when he was trapped leg-before sweeping at the medium pace of Goodwin.

Montgomerie's century took 124 balls and he added 38 for the third wicket with Umer Rashid before the latter was run out for 11. Rashid failed to make his ground after Montgomerie refused a single after pushing a delivery from Goodwin into the covers.

fields.headline: Scottish round-up
fields.trailText: Rangers showed no signs of taking their foot off the pedal yesterday as they beat Kilmarnock 2-0 with a side depleted by injury and suspension.
fields.body:
Rangers' record

Rangers showed no signs of taking their foot off the pedal yesterday as they beat Kilmarnock 2-0 with a side depleted by injury and suspension.

Expertly crafted strikes from Claudio Reyna on 43 minutes and Jorg Albertz 13 minutes from time put Rangers 22 points ahead of second-placed Celtic and made sure they will post the biggest ever winning points margin even if they lose their last two games and Celtic win theirs. The previous highest Premier League gap between top and runners-up was 15 points in 1994-95.

Sergio Porrini made his long-awaited return to the Rangers line-up after an ankle injury and the 19-year-old Robert Malcolm made a surprise debut.

 Aberdeen's manager Ebbe Skovdahl has warned his players they will lose heavily in the Scottish Cup final against Rangers on May 27 if they perform as they did against Celtic on Saturday.

The Dons were beaten 5-1 at Parkhead by a Celtic side who have now scored 25 goals against them this season in five cup and league meetings. "There is no chance for us at all in the cup final if we play like we did today," said Skovdahl. "I feel we have fallen back in recent months from the progress we were making. We have two league games left before then to improve the confidence."

 The amateur side Queen's Park won the Third Division championship with a 3-2 victory at Cowdenbeath on Saturday.

fields.headline: Third Division round-up
fields.trailText: Cobblers' credit
fields.body:
Cobblers' credit

About 2,000 delighted Northampton fans invaded the pitch after their team came from a goal down at Torquay to clinch the third automatic promotion place, Jamie Forrester and Steve Howard getting their goals before half-time.

Tony Bedeau opened the scoring for Torquay in the 17th minute, the first goal the Cobblers had conceded in almost eight hours of football and during which they had peeled off six consecutive wins. "The players have been a credit," said Kevin Wilson, the manager. "When we were relegated last season they vowed then to get straight back, and they've done it."

 It all rendered Darlington's 2-0 win at home to Lincoln irrelevant, but Jesper Hjorth and Peter Duffield's goals at least ensured that the Quakers finished fourth. They face Hartlepool in the play-offs, their near-neighbours winning 3-0 at Hull and securing seventh place thanks to Torquay's defeat and Cheltenham's 2-1 loss at Southend.

 Peterborough's 1-0 win at Chester dropped their hosts into the Conference and saved second-bottom Carlisle for the second consecutive season; last time round they held Scarborough to a draw. Peterborough will face Barnet, one of their manager Barry Fry's previous clubs, in the other play-off.

 Peter Davenport resigned as Macclesfield manager after failing to agree terms for a new contract and failed to travel to Halifax, where the team duly won 1-0.

fields.headline: Second Division round-up
fields.trailText: Rovers lose out
fields.body:
Rovers lose out

Bristol Rovers lost to the only goal at Cardiff and finished seventh, allowing Millwall and Stoke to make it to the play-offs. The Lions got there by virtue of a 1-0 win against lowly Oxford to finish in fifth place and the Potteries club came sixth despite losing by the only goal at Reading.

Gillingham, whose 1-0 defeat at Wrexham denied them automatic promotion, will play Stoke, with the first game at the Britannia stadium, while Wigan, who drew 2-2 at Bournemouth, face Millwall, a repeat of last season's Auto Windscreens final which the Lancashire club won 1-0. The south Londoners host the first game.

 Darren Caskey's 81st-minute penalty put Reading out of reach of Stoke City, and Bristol Rovers' defeat came at the hands of already-relegated Cardiff, where Scott Young got the goal. Millwall's came from Neil Harris, who made it 25 for the season. Pat McGibbon and Neil Roberts levelled for Wigan in the final five minutes.

 Preston ruined Tony Fawthorp's first day as Bristol City's manager, goals from Brett Angell and Michael Appleton delighting the champions' 3,000 travelling fans.

fields.headline: First Division round-up
fields.trailText: Relief for Albion
fields.body:
Relief for Albion

Two goals in five minutes midway through the second half against Charlton secured West Bromwich Albion's survival, writes Trevor Haylett . A fifth goal in eight games for Bob Taylor, whose two goals won a key Easter Monday victory against Preston, followed Richard Sneekes's 65th-minute score and sealed the champions' end-of-term run of seven defeats.

 Wolves won 1-0 at the already relegated Port Vale thanks to a late goal from Colin Robinson but failed to make the play-offs as Bolton beat Norwich. "The Bolton defeat last week looks as if it cost us but the poor start has been just as costly," said the Wolves manager Colin Lee.

 Swindon's manager Colin Todd said that he has much to do after seeing his relegated team draw 2-2 at Sheffield United. "Rome wasn't built in a day," he warned.

fields.headline: Terriers lack bite
fields.trailText: Fulham 3 - 0 Huddersfield
fields.body:
More than 3,500 Huddersfield supporters came south to see their team go for a win that would have secured them a play-off place, but they left London bitterly disappointed as Fulham convincingly denied them a tilt at the Premiership.

Despite the magnitude of what was at stake, Huddersfield were curiously lethargic and Fulham always looked the more potent attacking force despite having nothing to play for.

Lee Clark deservedly put the home side in front after a goalmouth scramble on 33 minutes, then doubled the lead in the second half from the penalty spot when Barry Hayles was pulled down by Steve Jenkins. With 14 minutes remaining, Bjarne Goldbaek sealed Huddersfield's fate by beating the goalkeeper Nico Vaesen with an exquisite chip from 18 yards.

The final scoreline, coupled with Bolton's 1-0 home victory over Norwich, dropped the Terriers from sixth to eighth place and left the manager Steve Bruce "totally disappointed".

"The players have worked very hard this year and it's the first time we've dropped out of the top six in a long time," he said afterwards. "Maybe the season lasted a month too long. Having to patch people up with injuries and play people who were not fit has caught up with us.

"Those injuries have hit us badly. We did not have enough strength in depth to cope and that's something I will have to address next season. The players have given it their all and I couldn't ask for any more, but certainly we were not good enough, with that little bit of quality lacking."

Fulham's caretaker manager Karlheinz Riedle was also pondering a season of missed opportunity. "The players showed big character in a game we did not have to win," he said. "They showed great quality and I think in the end justice was done with the result.

"Our biggest problem this season has not been the home matches but away from home. We have not won enough away from home and that's why we're not in the play-offs either."

Despite the magnitude of what was at stake, Huddersfield were curiously lethargic and Fulham always looked the more potent attacking force despite having nothing to play for. Lee Clark deservedly put the home side in front after a goalmouth scramble on 33 minutes, then doubled the lead in the second half from the penalty spot when Barry Hayles was pulled down by Steve Jenkins. With 14 minutes remaining, Bjarne Goldbaek sealed Huddersfield's fate by beating the goalkeeper Nico Vaesen with an exquisite chip from 18 yards. The final scoreline, coupled with Bolton's 1-0 home victory over Norwich, dropped the Terriers from sixth to eighth place and left the manager Steve Bruce "totally disappointed". "The players have worked very hard this year and it's the first time we've dropped out of the top six in a long time," he said afterwards. "Maybe the season lasted a month too long. Having to patch people up with injuries and play people who were not fit has caught up with us. "Those injuries have hit us badly. We did not have enough strength in depth to cope and that's something I will have to address next season. The players have given it their all and I couldn't ask for any more, but certainly we were not good enough, with that little bit of quality lacking." Fulham's caretaker manager Karlheinz Riedle was also pondering a season of missed opportunity. "The players showed big character in a game we did not have to win," he said. "They showed great quality and I think in the end justice was done with the result. "Our biggest problem this season has not been the home matches but away from home. We have not won enough away from home and that's why we're not in the play-offs either."

fields.headline: Reds draw fourth straight blank
fields.trailText: Liverpool 0 - 0 Southampton
fields.body:
It is becoming all too easy to forget just how much progress Liverpool have made this season for they have lost the plot to such dramatic effect that they seemingly have little interest in penning the final chapter.

After their fourth game without a goal, the Champions League place which seemed theirs for the taking now represents nothing more tangible than a waking dream.

They sit third in the Premiership table this morning but if Leeds United should defeat Everton at Elland Road this evening they will probably have to settle for a place in the Uefa Cup.

At the end the leaden-footed Reds trudged away towards the dressing room, the manager Gérard Houllier shaking each of them warmly by the hand. They have done exceptionally well, exceeding all expectations, but, as the Frenchman knows, the tank is now dry, the batteries drained.

"There is no funeral here at all," he said. "What we must remember is that we have qualified for Europe; last season we finished with nothing at all. Even if Leeds United do win against Everton we will still be chasing a place in the Champions League next weekend."

Two successive defeats is more than Houllier can bear and so, in the traditional manner, the axe was swung. Discarded were the out-of-touch Dietmar Hamann, the often clumsy David Thompson and the exhausted Michael Owen. "He had played five games in 25 days," Houllier said, "and considering the problems he has had it was a sound decision to give him a rest."

The most celebrated of the returnees was Robbie Fowler, free of ankle trouble and able to start a senior fixture for the first time since last September. With a forward of his predatory instinct in the side it is incumbent upon team-mates to present him with the ball in advantageous positions. This Liverpool neglected to do and just before the hour the crestfallen Fowler was substituted.

He had wandered around like a lost soul on the periphery of the action while all the chances of any note were squandered by the other striker to win promotion from the bench.

Titi Camara sprints forward like a gazelle but then, as the frame of the goal comes into focus, he shoots irrespective of distance, irrespective of angle. He can be magical, he can be almost comical but only rarely does he occupy the middle ground.

In a first half which only rarely raised itself to an acceptable level Southampton always seemed the more likely to score, and they would have done had Liverpool's goalkeeper Sander Westerveld not produced a quite remarkable save to turn aside Jo Tessem's header after 30 minutes.

Indeed Westerveld was to rescue his colleagues on several occasions, particularly in the second period when Liverpool's desperation was at its most pronounced. Their football disintegrated as, fittingly, the early-afternoon sunshine was replaced by ominous grey clouds.

With too many players swift to delegate responsibility there was no cohesion, no hint of fluency and no penetration. It was painful to watch.

Liverpool will toss the dice for one last time against Bradford City next Sunday. You really would not put a bean on them winning at Valley Parade, an alarming prospect for Houllier, for Liverpool's bankers and, of course, for Wimbledon.

fields.headline: Ogrizovic gives lesson in loyalty
fields.trailText: Coventry 4 - 1 Sheff Wed
fields.body:
Long after the final whistle several Coventry players, led by their captain Gary McAllister, fell to their knees and performed the "we are not worthy" salute to Steve Ogrizovic, the gentleman-goalkeeper retiring after his 601st and last game in Sky Blue colours.

As many games may pass before Sheffield Wednesday diehards forget, if not forgive, this gutless performance. It was Wednesday's players who should have offered a gesture of unworthiness to their long-suffering support.

Relegation will surely be pronounced official at Highbury tomorrow, but the fans have already delivered their verdict; seldom can even such a poor team have been so derided by their own. Long before Coventry's fourth goal they chanted "you're not fit to wear the shirt" and "cheerio". The foreigners expected to jump ship soon were roundly booed; the home-produced players were cheered.

The recriminations have started and it was difficult not to sympathise with Wednesday's own loyalist goalkeeper Kevin Pressman, for whom this is a grisly rerun of relegation 10 years ago.

"It was a very poor show," he said. "We must appreciate how [the fans] feel. They've paid good money all season and it must have been horrific for them. The spirit is not as strong as in years gone by."

Of Wednesday's overseas contingent, Pressman said: "They may not be 100% committed. They are coming to earn a wage but how many of them are going to retire here at the end of it?"

On Saturday it was McAllister's show as much as Ogrizovic's. The 35-year-old midfielder scored twice with lovely precision, set up Ysrael Zuniga's header with a shot against the bar and hit the underside of the bar with a 30-yard free-kick.

Moustapha Hadji, who deserved a hat-trick, was compensated by his well placed drive late on. It rendered Gilles de Bilde's strike a minute later utterly academic.

webTitle: Jewell's smash and grab doomed to fail

fields.headline: Jewell's smash and grab doomed to fail
fields.standfirst: Bradford manager left pondering how to beat Liverpool after slipping back into bottom three
fields.trailText: Leicester 3 - 0 Bradford
fields.body:
Shortly before kick-off the former Leicester midfielder Alan Birchenall and his entourage completed their hour-and-a-half charity run around the perimeter of the pitch. The performance Bradford produced over the 90 minutes that followed suggested they had taken part too.

For a team in such desperate need of a win, theirs was a curiously - suicidally - negative and inept display. Paul Jewell's team looked worthy of the relegation spot they occupy this morning. The wonder was how they have survived to the final day.

Dean Saunders, Bradford's lone striker, said they had "tried to come and smash and grab". It ended up more trash and drab. All they have achieved is to take their destiny from their own hands: a repeat of this at home to Liverpool on Sunday and they will go down.

"They were a bit flat," said Leicester's midfielder Neil Lennon. "I thought they would be a lot more fired up. When we played them up there they were tremendous, really up for it, and they beat us pretty convincingly [3-1]. They sat back quite a bit here and let us have a lot of the ball."

Certainly Jewell's decision to play Saunders on his own looked ill judged. Sure, the same policy had gained a 1-0 victory at Sunderland in their previous away match. But even Leicester's manager Martin O'Neill admitted that, after the "euphoria" of victory at Anfield, "it might have been the best time for Bradford to get into us".

Instead they retreated, isolated Saunders and invited pressure they never looked capable of withstanding. When they got the ball they wasted it. Rarely can Leicester have been granted so much space and possession.

Saunders declined to criticise his manager's tactics but one comment about his solo role - "It's hard enough when you're 25, never mind 35" - suggested it is as popular with him as Shakespeare is chez Vorderman. Bradford created not a single noteworthy chance from open play.

"We're gutted that we played like that when we needed a world-beating performance," Saunders said. "We're not blessed with some of players other teams have got so we have to be up for every game. We deserved nothing. The only thing we can take is that Wimbledon didn't win."

Wimbledon did, though, climb above Bradford on goal difference thanks to their late draw with Aston Villa. Wimbledon's goal difference is better by five and Sunday's trip to Southampton gives them an advantage. Liverpool will arrive at Valley Parade in search of points and a Champions League place.

Yet Leicester proved last Wednesday that Gérard Houllier's team are vulnerable and Bradford's home form will give them hope. "They've got to knock Liverpool out of their rhythm," Lennon said. "They've got to be positive and think they can win."

If they thought they could win here, they did not show it. Three Leicester goals in nine second-half minutes confirmed the inevitable. Matt Elliott, pushed into attack because there was so little to do in defence, first headed in Steve Guppy's corner and then a Lennon cross. Tony Cottee spun past Andrew O'Brien and coolly added the third.

"Most people thought we'd be buried by Christmas," Saunders added. "Hopefully it will come right for us but we'll have to play a lot better than that."

fields.headline: Ipswich tread familiar ground
fields.trailText: Ipswich 2 - 0 Walsall
fields.body:
It would be stretching the truth to suggest there were more happy faces at Frank Dobson's headquarters on Thursday night, but this was not the place to be for a party. Defeat sent Walsall straight back down and Ipswich must endure the play-offs again.

In each of the past three seasons George Burley's Ipswich side have stumbled in football's lottery without so much as a sniff of the Wembley burgers. To add to their worries Bolton, their conquerors on away goals last year, are lying in wait once more.

It is impossible to imagine Ipswich not being filled with trepidation, but they deserve a change of luck. Their fans, generous and stoic in their disappointment, are hopeful. "We're going to do it this year," they chimed, though no one will be booking coaches to north London yet.

For 10 minutes on an afternoon of sweeping emotions Ipswich had second place in their grasp. But the hysteria that greeted David Johnson's first goal, when Manchester City were 1-0 down, evaporated as news of events at Ewood Park filtered through. The dejection was tangible on and off the pitch. Johnson's second was merely a footnote.

Ipswich showed here that they are a more stylish team than City, sweeping through midfield and down the flanks. But they remain vulnerable to opponents who set out to stop them playing, and have paid for failing to kill sides off.

"Blackburn hit the post twice when they were 1-0 up, but it didn't go for us," Burley reflected. "It's still been a terrific season. We knew this would be the toughest for four or five years but our squad is stronger and we go into the play-offs on the back of two very good performances."

The victories at Charlton last week and in this match showed the team can cope with high-pressure matches, Burley insisted. "That," he said, "will stand us in good stead."

There was no doubting Ipswich's superiority here, though Bolton will be a different prospect from a Charlton side already guaranteed promotion and a Walsall team heading straight back to the Second Division.

How Ipswich had failed to score in the first half beggared belief. Twelve chances came and went, among them a Johnson header against the bar.

Johnson made the breakthrough just after half-time by volleying in a Tony Mowbray cross but as the tide turned at Ewood Park the urgency drained. Johnson sidefooted the second from a centre by the impressive Jamie Clapham but Ipswich knew their fate.

By then Walsall's was sealed too. "I certainly don't look on my players or myself as failures," said their manager Ray Graydon. "There's no doubt we will come again."

Burley, not surprisingly, was a little more circumspect. "Hopefully," he reflected, "this will be our year." Time will tell.

webTitle: Henry leaves Chelsea sweating on Cup success

fields.headline: Henry leaves Chelsea sweating on Cup success
fields.trailText: Arsenal 2 - 1 Chelsea
fields.body:
Arsenal at the moment are like the golfer who, having missed a putt for the championship, practises the shot over and over and holes out every time. Saturday's elegant win over Chelsea here was their eighth successive Premiership victory, form which, had it been found earlier, would at the least have delayed Manchester United's celebrations.

Arsenal blew their chances over Christmas and the New Year. Subsequent defeats by Liverpool and Middlesbrough ensured Highbury would remain title-free for another season. It is assumed that this still matters. If, however, the Premiership is seen as merely a pre-qualifier for the Champions League then Arsène Wenger's team have more or less achieved their season's aims.

A point from tomorrow night's home game against moribund Sheffield Wednesday and Arsenal will again join United in the Champions League. They could then concentrate on a silver collection which would see the Uefa Cup at Highbury, provided they beat Galatasaray in Copenhagen on Wednesday week.

It all smacks of second options - Arsenal are only in the Uefa Cup because they failed to hack it in the Champions League - but at least Wenger is in a happier situation than Gianluca Vialli, for whom this defeat ended Chelsea's hopes of gaining a Uefa Cup place via the Premiership. They can still achieve this by winning the FA Cup, otherwise Chelsea's only chance in Europe next season will be the Intertoto Cup. It is difficult to imagine Vialli's French contingent being agog at the prospect.

Too often at Highbury Vialli's players were a bad second to 50-50 balls. In midfield Patrick Vieira and Emmanuel Petit almost totally dominated the persevering Dennis Wise and Jody Morris and Chelsea only established some sort of parity once Gustavo Poyet had come on and Petit gone off.

Vialli's use of Poyet, who at one time seemed to have established himself as his team's talisman, is a mystery. Two astutely taken goals by the Uruguayan took Chelsea to the FA Cup final in the face of an excellent recovery by Newcastle United and here another, taken with typical aplomb when he chested down Emerson Thome's cross before beating David Seaman, put Arsenal's victory briefly in doubt.

Poyet replaced Gianfranco Zola, who had given another performance of tireless dexterity, for the last half-hour. If both are not in Vialli's starting line-up against Aston Villa at Wembley then theory will have upstaged common sense. On Saturday it was bad enough seeing Tore Andre Flo, Chelsea's top scorer, confined to the left wing for the first half.

Vialli explained that he had meant the Norwegian to be a link between the midfield and the two up front, Zola and George Weah, but "unfortunately we forgot about [him]". Once Flo had been moved to the middle and supported by Poyet's quick, accurate passes Chelsea looked a force again, but it was too late.

Arsenal won the match simply enough with two goals from Thierry Henry, who took his season's total to 25. The first punished a hash of a headed interception by Frank Leboeuf. Henry waited for Ed de Goey to commit himself before scoring from a narrow angle.

His second was notable for the way that, having gathered Dennis Bergkamp's pass, the striker muscled his way past Marcel Desailly before scoring from another awkward position.

Vialli excused Chelsea's generally vapid performance on the ground that the day was unexpectedly hot, never a wise plea when your attack is led by a Liberian.

fields.headline: Hartson sets up crazy finale
fields.trailText: Wimbledon 2- 2 Aston Villa
fields.body:
Saints preserve us. Wimbledon go into next weekend's denouement at Southampton with renewed hope of Premiership survival thanks to an unlikely injury-time headed equaliser from John Hartson, a stone overweight, laughably unfit and facing a disrepute charge for digging himself into a hole in a tunnel last weekend. It ain't over until the fat Welshman springs.

In a way Hartson's bizarre rescue act showed that Wimbledon are still crazy after all these years. But far from being seen as a welcome return to old values, Saturday's finale more likely represented the last hurrah for an outdated creed. For the club's Norwegian bosses have just called in an interior designer.

Terry Burton would look out of place on Changing Rooms. But he is at home in them, a career coach who has studied with the best in Europe and wants to use his rich palette of ideas to give Wimbledon a makeover.

Burton, whose title is manager, not, as reported, caretaker, goes into Sunday's final game at the Dell with Wimbledon seeking only to match Bradford's result against Liverpool that same tense day to safeguard their 14-year membership of the top flight. He will then lay plans for the next 14. "I'm preparing for the rest of our future," he says. "We have our vision of how we want to move forward."

He is not forthcoming about what that vision is. But though commitment will always remain vital to any successful team, the crazy days are definitely numbered.

Vinnie Jones, crazier than most, calls Burton a natural No2. So whether he is a good enough motivator to lead the revolution is unclear. But his coaching credentials are impeccable. He guided players such as Tony Adams and Paul Merson at Arsenal, then became Joe Kinnear's tactical brains at Wimbledon and was even wanted for the England staff by Glenn Hoddle.

Still, two years ago he decided to further his education. "After 20 years as a coach I wanted to see what else was out there. Other coaches had gone into Europe and said it opened their eyes. I wanted some of that."

So off he went to study how they do things at Barcelona, Ajax, Bayer Leverkusen and the French national school, returning to put his new ideas into practice as director of Wimbledon's academy. Now he plans to try them out on the grown-ups.

Not that Wimbledon were anything but poor in Burton's first game in charge, suffering further when Michael Hughes broke his leg after an awful tackle by Mark Delaney and Kenny Cunningham limped off injured.

fields.headline: City back in big league
fields.standfirst: Stuttering start turns into Royle procession
fields.trailText: Blackburn 1 - 4 Man City
fields.body:
Perhaps Manchester City only do it to annoy because they know it teases. Eventually City returned to the Premiership in resounding style here yesterday, but not before putting their supporters through one last bout of nail-chewing, heart-thumping anxiety.

Four goals in the space of 20 minutes during the final half-hour won City a match they might easily have lost by a similar margin. Before Shaun Goater brought the scores level Blackburn Rovers had not only taken the lead and hit bar or posts four times, they had also performed with sufficient superiority to raise doubts about whether Maine Road's journey towards the land of milk, honey and fat TV fees was really worthwhile.

That said, the way City turned the game around once they had scored fully reflected the strength of character and consistency of purpose which has now taken them from Second Division to Premiership in successive seasons.

In the 26 months since he replaced Frank Clark as manager Joe Royle has restored a Mancunian derby previously limited to encounters with Stockport County. Clearly the prospect of renewing hostilities with Manchester United had long since occurred to the City supporters celebrating loud and long after this victory. But the reality is that whoever Royle buys this summer his team will need to emulate, say, Leicester City's infinite capacity for running, challenging, hustling and harassing if they are to survive, rather than United's expensive callisthenics.

The most impressive part of a City performance which for nearly an hour suggested they were about to leave the First Division by the bottom exit, not the top, was the way they clung to the belief that the more times Blackburn shots ricocheted off the frame of their goal the greater chance they had of avoiding the purgatory of the play-offs.

The changes Royle made early in the second half, moreover, proved crucial to the outcome. Having spent 45 minutes playing the ball high and long and vaguely in the direction of Robert Taylor in the hope that Goater could feed off his knockdowns, City's movements acquired infinitely more subtlety once Ian Bishop and Paul Dickov had replaced Jamie Pollock and Taylor.

Dickov's speed on the turn and swift accelerations through the middle soon unsettled a hitherto undisturbed Blackburn defence and the accuracy and imagination of Bishop's passes added a much-needed dimension to City's midfield. In the end they were knocking the ball around with an aplomb which would have seemed barely credible before the interval. "When our second goal went in you could feel the swell of relief among the fans," said Royle. "Before we scored we had been poor at times, worse at others. Blackburn really gave us the run-around for 45 or 50 minutes."

True enough. Indeed there were times in the first half when Rovers, relegated last season, appeared worth rather more than a mid-table position. Time and again the precocious skills of Matt Jansen, combined with Ashley Ward's industry and the consistent width given to Blackburn's movements by Jason McAteer and Damien Duff, caught the City defence square and spreadeagled. All this achieved, however, was one goal accompanied by a regular tattoo on City's wooden bits. Shortly before the half-hour Marlon Broomes met David Dunn's cross with a header against the bar. Shortly afterwards Dunn let fly from 20 yards with a similar result.

In the 42nd minute Ward took two City defenders with him as he moved for a throw from Simon Grayson on the right. The ball clipped one of them, Spencer Prior, before bouncing high to Jansen, who chested it down deftly and drove a smart, left-foot shot inside the right-hand post.

This was a logical development considering the prevailing pattern of the game and when, early in the second half, Duff's close control turned City on the left before Ward cut inside Richard Edghill to send a shot against the right-hand angle, Blackburn appeared to be carrying on where they had left off. Less than a minute later Jansen turned beautifully under pressure before striking the right-hand post, but there Rovers' domination ended.

On the hour their defence failed to cut out a quick, early cross from Kevin Horlock and Goater, previously anonymous, popped up at the far post to drive in his 29th goal of the season.

Five minutes later Christian Dailly's attempt to nod a high ball from Richard Edghill back to his goalkeeper Alan Kelly, who was already advancing towards it, produced one of the season's more significant own-goals.

Mark Kennedy and Dickov scored opportunistically in the 74th and 79th minutes to send City fans inside and outside Ewood Park into fresh raptures, and the rest was all congas and champagne corks.

"What happened to us in the last half-hour was totally unacceptable," said Graeme Souness, the Blackburn manager, darkly. "Today you saw the best and worst of Blackburn Rovers." As much went for Manchester City - but at least they got the order right.

fields.headline: Bolton time it right
fields.trailText: WBA 2 - 0 Charlton
fields.body:
Sam Allardyce's first season in charge of Bolton Wanderers was written off a month ago. After semi-final defeats in the FA and Worthington Cups, a defeat at Manchester City left them hopelessly adrift of the top six and all the talk was of a summer exodus.

Thirty-two days after he had trudged into the Maine Road press room to declare it was "still a possibility, albeit a very tall order", Allardyce yesterday celebrated a remarkable comeback. A fifth win in six matches, aided by Huddersfield's defeat at Fulham, secured another semi-final showdown for Bolton against Ipswich Town.

Now it merely remains for Allardyce to lead his team back to the Premiership and he can congratulate himself on a job well done. "We've got a few tired boys now," he said, "because that was our 60th game of the season, but it has been a fantastic achievement to get this far. Someone told me it's the first time we've been in the top six since November 23. Well, there's no better time to get back up there than on the last day."

Bolton's hero was the substitute Dean Holdsworth, whose miss in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa was so costly. The 72nd-minute goal, a scrambled effort after Robbie Elliott's long throw-in, was his third match-winning substitute appearance in eight days.

But for long periods it looked as though Norwich's sound defending and swift counter-attacks would deny Bolton. Iwan Roberts struck the bar midway through the first half and Fernando Derveld should have scored soon afterwards.

Bolton were far from convincing yesterday but in Claus Jensen and Eidur Gudjohnsen they boast two of the most technically accomplished players in the country. They, along with the South African defender Mark Fish, will surely be the subject of interest from Premiership clubs if Bolton fall at the penultimate hurdle again.

Others, such as the Scotland internationals Paul Ritchie and Allan Johnston, are on loan, and Gudni Bergsson and Michael Johansen are set to return to Scandinavia to become a lawyer and play for AB Copenhagen respectively.

fields.headline: Birmingham stroll into the play-offs
fields.trailText: Birmingham 0 - 0 Grimsby
fields.body:
No frills, no dramas, no problem. Needing a point here yesterday to secure their place in the play-offs for the second successive season, Birmingham City achieved exactly that.

With Grimsby providing clear evidence of why they have not won for 11 games by failing to test Thomas Myhre with a direct shot, Birmingham's passage to a semi-final meeting with Barnsley was relatively untroubled.

All of which has to be something of a surprise for a club who have specialised in doing things the hard way over the years. Reaching the play-offs this season has been a case in point, as their manager Trevor Francis pointed out.

"Given the injuries we've had and that we were 13th at the end of the year, I'm staggered we've made it," he said.

This being Birmingham, however, it was perhaps predictable that the midfielder Graham Hyde should collide with his team-mate Darren Purse midway through the first half and sustain a knee injury that will probably sideline him for the play-offs.

Despite that setback, Birmingham enjoyed enough possession and territorial advantage to have won by a cricket score. That they did not was down to familiar failings in front of goal, with Paul Furlong, Andrew Johnson and Bryan Hughes all missing good opportunities. As the game progressed even the chances of a fluke goal disappeared as City got worse.

"We were useless in the second half," admitted Francis, who is not optimistic that his team will make it to the Premiership. "While I'm obviously delighted we've qualified for the play-offs, I don't want the players thinking 0-0 at home to Grimsby is a good result, because it isn't."

fields.headline: Boxing clever
fields.standfirst:
The Delgados
Zodiac, Oxford
Rating: * * * * *
fields.trailText:
The Delgados
Zodiac, Oxford
Rating: * * * * *
fields.body:
Four years on from its release, the title of their debut album Domestiques still encapsulates much of what the Delgados are about. Healthily obsessed with the problematic ways of human interaction, the Glasgow quartet's forte is identifying the tiny details that add up to the major scenes in households everywhere, and turning them into music of singular drama. It's hard to imagine any other band who could open their set with a song seemingly about infanticide and have an audience sighing in supplication.

For live purposes, the group's core is currently augmented by keyboards, flute and a four-strong string section to make up a sort of chamber-folk orchestra. Emma Pollock and Alun Woodward, the band's notoriously diffident vocal pairing, seem to enjoy life under the lights more now than they once did. Much of the show's magic derives from watching the Delgados weaving complex patterns of sound around each other before landing the emotional uppercut in a triumph of sensuous style and substance. Amid a pop world of opportunist sluggers, the Delgados represent a purer brand of pugilism, boxers as opposed to fighters, masters of their noble art.

 The Delgados play the Hop & Grape, Manchester on Wednesday, then tour.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Brown attacks City herd
fields.standfirst: Inquiry will focus on failure to support British manufacturing industry
fields.trailText: The institutional investment inquiry to be launched next week will focus on failure to support British manufacturing industry.
fields.body:
The chancellor, Gordon Brown, will tonight set out the parameters of the review of institutional investment which is being launched next week by Paul Myners, head of the fund manager Gartmore and chairman of Guardian Media Group.

Treasury sources said the chancellor has asked Mr Myners to investigate whether the City is governed by "systematic herd behaviour" to the detriment of growing businesses and manufacturing.

The study will look at how pension fund trustees are chosen, how expert they are, what incentives they have, and what sort of information pension fund members and life insurance policy holders have about how their money is invested.

Mr Brown also wants an investigation into the role of highly influential pension fund consultants, who advise pension fund trustees about their investment decisions.

The government fears that inexperienced trustees are often pushed into making decisions by a small number of firms of actuaries.

In the wake of news in the Budget that Mr Myners had been asked to tackle the subject, Mr Brown will use a lecture tonight to launch a strong attack on the City's failure to invest in Britain's struggling manufacturing sector.

After a decade in which Labour has courted financiers in an attempt to show that it no longer poses a threat to the City, the chancellor will say that the government must ensure that "there are no unnecessary constraints restricting investment decisions" and that investors "have every opportunity and encouragement to back dynamic small and growing companies in manufacturing and services in all our regions."

Treasury sources said that the government did not intend to tell investors how to do their jobs, but stressed that the government wanted a root and branch inquiry into the barriers preventing small and growing companies from attracting funds from the City.

"We believe that the City should serve the interests of the wider economy and those interests are not being served. The interests of manufacturing have not been given proper weight," one insider said.

"Some people argue that governments cannot affect productivity levels," Mr Brown will say. "I reject this pessimistic view. Of course it is businesses that create wealth and managers that create jobs and work forces that create jobs and higher output.

"But governments must ensure that the environment in which wealth is created is one that favours competition not monopoly or vested interests and that the economy has properly functioning labour, capital and product markets."

The treasury expects the Myners review to identify accounting, regulatory and legal issues to be considered in the run-up to the budget. All areas of institutional investment will be scrutinsed, including defined benefit pension schemes, defined contribution schemes and life insurance.

"We expect this to be a very important piece of work" one aide added last night.

Mr Brown will say in his lecture tonight that the government must not be deviated from its long-term strategy.

"The last few decades teach us to reject the short-termism of flawed quick fixes - policy lurches in the face of short-term difficulties rather than taking tough decisions."

However, he has become convinced that one barrier to greater productivity is short-termism in the City. UK pension funds invest only 0.5% of their funds in venture capital, compared to 5% in the US. Britain's venture capital in dustry received only 13% of its funds from UK institutional investors, compared to 37% from overseas investors.

One area the Myners report will look at is minimum funding requirements - the need for pension funds and life assurance companies to show that they have enough assets to cover their obligations. The chancellor wants to know if the assumptions and valuations underpinning this process should be changed to make investors less risk-averse.

"We are not saying that we know better than the City how to invest," one source said last night. "But institutional investment seems to be an industry that is rather closed and traditional. There are some important questions to be asked".

fields.headline: It's all down to me
fields.standfirst: Sheena Brown talks about the relentless pressure of being a put-upon PA
fields.trailText: 'My workload is relentless - that's not an unfair description. I have peaks and troughs, but there's no such thing as a clear desk at the end of the day. I am a PA to the chairman of an investment trust, who also has philanthropic, artistic and community commitments outside his main corporate job. It's all work: whether it's the dry cleaner or the executive jet, it's all down to me.
fields.body:
'My workload is relentless - that's not an unfair description. I have peaks and troughs, but there's no such thing as a clear desk at the end of the day. I am a PA to the chairman of an investment trust, who also has philanthropic, artistic and community commitments outside his main corporate job. It's all work: whether it's the dry cleaner or the executive jet, it's all down to me.

I start between 9 and 9.30am. Lunch more often than not is a sandwich at my desk, and I get away between 6 and 7pm, sometimes taking work home because I can't find a quiet moment during the day. Trying to reconcile the credit card statements is difficult if you are constantly interrupted.

A lot of my time is spent organising things, thinking 'If he's going to be at that meeting, I need to organise this, and he'll have to go from that to the next meeting, so I need to remind him that when he does that he needs to do this.' It's about thinking things through and organising as much of his life as possible.

As a secretary, by definition it is my job to take on the stress of other people's jobs. It goes without saying that secretaries are less in control of their own workloads. fields.headline: House work
fields.standfirst: Wonder which MPs are thinking of retiring? Lucy Watson probably knows, but she won't tell.  Andy Farquarson reports
fields.trailText: "I love the House of Commons - after 14 years I still get a real buzz out of working here," says Lucy Watson.
fields.body:
"I love the House of Commons - after 14 years I still get a real buzz out of working here," says Lucy Watson. Working from an office in the shadow of Westminster Abbey, Watson, 32, is the pension unit manager of the House of Commons finance and administration department, responsible for administering payments to almost everyone who works there, from part-time cleaners to senior cabinet ministers.

Despite having dropped out of A-levels at school, Watson's move to the corridors of power was a fairly rapid one. She worked for a year as a clerical assistant for the ministry of defence near her home in York, before moving to London at the age of 18.

"I applied for an administrative position in the House of Comons personnel department which, at that time, dealt with pensions. By 1996 I was running the MPs' pension scheme, although the staff scheme was someone else's responsibility. This unit was set up in 1998 to streamline the admin of the pension schemes and I was appointed to help initiate and then run it."

The staff pension scheme is responsible for 1,400 House of Commons staff. "The public know what MPs do, but few people appreciate how large an administration establishment is needed behind the scenes," says Watson.

The parallel MPs' scheme covers 659 sitting Members as well as about two dozen government ministers in the House of Lords. The unit also deals with the 700 retired staff and 800 ex-MPs who draw pensions. In addition, 200 former members will be eligible when they reach pensionable age - they are entitled to a full pension whether they have served for one parliament or a lifetime.

Part of keeping this information up to date is monitoring the obituary columns. "Most former MPs get an obituary in the broadsheets and there are usually benefits payable to their families. But approaching the recently bereaved needs handling with great tact and sensitivity."

Technically, she is not a civil servant. "Constitutionally, the monarchy and parliament are separate institutions and civil servants work for the crown. Our employer is the House of Commons Commission, an independent body that administers the workings of parliament, although its conditions of service and pay are broadly based on those of the home civil service." Commission employees are not allowed to take active roles in political parties, but Watson doesn't find that onerous. "Working in Westminster, I hear enough about politics during the day so I wouldn't want to spend my own time campaigning!"

Watson's job has two distinct roles. As well as running the pensions office, she also provides secretarial support to the trustees of the Members' pension scheme, a nine-strong all-party group chaired by the Rt Hon John MacGregor MP.

"I arrange - and attend - the trustees' regular meetings in the House of Commons, reporting on my unit's work, taking the minutes, and pursuing any points the trustees want actioned.

"As well as those official meetings I'm in regular contact with the chairman and frequently pop over the road to his office in the Commons." She also makes use of one of the perks of the job, "dropping in" for an informal lunch or drinks in the Houses of Parliament.

The pensions unit has six full-time staff and one part-timer. "I believe passionately in teamwork," says Watson. "We work together closely, cover one another as necessary, and get on well personally."

She also appreciates that her workplace is relatively family-friendly. "The hours are reasonably flexible: in my case, I am able to start at 9.15am which allows me time to drop my 10-year-old son at school just down the road at Pimlico. I usually finish work at about 5.15pm."

What she likes best about her role is its variety. "As well as running the office, I might be checking calculations, going over to the City for a fund managers' meeting, attending internal meetings, collating information for the annual accounts, or liaising with Inland Revenue."

Watson also has to deal with a wide range of stakeholders' queries, both by phone and face-to-face. "The job demands a high degree of confidentiality - for example, Members who intend to stand down at the next election may wish to keep that information to themselves but still need to check their pension entitlement."

Is Watson ever tempted by the lucrative rewards of the private sector pensions industry?" There are more important things in life than a bigger salary. I'm happy here, I enjoy the job and I like my colleagues. Besides," she smiles, "the pension scheme is very good."

webTitle: Friends Provident to keep an ethical eye on its shares

fields.headline: Friends Provident to keep an ethical eye on its shares
fields.trailText: Friends Provident will announce today that it is to exert social and environmental scrutiny across its entire £15bn equity portfolio.
fields.body:
Friends Provident will announce today that it is to exert social and environmental scrutiny across its entire £15bn equity portfolio.

The mutual insurer, which announced last week that it is planning a stock exchange flotation, will be the first big investment manager to take an active stance with all its invested companies on issues such as human rights and pollution.

The new policy means that fund managers will take account of companies' management of sensitive issues in their routine financial investment judgments. This will be in addition to pressure from the company's ethics unit on specific issues such as oil spills and human rights.

Friends Provident will also be stepping up this kind of focused activity. It will be prepared to join other shareholders to put critical resolutions to company meetings, and will vote against adopting annual reports if they do not adequately address social and environmental issues.

Friends Provident's chief executive, Keith Satchell, described the approach as "engagement" with companies. He said that the objective was improved financial performance and that shareholders would benefit.

"Good corporate practice on human rights, child labour and environmental pollution is good for society but it's also good for shareholders," he said. "It is right that we use our influence to encourage responsible business practices while serving the financial interests of our customers."

The engagement approach will be backed by the ethics unit of its subsidiary, Friends Ivory & Sime, which has previously been responsible only for the firm's £1.5bn Stewardship ethical funds.

Craig Mackenzie, head of the ethics unit, said that the new policy will have more impact on companies than the traditional ethical investment approach of avoiding unacceptable shares. Investment decisions in Friends Provident's mainstream funds will still be made purely on financial grounds but ethics research will be used to identify issues companies need to resolve.

Initially the firm will concentrate on four issues: environmental management, climate change, human rights and labour standards.

Friends Provident's move comes as pension fund trustees are deciding how to meet the government's requirement to make a statement about their ethical policies. The new rule has already prompted two of the biggest pension funds - BT and the Universities' Superannuation Scheme - to include social and environmental issues in their discussions with companies.

The Co-op insurer, CIS, has also begun to consider ethical issues as part of its corporate governance policy. Ethical investment managers such as Henderson NPI and Jupiter already have an "engagement" approach but this is confined to their ethical funds.

fields.headline: Ernani
fields.standfirst:
The Coliseum, London
Rating: * * * * *
fields.trailText:
The Coliseum, London
Rating: * * * * *
fields.body:
The best of Verdi's early operas, Ernani was deemed strong stuff at its 1844 premiere. Set in Counter-Reformation Spain it depicts a world in which male sexuality is thwarted by unshakeable ideals of honour. Three men - the Byronic bandit Ernani, the Hapsburg emperor Carlo and the decrepit, high-principled Silva - violently slug it out for the love of the spirited Elvira. At the end, the opera twists into almost Dostoevskian territory as Ernani, having taken a voluntary oath to commit suicide when required, is forced to face up to the consequences.

ENO have done it proud in Mike Ashman's sexy, glamorous production, using Maria Bjornson's designs for a 1979 staging by Welsh National Opera. Ernani and his followers, got up Mad Max-style in black leather, are counterpoised to an imperial court straight out of Velázquez. At the end, Ashman pulls off an astonishing coup: Elvira is left clutching the knife with which Ernani has killed himself; she clearly intends to use it - but on whom? We aren't told, but another cycle of violence is about to begin.

Musically, it's also impressive. David Parry's conducting is electric. Sandra Ford hasn't quite got the requisite fullness in her lower registers for Elvira, but she's wonderfully feisty. Peter Rose's Silva is imposingly stentorian while Alan Opie expertly suggests Carlo's progress from impassioned hot head to moral monarch. Julian Gavin steals the show, however, as Ernani, vividly realising every emotional and psychological shift.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Wound-up over work
fields.standfirst:
The results of the first Office Hours survey into secretarial stress are here. And the news isn't good. Emma Brockes reports
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Take a close look at your colleagues. If they are eating, emailing, or emitting a high-pitched whine in the manner of a mosquito, they are likely to be suffering from a condition that affects more than half of all office support workers.
fields.body:
Take a close look at your colleagues. If they are eating, emailing, or emitting a high-pitched whine in the manner of a mosquito, they are likely to be suffering from a condition that affects more than half of all office support workers. We all like to complain of stress - the classic ailment of the 21st-century office worker - from time to time, occasionally suffering minor meltdowns when everything gets just too much. Now a Guardian survey has provided the most concrete evidence yet of the affect of stress on secretarial and office support staff - and the news isn't good.

More than 15,000 of you responded to the Office Hours survey into workplace stress, and 52% said it was a major factor in your working life. The signs to watch out for include moaning to colleagues, compulsively snacking and indulging in personal use of the phone and email facilities. And the reason? Three main factors got most of the blame: quantity of work, difficult colleagues, and worries about a stress-filled future - beset with comfort-eating.

They are probably problems that most workers can relate to. But what was surprising was the violence of feeling you demonstrated about stress in the workplace. While three-quarters of respondents have never shouted at their boss, taken up smoking or displayed the external signs of nervous breakdown, the survey asked you to share what you would really, really like to tell your boss given the chance - and some fairly ferocious demons were unleashed. "I'd tell her to shut up, stop being a hypocrite, stop getting on everyone's nerves," runs a typically vitriolic response. "Then I would punch her on the nose."

One secretary dreamed of saying, "Get stuffed you gutless little man", another aspired to castrating her boss. "Go on a diet," said another, while one hard-done-by secretary - a particular favourite, this - wanted to yell "Do it yourself - and get a bath." There is presumably, some stress-busting value to these outbursts, but the vehemence with which they are expressed is a little alarming. There certainly seems to be some seething resentment bubbling under the businesslike air and polite telephone manner.

Fantasy scenarios aside, angry gripes seem to be based on three main legitimate grievances. Unrealistic expectations, particularly concerning deadlines, are perceived to be the most provocative of management abuses. "I would ask him to communicate better so I could leave my crystal ball at home," said one respondent, witheringly. "I'd have him be me for a day so he can see how long things take, and that a five-minute deadline is not good enough," said another, along with the sweet reminder, "I'm important too".

This sense of being under-appreciated was another common complaint, PAs sharing plaintive fantasies to "tell him how I feel," hoping that the boss would "involve me more and keep me informed," and "say thank you."

And, no surprise here, money is the final source of upset, with respondents finding a variety of creative ways, some involving minor assault, to demand a pay rise. A lot of respondents appeared to have spent time formulating scenes in which they verbally incinerated their seniors. "I'd ask him if he has to practise to be so obnoxious or whether it just comes naturally," ran one insult that, one suspects, has been polished in front of the mirror in the ladies', but will never be used face-to-face.

Everybody needs to let off steam, and those of you who replied to the survey probably felt a lot better having shared your true feelings, on paper at least. But there is an important hidden reason for all this outrage. Just under half believed themselves to be stuck in the wrong job: fretting, resentful and storing up unhappiness to unleash at home. Apart from compulsively emailing and wailing to colleagues, the stressed majority found their condition expressing itself most seriously away from the office. A quarter of those who replied believed their sex life had deteriorated since starting their job; a third said stress was having a detrimental effect on their relationship with their partner. More than half had suffered from insomnia. And yet, in spite of these hardships, almost two-thirds of respondents said they would be willing to take on more pressure for a salary increase.

More pressure is not, of course, the same thing as more stress, and respondents were keen to differentiate between an environment so hard-boiled it damaged them (such as harassment and bullying) and one in which they were merely given a daunting amount of responsibility. As stress becomes more prevalent, so sufferers learn to lessen its impact by fitting it into a sliding scale of harmfulness, a self-preservation mechanism common in workplaces where stress permeates the atmosphere as much as the air-conditioning. The majority of respondents recognised a difference between healthy and damaging stress, between that which stimulated the adrenaline and enabled them to meet deadlines, and that which caused mental paralysis.

Some industries are probably more difficult than others: "There is still a culture in the legal profession that says if you aren't stressed, you're not working properly," says Barry Pritchard of Solcare, the legal healthcare charity. "We've had calls from people who were certain they'd lost their jobs because they had complained about their workload." But like a rather pernicious virus, stress can infect even the most seemingly cosy of work environments.

"There are quite a lot of companies that still think stress is a wimp's issue," says Cary Cooper of the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology. This makes it particularly painful for male stress sufferers to seek help. If women are under a lot of pressure, they talk about it. That gives a release. Men are more likely to bottle it up, or turn to unhealthy coping mechanisms such as drinking."

This is when stress becomes more than just something to be moaned about with your mates over a bottle of wine. In a recent survey conducted by ICM, workplace tensions were found to have caused one in eight men and one in ten women to shout at colleagues. Many also admitted to having broken down in tears as a result of problems at work.

But the Office Hours survey found that while bosses were indirectly blamed for a stressful environment, the majority of respondents didn't think their jobs would be less stressful if they had a better relationship with their managers. It wasn't the stand-up fights and the tearful outbursts that caused stress, but the bitchy undercurrents that never made it to a confrontation and were thus never taken seriously.

This is the heart of the matter. "Employers treat stress very differently to other hazards," says Hugh Robertson, of the public services union Unison. "We have to stop them thinking that there are two kinds of hazard - one that they have to do something about and one that they can ignore." Employers: take note. Ignoring your stressed out secretaries may be an occupational hazard. One day, they may decide to let you know how they really feel, and it won't be pretty.

Some industries are probably more difficult than others: "There is still a culture in the legal profession that says if you aren't stressed, you're not working properly," says Barry Pritchard of Solcare, the legal healthcare charity. "We've had calls from people who were certain they'd lost their jobs because they had complained about their workload." But like a rather pernicious virus, stress can infect even the most seemingly cosy of work environments. "There are quite a lot of companies that still think stress is a wimp's issue," says Cary Cooper of the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology. This makes it particularly painful for male stress sufferers to seek help. If women are under a lot of pressure, they talk about it. That gives a release. Men are more likely to bottle it up, or turn to unhealthy coping mechanisms such as drinking." This is when stress becomes more than just something to be moaned about with your mates over a bottle of wine. In a recent survey conducted by ICM, workplace tensions were found to have caused one in eight men and one in ten women to shout at colleagues. Many also admitted to having broken down in tears as a result of problems at work. But the Office Hours survey found that while bosses were indirectly blamed for a stressful environment, the majority of respondents didn't think their jobs would be less stressful if they had a better relationship with their managers. It wasn't the stand-up fights and the tearful outbursts that caused stress, but the bitchy undercurrents that never made it to a confrontation and were thus never taken seriously. This is the heart of the matter. "Employers treat stress very differently to other hazards," says Hugh Robertson, of the public services union Unison. "We have to stop them thinking that there are two kinds of hazard - one that they have to do something about and one that they can ignore." Employers: take note. Ignoring your stressed out secretaries may be an occupational hazard. One day, they may decide to let you know how they really feel, and it won't be pretty.

fields.headline: Swan Lake
fields.standfirst:
Festival Theatre, Edinburgh
Rating: * *
fields.trailText:
Festival Theatre, Edinburgh
Rating: * *
fields.body:
All is not well with Swan Lake. On Tuesday night the Kirov gave us a museum-piece La Bayadère with some magic moments. This second offering at the beginning of the company's national tour is just plain old-fashioned.

In the opening scene the boys and girls come out to play at Prince Siegfried's coming of age. A jester (given fine lines by Kirill Simonov) frolics among them. The queen mum enters and puts a stop to it all, but when her back is turned, they are at it again. All grins and daft play-acting, this scene is best got through by listening to Tchaikovsky in the background. One of the most melodic and recognisable of all ballet scores, his Swan Lake is a peach but, unfortunately, not so sweetly played here.

The tone of the evening is set. Throughout every act, the dancers just seem to be going through the paces. Only when the famous cygnet quartet trips out, arms linked, feet snapping, to a tune so often plucked out and recycled by advertising and film-makers, is there any sense of real connection with the audience. Yulia Makhalina cuts an elegant figure, but makes little of the drama that her double role as Odette/Odile can offer. Her partner, Igor Zelensky, makes a shy prince surprisingly lacking in passion. And what of the massed band of white-tutued swans so beloved of audiences? They too seem muted and solid as the model swans that herald their entrance.

So, no lovers' chemistry, no lip-trembling sorrow (this interpretation chops the lovers' double suicide by drowning and opts for a shortcut happy ending), no jeers for bad girl Odile. As told in this production, the old fairy story fails to excite, with most of its treasures buried among a rather weary set of rules and conventions.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Platform for growth
fields.standfirst:
Abbey National goes online

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Abbey National will today launch an assault on its rivals in an attempt to lure their customers to its new internet banking service.
fields.body:
Abbey National will today launch an assault on its rivals in an attempt to lure their customers to its new internet banking service.

The move, part of the bank's aim to have 1m customers banking online in 12 months, is also the thrust of its strategy to double its 2m current account customers in the coming years.

It predicted that at least 5m customers will be using its online services within four years.

The new online bank, unveiled after £40m of investment, is a catch-up move by Abbey, one of the last banks to go online. Abbey, which yesterday declined to comment on reports that rival Barclays may be eyeing a takeover, insisted that its e-banking service was to be the "most comprehensive and easy to use proposition on the market".

Ambrose McGinn, Abbey's director of e-commerce, said that it would provide a "switching" service for non-customers who want to transfer their current account from another bank.

He acknowledged that the bank was later than some of its competitors to launch its e-initiative, which is being unveiled amid a frenzy of competition among the banks to prove their e-credentials to boost their stock market ratings.

Lloyds TSB will similarly reveal further details of its e-strategy this week, and Barclays, which claims to have more online customers than its rivals, is holding an e-day later this month.

While Abbey is aiming to win customers from the big clearing banks it will also be targeting its own 13m customers, only 2m of whom hold its current accounts. The new service will allow customers to transfer money between Abbey accounts, pay bills and apply online for 11 types of Abbey National account. Later in the year it will expand the service on to digital television and introduce online share dealing.

Abbey said that it would not be offering preferential rates of interest to online customers, who will also be able to use branches and the telephone.

It is more cost-efficient for Abbey, and other banks, to have online customers as its own research shows that simple internet transactions cost as little as 1% of branch banking and improve customer retention and cross-selling rates.

Abbey is also planning a separately branded online venture, cahoot.

fields.headline: Quarantine
fields.standfirst:
Birmingham Rep
Rating: * *
fields.trailText:
Birmingham Rep
Rating: * *
fields.body:
Four people travel into the wilderness for a 40-day retreat. Through the heat and dust of the journey they think they see a shadowy fifth behind them. A grasping, greedy merchant believes a young man from Galilee has saved him from death. A boy in a cave throws his clothes to the angels and starves himself to death. Is he mad or holy? Is his death a sign or a betrayal?

The desert throws up many mirages and a familiar biblical story takes on many facets in Jim Crace's novel, adapted here for the stage by Birmingham Rep's literary manager, Ben Payne. But despite the inventiveness of Bill Alexander's promenade production, this remains a rather literary evening in which the intensity of the book translates into mere ponderousness on stage.

There is too much signposting and not enough subtlety, so what seems ambiguous in the novel is obvious in performance, and the ironies and oppositional tensions feel creakily contrived. Right from the start you know that in seeking God the pilgrims will find the Devil, that they are prepared to give up everything only because of a secret need, and that good can come from bad, miracles from the mundane.

A lighter touch, more humour and considerably less dry ice would help leaven a long evening burdened by self-importance as it examines the unreliability of testimony and the nature of faith. As it is, that task is left entirely to the actors, who play it to the hilt as a bunch of all-too-human nutters, self-deceivers, saints and wise men, all chasing their own shadows and dreams in the sand dunes.

 Till May 20. Box office: 0121-236 4455
