webTitle: Calais finally run out of miracles

fields.headline: Calais finally run out of miracles
fields.standfirst: Calais 1 - 2 Nantes
fields.trailText: Nantes owe their victory in the French Cup Final to a contentious refereeing decision which handed them a last-minute penalty.
fields.body:
Minnows Calais let a half-time lead slip in the Stade de France as Nantes lifted the French Cup for the second successive year.

But Nantes owed their victory to a contentious refereeing decision which handed them a last-minute penalty.

Fabrice Baron was adjudged to have brought down Alain Caveglia inside the penalty area and Antoine Sibierski blasted in the resulting penalty off the legs of goalkeeper Cedric Schille.

It was harsh on amateur side Calais as Caveglia looked to have fallen before any contact was made.

Calais' extraordinary run to the final included a victory over Strasbourg and an extra-time triumph over 1999 league champions Bordeaux in the semi-finals.

And when Jerome Dutitre slipped the ball home from a tight angle after 34 minutes it looked like the cup might be heading to the northern port for the first time.

Calais hurried, hassled and gave their top-flight opponents all sorts of problems right from kick-off, commendably stopping Nantes from imposing their quality on the match. Almost 80,000 spectators crammed into the stadium which hosted the 1998 World Cup final and the Nantes contingent erupted in relief when Sibierski headed home an equaliser on 50 minutes before smashing home the late penalty to break Calais' hearts.

Despite their lowly status in the championship Nantes go into the UEFA Cup next season, while Calais go back to the Fourth Division with their dream of European football now at an end.

webTitle: Doctor with a private remedy for the NHS

fields.headline: Doctor with a private remedy for the NHS
fields.standfirst: Healthcare chief Chai Patel is pitching for partnership - and Ministers are listening
fields.trailText: 'Private health boss urges massive increase in business activity in NHS' is a headline to which even Margaret Thatcher would not have given credence. Once upon a time, Labour would have dismissed it out of hand, but things have changed. Oliver Morgan profiles Chai Patel, New Labour's very own private health care tycoon.
fields.body:
Profile

Name: Dr Chai Patel

Age: 54

Job: Chief executive, Westminster Healthcare

Other directorships: none

Hobbies: Golf (handicap 11), music, the arts, reading, painting, spectating at sports events

'Private health boss urges massive increase in business activity in NHS' is a headline to which even Margaret Thatcher would not have given credence.

Even a year ago the whole notion would have been dismissed with a down-to-earth, 'Bugger off' from the Government's straight-talking old Labour Health Secretary, Frank Dobson. The idea that anyone making such an argument could actually be allowed to advise the Department of Health would have made his beard fall out.

But now we have a clean-shaven New Labour Health Secretary, Alan Milburn, and a partnership between business and the NHS is under discussion.

Dr Chai Patel, chief executive of Westminster Healthcare, the nursing home, diagnostic test provider and mental health group, is saying that the more companies such as his can do for the NHS, the better. And the Government is listening.

Patel's opinion has extra authority in that he heads one of six 'action teams' advising on how to make the NHS work better.

Last week one of his suggestions - that private nursing homes should be used to take the 20 per cent of people in badly needed NHS hospital beds who do not need to be there but are not well enough to go home - was endorsed by junior health Minister John Denham.

Patel's view is that providing intermediate care, or recuperation between hospital and home, in a private sector nursing home is better for patients and more efficient than building extra hospital capacity in the NHS.

But he would say that, wouldn't he - and surely there's a clear conflict of interest between his commercial and public roles?

'Absolutely not,' says Patel. 'In long-term care, the private sector has been creating great change, innovating and expanding capacity. I don't see why we should not talk to the Government about health care in the same way as people talk to them about providing telecoms services.'

Fighting talk. But Patel is no free market nutter. He wants profits, to be sure. But his ideas must be taken seriously. There is, he maintains, a clear distinction between allowing the private sector to provide services to NHS patients and the far more radical suggestion that private insurance should be expanded to displace NHS tax funding for healthcare.

The virtue, as he sees it, is that the private sector can assess risks, raise capital, and provide services to the NHS on preferential terms, while operating assets commercially by allowing private access to them.

In other words, he is just the kind of man to deliver Tony Blair's 'whatever works' vision.

The son of Indian parents who came to Britain in 1969, Patel qualified as a doctor, but worked as a banker for Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers before founding nursing home group Court Cavendish in the Eighties.

A year ago, with backing from Goldman Sachs, he took ailing Westminster Healthcare private for a total of £350 million. The aim was to create a pan-European healthcare operation worth at least £1 billion before refloating it.

Turnover has gone from £135m in 1998 to a projected £225m for the coming year.

'The business has gone to target. The growth expected in our business plan has come through,' he says.

Patel has thinned the company's divisions from four to three, selling its sheltered housing operations. The backbone of the business is 'senior living', ranging from 90 care homes, to 'assisted living' services to help people remain in their own homes.

Its specialist services division - dealing with behavioural and brain conditions - has been boosted with the £100m purchase of the Priory Healthcare hospitals group, which includes the south London clinic relied on by so many celebrities.

Patel wants to expand this part of the business to offer stress management treatment to companies and individuals. Westminster is holding talks with firms including Welsh utilities group Hyder and leisure companies such as the David Lloyd health clubs about providing stress management to employees and members.

The third element of the company is diagnostics services, including provision of hospital scanning equipment.

Patel took a 2 per cent stake in the buyout vehicle when the Westminster acquisition was made last year, with the chance to raise this to 12 per cent if targets were hit. He says he is on course.

'We paid £350m for the business and we have spent £100m on Priory, which makes £450m. If you look at where the business is today and calculate future earnings, you would be looking at a present net value of about £600m,' he says.

But Patel is shy of going too much further. 'Making profits out of healthcare is still an emotional issue,' he says. One benefit of being private is that he is not forced to make earnings statements to please the City but irritate patients and NHS staff.

Nevertheless, these problems will increase if his vision of a relationship between the NHS and business blossoms.

Despite the recent publicity, that relationship has existed for decades. NHS hospitals have provided pay beds for private patients since the Fifties, and general practitioners have long referred patients to private hospitals for surgery, often because of waiting lists. And, as Patel says, many care home places are now provided privately.

But what he is now advocating is a quantum leap in the scale and scope of what the private sector offers.

The use of private provision is ad hoc and complicated, with local social services departments and health authorities allocating budgets across the medical, nursing and residential sectors.

Patel would like to see long-term national agreements drawn up across treatments, from acute care through nursing homes to home care. These agreements would be between the Government and named private providers which would have to meet quality criteria. Alongside these would be regional deals tailoring the national framework to local needs, possibly through new, simplified funding agencies.

It all sounds neat, but how would it work?

'There should be long-term contracts, signed nationally, saying that if there is an overflow in a given service in a given area, this is how we would like the service to be provided, and this is who we would like to do it. On top of this, we see some areas - such as pathology and diagnostic testing - where we could become primary providers.'

Potentially, then, companies such as Westminster could massively fatten their profits from taxpayers if they were included in contracts.

True, says Patel, but 'provision should be by who can provide efficient and effective solutions'.

He argues that only through public-private partnerships can new and effective methods of caring for patients be developed.

Patel wants greater use of intermediate care and of remote technology to monitor patients at home. Both should come from the private sector - the first because spare places are available in homes at costs lower than in hospitals, and the second because buying home monitoring kit is more suited to the private sector, he says.

The same logic applies to diagnostic services, such as hospital scanners. He says the NHS invests too little in this technology and uses much of what it has inefficiently.

It is a plausible vision, which has been packaged so it can be defended against accusations of privatisation, and it's clear why the Government has chosen Patel to investigate its potential.

But he will face problems. Simply saying that publicly funded healthcare carried out by the private sector remains a public good does not answer fully concerns about private involvement.

The need for commercial returns, particularly from publicly quoted companies which have to make major investments in healthcare, could increase the cost of providing it.

And regulating large-scale business providers would open a new series of economic and ethical questions, which would make overseeing Rail track or United Utilities seem like nursery school.

Patel may be able to hide behind the convenience of corporate privacy now. But to realise his ambitions, it is not a position he will be able to maintain for ever.

webTitle: Phillips serves up a timely reminder

fields.headline: Phillips serves up a timely reminder
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan was furnished with further evidence, if any were needed, that Kevin Phillips is a realistic candidate to start alongside Alan Shearer in Euro 2000.
fields.byline: John Wardle at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan was furnished with further evidence, if any were needed, that Kevin Phillips is a realistic candidate to start alongside Alan Shearer in Euro 2000.

The England manager was here to see Phillips score his 30th Premiership goal of the season, but it wasn't just Phillips's finishing which helped his international cause. There were echoes of Keegan the player in the running, determination and sheer enthusiasm he showed all afternoon. Justification indeed for team-mate Niall Quinn's belief that Phillips may emerge as one of the stars of this summer's European Championship.

West Ham were without an entire team of players because of injuries and three more went missing when Phillips hit the target in the 14th minute.

Central defenders Igor Stimac, Rio Ferdinand and Marc-Vivien Foe are all solid six-footers, yet they each allowed Phillips a free header from the edge of the six-yard box. And while Phillips does not miss such opportunities, much of the credit must also go to Nicky Summerbee and the referee, Neale Barry.

Summerbee, arguably the best crosser of the ball in the Premiership after David Beckham, picked out Phillips superbly, while Barry sensibly allowed play to continue when Niall Quinn was fouled early on in the move.

fields.headline: Schofield in charge
fields.trailText: Lancashire, notoriously slow off the blocks in the county championship race, clinched a 20-points success over Leicestershire to bring a big smile to the face of Bob Simpson.
fields.body:
Lancashire, notoriously slow off the blocks in the county championship race, clinched a 20-points success over Leicestershire to bring a big smile to the face of Bob Simpson.

The Old Trafford coach said: 'It's some years, back in 1993 we think, that we had such an early win in the season. And it was very necessary because we haven't played a lot of cricket so far and, until this game, the cricket we had played wasn't very good.'

After poor starts in 1998 and 1999 Lancashire recovered to finish runners-up each time. The message was clear and they responded superbly to the demands for an improvement from captain John Crawley.

Leicestershire were over-powered, lasting only 75 minutes on the last day after resuming at 155 for six, and they slumped to defeat by an innings and 25 runs. They re-emerged for a game of football. Crawley also went back onto the field, but to have a net with Simpson watching carefully.

England Test candidate Chris Schofield polished off Leicestershire with three of the last four wickets, finishing with four for 82 to add to his 66 the previous day.

It was the seventh time in his short championship career that he has claimed four wickets or more in an innings, but his bowling was inconsistent - a factor acknowledged by Simpson who has reservations about his meteoric rise into the England reckoning.

'He is a superb wicket-taker but he is still in the apprenticeship stages of his career,' said Simpson.

Schofield struck in his first over, removing the biggest obstacle, Vince Wells, for 45, Saurav Ganguly taking a simple slip catch. Later he bowled Anil Kumble around his legs, and had Neil Burns easily stumped well out of his ground.

In between Peter Martin knocked back Phil DeFreitas's leg stump after the ex-Lancashire star had punished some loose Schofield deliveries.

Lancashire, who have also beaten Leicestershire in the Benson and Hedges Cup, now bid for a treble in the Norwich Union National League game at Old Trafford today.

 Kent fast bowler Dean Headley is to undergo spinal surgery that threatens to rule him out of England's busiest ever domestic season.

The surgeon has recommended that Headley, one of England's 12 contracted players, must rest for 'three to four months'.

fields.headline: Hosts blown away by Inzi
fields.trailText: Inzamam-Ul-Haq hit an undefeated 117 to pull Pakistan from the early crisis of 39 for five to 221 without further loss by the end of the first day of the opening Test against the West Indies.
fields.body:
Inzamam-Ul-Haq hit an undefeated 117 to pull Pakistan from the early crisis of 39 for five to 221 without further loss by the end of the first day of the opening Test against the West Indies.

Inzamam shared an unbroken stand of 182 for the sixth wicket with all-rounder Abdur Razzaq, who hit a career-best 80 not out.

Curtly Ambrose led the home team's early assault with three wickets, ending with three for 37 off 18 overs.

Ambrose and his longtime new ball partner Courtney Walsh, reduced the Pakistanis to 21 for four in the opening hour. Walsh, 37, recently crowned the world's leading wicket-taker, captured one for 28 off 16 overs.

When Reon King removed Pakistan captain Moin Khan with his first delivery, the tourists had slipped to 39 for five.

But Inzamam underlined his status as one of the world's leading batsmen, leading a confident rescue mission. He notched his second century in successive Test innings following his 138 against Sri Lanka last March in Karachi.

He received assistance from the 20-year-old Abdur Razzaq, in only his fourth Test. Razzaq, whose previous highest score was 11, struck 11 boundaries from 241 balls in 288 minutes.

Inzamam and Razzaq took lunch at 68 for five and batted confidently throughout the last two sessions with few alarms.

The West Indies would have been delighted with the start they got after winning the toss and deciding to bowl first.

Walsh struck in the sixth over, breaching Wajahatullah Wasti's uncertain defence and Ambrose soon got into the act, sending back Mohammad Wasim five balls later.

Ambrose soon added the wickets of Younis Khan and Yousuf Youhana from successive balls.

King replaced Ambrose and, in his first Test on his home ground, hit with his first ball, Moin Khan cutting a catch to Jimmy Adams in the gully.

The West Indian players and the 6,000 in the crowd were then in a jubilant mood. But Inzamam and Razzaq gradually lifted the home team's grip and, by the close, the momentum had well and truly shifted.

fields.headline: Hayden joins the A stream
fields.trailText: There must have been moments this week when Matthew Hayden felt like one of the dunces in the Aussie class of 12. He was in disgrace, dispatched ignominiously to the corner of the classroom alongside that naughty Shane Warne, who acquired his maiden pair in his maiden county match plus a solitary wicket.
fields.body:
There must have been moments this week when Matthew Hayden felt like one of the dunces in the Aussie class of 12. He was in disgrace, dispatched ignominiously to the corner of the classroom alongside that naughty Shane Warne, who acquired his maiden pair in his maiden county match plus a solitary wicket.

Until yesterday Hayden had also failed to confirm the recently expressed view of Jeff Thomson that Australia are the best and the rest are rubbish (mind you, he's always said that, especially when invited to express himself in our tabloids).

In Hayden's first innings he had been dismissed by Angus Fraser for a paltry 20. This was a most conspicuous failure, even though there are a few English opening batsmen who would be glad to scrape to 20 at this stage of the season. But for an Aussie in England, 20 was a disaster. Wherever you looked last week the Aussies were supreme; from Durham's Simon Katich to Somerset's Jamie Cox, antipodean batsmen were gladdening Thommo's heart. At Lord's Justin Langer had helped himself to 157 runs for once out - he effortlessly grabbed another 37 from 27 balls to set up Middlesex's declaration yesterday morning.

Then Hayden had the chance to rid himself of his first innings ignominy. His Northamptonshire side - remember Hayden is one of three Aussies captaining county teams - had been set 391 from a minimum of 84 overs. The way Hayden set off he was interested in such a steep target. He hit 93 from 123 balls before being bowled by Richard Johnson and thereafter Northamptonshire sights were set on a draw. This was easily achieved thanks to the devoted efforts of Adrian Rollins who was caught at mid-off four runs short of his second hundred in the match.

The assertion of Thommo, over here as Zimbabwe's bowling coach, that Australia's second team would beat England, does not seem so ridiculous. It's hard to deny that a good proportion of Australia's second stringers would be good enough to play for our national team, whether it be Cox, Law, Lehmann, Elliott or indeed Hayden.

Thommo's other carefully considered opinion - that Zimbabwe have nothing to worry about against England - is less easy to justify since the poor tourists have just been thrashed by an innings by Kent at Canterbury. Thommo, as ever, has been shooting from the hip.

Hayden discovered a most benign fourth-day batting surface to atone for his first innings failure. Straw-coloured, despite the recent deluges, it offered nothing to the seamers and some slow turn for the spinners, all of which made Langer's cautious declaration understandable.

Hayden had only three moments of anguish in his innings. There was a vehement appeal for lbw from Fraser at the start; in mid-innings he had to scamper when a direct hit from Shah at cover shattered the stumps at the bowler's end; at the end he was duped by an inswinger from Johnson.

There's nothing enchanting about his batting. At 6ft 2in, he can get a long way down the pitch; he watches the ball fiercely and is clinical in the way he disposes of the poor ball; almost mechanical except there were occasions when he swept the turning ball with surprising deftness.

His ally during an opening partnership of 152 was Rollins, a good acquisition from Derbyshire. Not many frills about him either. At nearly six-and-a-half feet tall, Rollins rocked on to his front foot diligently for four and a half hours; Hayden and Rollins will make a hefty opening pair for Northamptonshire whether you measure their runs or their pounds.

David Sales' entry corresponded with the appearance of Mike Gatting in the press box. When Sales padded up to Tufnell, Gatting expressed both joy (as Middlesex coach) and exasperation (he was also Sales' manager on the A tour). It was indeed an infuriating dismissal for one so talented. Somehow all these Aussies seem to make the most of their ability. Sales and other gifted young Poms have yet to learn how to do that.

webTitle: Hector's house built on honest endeavour

fields.headline: Hector's house built on honest endeavour
fields.trailText: No one in Valencia can quite believe this is happening. The city loves its football team but never expects them to win much. And it is 20 years ago this month that they last achieved anything in Europe, taking the Cup Winners Cup after a young, exhausted Graham Rix fluffed his penalty for Arsenal.
fields.body:
No one in Valencia can quite believe this is happening. The city loves its football team but never expects them to win much. And it is 20 years ago this month that they last achieved anything in Europe, taking the Cup Winners Cup after a young, exhausted Graham Rix fluffed his penalty for Arsenal.

This is a lovely city: hot, friendly, and devoted to marcha , or fun. Valencia is less beautiful than Barcelona, but also less prissy. The locals make money, sit on the beach, and at midnight throng the restaurants where they converse, by preference, at the tops of their voices. 'The people are adorable,' says Jocelyn Angloma, Valencia's French defender. They pack the Mestalla stadium, but take disappointment for granted.

This means that while life for the ordinary Valencian is pretty good, for the professional footballer it is perfect. Lots of money (Angloma, who came here from Inter, earns twice as much as in Italy) and none of the stress of playing for Barca or Real.

This looked like shaping up to be another of those seasons. A new manager, Héctor Cúper, of whom much was expected; a dismal start, with one point from five games; tossed hither and thither in the Champions League, with a 3-0 defeat at Old Trafford putting them in their place; and, repeatedly, thousands of white handkerchiefs demanding Cúper's sacking.

And now they are 90 minutes from the final of the Champions League.

On Tuesday, Valencia thrashed Barcelona 4-1 in the first leg of the semi-final. Afterwards, the bars around the stadium were packed with T-shirts bearing the message: 'Hello Paris, I am from Valencia, and the cup belongs to us'.

If that turns out to be true, no one can claim to have predicted it. Valencia had to qualify for the Champions League, beating Hapoel Haifa home and away, and after that always seemed on the brink of leaving it. They began as 25-1 outsiders and later moved out to 40-1, but still no punters bit. Graham Sharpe, the William Hill spokesman, says: 'If we get a Valencia-Real Madrid final, we'll be dancing in the streets because we haven't taken any big bets on either. All the big money is on Bayern and Barcelona, and of course it was on Manchester United.' The largest bet Hill's have taken on Valencia is £2,500 at 15-2. Today the odds are 5-4.

As Tuesday night became Wednesday morning, and the T-shirt wearers began to think about dinner, a few must have wondered: 'How on earth did this happen?'

It began in 1919, the year Valencia were founded, around the same time that an Englishman named Cooper emigrated to Argentina, where he married an Italian. The family changed their name to Cúper, and eventually produced Héctor, who became a mediocre footballer. Later he coached Huracan and Lanus in Argentina, excelled, and won himself a ticket back to Europe.

At Mallorca he excelled again, taking the club to the first division and threatening to win the league. Last season, the club's first in Europe, Cúper took Mallorca to the final of the Cup Winners Cup.

Now he has excelled with Valencia. Louis van Gaal, the Barcelona manager, has called Cúper the best coach in Spain. Joachim Bjorklund, Valencia's Swedish defender, a voluble and expressive man for a Swede, says of him: 'Hard work. Successful. Honest man.'

Cúper is all that and, at times, a nice guy too. A few weeks ago, on a glorious day at the Valencia training ground when you could hardly believe that playing here qualified as work, I thrust a microphone under his nose and asked him to introduce himself. 'Héctor Cúper,' he said. 'Argentinian, married, two children, wanted by Interpol.'

Under Cúper, everyone plays for the team. Earlier this season, after the club captain, Francisco Camarasa, announced that Cúper's training sessions were boring, he was instantly benched and has remained absent from the campaign.

Over time, Cúper has built a true team: gnarled old men in defence, fronted by young players who swarm forward and back en masse and can play football too. A year ago Valencia were a counter-attacking side who hated having the ball. Now they are glorious to watch.

Yet there is a sad truth behind Valencia's surge: they have gone so far partly because they have played badly in Spain. Their rivals in the Champions League have almost all been consumed with trying to win domestic prizes. Valencia have coasted at home. They went out of the cup before Christmas, and in the league have only recently risen as high as fifth.

It means that recently in the Champions League they have been fresh. In the most overloaded competition in the history of European football, that makes the difference. It explains how they thrashed Lazio 5-2 and Barcelona 4-1.

On Wednesday in the Nou Camp, Barcelona might make up the deficit. That would be a shame. The Champions League, a trophy that exists solely for big clubs to make money, deserves to be won by a small club.

They went out of the cup before Christmas, and in the league have only recently risen as high as fifth. It means that recently in the Champions League they have been fresh. In the most overloaded competition in the history of European football, that makes the difference. It explains how they thrashed Lazio 5-2 and Barcelona 4-1. On Wednesday in the Nou Camp, Barcelona might make up the deficit. That would be a shame. The Champions League, a trophy that exists solely for big clubs to make money, deserves to be won by a small club.

fields.headline: Calais defies Cup Goliaths
fields.standfirst: French football history is being written in the turf tonight as a team of part-time players take on the giants of Nantes for the Cup Final in Paris
fields.trailText: It's called 'Calaismania', and it has France in its grip. It was impossible yesterday to open a newspaper, watch TV or listen to the radio without reading or hearing the name of the downtrodden port town whose amateur footballers will this evening step on to the hallowed turf of the Stade de France to contest the French Cup Final.
fields.byline: by Jon Henley in Paris and Will Buckley in Calais
fields.body:
It's called 'Calaismania', and it has France in its grip. It was impossible yesterday to open a newspaper, watch TV or listen to the radio without reading or hearing the name of the downtrodden port town whose amateur footballers will this evening step on to the hallowed turf of the Stade de France to contest the French Cup Final.

'Of course, you can never have enough of it, but it's getting a bit much even for us,' said Roger Dumont, sitting in a bar near the Gare du Nord. One of the Calaisiens already in Paris on the eve of the big match, he was fresh off the train, sporting a multicoloured scarf and an 'Allez Calais' hat, for a long - and, he hoped, triumphant - weekend in the capital.

'This past week you couldn't move for reporters,' he said. 'They were everywhere, and they wanted anyone who could put two words together. My mate was on the eight o'clock news, and the Washington Post got hold of my cousin. We haven't seen that one yet, though. But when a serious paper like Le Monde publishes an eight-page supplement on Calais, you start to wonder what's up.'

What's up is the football match of the season - some would say of the decade. This evening, turn off Manchester United, Chelsea, Leeds and the other public companies tediously playing each other to please their shareholders. Watch instead, if you can, a game that harks back to a more romantic time.

In the black, red and yellow corner we have Calais Racing Union FC, an amateur club in the French Fourth Division, with a squad that includes a right-back who is an agent commercial dans une entreprise d'agencement de magasins , a midfielder who is a jardinier de la ville de Gravelines , and a centre-forward who is a magasinier dans un cash-and-carry .

Their opponents, wearing yellow and green, are 11 Porsche and BMW-driving professionals from First Division club and cup-holders FC Nantes Atlantique, all of whom earn about £5,000 a week. It is the first time an amateur club has made it to the Cup final in France or, indeed, anywhere. It's as if Folkestone Invicta had made it to Wembley.

In England it could only be the stuff of fiction. J.L. Carr's How Steeple Sinderby Wanderers Won the FA Cup , for example, tells the story of a small amateur team triumphing thanks to a few remarkable men being in the same place at the same time.

In France, it's for real. Television talkshows have been broadcasting from the town live for the past three days. 'Calais maketh the Cup run over!', screamed yesterday's front-page headline in the ever-irreverent Libération . 'All of France behind Calais!' screeched a popular rival, Le Parisien .

Out at Clairefontaine, the French national team's training centre, where the Calais team have been since Wednesday, the officials offered coach Ladislas Lozano the room used by Aimé Jacquet, France's World Cup-winning trainer. He refused. He might be an OK coach, he said, but Jacquet was something else.

The Calais hype is so overwhelming that some Nantes players are losing patience. 'In the beginning it was nice,' said forward Olivier Monterrubio. 'But now if they're on the telly, I switch channels. The worst thing is that, if we win, we'll be the big and bad and ugly, and we'll be booed. It's not good.'

Calais is not, generally, a happy town. Unemployment is nearly 17 per cent, and almost half of its 75,000 inhabitants earn less than £5,000 a year. Virtually all of the lucky few who got hold of the club's allocation of 19,300 tickets will travel down to Paris today on clapped-out old trains laid on for a special return fare of £17.50.

'The tickets have been a big disappointment,' admitted the newly-elected Communist Mayor, Jacky Hénin. 'As soon as we knew we were in the final, we rang round all the clubs to try to buy some of theirs. None wanted to [sell]. Now people have been calling up offering tickets for £100, £200. It's hard for people who hope so much.'

But outside a brasserie at the Gare du Nord, a small group of young Calais fans were none the less determined to try their luck. 'It's the event of my life so far, no question,' said Nicolas, 17, an apprentice machinist. 'I'll try for a ticket tomorrow. But I can't go higher than £50, and with the train that already means kissing goodbye to my summer holiday.'

The Stade de France, where France beat Brazil to lift the World Cup two summers ago, will come as a change. The 80-year-old Calais ground would shame a side in the Kent county league, just across the Channel.

There is one stand with seats for 500, shabby nets above the goals to prevent the ball going onto the main road, and a prefabricated hut where a Port Vale pennant has pride of place.

This is the office of the club's chairman, Claude Thiriot. He came to Calais 32 years ago, fell in love, and stayed. During his tenure he managed to halve the club's debts of over 2 million francs (about £200,000). The cup run has covered the rest. The debts have disappeared and the profits have been redistributed among the players, who received £10,000 a man for the semi-final victory and will receive another £20,000 if they win tonight.

But the strain is telling. 'Because he is a passionate guy working all the hours of the day and night, he has lost a stone and a half,' says his son, Nico. 'And at the age of 66, you do not want to lose weight like that.'

Some of the Calais success is down to Thiriot Snr, and some to Lozano. He was brought from Spain to France at the age of five when his parents fled the Franco regime. He was a talented footballer in his youth, but unable to attend national trials because of his Spanish nationality. He is now a council foreman overseeing 60 workers who look after the local sports halls and grounds.

A refreshingly straight-talking star of the French media last week, he has sparked furore by daring to suggest that his side's values of hard work, commitment, teamwork and the will to win had somehow been lost from the pampered world of French professional football.

'We have written one of the most beautiful pages in French football history,' he said, in more conciliatory tones. 'The results have come from incessant work and enormous sacrifices from everyone. My players are going beyond themselves in search of the unthinkable.'

After the semi-final win against Bordeaux, the reigning French league champions - when 40,000 Calais fans travelled to Lens to see their unlikely heroes win 3-1 in extra time - the team and their supporters returned to Calais for a reception in the Town Hall at 2.30am, a bus ride through the packed streets (3am) and a duck and foie gras dinner (4.30 am).

'Between the podium and the restaurant, he had a faint,' says Nico Thiriot. 'They were shouting "faint, faint, faint, someone's had a faint". I thought it was my Dad. Everyone thought that. Ladislas spent three days in hospital. Only two people had his number, his wife and my Dad. But President Chirac got through and said, "Hello, I'm Jacques Chirac. Can we meet at the Stade de France"?'

fields.headline: Wednesday on the edge
fields.trailText: Mathematically Sheffield Wednesday are still not down. But for all intents and purposes they will play First Division football next season. Coventry outplayed them from the start and could well have doubled their total.
fields.body:
Mathematically Sheffield Wednesday are still not down. But for all intents and purposes they will play First Division football next season. Coventry outplayed them from the start and could well have doubled their total.

On a tension-filled afternoon for Wednesday, the Coventry manager Gordon Strachan enjoyed the luxury of bringing in Steve Ogrizovic for his final home appearance before retiring.

'He is one of the finest pros of the modern era, a superb example to all players and a thoroughly decent and pleasant man,' Strachan wrote in his programme notes of the goalkeeper who has made more than 600 appearances in nearly 16 years with the club.

Ogrizovic, who is taking up a coaching appointment with Coventry, was reduced to the role of spectator as his opposite number, Kevin Pressman, came under a barrage of pressure. Pressman was grateful when Robbie Keane, running onto a pass from Moustapha Hadji shot into the side netting and did well to parry a drive from the Moroccan after Israel Zuniga set him up.

The Wednesday keeper had fortune on his side when an attempted clearance was charged down by Zunija and he managed to collect the ball at the second attempt but redeemed himself with another smart save from Hadji.

By now the pressure was unrelenting. Keane, released by Zunija, went round Pressman but stumbled and placed his effort wide of the near post. In contrast Ogrizovic's only moment of concern in the first half came when Alan Quinn took possession at a far post position, only to drive the chance into the crowd.

But, in truth, it was hardly a contest. Coventry took the lead after 37 minutes when Zunija's challenge in midfield enabled Gary McAllister to stride through a large hole in the Wednesday defence and beat Pressman emphatically for his 12th goal of the season.

Wednesday briefly came back into the game when a free-kick from Andy Hinchcliffe was knocked down by Peter Atherton although Andy Booth was unable to take advantage. But they did better through Quinn who accelerated onto a neat back-heel by Gilles de Bilde to fire just over.

However, that proved a rare interlude from Coventry's domination. McAllister had a free-kick from 25 yards pushed against the top bar by Pressman. Then within the space of three minutes Coventry scored twice. McAllister again hit the crossbar with a shot with the outside of the boot and Zuniga headed in the rebound. Then, Hadji rolled a pass across the face of the penalty box for McAllister to drive low into the corner to take over as his team's leading scorer for the season with one more than Keane.

Hadji made it 4-0 after Pressman beat out a shot from Zuniga and by the time de Bilde went round Ogrizovic to pull one back it was scant consolation.

webTitle: United in the eyes of God

fields.headline: United in the eyes of God
fields.trailText: Eric Cantona's thespian talents have yet to propel him even onto Hollywood's C-list, but he still has the presence and allure to captivate this audience.
fields.body:
Eric Cantona's thespian talents have yet to propel him even onto Hollywood's C-list, but he still has the presence and allure to captivate this audience.

While his former Manchester United team-mates continued their progress towards their target of 100 Premiership goals in a season, the sight of the man they called 'Dieu' in the directors' box was sufficient to avert the gaze of many supporters.

The Frenchman nodded his approval as United produced a mesmerising first-half display - which reaped goals for Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, David Beckham and Teddy Sheringham - but made a discreet exit before the latest coronation of the club he did so much to transform in the five years he spent here in the mid-Nineties.

As unthinkable as it seems now they had not won the championship in 26 years before Cantona's arrival. Shortly before they saw their sixth Premiership title in eight years yesterday, the Old Trafford crowd launched into their repetoire of eulogies to their former idol. Heroes come and go, but none commands the adulation the Frenchman enjoys on his occasional returns to Manchester.

Some would have it that Cantona's team, the one that ended the agonising wait and then won the Double the following year, is the finest in the club's history. In reality, however, it is hard to argue against Sir Alex Ferguson's protestation that this is his best side. The ton of goals may prove elusive, since they are four short ahead of next Sunday's trip to Aston Villa, but their greatness was reaffirmed yesterday.

Ferguson said: 'For me, this is probably the best championship we've won. The performances have been excellent. We've scored 96 goals and we've got 88 points with a game left. That's unbelievable. But we shouldn't settle for that.

'The performance in the first half was absolutely marvellous. In the second half they were just enjoying themselves and I can't blame them for that. You don't often get the opportunity to relax these days.'

George Graham's continued ill health denied him the chance to accompany his Tottenham team north, but he was fit enough to instruct Stuart Houston to play the youngster Matthew Etherington in place of David Ginola, who was not even among the substitutes. 'I explained to David this morning and he quite rightly was disappointed but he took it on board,' said Houston.

United took just five minutes to break the resistance of a young Tottenham side, Solskjaer diverting Jaap Stam's header past Walker, but the visitors levelled on 20 minutes when the unmarked Chris Armstong scored with a diving header from Darren Anderton's cross.

Yet again the thought occurred that United would enjoy the world-beating status they aspire to if only they could sort out a defence whose record is the worst in the top six.

But, with Ryan Giggs playing superbly, a United victory was never in doubt. Beckham then curled home a stunning second before Sheringham ran clear to score on what was surely his Old Trafford swansong.

Sadly the masterclass was not continued after the interval, but 45 minutes are usually all United need to build up an unassailable lead. Same again next year.

fields.headline: Stoke get a right result
fields.trailText: Reading won the day, but Stoke won a place in the Second Division play-offs even though their 16-game unbeaten run game to an end and the visitors were left relying on other results to go their way when Darren Caskey scored from the penalty spot with 10 minutes to go.
fields.byline: Nick Callow at the Madejski Stadium
fields.body:
Reading won the day, but Stoke won a place in the Second Division play-offs even though their 16-game unbeaten run game to an end and the visitors were left relying on other results to go their way when Darren Caskey scored from the penalty spot with 10 minutes to go.

For once, the boisterous Stoke fans fell silent but their biggest cheer of the afternoon was to follow with the news of the demise of promotion rivals Bristol Rovers.

Stoke celebrated in style and they now face a two-legged tie against Gillingham to earn a place at Wembley in the play-off final.

Passions were running high before the game. One double-decker bus of Stoke supporters was so keen to get into the ground they started smashing the top deck windows in an attempt to get off early. The atmosphere inside the Madejski Stadium was tense, but far more positive as the 3,500 visiting fans supported their team relentlessly with chants of, 'We are going up'.

The game started with their team in attack mode, seeking the one point that would guarantee a place in the play-offs.

Reading, relegated to the Second Division with Stoke two years ago, have also had a good second half of the season and were clearly a match in terms of spirit, if not always quality.

All the early chances went Stoke's way. Brynjar Gunnarsson headed just wide at the far post in the ninth minute, and Peter Thorne lifted a shot over the bar soon after. Kyle Lightbourne drove a shot narrowly wide and another threatening drive from Gunnarsson almost broke the deadlock approaching half-time.

Lightbourne's 40th-minute free-kick was closer still and required a good save from Phil Whitehead to keep it goalless.

Stoke, however, knowing that a draw would be sufficient, were more clinical when challenged in front of their goal, scything down any Reading player who looked like coming close. It was a dangerous tactic and none too pretty to watch, and it led to first-half bookings for Graham Kavanagh, Gunnarsson and the captain Nicky Mohan.

Whatever the purists may think, it was nevertheless effective as the Stoke keeper Gavin Ward did not have a single shot to save in the opening 45 minutes.

The visitors looked to consolidate their attacking base by sending on Arnar Gunnlaugsson for James O'Connor at the start of the second half and they were forced into replacing the injured Lightbourne with Paul Connor in the 55th minute.

The changes made little difference to the pattern of the game, while off the pitch a small section of the Reading supporters briefly took out their frustrations on the police in what turned out to be nothing more than a minor scuffle.

The stakes, obviously, grew higher as the match progressed and while the standard was most definitely Second Division, the commitment was out of the top drawer and there is every reason to believe that both teams need only a little fine tuning to move up to a higher level.

For once, the boisterous Stoke fans fell silent but their biggest cheer of the afternoon was to follow with the news of the demise of promotion rivals Bristol Rovers. Stoke celebrated in style and they now face a two-legged tie against Gillingham to earn a place at Wembley in the play-off final. Passions were running high before the game. One double-decker bus of Stoke supporters was so keen to get into the ground they started smashing the top deck windows in an attempt to get off early. The atmosphere inside the Madejski Stadium was tense, but far more positive as the 3,500 visiting fans supported their team relentlessly with chants of, 'We are going up'. The game started with their team in attack mode, seeking the one point that would guarantee a place in the play-offs. Reading, relegated to the Second Division with Stoke two years ago, have also had a good second half of the season and were clearly a match in terms of spirit, if not always quality. All the early chances went Stoke's way. Brynjar Gunnarsson headed just wide at the far post in the ninth minute, and Peter Thorne lifted a shot over the bar soon after. Kyle Lightbourne drove a shot narrowly wide and another threatening drive from Gunnarsson almost broke the deadlock approaching half-time. Lightbourne's 40th-minute free-kick was closer still and required a good save from Phil Whitehead to keep it goalless. Stoke, however, knowing that a draw would be sufficient, were more clinical when challenged in front of their goal, scything down any Reading player who looked like coming close. It was a dangerous tactic and none too pretty to watch, and it led to first-half bookings for Graham Kavanagh, Gunnarsson and the captain Nicky Mohan. Whatever the purists may think, it was nevertheless effective as the Stoke keeper Gavin Ward did not have a single shot to save in the opening 45 minutes. The visitors looked to consolidate their attacking base by sending on Arnar Gunnlaugsson for James O'Connor at the start of the second half and they were forced into replacing the injured Lightbourne with Paul Connor in the 55th minute. The changes made little difference to the pattern of the game, while off the pitch a small section of the Reading supporters briefly took out their frustrations on the police in what turned out to be nothing more than a minor scuffle. fields.headline: Gills edged out
fields.trailText: If the football gods were being fair then Gillingham would have scored twice in injury time to seal promotion to Division One for the first time in their 107-year history. Sadly, instead they condemned them again to the purgatory of the play-offs as Burnley leapfrogged them into an automatic promotion place.
fields.byline: Duncan Mackay at The Racecourse Ground
fields.body:
If the football gods were being fair then Gillingham would have scored twice in injury time to seal promotion to Division One for the first time in their 107-year history. Sadly, instead they condemned them again to the purgatory of the play-offs as Burnley leapfrogged them into an automatic promotion place.

The Gills, of course, suffered the agony last season of being two up in the final against Manchester City only to concede two late goals and eventually lose on penalties. This season, six wins in their last eight matches had lifted them from outside the play-off zone into second only for Peter Taylor's side to falter at the last.

This ground already had a special place in Taylor's heart because it was here in 1976 that he became the last player from the old Division Three to make his debut for England. It had been especially memorable because he had come off the substitute's bench to score against Wales.

One of his opponents that day was Brian Flynn, who again lined up against him yesterday as Wrexham's manager. As a former Burnley favourite, he had his own special reason for wanting to win besides extending Wrexham's end-of-season run of four consecutive victories.

There was a frenzied atmosphere in the away end, which was a mass of colour and noise a full 90 minutes before kick off. But their enthusiasm was dampened after 11 minutes thanks to Mark McGregor's first goal of the season for Wrexham. It was worth waiting for too; the right back collected the ball 30 yards from goal before arrowing a shot beyond Vince Bartram into the corner of the net.

Wrexham's nervy defence gave Gillingham plenty of reason to feel optimistic and the news Scunthorpe had taken the lead against Burnley restored the Gillingham fans' vigour. They thought they had something else to celebrate in the 29th minute when Onuora saw the Wrexham keeper Kevin Dearden fumble his header on the line before it was hacked clear.

Gillingham started the second half at a gallop and for long periods Wrexham. But the closest they came during this period was when the unlucky Onuora was again denied in the 48th minute when Dearden blocked a close-range effort with his legs.

However, they were also kept in the game by reflex saves from Bartram in the 58th and 74th minutes from Robin Gibson.

Sandwiched between these saves, the visitors continued to swarm around the Wrexham penalty area, the best chance falling to Carl Asaba in the 69th minute. He burst through on to a long pass, but lobbed over the bar when faced with only Dearden to beat.

A few minutes later they knew that Burnley had taken the lead and Gillingham's fate was sealed. Never had a potential visit to Wembley been greeted with such disappointment.

fields.headline: Doomed Watford keep on singing
fields.trailText: A goal from Watford's Darren Ward frustrated Bryan Robson's ambitions for his Middlesbrough side to finish a point higher than the 51 they managed in last season's campaign.
fields.byline: Darren Morley at The Riverside Stadium
fields.body:
A goal from Watford's Darren Ward frustrated Bryan Robson's ambitions for his Middlesbrough side to finish a point higher than the 51 they managed in last season's campaign.

Robbie Stockdale's first goal for the home side after 27 minutes moved his side closer to their 52-point Premiership target. But Watford, already relegated, put in a performance that belied a banner flying cheekily in the visitors' section declaring: 'We're out of your league.'

But they were unable to prevent Stockdale getting the better of David Perpetuini and squeezing his shot under the advancing Hornets keeper Chris Day into the corner of the net.

Middlesbrough's Brazilian maestro Juninho had the first chance of the opening quarter-hour when Paul Robinson fouled Hamilton Ricard 25 yards from goal and Juninho's free-kick sailed inches over the bar.

After 11 minutes doomed Watford, whose colourful fans were clearly intent on an end-of-season party, had a similar chance but Micah Hyde fired his free-kick over at the other end.

With Middlesbrough marooned in mid-table, there was the inevitable lack of cut-and-thrust, although Bryan Robson insisted there was a lot to play for yesterday and in next week's finale at Everton.

Andy Campbell again led the forward line alongside Ricard, in the absence of the injured Brian Deane.

Frustration among the home faithful spilled on to the pitch after 34 minutes when Ricard was booked for dissent. Two minutes later, Ricard almost had a hand in putting his side 2-0 up. The Colombian laid the ball off to Juninho, who looked set to charge into the box before he was foiled by a last-ditch tackle from Steve Palmer.

The Watford manager, Graham Taylor, added much-needed firepower in the shape of strikers Tommy Mooney and Nordin Wooter at half time. Boro started the second period in a different gear and after 52 minutes carved out another glorious opportunity. The busy Ricard again caused problems down Watford's left and squared the ball to Juninho. But somehow the Brazilian fired his shot high of the target.

Then out of nowhere Watford equalised after Tommy Smith mis-hit his shot in the left corner of the box. But it squirted conveniently to Ward, who could not miss from four yards.

fields.headline: Derby's point for survival
fields.trailText: Derby were able to celebrate safety even though results elsewhere rendered their point won against Newcastle meaningless.
fields.body:
Derby were able to celebrate safety even though results elsewhere rendered their point won against Newcastle meaningless.

Starting the game needing a draw to maintain their Premiership status, the Rams controlled the contest for long periods and always looked likely to earn a share of the spoils.

It could have been three points but the Newcastle goalkeeper Shay Given, superb throughout, was able to pull off a brilliant stop to deny Deon Burton's near-post flick eight minutes from time.

The suspended duo Rory Delap and Seth Johnson missed out for Derby so Jim Smith drafted Tony Dorigo and Adam Murray into his starting line-up.

The home side created the first opening when Dorigo played a neat one-two with Deon Burton down the left. Burton lobbed a pass to the edge of the box, Murray steadied himself and volleyed only for Given to make a superb save and then react fastest to claw the ball away from his own line.

Derby's Georgi Kinkladze took possession on halfway and there seemed little danger but after spiriting past two defenders, the defence backed off and Kinkladze produced an impish chip from the edge of the area that deserved better than to cannon off the underside of the crossbar, hit Given on the way out and win only a corner.

With his defence a shambles, the Newcastle manager Bobby Robson threw on Didier Domi for Alessandro Pistone after just 13 minutes, although the Italian did clutch his hamstring for effect as he reached the touchline.

Robert Lee was shown the yellow card for a nasty looking challenge on Kinkladze and then risked an early end to his afternoon by lunging in on Burton, although referee Alan Wiley felt a free-kick and a ticking off were sufficient punishment.

Mart Poom - named as Derby's player of the season before the match - made his first real save after half an hour from Temuri Ketsbaia's 20-yard shot that the Estonian turned round his left-hand post.

The midfield battle between Kinkladze and Lee continued when a free-kick was given against the Newcastle midfielder for shirt-pulling, a foul that earned him his second lecture.

At half-time the injured Kinkladze was replaced by Dean Sturridge, yet Derby started the second half as they had the first.

Lee and Ketsbaia both went close for the visitors but it was Given's goal that came closest to being breached. Sturridge pulled a cross back from the by-line to Burton, who got the slightest flick at the near post. Given was already down but reacted superbly to the change of direction and saved on the line.

webTitle: Cue Hartson for the final drama

fields.headline: Cue Hartson for the final drama
fields.trailText: There's some fight in the old underdog yet. Three minutes into injury time and it was as good as over, it really was. Corner to Wimbledon, floated in by Neal Ardley, flapped at by David James, thumped by John Hartson. Mayhem. Just how this idiosyncratic club have always liked it.
fields.body:
There's some fight in the old underdog yet. Three minutes into injury time and it was as good as over, it really was. Corner to Wimbledon, floated in by Neal Ardley, flapped at by David James, thumped by John Hartson. Mayhem. Just how this idiosyncratic club have always liked it.

Write them off and they biff you on the nose.

Cue a mob of navy shirted bodies pogoing together by the corner flag. Down the touchline at the dugout stand in manager Terry Burton merely brushed a hand through his not yet grey mop.

Well he knows they are not yet out of the woods. The skipping heartbeats and sweaty palms continue until the campaign's final 90 minutes next weekend. Neck and neck with Bradford on points, their superior goal difference means they go to the Dell knowing they must match whatever the Bantams manage against Liverpool to preserve their 14 year stint amongst the big boys.

If ever there was a time to summon up that old Crazy Gang mentality it was right here, right now. For a club who have supposedly been unwelcome gatecrashers of the elite over the past 14 years they have generally managed to steer clear of the relegation terrors. Experienced upsetters of the form book they may be, but the sensation of the Premiership guillotine hovering an inch above their necks is a new challenge to most of this perplexed squad. Nerves were palpable.

It was Wimbledon's fortune to find opponents preoccupied by a combination of FA Cup Finals and sunbathing. Dion Dublin could become an honourary Don for two massive let offs. The first, looping a free header harmlessly high, was one of those things. Dragging wide in first half stoppage time made one more than the the odd cynic raise an eyebrow.

In between Villa's generosity helped Wimbledon forge ahead on the quarter hour. The Dons seemed as surprised as anyone to see Michael Hughes's inswinging cross ricochet off Ugo Ehiogu and past a bemused David James. A scruffy goal for Wimbledon? No matter. On the way back to the centre circle Marcus Gayle pointed to his temples. Use your heads, lads.

Although Villa were vaguely interested at best, they still possess individual quality which needed to be watched. Neil Sullivan was more than alert to thwart Alan Thomspon's rifled shot with an impressive poise.

For all the fresh urgency a new head honcho can inspire, Terry Burton's men were never going to emerge a side reborn overnight. Although Gayle and Neal Ardley went close to extending Wimbledon's lead, overall it was anxious, edgy stuff. Those eight straight slap-in-the-face defeats has drained too much confidence for a slender advantage to ease their ills.

For such a critical occasion just what Wimbledon didn't need was to lose their skipper and their most creative player before half time. Kenny Cunningham had already limped off by the time Mark Delaney's damaging tackle did for Michael Hughes and called for the stretcher bearers.

The bitterest blow came eight minutes after the restart, Wimbledon succumbing to the kind of soft goals which have become a bad habit. Alan Wright's lofted cross was glanced back by Delaney, and little Lee Hen drie was completely unmarked. Nodding past an exposed Sullivan was like a doddle in the park. That Villa were able to recover without trying particularly hard spoke volumes.

Then they were ahead. With Wimbledon's defence frozen and claiming offside, Dublin ambled onto Gareth Southgate's pass and twisted the knife with a ferociously hammered volley. How bitterly ironic if Wimbledon's fate is ultimately sealed by... a welly.

But the Dons were urged on by what surmounted to legions by their usual standards here in SE25, miles away from Merton. But who was prepared to raise the tempo, ruffle the feathers, storm the barricades? Where were the leaders? The characters? The scrappers? In the dim and distant past, mainly.

Cue John Hartson. Oh Hartson. A name perhaps more pertinent in terms of Wimbledon's demise than the maligned Egil Olsen when you consider the return from the kind of fee - £7.5 million - that could cripple a club of such paltry finances. That timely bash of head on ball might prove a goal in a million.

fields.headline: Clarets steal the big prize
fields.trailText: Burnley are back in Division One after five years but boy what a ride.
fields.body:
Burnley are back in Division One after five years but boy what a ride.

In a riveting climax to the season the Clarets knew that winning against relegated Scunthorpe would mean nothing if Gillingham beat Wrexham at the Racecourse Ground. Already relegated Scunthorpe clearly hadn't read the script. They went ahead early, dominated for long spells and will count themselves very unlucky not to have spoiled Burnley's promotion party.

Burnley were furious that Scunthorpe limited their allocation of tickets to just under 2,000 seats. It is easy to see why. Scunthorpe failed to sell out their end of the ground while 7,000 Clarets fans were forced to watch the game on a big screen at Turf Moor.

With the Scunthorpe fans taunting them with chants of 'Gillingham, Gillingham, Gillingham' Burnley knew of course that even the three points here might not be enough and the tension was evident from the start.

Top scorer Andy Payton missed a glorious chance to steady nerves in the first minute after Andy Cooke put in a delightful cross from the left and he headed over from five yards.

News of Wrexham scoring against Gillingham brought roars of excitement after 10 minutes. There was certainly nothing for them to cheer on the field. Scunthorpe midfielder Richard Logan picked up a loose ball 30 yards out and rifled an unstoppable shot into the top corner, the ball crashing in off the underside of the crossbar.

Scunthorpe skipper Chris Hope powered a header just wide as Burnley were pinned back but they recovered and ended the half strongly and were level shortly before the break. Keeper Ross Turner failed to connect with Paul Cook's corner, the ball was headed clear and with Turner stranded Mickey Mellon fired into the empty net from 20 yards.

Scunthorpe started the second half as the more threatening side. Brian Guailey failed to connect with a ball in from the dangerous Andrew Dawson, Hope's 20-yard free kick flew inches over and a brilliant run by Lee Hodges led to nothing.

But with 20 minutes remaining a free-kick by Cooke from the left hand side for Burnley fell to substitute Glenn Little on the edge of the box and he powered in an unstoppable shot to the top corner to Turner's right.

The Burnley fans mounted an instant pitch invasion though they were quickly ushered back as they began to sense promotion was theirs.

Payton had an effort cleared off the line before manager Stan Ternant sent on Ian Wright for a cameo appearance in the last few minutes for what will surely prove to be his final game in a Burnley shirt. He almost crowned it with a goal after running onto Cook's long ball but the effort was blocked. At the final whistle and the news from Wrexham 2,000 Burnley fans poured onto the pitch and the party could begin.

fields.headline: Bantams left on the brink
fields.trailText: No fairy tale for Bradford, not this week anyway. Three Leicester goals in nine minutes in the second half, two of them from Matt Elliott, brought the Bantams back to earth with a bang, although Aston Villa's recovery against Wimbledon still leaves a tantalising possibility of a last-day escape.
fields.body:
No fairy tale for Bradford, not this week anyway. Three Leicester goals in nine minutes in the second half, two of them from Matt Elliott, brought the Bantams back to earth with a bang, although Aston Villa's recovery against Wimbledon still leaves a tantalising possibility of a last-day escape.

Since Wimbledon are at Southampton next week while Bradford host Liverpool, if Paul Jewell's side pull it off they will certainly have done it the hard way. They will have to be a lot more assertive than this to get anything against Gèrard Houllier's side, though they need look no further than Leicester to see what is possible.

Already in Europe via the Worthington Cup, the Foxes have nothing left to play for this season, but no one can accuse them of switching off early or being half-hearted about their remaining league commitments. Wednesday's 2-0 victory at Liverpool did not just put a huge dent in Houllier's Champions League ambitions, it happened to be the third time Leicester have finished on the winning side at Anfield in three seasons, no mean achievement for a side condemned as negative and unambitious earlier in the season. Martin O'Neill, still smarting over the intensity of the criticism, is planning to send a video of the Liverpool game to the journalist who described Leicester as a blight on the Premiership, though he claims to be more disappointed by attacks from within the game. 'Chelsea and Aston Villa were two of the major clubs highly critical of our play, yet we have scored more Premiership goals than either of them,' he said. 'We have also won as many away games this season as Chelsea, so we must have been doing something more than occasionally crossing the halfway line.'

Not even O'Neill would have much use for a video of this match. One would have expected Bradford to take the game to Leicester in a more urgent manner than sticking 10 men behind the ball and employing Dean Saunders as a lone attacker. Leicester were practically invited to do as they liked in the first half, though on a warm afternoon they too struggled to find any real urgency.

After a couple of Steve Guppy crosses had evaded Tony Cottee Leicester decided Elliott might as well make a nuisance of himself in attack rather than have a day off in defence, and immediately the prospects of an opening goal improved. After 17 minutes Elliott's flick found Cottee and Muzzy Izzet in a promising position, but Matthew Clarke came out quickly to save from the latter.

Elliott and Phil Gilchrist then headed over from successive corners as Bradford added to their defensive problems by needlessly giving the ball away in their own half, and the Leicester captain was close with a long-range shot five minutes before the interval after Izzet had sent a free-kick just over the bar.

Elliott's best first-half chance came on the stroke of half-time when he gathered a rebound from Cottee in the six-yard box and appeared to have an empty net at which to aim, but his shot from three yards out was blocked on the line by David Wetherall.

Bradford, who brought on Lee Sharpe to replace left-back Wayne Jacobs after 10 minutes, had to wait half an hour for their first proper attempt on goal, a hopeful long shot by John Dreyer that did not pose Pegguy Arphexad any problems. A few minutes later Robbie Savage miscontrolled a pass to leave Robbie Blake a clear run, but after moving purposefully into the penalty area the Bradford striker only managed to fall over the ball.

Bradford tried to assert themselves more in the second half, perhaps having heard the half-time score from Selhurst Park. Yet no sooner had they brought their travelling support to life by winning a corner from which Wetherall headed narrowly wide, than Leicester calmly took play down to the other end and won a corner of their own, which Elliott headed firmly into Clarke's top-right corner.

Ten minutes later the Yorkshire disintegration was complete. Cottee should have scored a second before Neil Lennon's cross was met by Elliott's unerring forehead, then with Bradford heads hitting the deck faster than Frank Dobson election posters, Cottee latched on to a through ball and picked his way past O'Brien to slot a low shot beyond Clarke. Leicester relaxed enough to send on Theo Zagorakis for a final Filbert Street bow before returning to Greece, while the home fans chorused 'Boring, boring Leicester'. For the first time in the afternoon, the visiting fans were silent, probably because they had heard Villa were leading Wimbledon.

Arphexad produced a diving save to keep out Sharpe's free kick but rather than chase the game Bradford sensibly concluded their best plan was to conserve energy for an almighty effort next week. They must pray Southampton do the same.

fields.headline: Henry's champion
fields.trailText: Arsenal all but confirmed their position in next season's Champions League, and denied Chelsea one, with their twelfth consecutive victory, one that should have been more emphatic than the final scoreline after the thoroughbred Thierry Henry had sent them racing clear with a brace of goals that made it nine matches in succession in which he has scored.
fields.body:
Arsenal all but confirmed their position in next season's Champions League, and denied Chelsea one, with their twelfth consecutive victory, one that should have been more emphatic than the final scoreline after the thoroughbred Thierry Henry had sent them racing clear with a brace of goals that made it nine matches in succession in which he has scored.

Gustavo Poyet pulled a goal back in a late rally but Chelsea's performance was largely as limp as last week's win against Liverpool had been potent, enabling the referee Mike Reed to end his Premiership career with - thankfully - a whimper rather than a bang. You wonder which Chelsea will turn up to the FA Cup final in a fortnight.

With only victory, and another against Derby County at home next Sunday in their final match, giving Chelsea a chance of finishing in the top three, and then only if Leeds and Liverpool slip, Vialli clearly felt that attack was the best policy and chose to play George Weah, Tore Andre Flo and Gianfranco Zola up front. 'Bring on Chris Sutton,' chanted the Arsenal fans sarcastically.

The match may not have had the edge of antagonism that the history of this derby has produced, probably due to the sunny somnolence of the day and the fact that only six of the starting 22 were English, but there was still a pacy start to the game, Henry looking particularly sharp.

It was Chelsea who created the first opening, though. Mario Melchiot found Dennis Wise wide on the right and it seemed Zola might turn home his low cross until tackled, the ball falling for Roberto Di Matteo, whose shot David Seaman blocked with his knees.

It may have been the wake-up call Arsenal needed. Soon, Henry was diving to head Dennis Bergkamp's curling cross goalwards, only for Ed De Goey to save at his near post. Then Ray Parlour thumped in a 20-yard shot that the goalkeeper tipped over the bar.

Henry should have given Arsenal the lead when Bergkamp, fed by Patrick Vieira, slipped him through but De Goey again came to Chelsea's rescue, this time with his legs. A minute later, Henry made amends, however, the Dutchman unable to perform further heroics.

Vieira, by now cutting an imposing figure in midfield, hit a long ball forward that Frank Lebouef failed to cut out, allowing Henry another run on goal. He went round De Goey and for a moment it seemed as if he might have lost the chance as Leboeuf and Bernard Lambourde got back to cover. The Frenchman, composure itself, waited for them to commit themselves before slipping it home.

Vieira, who with Emmanuel Petit was winning the midfield contest and creating the space for Bergkamp to play some perceptive passes, almost had a deserved second when Parlour's cross hit Melchiot and dropped to him but, on the ground, he could only get in a weak shot that De Goey grabbed.

Zola's 25-yard shot that went well wide was typical of Chelsea's state of health at this point, though he was closer with another soon after. Heartened, Chelsea now looked more dangerous and Lee Dixon had to be alert to hook the ball away after Seaman could only turn aside Wise's low drive. Despite the flurry, Chelsea must have been relieved to reach the dressing room at half-time only a goal down.

The respite lasted only two minutes into the second period however. Bergkamp, again wreaking havoc, sent Henry clear and he impressively shrugged off the struggling Desailly, who had been playing him onside, before clipping the ball past De Goey.

Chelsea had reorganised, pushing Flo more forward, in an attempt to show greater attacking incision, but it was Arsenal who continued to look the more likely to score, De Goey having to fist away Bergkamp's powerful drive.

Then, out of the blue, came a goal by the Blues, at last stirred into life after Flo's shot had grazed the bar, thanks to two substitutes. Emerson Thome crossed from the right, Gilles Grimandi failed to cut it out, and Gustavo Poyet volleyed it home. It made for an uncomforable finish for the home side, but they did not deserve to be denied.

fields.headline: Chester out on goal difference
fields.standfirst: Nerves jangle at the bottom of the League as Carlisle and Shrewsbury enjoy Great Escape
fields.trailText: The mood among the teams battling to stay in the league was summed up when Chester City broadcasted the theme tune from the The Great Escape on their official website. However, in the absence of a Steve McQueen - or a goalkeeper to do what Jimmy Glass did for Carlisle this time last season - it was Chester who had to bid a regretful farewell to their Nationwide colleagues.
fields.body:
The mood among the teams battling to stay in the league was summed up when Chester City broadcasted the theme tune from the The Great Escape on their official website. However, in the absence of a Steve McQueen - or a goalkeeper to do what Jimmy Glass did for Carlisle this time last season - it was Chester who had to bid a regretful farewell to their Nationwide colleagues.

With Shrewsbury winning 2-1 at Exeter, Chester and Carlisle - through their 1-0 defeats against Peterborough and Brighton respectively - ended up sharing the bottom spot on points. But Chester, who had done so well in pulling themselves out of the drop zone after being six points adrift as recently as 26 February, were eventually counted out on goal difference.

Chester were sunk by a 34th minute goal by Ritchie Hanlon. At the time, Shrewsbury, needing a win to have any chance of saving themselves, were drawing 0-0. But Exeter's Danny Potter put through his own goal to give them a 59th minute lead and, suitably inspired, Shrewsbury went further ahead two minutes later through Michael Brown. Imagine the anxiety among the fans when Gary Alexander reduced the arrears six minutes from time.

Chester's sense of despair was compounded by the view of Scarborough's chairman, John Russell, on what they can expect in the Conference next season. Russell's side went down to the Conference in dramatic fashion this time last year when Jimmy Glass scored that infamous stoppage time goal to save Carlisle and send Scarborough down.

Russell said: 'It was weeks before it really started to sink in. But living in the town you could not avoid the subject because wherever you went that was all people wanted to talk about.

'It has made a huge difference to us, especially financially. Immediately you lose half of the Football League levy and I would estimate that would be worth around £300,000 this year.

'The top half of the Conference is easily as good as the Third Division and you cannot expect to come straight back up.'

'The last teams to do that were Lincoln and Darlington 10 or 11 years ago and those days are long gone.'

 Peter Davenport has resigned as Macclesfield manager after just four months in the job. The former Nottingham Forest, Manchester United and Middlesbrough striker who took over from Sammy McIlroy at the Third Division club, quit over a contractual dispute.

He was absent from the Macclesfield party for yesterday's trip to Halifax, and the club secretary, Colin Garlick, said: 'We thought we had put a more than acceptable deal together over two years but Peter obviously did not agree.

'We were advised this morning that he would not be coming to the game and we have learned since that he has resigned.

'It has come as a shock to us and it is all very disappointing. This is the last game of the season and for it to happen now makes it all the more surprising.

'I will be going back to him on Monday to try and change his mind but I am not hopeful about the outcome.'

In Davenport's absence the team for the match at Halfiax was selected by Macclesfield's chairman, Eddie Furlong, in consultation with the captain Darren Tinson and senior players John Askey and Steven Wood.

fields.headline: Explain...
fields.trailText: Insurance
fields.body:
Insurance

If it weren't for a particularly pernickety insurance company, Ruud van Nistelrooy would today be a Manchester United player. Thankfully for all concerned (except, of course, PSV), they insisted on some further checks and disaster - for them, as well as the club - was averted.

That company was Avon Insurance, based in Stratford-upon-Avon, which deals with the insurance for several top clubs, including Manchester United. Before they committed to insuring the £19 million striker, they had to be as certain as possible that their money was safe. They weren't, and they were right. But insuring players against injury is just the most obvious type of football insurance. Many clubs take out life insurance in case disaster strikes one of their top players - Ronaldo is insured with a British firm for something approaching £30m. Then there is insurance against failure, a growth area just being investigated by major clubs. Spanish flops Atletico Madrid are rumoured to have taken out such protection against relegation, and Chelsea have considered insuring themselves in case they miss out on the Champions League next year. They are also considering protecting themselves against winning, so that bonuses are paid for if they do win trophies. A lot of sponsors who provide incentives do the same.

Then there are specialists in cancellation and abandonment, who insure organisers of events - from concerts to the Olympics - against cancellation costs. They also insure the event's sponsors and broadcasters against loss of revenue should the event be cancelled.

In short, your nearest professional football club, be they big or small, pay out an enormous amount in premiums. But the whole business is set to turn full circle with football clubs starting to offer their own insurance. According to a recent report from the market research firm Datamonitor, such services will grow by 40 per cent over the next year.
