fields.headline: Day of joy and despair
fields.standfirst: Manchester United keep it in the family but for many it's knife-edge drama
fields.trailText: Sir Alex Ferguson lifted the Premiership trophy into a cloudless blue sky and the party began to celebrate six titles in eight years - but away from Old Trafford the nerves were fraying all over England.
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson lifted the Premiership trophy into a cloudless blue sky and the party began to celebrate six titles in eight years - but away from Old Trafford the nerves were fraying all over England.

A 3-1 victory over Spurs - taking United's goal tally to 96 - was saluted by a 61,000 crowd. Fireworks, tickertape and fountains of champagne were in the air.

Forget that this was their 10th successive league win and that they were the first team to win the Premiership in April, with four games remaining and with a record points total.

Today was special and Ferguson, with grandson Jake in one arm and the Premiership trophy in the other, grabbed a microphone to tell the Old Trafford faithful: 'It's not easy winning this league and this day is special to this club. I want you to remember that.'

It was a family day with many of the players being joined by wives and children - not least David Beckham, who celebrated with wife Victoria and toddler Brooklyn.

It was in stark contrast to the bottom, where all three relegation-threatened sides went into the closing moments facing defeat. Only Wimbledon escaped - drawing 2-2 at home to Aston Villa thanks to John Hartson's last-gasp goal.

Defeat for Bradford at Leicester and Sheffield Wednesday at Coventry make them favourites to join Watford for the drop.

With the First Division facing a Sunday shoot-out, the drama continued in the lower leagues, with Burnley celebrating automatic promotion to the First Division after coming from behind to beat Scunthorpe 2-1 while Gillingham, second at the start yesterday, went down 1-0 at Wrexham and must face the play-offs again.

Millwall won 1-0 at home to Oxford to leapfrog Bristol Rovers and claim a play-off place.

In the third, Swansea took the title with a 1-1 draw at second-placed Rotherham, and Northampton took the last automatic promotion spot by winning at Torquay. The play-offs will be contested by Darlington, Peterborough, Barnet and Hartlepool.

The battle to stay in the league was compelling, with Carlisle again escaping, with Shrewsbury, to condemn Chester City to relegation to the Conference. Chester, second bottom at the start, lost 1-0 at home to Peterborough while Shrewsbury - who had to win at Exeter to have a chance to survive - did just that with a 2-1 victory.

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: Beeb charts England downfall
fields.body:
Beeb charts England downfall

Where did it all go wrong for English football after 1966? The subject of endless bar-room debates is finally being made into a major television documentary series by the BBC. Three Lions , billed as the definitive history of England since that famous afternoon at Wembley, is the result of two years filming and scores of interviews with players, managers, fans and even some of the hooligans who have made English football synonymous with trouble. The three-parter will go out on consecutive nights in early June in the run-up to Euro 2000. Each 50-minute programme will cover a particular phase in England's decline and fall since the events that prompted Kenneth Wolstenholme to declare: 'They think it's all over - it is now!' The 1966-74 phase is examined by concentrating on the late, great Bobby Moore; 1974-86 by focusing on Kevin Keegan; and 1986-2000 by probing the life and times of Paul Gascoigne, probably the ultimate one-man embodiment of a nation's footballing frailties. The BBC claims that the series 'will strip the mystery away from our national heroes, our national villains and our national game'. Exclusive material is promised, and the interview with Keegan is apparently a belter. It will also feature Tina Moore's first interview about her husband's cancer and a peek at her collection of private memorabilia covering his illustrious career. Perhaps the reminder of more glorious days will inspire Adams, Shearer & Co over in Holland and Belgium.

Green and Gray: the feud continues

Prepare for more hostilities between Alan Green and Andy Gray. Remember the Sky TV pundit recently riled the uncompromising Radio 5 Live match commentator by questioning his right to criticise the Bolton-Villa FA Cup semi-final on the dubious grounds that he had never played football at such a high level? Now the excitable Ulsterman has hit back by accusing the equally excitable Scot of 'ignorance and arrogance'. Green uses the launch of a new football website involving himself and Mirror super-sleuth Harry Harris to say: 'Even if he is right [that the dour Wembley game was worth watching], then he is discriminating against 99.5 per cent of his own viewing public who have never played at his level. What is he saying? Barry Norman is our foremost film critic but he did not direct Gone With The Wind .' Direct, opinionated stuff. Expect more of the same at www.voiceoffootball.com , which launches tomorrow.

Gay footballers play numbers game

Where can a team of gay footballers get a regular game without encountering abuse, ridicule and homophobia? The new issue of the FA's excellent FC magazine relates how Village FC, an all-gay side from Manchester's Gay Village area, resolved that dilemma by joining the Manchester Accountants League. 'We would have faced hostility in many local leagues and I wasn't prepared to put the players through that,' explains founder Graham Goggins. 'We've been welcomed very warmly by the league and by the vast majority of the teams and players we face.' Given that accountants are the butt of almost as many jokes as gays, and are viewed in some quarters with at least as much suspicion, it seems a highly appropriate link-up.

French honour their heroes

One of the more intriguing books amid the deluge of soccer literature is Le Foot: the legends of French football , which is launched tomorrow at the official residence in London of the French ambassador to Britain. Chris Waddle will be there, along with Arsène Wenger, Marcel Desailly and Frank Leboeuf and some of Arsenal's French contingent. The book's contributors include Salman Rushdie on David Ginola, David Baddiel (on Harald Schumacher's outrageous 'tackle' on Patrick Battiston at the 1982 World Cup), Irvine Welsh (a very affectionate introduction) and several Observer writers. It covers both the obvious - Platini, Cantona, success on home soil in 1998 - and, less predictably, Franck Sauzee, almost unknown in England but a legend at his current place of work, Easter Road in Edinburgh.

fields.headline: So where is the Mafia?
fields.standfirst: Howard Marks travels to Sicily in search of one of the country's most pervasive and elusive cultural influences: the Mob
fields.trailText: Does any urban holidaymaker really want to fry in a freak Athenian heat wave, fall from a Madrid high-rise, be shot by a London road rager, or get mugged at the carnival in Rio?
fields.body:
Does any urban holidaymaker really want to fry in a freak Athenian heat wave, fall from a Madrid high-rise, be shot by a London road rager, or get mugged at the carnival in Rio?

Play safe and stay in the metropolis that houses Europe's third largest opera house, whose centre consists of lush, expansive botanical gardens and in which the greatest civilisations have stayed for centuries, bequeathing their cultural and culinary legacies. Visit the city where the young gather during the day, hungry and enthusiastic to participate in contemporary art, avant garde theatre and cultural debate; where the elderly throng the streets all night; and which has had no murder for at least 14 months. Stroll unhindered through illuminated avenues where elegant baroque churches, Norman monuments, Spanish palaces, Arabic cupolas, and Renaissance churches are comfortably juxtaposed. Get sidetracked by Byzantine street markets clogging creakingly medieval warrens. Take a tip from Guy de Maupassant: 'If you search for knife wounds or for arrests, then go to Paris or London, but don't come here, where you can travel throughout night and day, without escort or arms; you will find only extreme benevolence towards foreigners.'

The city is Palermo, in Sicily. Grabbed first by the Carthaginians, it later fell to the Romans, then the Saracens, and later to the Normans, under whom it flowered as Europe's greatest metropolis, famed for its wealthy court, its centre of learning and its slightly devilish reputation. Palermo's cultural and commercial importance was maintained for several centuries under Spanish domination until Garibaldi decided to use it as a starting point for his successful unification of Italy during the latter half of the nineteenth century. At the beginning of the twentieth century, Palermo elected modernism (Art Nouveau) to express the wealth and prestige of a thriving entrepreneurial class that built theatres rather than churches. Nowhere was this better manifested than by the grand hall of the hotel in which I was registering for my first Sicilian night, the Villa Igiea, a classic Art Nouveau villa designed by Ernesto Basile in 1900 and which originally belonged to relatives of the Florios, Palermo's most important industrial family and the first people to put tuna into cans.

Woken the next morning by a strong wind, I felt confused and puzzled. Palermo? Wasn't it meant to provide a heavy, dangerous and life-threatening ambience? Wasn't it the place that all the American gangsters I met in prison regarded as their holy of holies? Wasn't it the headquarters of the world's greatest-ever criminal organisation, the Mafia? Where are they?

Although there is an alternative theory (Mafia is derived from the Arabic mu'afah, meaning 'refuge or protection'), it is widely thought that Mafia is the acronym of Morte Ai Francesi Italiani Allarme, (Death to all the Waiting Frenchmen threatened by the Italians) the battle cry of the Sicilian Vespers, a fierce thirteenth-century separatist movement, which opposed the injustice of perpetual foreign rule and pursued an egalitarian ideal. And that's the way it stayed for almost all of the second millennium, as French rule gave way to Spanish and Austrian despots. Even Garibaldi's unification fell far short of Sicilian expectations: the island was still ruled by remote and uncaring bureaucrats, only now from Rome rather than any other European capital. By this time, the Mafia, with its ubiquitous anti-imperialist tentacles, had become the people's champion.

But even in an autonomous country which is politically at rest, organised crime can be equally well spawned by the government enacting a few irrational and unjust laws and regulations. During the early years of the twentieth century, the United States government informed hundreds of thousands of its newly welcomed Italian immigrants that they could no longer pursue their traditional practices of drinking wine and buying lottery tickets. Prohibition and the elimination of the so-called numbers rackets were the orders of the day.

The Mafia saw another opportunity to represent the populace. Legal and illegal economies intertwined, as did criminal organisations and social institutions. Drugs and money laundering might well be the best known aspects of today's criminal activities, but the most devastating is the connection between politics and crime. This mixture of illegal and legal, criminal and institutional, is actually the heart of the Mafia's historical model.

In post-unification Sicily, violence and illegality have generally been regarded as non-punishable forms of survival and acceptable ways of acquiring a social role; the legal economy is too weak to offer substantial opportunities. The state and the institutions are seen as distant and foreign, and approachable only through the mediation of the Mafiosi and their friends. For the Mafia, rights don't exist; there are only favours. But where are they?

I didn't feel I had enough time to search for the Mob. After all, I had a travel piece to write and had to set about reaching the Aeolian Islands. A full Italian buffet breakfast should have helped hasten my resolve, but the waiters discomfited me by staring at my unmanicured nails, dishevelled hair, and clothes adorned with unknown designer labels. One, who seemed to take pity on me, looked at my guide book, and said: 'You will not get to the islands today, signore. The sirocco is blowing too strong. But there is much to see here.'

I'm a sucker for regular sightseeing tours, so I took one. I ogled unashamedly at the beauties sporting the latest Milanese and Florentian fashions, dodged the Vespas and the baby buggies, bought some cigarettes at an exquisite tobacco kiosk and popped inside the cathedral to view St Agatha's arm and Mary Magdalen's foot.

I was ready for Palermo's most gruesome attraction: its catacombs. Il Convento dei Cappuccini, on the edge of the city, houses almost 10,000 bodies preserved by chemical and dehydration processes, including the use of vinegar, arsenic and quick lime. The corpses are displayed either wearing their normal clothes in niches along labyrinthine corridors, or stacked in glass coffins. Most are vile, contorted, grinning, decomposed; others, with full heads of hair, stare right at you.

'Here the people of Palermo pay daily visits to their deceased friend - familiarise themselves with their future state - choose the company they would wish to keep in the other world - make choice of their niche - try if their body fits it - stand for hours,' wrote Patrick Brydone in his eighteenth-century account of A Tour through Sicily and Malta.

Surprisingly, the walk through the catacombs made me feel like lunch. I obviously had to eat at the Grande Albergo e delle Palme, where Richard Wagner composed Parsifal in 1882, and where Mafia leaders met in October 1957 to organise the world's drug trade.

A bottle of Brunello di Montalcino made me think again of the Mob. While the US alcohol industry and casinos became safely and legally controlled by Italians, things were getting a bit rough back home in Sicily. Mussolini had come to power and dispatched Cesare Mori to eradicate the Mafia. Mori unjustly jailed thousands for trivial offences, driving the Mafia deeper underground. Popular discontent continued to be manifested by brigandage and its accompanying omerta, or conspiracy of silence, deeply rooted not just in its romantic banditry but also in its more sinister network of mutual interests and politically binding organised criminality.

The moral stature of the outlaw increased to Robin Hood proportions as nobility and misery chased each other. The United States seemed a far more acceptable fatherland than Italy, so much so that the Mafia enabled General George Patton's US invasion of Italy in 1943. Sicilians had obviously expected some sort of appropriate reward for their unconventional wartime services, such as annexation to the US, membership of the British Empire, or at least independence. Instead, anarchy, hunger and a problematic, Stormont-type regional assembly followed the Second World War. Much of Palermo's port and medieval town had been bombed into a ramshackle building site and the sea had been pushed back 200 yards from a once-magnificent promenade. Rubble from wartime was dumped there and the newly created area was left as a squalid, weed infested, no man's land.

Encouraged by the US dollar, Communism was perceived to be the enemy and banditry was once again unleashed as separatism. Political patronage grew; Mafia-infested building projects littered the island with half-finished housing estates and office blocks. But where are they? Why aren't there tourist trips to known Mafia haunts of the past? Could today's drug-dealing Mafia be just the creation of pulp thriller writers, the imaginations of a sensationalist press, a fabrication of Italian and US governments anxious for scapegoats? Didn't Mario Puzo make it all up when he wrote The Godfather ? Puzo claims that his choice of the surname Corleone for his Godfather was random. It could just as well have been Montelpre, Lerca Freddi or Partinico. But when the boss of them all, il capo dei tutti capi, Salvatore Riina, was arrested in 1993, it was revealed that he had lived undisturbed for 20 years (with his children registered at the local school and hospital) in the small town of Corleone. Aren't coincidences amazing? Yeah, right.

I took a taxi to Corleone. There is absolutely nothing there that looks as though it could begin to be associated with any criminal organisation, or a Hollywood movie. I concluded that either all the Mafiosi were in Palermo's Ucciardone prison or that the Mafia is as invisible as it is ineradicable.

Next morning, boats between the Sicilian islands had resumed operations, but I decided to take the train along the Tyrrhenian Coast and get a boat from Milazzo to the Aeolian Islands. During the holiday season, there are other means of making the trip, such as a direct ferry from Palermo, but this way is hard to beat. For quite long stretches, the track is only a few yards from the water's edge.

I opened the carriage window and allowed my face to be bathed with friendly splashes of spray. This part of the coast is dedicated to holidaying with its series of cliffs, coves, sandy strips, stony strips, citrus groves, mighty medieval cathedrals, hilltop strongholds, Norman castles, Greco-Roman archaeological remains and oil refineries that look strangely at home. Roman villas crouch timidly under viaducts linking thermal spas with water good for both curing arthritis and making pasta. Despite the train's relaxed progress, the terrain was quickly and noticeably changing from the rough and rugged Arabic West coast to the green and fertile East. At the stations, you could detect the singsong Palermo accent giving way to a more clipped Siracusian, evidencing the centuries in antiquity that Sicily remained a divided island. When the Carthaginians settled in western Sicily in the eighth century BC, the Greeks simultaneously established a colony in the east and swiftly exploited the island's fertility (Demeter, Greek goddess of grain and fecundity, was Sicily's chief deity) and introduced the olive and the vine, heralding Sicily's role as Rome's granary (The Roman statesman Cato called it 'the nurse at whose breast the Roman people are fed'.) Siracusa became a prominent centre of early Christianity and was briefly the capital of the Byzantine Empire.

Three hours after leaving Palermo, I disembarked at Milazzo and was relieved to note that hydrofoils were opertating. The Aeolian Islands are sleepy, seductive and timelessly tranquil. Although frequent storms reinforce the feeling of isolation, an enveloping calm masks this volcanically active seven-island archipelago that abounds with myths associated with elemental and unpredictable power.

Volcanoes used to be seen as the mouths of hell. Jupiter's son Vulcan, the god of fire and metalworking, had his workshop there. Aeolus, the god of winds and navigation, kept his winds in one of the caves. He presented them in a wineskin to Odysseus (whose curious crew let them out, causing the ship to be blown back to port). More recently, Professor Lindbrook and his colleagues emerged there in Jules Verne's Journey to the Centre of the Earth .

An hour after leaving Milazzo, the hydrofoil stopped at Vulcano, which boasts mud baths, hot springs and a smoking crater. An extremely strong and unappetising, sulphurous rotten-egg smell permeates the atmosphere. Acrid and yellow plumes of vapour menacingly puff away, serving as constant reminders of the silent power beneath. Orange and red flashes indicate the underlying pyrotechnic progress. No one lived here before the eighteenth century, and there have been several hasty evacuations since.

Saffron-coloured earth and the intense reds and oranges of the iron and aluminium sulphates sear the eyes. Visitors and residents bathe in thick yellow soup pools of foul - smelling sulphurous mud, as if attending some deviant ancient ceremony.

I took the hydrofoil to Lipari, the most interesting of the islands. A Carthaginian base during the First Punic War with Rome, Lipari was the scene of a terrible slaughter in 1544 at the hands of the famous North African pirate, Red Beard (Barbarossa or Khair ed-Din), who consigned to slavery all 10,000 survivors of the massacre. Lipari's main commercial attraction (until the rest of the world invented steel) was its rare sharp black glass (excellent for weapon making) erupted by the now extinct Monte Pelato.

I walked through alleyways of chic boutiques and souvenir emporiums interspersed with alimentari (capers, olives, and malvasia grapes) and fishing tackle shops and checked into the Hotel Villa Meligunis, an eighteenth-century villa. I have never been looked after with such a perfect combination of dignified reserve and exuberant hospitality.

As evening approached, I took a walk up to Il Castello, a medieval castle where Odysseus lingered after his historical battle with Cyclops. Today, it is the site of one of the world's finest archaeological museums, Museo Eoliano, best known for housing the oldest and most complete range of Greek theatrical masks used in early performances of the tragedies of Sophocles and Euripides and the comedies of Aristophanes and Melander. Inside, you are immediately surrounded by 6,000 years of evidence that the Greeks once definitely knew how to large it and have a good time.

Lipari's income is based on tourism and a revitalised pumice industry. Pumice (red volcanic glass) is used for the manufacture of toothpaste, light bulbs, bleach, and fertiliser. Its extraction by quivering Heath Robinson/Meccano-style machinery a few minutes drive from Lipari kept me childishly fascinated for hours. Although the process leaves brilliant white scars in the lush Aeolian countryside, they blend in perfectly with massive rocks that have been striped by nature with red, orange and yellow hues. These colours flow into the ocean alongside 30-yard-long pumice chutes used by workers as the most effective way of getting their bodies into the sea to cool off. All work should be this much fun.

Lipari is ideal for leisurely natural history and archaeological excursions. Huge spiky multi-coloured rocks, or faraglione, protrude from a limpid and uncontaminated sea, watched by rare migratory birds nesting on cliffs. Excavations of superimposed layers of occupation from Neolithic to Roman times provide a continuous record.

The vices of mankind no longer seem to threaten anyone in Lipari. Cars and houses are left unlocked; police are absent or invisible; no one is looking for a fight. I went to bed praying for a storm so I could be stranded here indefinitely.

Howard Marks's travel between London and Palermo together with accommodation at the five-star Grand Villa Igiea, Palermo, was arranged by Magic of Italy (0208 748 7575; www.magictravelgroup.co.uk) which offers both three- and seven-night packages, starting at £449 and £689 respectively.

Accommodation at the Hotel Villa Meligunis and travel in the Aeolian Islands was arranged by Ossidiana Travel, Via Ten, Amendola, 22, Lipari 98055 (tel: 00 39 090 981 1519).

Although frequent storms reinforce the feeling of isolation, an enveloping calm masks this volcanically active seven-island archipelago that abounds with myths associated with elemental and unpredictable power. Volcanoes used to be seen as the mouths of hell. Jupiter's son Vulcan, the god of fire and metalworking, had his workshop there. Aeolus, the god of winds and navigation, kept his winds in one of the caves. He presented them in a wineskin to Odysseus (whose curious crew let them out, causing the ship to be blown back to port). More recently, Professor Lindbrook and his colleagues emerged there in Jules Verne's Journey to the Centre of the Earth . An hour after leaving Milazzo, the hydrofoil stopped at Vulcano, which boasts mud baths, hot springs and a smoking crater. An extremely strong and unappetising, sulphurous rotten-egg smell permeates the atmosphere. Acrid and yellow plumes of vapour menacingly puff away, serving as constant reminders of the silent power beneath. Orange and red flashes indicate the underlying pyrotechnic progress. No one lived here before the eighteenth century, and there have been several hasty evacuations since. Saffron-coloured earth and the intense reds and oranges of the iron and aluminium sulphates sear the eyes. Visitors and residents bathe in thick yellow soup pools of foul - smelling sulphurous mud, as if attending some deviant ancient ceremony. I took the hydrofoil to Lipari, the most interesting of the islands. A Carthaginian base during the First Punic War with Rome, Lipari was the scene of a terrible slaughter in 1544 at the hands of the famous North African pirate, Red Beard (Barbarossa or Khair ed-Din), who consigned to slavery all 10,000 survivors of the massacre. Lipari's main commercial attraction (until the rest of the world invented steel) was its rare sharp black glass (excellent for weapon making) erupted by the now extinct Monte Pelato. I walked through alleyways of chic boutiques and souvenir emporiums interspersed with alimentari (capers, olives, and malvasia grapes) and fishing tackle shops and checked into the Hotel Villa Meligunis, an eighteenth-century villa. I have never been looked after with such a perfect combination of dignified reserve and exuberant hospitality. As evening approached, I took a walk up to Il Castello, a medieval castle where Odysseus lingered after his historical battle with Cyclops. Today, it is the site of one of the world's finest archaeological museums, Museo Eoliano, best known for housing the oldest and most complete range of Greek theatrical masks used in early performances of the tragedies of Sophocles and Euripides and the comedies of Aristophanes and Melander. Inside, you are immediately surrounded by 6,000 years of evidence that the Greeks once definitely knew how to large it and have a good time. Lipari's income is based on tourism and a revitalised pumice industry. Pumice (red volcanic glass) is used for the manufacture of toothpaste, light bulbs, bleach, and fertiliser. Its extraction by quivering Heath Robinson/Meccano-style machinery a few minutes drive from Lipari kept me childishly fascinated for hours. Although the process leaves brilliant white scars in the lush Aeolian countryside, they blend in perfectly with massive rocks that have been striped by nature with red, orange and yellow hues. These colours flow into the ocean alongside 30-yard-long pumice chutes used by workers as the most effective way of getting their bodies into the sea to cool off. All work should be this much fun. Lipari is ideal for leisurely natural history and archaeological excursions. Huge spiky multi-coloured rocks, or faraglione, protrude from a limpid and uncontaminated sea, watched by rare migratory birds nesting on cliffs. Excavations of superimposed layers of occupation from Neolithic to Roman times provide a continuous record. The vices of mankind no longer seem to threaten anyone in Lipari. Cars and houses are left unlocked; police are absent or invisible; no one is looking for a fight. I went to bed praying for a storm so I could be stranded here indefinitely. Howard Marks's travel between London and Palermo together with accommodation at the five-star Grand Villa Igiea, Palermo, was arranged by Magic of Italy (0208 748 7575; www.magictravelgroup.co.uk) which offers both three- and seven-night packages, starting at £449 and £689 respectively. Accommodation at the Hotel Villa Meligunis and travel in the Aeolian Islands was arranged by Ossidiana Travel, Via Ten, Amendola, 22, Lipari 98055 (tel: 00 39 090 981 1519).

fields.headline: Hit the Strada del Vino
fields.standfirst: The Italians produce more wine than the French. John Brunton  uncorks the best and offers a tasting
fields.trailText: Wherever you're driving in Italy, it is only a matter of time until you pass one of those tempting signs marked Strada del Vino, pointing to a narrow road that disappears mysteriously among a gentle maze of criss-cross lines of well-tended vines.
fields.body:
Wherever you're driving in Italy, it is only a matter of time until you pass one of those tempting signs marked Strada del Vino, pointing to a narrow road that disappears mysteriously among a gentle maze of criss-cross lines of well-tended vines.

It is a reminder that although stopping off at wine producers in France has become an integral part of summer holidays, it is not the first thing that comes to mind when visiting Italy. There's so much cultural sightseeing here that after a day's dose of churches, castles, frescoes and paintings, museums and monuments, you tend to think about tasting the local vino only at dinner. Yet Italy produces more wine than France and is now increasing its quality by leaps and bounds.

There's always a huge difference between sampling wines among the vineyards where they're grown and at home, though many of the best Italian bottles never make it to Britain anyway. It is quite easy to plan a trip across a couple of the country's diverse regions, tasting not just the wine, but local cuisine and seeing some of the less-visited sights.

Italy became one country only as recently as 1861, so the wines are markedly different in each province, the customs and history differ, and the strange-sounding traditional dialects often mask a completely different language.

Rather than arm yourself with just a classic guidebook, it is worth investing in the English translation of Italy's leading annual wine handbook, Italian Wines, published jointly by Gambero Rosso Editore and Slow Food Editore, at £25.95. As for eating out, Italy is unbeatable for its simple, inexpensive osterie and trattorie, the ideal spot to feast on a plate of steaming pasta accompanied by a bottle of the local vino rosso or bianco.

1 Valpolicella

The region: Veneto, which stretches from the scenic Lake Garda across to the towering Dolomite mountains and down to the Adriatic sea, is one of the most seductive regions of Italy, and that is before you even set foot in the romantic cities of Verona and Venice. Apart from the picturesque vineyards, the landscapes are marked by elegant Palladian villas, walled medieval villages and grand Renaissance churches.

The wine: Much maligned over the years as cheap Italian plonk, the humble Valpolicella has a much more respected reputation at home. You'll discover that the superiore is markedly better than the less expensive classico. But the fun begins when tasting the local specialities. Amarone is a deliciously rich, aged Valpolicella, but it is exceptionally strong. Then there is Ricioto, a luscious, sweet red dessert wine.

The address: La Bottega del Vino, Via Scudo di Francia 3, Verona. Tel: (0039) 045 8004535. It is closed on Tuesdays.

Each April, Verona hosts Vinitaly, the nation's major wine fair, but right in the heart of Romeo and Juliet's city, great wines can be tasted every day at this cosy, wood-panelled wine bar. There's a fine restaurant at the back, but the real action is by the bar where the list of wines by the glass changes each day.

2 Marsala

The region: Sicily is the largest island in the Mediterranean, and resembles a tiny independent country outside Italy's borders and almost outside Europe. Invading Greeks, Spaniards, Arabs and Normans all left temples, palaces and churches across the island's ruggedly beautiful landscapes, while even our own Admiral Nelson built a private castle at the foot of Mount Etna as a love nest for Lady Hamilton.

The wine: Drunk as an aperitif or to accompany a sharp-tasting cheese, Marsala was developed for the British market at the end of the eighteenth century. This rich, heady wine takes its name from the port of Marsala, but the most scenic place to visit vineyards is around Agrigento, which has one of the finest Greek temples outside Athens.

The address: Hosteria dei Vesperi, Piazza Croce dei Vesperi 6, Palermo, Sicily. Tel: 0039 091 6171631. Closed Sundays.

Smack in the historic centre of the pulsating city of Palermo, this osteria specialises in both Sicilian wines and traditional cuisine. Some of the greatest new wines in Italy are being made in Sicily now, especially Chardonnay and Nero d'Avola, a Syrah-like grape. Try them accompanied by a classic pasta con sarde, or spaghetti with fresh sardines, pine nuts and wild fennel.

3 Barolo

The region: Piedmont is not simply next to France geographically but culturally too. Driving through the vine-covered hills of the Langhe and the truffle-filled forests around Alba has a feel similar to exploring Burgundy. Don't neglect to visit the region's dynamic capital, Turin, which will host the next Winter Olympics, and is refreshingly untouristy.

The wine: Barolo can quite simply be called the king of Italian red wines, an outstanding full-bodied wine that, like a Bordeaux, needs to age for several years for it to lose its hard tannic taste. Unfortunately, it is also seriously expensive, especially if you decide to taste some of the more renowned producers such as Gaja, Pio Cesare and the grandly-named Marchesi di Barolo.

The address: Boccondivino, Via Mendicita Istruita 14, Bra, Piedmont. Tel: 0039 0172 425674. Closed Sunday

Bra is home to the renowned Italian wine and food movement, Slow Food, so it's no surprise that the town's local enoteca stocks over 150 different types of Barolo in its cellar. Don't neglect some of the other excellent Piedmont vintages such as Barbaresco, Barbera and Dolcetto. They are perfect with a traditional bagna cauda, a delicious vegetable fondue based on anchovies and garlic.

4 Frascati

The region: Latium, the ancient area known in Italy as Lazio, is dominated by the national capital, Rome, and few tourists explore further than the Eternal City.

Apart from interesting Etruscan remains around Tarquinia and Cerveteri, there is one of Italy's best-hidden secrets waiting to be discovered, the idyllic island of Ponza.

The wine: Sit down at any restaurant in Rome and you can be sure that the vino di tavola will be a carafe of fresh, light Frascati. Grown in pretty vineyards less than 20 miles south of the capital, this is by no means the greatest white wine in Italy. But on a hot summer's day, sitting out on a sunny terrace, enjoying a bottle of one of the superiore vintages, especially from the cantina of Count Zandotti, can be unforgettable.

The address: Ristorante del Pallaro, Largo del Pallaro 15, Rome, Lazio. Tel: 0039 06 68801488. Closed Sundays.

A delightful dose of La Dolce Vita is guaranteed at this friendly old-fashioned trattoria, just by Rome's famed Piazza Navona. There there is no menu, just a steady stream of dishes prepared by La Mamma in the kitchen, from antipasti right through to dessert, with a chilled bottle of Frascati in the middle of the table.

5 Orvieto

The region: Umbria is a close rival to its neighbour, Tuscany, for dramatic country landscapes and perfectly preserved medieval and Renaissance towns. The crowds may flock to the renowned sights of Giotto's frescoes at Assisi and the cavernous Gothic cathedral in Orvieto, but you'll find the rest of the region much more peaceful, especially around Lake Trasemino, which is great for fishing and swimming.

It is worth noting two major festivals, for arts, music and film in July and August at Spoleto, and an irresistible chocolate festival in Perugia in October.

The wine: Although Umbria is trying to follow Tuscany's lead in producing a new range of superior red wines, the internationally popular white Orvieto still accounts for 80 per cent of all the wine produced here, and there are some very different levels of quality. The Etruscans began making wine in Umbria more than 2,000 years ago, and over the centuries Orvieto has been transformed from a light, sweet wine into today's dry, straw-coloured variety.

The address: I Sette Consoli, Piazza Sant'Angelo 1, Orvieto, Umbria. Tel: 0039 0763 343911. Closed Wednesdays.

With coachloads of tourists flocking to the town of Orvieto, there are plenty of rip-off places selling poor-quality, expensive local wine. The Seven Consuls, though, is a serious gastronomic restaurant with an equally serious wine list to sample some of the better Orvieto producers.

6 Chianti

The region: Tuscany is most people's dream destination in Italy, but images of opulent villas and wealthy expats sitting by the pool in 'Chiantishire' are a long way from the real picture. Outside the great cities of Florence, Pisa and Sienna, Tuscany is essentially a very rural community, and behind the serene lines of cypress trees atop rolling hills it doesn't take long to find quiet villages and friendly agroturismo guest houses unspoilt by tourism.

The wine: Enthusiasts will tell you that Tuscany's most respected wines today are Brunello di Montalcino and Vino Nobile di Montepulciano, but it is Chianti that is known throughout the world. Claiming to be the world's oldest officially defined wine-producing area, dating from a 1716 decree, the unique taste of Chianti was developed by Baron Bettino Ricasoli in the early nineteenth century, and it is still worth visiting his castle and vineyards in Brolio.

But be warned. Tasting Chiantis can be a minefield. Come upon a Castello di Ama or Cacchiano and you'll discover some of the most wonderful wines to come from grapes anywhere, but unfortunately there are some very poor producers too.

The address: C'Era Una Volta, Via Certaldese 11, Lucardo village, Montespertoli, Tuscany. Tel: 0039 0571 669162. Closed Tuesdays.

Only half an hour's drive from Florence, the tiny hilltop hamlet of Lucardo is surrounded by vineyards. The one shop, C'Era Una Volta, doubles as a grocery and cafi, as well as drawing gourmets to its restaurant. A great choice of reasonably priced Chiantis complements typical Tuscan dishes such as pappardelle pasta served with wild boar and a heaped plate of fritto - deep-fried chicken, lamb and vegetables.

7 Gewurtztraminer

The region: Meet an Italian in the mountains of Alto Adige and he'll greet you with gruss gott instead of salute. Noble medieval towns such as Bolzano and Bressanone are known more by their Germanic names of Bolzen and Brixen, and the locals prefer roast pork and sauerkraut to pasta. Welcome to the Italian Tyrol, a semi-autonomous region of splendid Alpine scenery, fairytale castles and onion-domed churches.

The wine: Precariously fastened along steep mountain sides, the vineyards are some of the most beautiful in Italy, and produce wines of the highest quality. Gewurtztraminer is a name more commonly associated with a fruity, aromatic wine from Alsace, but the climatic and soil conditions here produce a much dryer version. Visit the picturesque village of Margreid, and you'll discover the cantina of the region's greatest winemaker, Alois Lageder.

The address: Hilber Keller, Caines village, Merano, Alto Adige. Tel: 0039 0473 241017. Closed Wednesdays and from December to February.

High up in a spectacular glacial valley, this centuries-old wine cellar is hewn into the mountainside and in summer it has a huge, sunny terrace with a panoramic view over the vineyards. The jovial innkeeper serves carafes of local wine, and in autumn there is the turggelen season of roasted chesnuts and speck , or savoury smoked ham.

8 Franciacorta

The region: Lombardy is the region of the great lakes for tourists, despite having at its heart Milan, the commercial and fashion capital of Italy. It stretches from the shores of Lake Maggiore, Como, Iseo and Garda. And for a break from boating and bathing, just jump in the car and head for the fabled Renaissance city of Mantova, delightfully quiet and off the normal tourist track.

The wine: Lombardy has lagged behind much of Italy in upgrading the quality of its wine, with the notable exception of Franciacorta, which you'll find in both a white, Pinot Bianco version, and red, predominantly Cabernet Franc. Even more surprising is Franciacorta Gran Cuvie Brut of the excellent Ca' del Bosco cantina, in Erbusco, which is an outstanding sparkling wine to rival any champagne.

The address: Osteria dell'Orologio, Via Butturini 26, Salr, Lombardy. Tel: 0039 0365 290158. Closed Wednesdays.

With a wine bar on the ground floor and a restaurant upstairs, you can choose to just taste a wide selection of Franciacorta wines, or to feast off the excellent freshwater fish caught in Lake Garda - including carp, pike and perch. The resorts alongside the lake are known as the Garda Riviera, and Salr itself is famous as the site of the dictator Benito Mussolini's short-lived last Republic before his final capture as Italy and Germany were defeated in the Second World War.

9 Lambrusco

The region: Emilia-Romagna lies unknown to most tourists who flock instead to Tuscany and Umbria, but it is just as attractive in its own way. Bologna and Parma are not just interesting as classic sightseeing destinations, they're actually fun university towns, with great restaurants and bars. Ravenna, for its mosaics, and the grand palaces of Ferrara, are both worth a detour, while behind travel brochure images of modern hotels lining the seafront, Rimini and the whole Adriatic coast boast some of Europe's wildest summer nightclubs.

The wine: Love it or hate it, the sparkling red Lambrusco is so different from other wines that it leaves no one unmoved. What is sure, though, is that here in the region it is grown, this is the perfect wine to accompany the characteristic cuisine of what is Italy's gastronomic heartland. Although some wine makers produce a sweeter, amabile Lambrusco, it is better to stick to the dry variation.

The address: Trattoria Il Lurido, Piazzetta Ortaggi 7, Rimini, Emilia Romagna. Tel: 0039 0541 24834. Closed Tues.

Foodies are spoilt for choice in Emilia-Romagna, with Parma famous for its ham, Bologna for mortadella, parmesan cheese from Reggio, and Modena's renowned basalmic vinegar. Best of all, though, is the fresh pasta - tagliatelle and tortelloni - and there's no better place to sample that than in Fellini's favourite restaurant in his home town of Rimini. They don't have the best wine list in the world, but you'll taste a fine chilled bottle of Lambrusco.

10 Tokai Friulano

The region: Friuli makes up Italy's wild and rugged border with Eastern and Central Europe. Not many foreign travellers make it out this far, even though the elegant Venice is close. It is their loss, because historic towns such as Udine and Cividale, the dreamy lagoon at Grado, and the lush valleys and towering mountains of the Carnia lie totally unspoilt, waiting to be discovered.

The wine: To really discover the cutting edge of great Italian wines, it is well worth the trek to Friuli. The whites are stupendous - Chardonnay, Sauvignon, Malvasia - and in red wine, both the Cabernet and Merlot can be excellent. But the Friulani are most proud of their Tokai, and the dialect word for a glass of wine, tajut, always refers to a Tokai.

Banish all thoughts of the sickly sweet Hungarian Tokay. The Friuli version is a delicate dry white wine, which becomes great in the hands of master vintners such as Livio Felluga and Sandro Princic, both in the Collio vineyards.

The address: Enoteca di Cormons, Piazza XXIV, Maggio 21, Cormons, Friuli. Tel: 0039 0481 630371. Closed Tuesdays.

The village of Cormons is the unofficial wine capital of Friuli, and there is plenty of choice to have a lunchtime break between visiting different vineyards.

There are several rather smart restaurants, which are much favoured by wine makers entertaining customers, but the most sensible spot to head for is the town's official enoteca, where there is a vast selection of all the great wines of the surrounding Collio hills, which can be accompanied by bar snacks such as the local prosciutto crudo, salami and cheeses.

And for a break from boating and bathing, just jump in the car and head for the fabled Renaissance city of Mantova, delightfully quiet and off the normal tourist track. The wine: Lombardy has lagged behind much of Italy in upgrading the quality of its wine, with the notable exception of Franciacorta, which you'll find in both a white, Pinot Bianco version, and red, predominantly Cabernet Franc. Even more surprising is Franciacorta Gran Cuvie Brut of the excellent Ca' del Bosco cantina, in Erbusco, which is an outstanding sparkling wine to rival any champagne. The address: Osteria dell'Orologio, Via Butturini 26, Salr, Lombardy. Tel: 0039 0365 290158. Closed Wednesdays. With a wine bar on the ground floor and a restaurant upstairs, you can choose to just taste a wide selection of Franciacorta wines, or to feast off the excellent freshwater fish caught in Lake Garda - including carp, pike and perch. The resorts alongside the lake are known as the Garda Riviera, and Salr itself is famous as the site of the dictator Benito Mussolini's short-lived last Republic before his final capture as Italy and Germany were defeated in the Second World War. 9 Lambrusco The region: Emilia-Romagna lies unknown to most tourists who flock instead to Tuscany and Umbria, but it is just as attractive in its own way. Bologna and Parma are not just interesting as classic sightseeing destinations, they're actually fun university towns, with great restaurants and bars. Ravenna, for its mosaics, and the grand palaces of Ferrara, are both worth a detour, while behind travel brochure images of modern hotels lining the seafront, Rimini and the whole Adriatic coast boast some of Europe's wildest summer nightclubs. The wine: Love it or hate it, the sparkling red Lambrusco is so different from other wines that it leaves no one unmoved. What is sure, though, is that here in the region it is grown, this is the perfect wine to accompany the characteristic cuisine of what is Italy's gastronomic heartland. Although some wine makers produce a sweeter, amabile Lambrusco, it is better to stick to the dry variation. The address: Trattoria Il Lurido, Piazzetta Ortaggi 7, Rimini, Emilia Romagna. Tel: 0039 0541 24834. Closed Tues. Foodies are spoilt for choice in Emilia-Romagna, with Parma famous for its ham, Bologna for mortadella, parmesan cheese from Reggio, and Modena's renowned basalmic vinegar. Best of all, though, is the fresh pasta - tagliatelle and tortelloni - and there's no better place to sample that than in Fellini's favourite restaurant in his home town of Rimini. They don't have the best wine list in the world, but you'll taste a fine chilled bottle of Lambrusco. 10 Tokai Friulano The region: Friuli makes up Italy's wild and rugged border with Eastern and Central Europe. Not many foreign travellers make it out this far, even though the elegant Venice is close. It is their loss, because historic towns such as Udine and Cividale, the dreamy lagoon at Grado, and the lush valleys and towering mountains of the Carnia lie totally unspoilt, waiting to be discovered. The wine: To really discover the cutting edge of great Italian wines, it is well worth the trek to Friuli. The whites are stupendous - Chardonnay, Sauvignon, Malvasia - and in red wine, both the Cabernet and Merlot can be excellent. But the Friulani are most proud of their Tokai, and the dialect word for a glass of wine, tajut, always refers to a Tokai. Banish all thoughts of the sickly sweet Hungarian Tokay. The Friuli version is a delicate dry white wine, which becomes great in the hands of master vintners such as Livio Felluga and Sandro Princic, both in the Collio vineyards. The address: Enoteca di Cormons, Piazza XXIV, Maggio 21, Cormons, Friuli. Tel: 0039 0481 630371. Closed Tuesdays. The village of Cormons is the unofficial wine capital of Friuli, and there is plenty of choice to have a lunchtime break between visiting different vineyards. There are several rather smart restaurants, which are much favoured by wine makers entertaining customers, but the most sensible spot to head for is the town's official enoteca, where there is a vast selection of all the great wines of the surrounding Collio hills, which can be accompanied by bar snacks such as the local prosciutto crudo, salami and cheeses.

fields.headline: City of magic and music
fields.standfirst: Its duke was canny enough to hire Monteverdi and the ghost of Verdi's Rigoletto haunts its winding streets.  Stephen  Pritchard  fell for the charms of Romeo's refuge
fields.trailText: What does the name Mantua mean to you? It probably conjures up images of the classroom, dusty books and ill-fitting costumes, because Mantua, like Padua, is Shakespearean Italy. It is here that Romeo flees in exile after the killing of Tybalt, and where he buys the poison that he will swallow in his cruelly mistaken belief that Juliet is dead.
fields.body:
What does the name Mantua mean to you? It probably conjures up images of the classroom, dusty books and ill-fitting costumes, because Mantua, like Padua, is Shakespearean Italy. It is here that Romeo flees in exile after the killing of Tybalt, and where he buys the poison that he will swallow in his cruelly mistaken belief that Juliet is dead.

Shakespeare didn't exactly go out of his way to sell Mantua as an attractive destination for the sixteenth-century tourist. Romeo recalls seeing a poor, thin apothecary - the poison-maker - hanging about the streets, 'and in his needy shop a tortoise hung, an alligator stuff'd, and other skins of ill-shaped fishes; and about his shelves a beggarly account of empty boxes, green earthen pots, bladders and musty seeds, remnants of packthread, and old cakes of roses were thinly scattered to make up a show' . No Marks and Sparks then. And Verdi didn't help. Seizing upon Victor Hugo's Le Roi s'amuse as a good plot for an opera, he dismayed the Venetian opera house management by portraying a French king as a libertine and subject of an assassination plot. Forced to rethink four weeks before the opening night he moved the action from Paris to Mantua, turned the lecherous monarch into a duke and italianised the court jester Tribolet into Triboletto and eventually Rigoletto (from rigoler, to guffaw).

A great opera was born, and thrust on to unsuspecting Mantua, which appears to have taken it to its heart, for although he never existed 'Rigoletto's House' stands across the main square from the ducal palace, the setting for the fictitious action. In the garden a large bronze Rigoletto, complete with jester's cap and bells, stands caught in mid-joke. This great tragic figure of nineteenth-century opera, desperate to protect his daughter, resolves to kill the philandering duke and comes across Sparafucile, a professional killer, in the dark, narrow streets of the city.

Even today, the winding thoroughfares near the Piazza Sordello outside the palace feel ready for that fateful meeting.

This graceful square, which retains its medieval plan, is a perfect place to watch the Mantuan world go by. The east side is dominated by the ducal palace, the west by the episcopal palace, and the north by the cathedral and its campanile. As the sun moves across the piazza, it picks out the rough reds and mellow terracottas of the buildings, setting them aglow with that rosy lustre that makes Italy's towns and cities so seductive.

The action of Rigoletto may never have taken place in the ducal palace but one hugely significant musical event certainly did - the staging of the first true opera, Orfeo, took place here in 1607. Duke Vincenzo Gonzaga spent lavishly on music, and employed Claudio Monteverdi as a court singer, instrumentalist and composer, and took him with him on military expeditions to the Danube and Flanders, presumably to soothe the troubled breast when the going got tough. The Oxford Dictionary of Music says that Monteverdi's place in the history of Renaissance music can justly be compared to Shakespeare's in literature. The Gonzagas knew a star when they saw one.

Orfeo sets the entire classical legend of Orpheus to ravishing music that was to make Monteverdi famous and was to inspire an Italian infatuation with opera that today has largely been supplanted by football.

The duke died in 1612 and Monteverdi moved to Venice to be Master of the Music at St Mark's, where he found lasting fame, but it is tragic to reflect that when the Austrians sacked Mantua just a few years later they destroyed 12 of the operas Monteverdi had written there.

Howard Goodall's oustanding recent Channel 4 series on the history of music revealed that the very room in which Monteverdi composed has recently been discovered in the vast Mantuan palace. Bricked up and forgotten centuries ago, it retains its delicate freschi of cherubs and fanciful lutenists; a room frozen in time, music hanging in the air.

We had reached Mantua by driving south across the wide, fertile plain that wraps around the ancient city, a plain that contrasts sharply with the mountainous landscape around our base camp, Lake Garda.

The green haze of spring hung on the trees that ran down to the lake and the sun's rays were full of the promise of summer as we set out to explore the shoreline of this beautiful inland sea.

Catullus, the Classical poet, is reputed to have lived on a narrow spit of land that runs out into the lake. The picturesque town of Sirmione grew up round the ancient ruins of what is said to be his house, right on the end of the promontory. The ruins are certainly ancient, and once formed a substantial villa, or even a small town, but firm evidence of Catullus having lived here is more difficult to establish.

But why spoil a decent legend? This romantic site, with its beautiful views across the lake to the mountains beyond, would inspire any poet, ancient or modern. The little town is almost too cute to be true, having a fairytale air about its impressive fourteenth-century castle, which is of the drawbridges-battlements-and-swooning-maidens variety.

I discovered another swooning maiden in the bathroom at our hotel. She was naked, save for a strategically placed piece of muslin, and was being pursued by a young, moustachioed swain, also in his birthday suit. Alas, he will never catch her. They are frozen in paint in a lovely sixteenth-century fresco, condemned for ever to be just out of each other's reach. The hotel, the Palazzo Arzaga, claims to be a former monastery. Whether this fresco and others like it around the hotel date from the time of its monastic foundation is difficult to establish, but I hope they do; I feel sure the monks would have enjoyed the cheeky lovers.

I'm not sure what they would have made of Tai Chi. Early next morning we joined a group of six on a small hill at the back of the hotel and, as the sun played on the waters of the lake, learnt something of this ancient Chinese art, moving our limbs slowly to a series of gentle commands from our instructor.

I can't say it did a great deal for me. I can find my inner self more easily by simply listening to the music of this glorious country. Thank you, Monteverdi. Thank you, Mantua.

Citalia (Tel 020 8686 5533 or visit www.citalia.co.uk) offer seven nights at the Palazzo Arzaga for £1,165. Price includes bed and breakfast, British Airways flights and transfers. The hotel has a health centre and clubhouse with two 18-hole golf courses designed by Jack Nicklaus II and Gary Player.

fields.headline: Officers must get a grip
fields.standfirst: The ICC meeting at Lord's did not address the pertinent issues
fields.trailText: 'Soldiers are from the north, officers from the south.' That's the language working-class Geordie girl Angela Gobin says the toffs of Sandhurst used to freeze her out of the Royal Military Academy; she might easily have been describing Lord's and all its old prejudices.
fields.body:
'Soldiers are from the north, officers from the south.' That's the language working-class Geordie girl Angela Gobin says the toffs of Sandhurst used to freeze her out of the Royal Military Academy; she might easily have been describing Lord's and all its old prejudices.

It would be unfair to characterise every administrator in the game as a Bufton-Tufton stuck in the last century (or the one before, for that matter) - indeed, Lord MacLaurin has tried his best to drag some of the dinosaurs out of the saloon bar and into the sunlight - but they did themselves no favours last week with their laughably unenforcable edicts on match-fixing.

In essence, the wise men of the International Cricket Council expect the ranks to step forward and rat on their mates, thus cleaning up a mess that has sat festering under their noses for the best part of two decades. And then it's jankers all-round, apparently.

This is a liar's charter, if ever there was one. The dressing-room culture of cricket almost guarantees that the players' first loyalty is to their colleagues; this, after all, is how the Establishment operates anyway. In its purest sense, it is masonic from top to bottom. So players will not be baring the souls to anonymous investigators and absolutely nothing will be unearthed that is not already known.

There are two windows of opportunity open, however: the Qayyum report, which we are told will finally be made public this week, supposedly naming the Pakistani names we already have been reading about for months; and the Hansie Cronje investigation, which starts tomorrow in South Africa. Both of those have judicial weight. As does the police inquiry in Delhi that first accused Cronje and three (or four) of his team-mates of taking bribes.

Cronje, whose love affair with the telephone has been suspended apparently (Allan Donald revealed last week he got through to his former captain's parents' house but Hansie would not come to the phone), will have to come out of hiding for this one. Will he be able to explain how the phone call he is alleged to have taken from the Indian bookmaker Sanjeev Chawla was taken on the mobile phone of the South African team manager, Goolam Raja - or will that little detail be quietly passed over?

This is the fine print the ICC investigators will be hard-pressed to pin down without the total cooperation of the troops. And just how persuasive are the officers?

MacLaurin (as you are allowed to call a peer after first use of his title) last week described Simon Pack, the international teams director of the England and Wales Cricket Board, as 'a first-rate officer'. No doubt that is so. But, if the players are to believed, when they were desperate to talk with Pack last year over central contracts, they were told he could not go out to Sharjah to meet them because he was busy working on his garden. It is to be hoped his roses are blooming.

We may be doing MacLaurin and Pack a disservice. Theirs is a tough job, and they're probably doing their best. But, if it is not good enough - and if the ICC are failing in their duty as guardians of the sport worldwide - surely we are led to the conclusion that somebody else could do it better.

The view that there is a cultural gap between the rulers and ruled was given voice in a conversation I had last week with someone close to the Pakistan team who objects to the way the old order have rushed to several assumptions about cricket in Asia.

He reminded me that, when England's cricketers arrive in Karachi in October to start their first tour of Pakistan since Mike Gatting waved his finger at Shakoor Rana 13 years ago, you can bet - sorry, be reasonably certain - that the welcoming committee will have plenty to say off the record to their guests.

Not much of it will be about old umpiring decisions; there are plenty of new arguments to be going on with.

'What a lot of these people are slow to realise,' he said, 'is that the power in cricket has shifted. If the general view is that corruption is concentrated in south Asia because of the proliferation of one-day games there - and what other conclusion could you draw from last week's meeting at Lord's? - perhaps the establishment figures should ask themselves why that is the case. More pertinently, they should ask themselves why countries such as Sri Lanka and Zimbabwe - and Pakistan and India even - have been awarded so few Tests in England, even though it is obvious to the rest of the world that things are not as they were.

'Cricket is not just about the Ashes, anymore. These people have closed their eyes to a lot of things over the years and now they are reacting when the damage is done.'

That damage is the loss of trust between players and public, due to the seemingly unstoppable flood of match-fixing allegations. If the players are at the hard end of the perceived corruption - and the conclusive evidence has yet to be tabled, whatever the weight of rumour - then administrators are surely culpable as well.

It is not difficult to sympathise with the view that, if Asian teams have turned to the one-day game because that is where the TV money is, one of the contributing factors might have been that their teams were considered 'unfashionable', not the stuff of traditional Test series, tours that had to be fitted in between the bigger ones against Australia or the West Indies. You will certainly find sympathy for that view among the younger Test nations.

Nevertheless, nearly all the circumstantial evidence is heavily weighted against Pakistan and India, along with the sacrificial white lamb, Hansie Cronje. One reason for that is the almost total absence of libel laws on the sub-continent, a lack that makes for interesting copy but not very responsible journalism.

While it is inconceivable that every betting tale or conspiracy theory is a total fairy story, divining truth from malice is an almost impossible task without the intervention of the judiciary. To that end, the emergency meeting chaired by the Calcutta businessman and outgoing ICC president, Jagmohan Dalmiya, in London last week, produced perhaps the most useless international document since the Treaty of Versailles.

Mr Dalmiya, himself under pressure from enemies in India who are striving to implicate him in the scandal, did not answer those charges with anything more convincing than threats to issue writs. That is not leadership; it is an abrogation of his duty.

fields.headline: Baseball offers a clean-up blueprint
fields.standfirst: It's been one bet and you're out since a scandal in 1920 ,  explains Oliver Owen
fields.trailText: Many still regard the Twenties as baseball's 'golden age' - Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig and the birth of the New York Yankee dynasty - but the sport staggered into the decade under a shroud of scandal and skulduggery.
fields.body:
Many still regard the Twenties as baseball's 'golden age' - Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig and the birth of the New York Yankee dynasty - but the sport staggered into the decade under a shroud of scandal and skulduggery.

Rumours began to circulate in 1920 that the previous season's World Series was not exactly on the level. The heavily favoured Chicago White Sox had lost five games to three to the Cincinnati Reds and accusations swirled against the Chicago club to such an extent that a grand jury was convened to investigate the charges.

Under false promises that no action would be taken against them, two White Sox players, star pitcher Eddie Cicotte and 'Shoeless' Joe Jackson confessed to a fix and they and six others were immediately suspended. The worms were out of the can. In June 1921 the eight were tried on charges of fixing the series but were acquitted through lack of evidence. But the story doesn't end there.

Allegations and rumours of fixed games had been rife throughout the previous decade. Players openly mixed with gamblers who supplemented their often meagre wages and the powers that be, fearing gates would dip if they made public their fears of corruption, did nothing. The Black Sox scandal would change all that. If the World Series wasn't straight then what was? The owners took a radical step by appointing an all-powerful commissioner.

Kenesaw Mountain Landis, a former federal court judge, made it his first act as commissioner to uphold the suspension of the eight 'Black Sox'. He stated: 'Regardless of the verdict of juries, no player who throws a ballgame, no player that undertakes or promises to throw a ballgame, no player that sits in conference with a bunch of crooked players and gamblers where the ways and means of throwing the game are discussed and does not promptly tell his club about it, will never [sic] play professional baseball.'

A further 11 players were also banned outright or made persona non grata, four retired players were seriously implicated in past scandals and another 12 were subject to various bans for their part in damaging the integrity of the game. In one fell swoop, Judge Landis stomped on the problem. The message was clear, if you have anything to do with, or know anything about, fixing and you keep quiet then you are history.

The current commissioner, Bud Selig, earns more than $2 million a year in what is regarded as the most important post in American sport. He has the same powers as Landis did. 'We've had very few problems since the 1919 World Series,' says Richard Levin, Selig's spokesman. 'You try to fix a game and you're gone. If you get involved with gambling on your own team, you're banned for life with no appeal.'

These rules, if adopted by cricket, would have meant life bans for Rodney Marsh and Dennis Lillee, who had a punt, at 500-1, on England to win the 1981 Headingley Test. Shane Warne and Mark Waugh would have been allowed to take no further part in the game after it emerged that they received money from bookmakers in exchange for information. The South African team who toured India in 1996-97 would also be out, as on two occasions they discussed the possibility of throwing games. They agreed not to and said nothing at the time, but that would have been enough to finish their careers.

Baseball's fear of the bookies is still strong today. Consider the case of Pete Rose. Last year Rose was elected to Major League Baseball's All Century team. In a 23-year playing career with the Cincinnati Reds and the Philadelphia Phillies he compiled more hits than any other player before or since.

Off the diamond, though, he was a compulsive gambler. In 1989 Rose, by now a manager, was investigated for tax evasion. The then commissioner of baseball, Bart Giamatti, hired a special prosecutor to look at Rose's gambling habits. The findings revealed that Rose 'consorted with known bookmakers and drug dealers' but, more importantly, it emerged that Rose had bet on baseball.

Giamatti banned Rose for life and excluded him from the sport's Hall of Fame. What is overlooked is that the investigation found that Rose always backed his team to win .

Baseball's rules are draconian but they have clearly served to avoid the kind of problems cricket now faces. Perhaps it is time for cricket to bring in a highly paid commissioner. Only then would players find that involvement with bookies is a bet not worth taking.

webTitle: Coming to a screen near you

fields.headline: Coming to a screen near you
fields.standfirst:
Get ready for a virus that will make last week's 'love bug' look laughable. Jason Burke and Nick Paton Walsh report on a fast-growing invisible menace to us all.

FBI - NIPC Advice & Warning
Sophos virus information
fields.trailText:
Get ready for a virus that will make last week's 'love bug' look laughable. Jason Burke and Nick Paton Walsh report on a fast-growing invisible menace to us all.

FBI - NIPC Advice & Warning
Sophos virus information
fields.body:
You sit at your desk, park your coffee next to your mouse, fire up your computer and click to check your e-mail. And in that one tiny movement, before you have even looked to see if there are any suspicious messages from 'NastyVirus.com', it could be too late.

Just by clicking on your 'Get Mail' you could have turned your £2,000 machine into a pile of useless plastic. It is every computer user's worst nightmare - and it is coming soon to a screen near you. Brace yourself for the supervirus.

Meanwhile, the 'love bug' has given us all a taste of what could be coming. Though its creator - the only names released by investigators so far are Barok or Spyder - must be concerned about the police knocking on his door within hours, he must also be feeling fairly pleased with himself. The virus he set loose on the world on Thursday has already caused up to £1 billion worth of damage, more than any other virus or hacking attack since the dawn of cyber-history.

His program worked because it was simple. It was posted on the Web 10 days ago, almost certainly from a computer operating in Manila, capital of the Philippines. It lay dormant for nearly a week before surfacing on computer screens in Hong Kong. The message - seemingly sent by someone known to the computer user - said 'ILOVEYOU' and had an attachment which appeared to be a love letter.

But it was no billet doux. Launching the attachment allowed a program to invade the computer which not only sent copies of the e-mail to all the addresses listed on the machine but also scooped up all the passwords it could find and sent them back to the creator of the bug.

Those first clicks - at around 8am local time on Thursday - triggered a flood. Billions of pulses raced through the world's phone lines, spattering the virus in all directions. It was the fastest-spreading bug ever, infecting five million machines within 36 hours. Everyone from the Pentagon to the House of Commons to New Zealand universities was hit. An estimated 20 per cent of the world's computers were affected and half of all machines in the UK.

Yet it could have been an awful lot worse. The love bug worked by proliferating at such a rate that Internet systems could not handle the overload. That may cause temporary collapse, but there is little long-term damage. The damage that this bug - technically known as a worm - did to picture and music files did cause problems, but these were far from catastrophic.

Cyber-sabotage of a more deadly kind by was indicated by a development in November when researchers at Network Associates, an American computer security firm, received a series of e-mails with the subject heading 'Bubbleboy is back!'. As they examined the virus their eyes widened. It was, says Vincent Gullotto, director of the company's anti-virus team, 'a watershed'.

The Bubbleboy virus broke the long-standing rule that you have to open an e-mail attachment to become infected. By the time it was in your inbox it was too late.

Thankfully Bubbleboy, though it e-mailed itself to everyone in a computer's address book, did not have a 'destructive payload' and so did little damage. Few took much notice of the quantum leap that it represented.

And virus writers have made advances in other areas. In April last year a virus called Chernobyl was activated in hundreds of thousands of computers in Asia and the Middle East, striking on the anniversary of the nuclear accident it was named after. Not only did it wipe out stored data, it destroyed BIOS - the basic instructions that tell a machine how to start.

Now, The Observer has learned, virus writers have married the destructive capabilities of Chernobyl, with the invasive capabilities of Bubbleboy and the speed of the Love Bug. The combination is the supervirus.

According to anti-virus experts, at least 50 such superviruses have already been detected on the Internet. None have yet been launched at the public. Some may not work; some may be shot down by existing virus defences; some might get through. And that is the nightmare scenario.

A hacker known as Dark Tangent, who heads a group which advises big businesses on their security, says the only surprise is that a 'supervirus hasn't happened yet'. 'For the last two years we've all been waiting. I don't know why we have not seen one. It could happen next week.'

The damage a successful supervirus could do is almost incalculable. 'It would be as if the Millennium Bug has actually done everything it was feared it could do,' said one London-based computer security expert last week.

The first question confronting law enforcement agencies and commercial outfits hired to protect companies and institutions against such an attack is who would be likely to launch it. Authorities are focusing on the threat from terrorist groups, who they fear might use viruses to extort money or blackmail governments into giving in to political demands.

It would be relatively easy for a group to launch a virus against a specific set of targets - maybe one institution or a single ministry - and then threaten to release further e-mails elsewhere. Such actions could paralyse the workings of a government while avoiding killing innocent people.

One source close to British intelligence services says MI5 believe both the Basque separatist group ETA and the Kurdish terror organisations have drawn up plans aimed at crashing air traffic control systems through the use of hacking or viruses. Irish Republican terrorists are also thought to have considered similar methods. 'The supervirus is going to happen soon,' the source said. 'There are people out there with that intention. They may coincide their actions with protests against the International Monetary Fund and the World Trade Organisation, just to muddy the water.' Many of the organisations connected with anarchist violence in London number hackers in their ranks.

Another threat is from hostile governments. The US defence department believes 120 countries pose a serious threat to cyber-security. They include Libya, Iraq, Croatia and Serbia. The Chinese are thought to have created military regiments dedicated to cyber-warfare.

Experts say national security authorities are only just waking up to the threat from the Internet - a threat that will be magnified when technology allows e-mails to be read on mobile phone-type units. Critics say British authorities have yet to establish an effective, single body to deal with the threat.

Policing of the Internet is at present the responsibility of the National Criminal Intelligence Service (NCIS) and a computer crimes squad at Scotland Yard. MI5, Customs and Special Branch also have an interest.

'There is a turf war between these agencies,' said Caspar Bowden, director of the Foundation for Information Policy and Research. 'The Government's entire strategy for policing information technology is in disarray.'

Critics say a new £25m system which will monitor e-mail and Internet surfing across the UK endangers civil liberties and will be impotent against serious criminals.

Many experts also say the security agencies are looking in the wrong place. Mike Bluestone, director of Berkeley Security Bureau, said those who launch virus attacks are more likely to be 'cyber-vandals' not 'cyber-terrorists'. 'Terrorists make targeted demands and like a high degree of control over their operations. A supervirus is more likely to be the brainchild of a spotty adolescent than some terrorist mastermind.'

The standard profile of a virus writer is a young man with a grievance. He is often a professional programmer who feels his skills are not being recognised. Hidden behind a series of fake and anonymous e-mail accounts the virus writer is rarely detectable.

But this weekend investigators seemed confident they were close to catching the man behind the love bug. Nelson Bartoleme, head of the Manila police anti-fraud and computer crimes division, told reporters his agents had placed a suspect, believed to be a 23-year-old man living in a wealthy Manila suburb, under surveillance.

The arrest of one young man on the other side of the world may seem scant consolation if you are still smarting from last week's attack, but you should take heart. Just remember, as your fingers dip towards your mouse tomorrow morning and the cursor starts its glide towards the inbox icon - it could have been an awful lot worse. And one day, undoubtedly, it will be.

Additional research: Peter Warren

Click here for global chaos

Social mayhem
Home computers would be shut down and many essential services would suffer a catastrophic loss of data.

Terrorism
In the worst scenario, either through negligence or sabotage, a supervirus could infect air traffic control.

Commercial crime
Criminals could blackmail financial institutions, which would be anxious to avoid the costly damage a supervirus could cause their systems, their company's performance and their share value.

How to sabotage the world
1. Download a virus writing programme from the Internet, which can enable anyone to author a virus.

2. Download an e-mail harvester which will search the Net for e-mail addresses and collect up to 25,000 addresses in an hour.

3. Find a series of Internet Service Providers in foreign countries through which to send your e-mails without being traced.

4. Create a message and e-mail it to the randomly generated addresses, plus any specific organisations you wish to target.

5. Send the virus off and watch global chaos ensue.
