webTitle: I went through hell for  the job I had to have

fields.headline: I went through hell for  the job I had to have
fields.standfirst:
A tearful Ken Livingstone tells Andy McSmith how he triumphed over the system to become London Mayor, despite Labour dirty tricks and tabloid attacks

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText:
A tearful Ken Livingstone tells Andy McSmith how he triumphed over the system to become London Mayor, despite Labour dirty tricks and tabloid attacks

The London mayor: special report
fields.body:
It is not often you see a grown man cry, but Ken Livingstone's eyes turned as red as his politics are reputed to be as he relived the moment when he finally knew that he had won.

'It suddenly dawns on you that all those people have gone out and voted for you, and it was overwhelming and incredibly humbling, and I hadn't expected to have that feeling,' he said, the words emerging more and more slowly.

We are in the huge, well-lit and almost empty room marked 'Mayor's Office' in Romney House, a converted hotel not far from Horseferry Magistrates' Court, which will be the headquarters of the Mayor and London regional Assembly until a permanent site is found.

The interview was delayed, because Livingstone had forgotten the way back to his office through the labyrinth of staircases and corridors. 'Well, we're not here for that long,' scoffed a spokesman. 'We'll be out of here in a year.'

It was the only press interview Livingstone gave yesterday, having had 24 hours to absorb the fact that he has finally achieved the goal to which he has devoted three years of his life with astonishing single-mindedness. He'd made his way to the office by Underground from Cricklewood; his journey documented by a team of photographers.

The tears in his eyes and crack in his voice were so unmistakable that I asked him a few minutes later whether he often cried like that. It was like pressing a button. He was in tears again as he explained that the announcement of his victory 'was a very, very powerful moment, and I get weak every time I go back to it. Bear in mind that I had to break with the party I had been in for 30 years. I then had these incredible pressures. I mean it was just about the dirtiest campaign. Every aspect of my life hauled over, and day by day you never knew what the next thing was going to be. It was a huge strain. I lost half a stone - that was the only good thing in all this. And then you had those last dreadful few days. You had the really vile stuff in the Sun and the rather snobby attitude in most of the other papers that I wasn't really up to the job. It was pretty relentless, you survive it - and that is a wonderful moment.'

Livingstone's voice started breaking up again. This is a man who feels he has had almost the whole world ganging up against him, he has taken them on, and he has won. By his reckoning, he holds the second best job in British politics: 'This was a job created for me. It is sort of perfect. I am free from party whips and constraints, and there's a sort of direct relationship with London which is wonderful to have.'

The model of the kind of Mayor he wants to be is New York's Ed Koch, or Fiorello LaGuardia from the 1930s - 'the interesting ones, the Mayors who have been characters, the rather lippy, opinionated people who loved the city and took a very hands-on approach.

'LaGuardia has this line, "when a sparow dies in Central Park, I feel responsible" - that's barmy, but there's an element there about how the Mayor should work the city.'

How he proposes to 'work' the city with a budget so tight that it leaves him about £20 million a year to spend and no political base at all is something of a mystery. Charging motorists to drive into London will give him some extra revenue, but he does not expect the policy to be in force at least until May 2002. 'It is the single most important thing I will do, in the rest of my life. Even if there was no net revenue income to the Mayor, I would still do it, because London is close to gridlock.'

Another issue much on his mind is the threat to production of Ford cars at Dagenham, which he raised on the telephone with Tony Blair yesterday. Livingstone blames an overvalued pound, and British employment laws which allegedly make it cheaper to sack workers here than in other countries where Ford has factories. But, as for a solution, he frankly admits that he has none, except that, if the factory goes under, he will demand that the Government turn the affected part of Dagenham into an enterprise zone. However, the good news for car workers is that Blair and Livingstone are at least talking about their fate and, according to Livingstone, 'the Mayor and the Government will be taking one common line'.

He has informed the Prime Minister that he is as determined as ever to fight his expulsion from the Labour Party. Officials from Labour's Millbank headquarters are adamant that Livingstone is out for at least five years.

'I know there's a lot of people in the party want me back in, and there is sure to be a debate about this at the conference. By the autumn a lot of journalists who predicted the end of civilisation as we know it and a collapse back into a dark age in London will be saying: "Oh, he hasn't done too badly after all. Not many dead." These issues are going to be resolved by the Prime Minister, not by apparatchiks in Millbank, who have not actually covered themselves in glory in their conduct of the election. The day I declared as an independent candidate, I had four staff, and even at the end of the campaign I had 11 and about 50 volunteers, and we took on and defeated three very powerful parties.'

He is also hoping to avoid a court battle with the Deputy Prime Minister, John Prescott, over the future of the Underground, believing (somewhat optimistically) that Prescott will abandon his plan to bring in private finance, instead opting to fund investment Livingstone's way. That, as they say, will be the day. Relations with the newly elected 25-member Greater London Assembly have got off to a mixed start. Livingstone has a promise of co-operation from Labour from Blair in person, and sings the praises of one particular Labour Assembly member, Nicky Gavron, whom he has appointed as his deputy.

But relations with the best-known Labour Assembly member, former LWT presenter Trevor Phillips, could hardly be worse. Phillips himself says he is mystified by Livingstone's hostility, which he regards as unprovoked. Livingstone says: 'I didn't like the fact that all Trevor's campaign was attacks on other people. I think negative campaigning doesn't have any place between the parties. Within the parties, it's unacceptable. We then discovered that all the stuff about my personal finances had come from Trevor's former press officer.'

He is also scathing about the way the Assembly's four political parties are organising their business. 'The first thing the Labour group decides after a drubbing like this is how to draw up a disciplinary code so that everybody does as they are told! To have four groups, four leaders and four disciplinary codes - it's bizarre. The Assembly's about the size of a large Islington dinner party.'

He can now bid goodbye to a job he increasingly disliked, as a backbench MP going nowhere. After Tony Blair's victory, he convinced - or deluded - himself that he had a chance of winning office, particularly after he had demonstrated that he was popular enough with Labour activists to beat Peter Mandelson to a seat on Labour's National Executive. Then the rules for NEC elections were changed, and he realised that he was doomed to be a marginal figure in the Commons.

Of course, none of this was his fault - at least not in Livingstone's eyes. Though he lacks the brazen arrogance of many members of his profession, he can be breathtakingly short of modesty. When asked, for instance, whether he will exercise one of his new mayoral prerogatives by appointing two full-time personal advisers, he says he probably will not, because 'no one is less in need of political advice than I am, and when I get it I usually ignore it'.

No, the dreariness of his years on the backbenches was the fault of all the other MPs, not Livingstone.

'Tony Blair and I never spent time socialising - that's one thing we had in common,' he says. 'We had a job of work to do. We didn't hang around the bars. It wasn't an encouraging environment. So, no I didn't enjoy it. It became increasingly sterile, and with each election the intake of people who were just "yah-boo, your side is worse" increased and the number of characters with any spirit of independence reduced. I just got so used to being in this Parliament where everybody just advances by stabbing you in the back.'

Additional reporting by Burhan Wazir

The interview was delayed, because Livingstone had forgotten the way back to his office through the labyrinth of staircases and corridors. 'Well, we're not here for that long,' scoffed a spokesman. 'We'll be out of here in a year.' It was the only press interview Livingstone gave yesterday, having had 24 hours to absorb the fact that he has finally achieved the goal to which he has devoted three years of his life with astonishing single-mindedness. He'd made his way to the office by Underground from Cricklewood; his journey documented by a team of photographers. The tears in his eyes and crack in his voice were so unmistakable that I asked him a few minutes later whether he often cried like that. It was like pressing a button. He was in tears again as he explained that the announcement of his victory 'was a very, very powerful moment, and I get weak every time I go back to it. Bear in mind that I had to break with the party I had been in for 30 years. I then had these incredible pressures. I mean it was just about the dirtiest campaign. Every aspect of my life hauled over, and day by day you never knew what the next thing was going to be. It was a huge strain. I lost half a stone - that was the only good thing in all this. And then you had those last dreadful few days. You had the really vile stuff in the Sun and the rather snobby attitude in most of the other papers that I wasn't really up to the job. It was pretty relentless, you survive it - and that is a wonderful moment.' Livingstone's voice started breaking up again. This is a man who feels he has had almost the whole world ganging up against him, he has taken them on, and he has won. By his reckoning, he holds the second best job in British politics: 'This was a job created for me. It is sort of perfect. I am free from party whips and constraints, and there's a sort of direct relationship with London which is wonderful to have.' The model of the kind of Mayor he wants to be is New York's Ed Koch, or Fiorello LaGuardia from the 1930s - 'the interesting ones, the Mayors who have been characters, the rather lippy, opinionated people who loved the city and took a very hands-on approach. 'LaGuardia has this line, "when a sparow dies in Central Park, I feel responsible" - that's barmy, but there's an element there about how the Mayor should work the city.' How he proposes to 'work' the city with a budget so tight that it leaves him about £20 million a year to spend and no political base at all is something of a mystery. Charging motorists to drive into London will give him some extra revenue, but he does not expect the policy to be in force at least until May 2002. 'It is the single most important thing I will do, in the rest of my life. Even if there was no net revenue income to the Mayor, I would still do it, because London is close to gridlock.' Another issue much on his mind is the threat to production of Ford cars at Dagenham, which he raised on the telephone with Tony Blair yesterday. Livingstone blames an overvalued pound, and British employment laws which allegedly make it cheaper to sack workers here than in other countries where Ford has factories. But, as for a solution, he frankly admits that he has none, except that, if the factory goes under, he will demand that the Government turn the affected part of Dagenham into an enterprise zone. However, the good news for car workers is that Blair and Livingstone are at least talking about their fate and, according to Livingstone, 'the Mayor and the Government will be taking one common line'. He has informed the Prime Minister that he is as determined as ever to fight his expulsion from the Labour Party. Officials from Labour's Millbank headquarters are adamant that Livingstone is out for at least five years. 'I know there's a lot of people in the party want me back in, and there is sure to be a debate about this at the conference. By the autumn a lot of journalists who predicted the end of civilisation as we know it and a collapse back into a dark age in London will be saying: "Oh, he hasn't done too badly after all. Not many dead." These issues are going to be resolved by the Prime Minister, not by apparatchiks in Millbank, who have not actually covered themselves in glory in their conduct of the election. The day I declared as an independent candidate, I had four staff, and even at the end of the campaign I had 11 and about 50 volunteers, and we took on and defeated three very powerful parties.' He is also hoping to avoid a court battle with the Deputy Prime Minister, John Prescott, over the future of the Underground, believing (somewhat optimistically) that Prescott will abandon his plan to bring in private finance, instead opting to fund investment Livingstone's way. That, as they say, will be the day. Relations with the newly elected 25-member Greater London Assembly have got off to a mixed start. Livingstone has a promise of co-operation from Labour from Blair in person, and sings the praises of one particular Labour Assembly member, Nicky Gavron, whom he has appointed as his deputy. But relations with the best-known Labour Assembly member, former LWT presenter Trevor Phillips, could hardly be worse. Phillips himself says he is mystified by Livingstone's hostility, which he regards as unprovoked. Livingstone says: 'I didn't like the fact that all Trevor's campaign was attacks on other people. I think negative campaigning doesn't have any place between the parties. Within the parties, it's unacceptable. We then discovered that all the stuff about my personal finances had come from Trevor's former press officer.' He is also scathing about the way the Assembly's four political parties are organising their business. 'The first thing the Labour group decides after a drubbing like this is how to draw up a disciplinary code so that everybody does as they are told! To have four groups, four leaders and four disciplinary codes - it's bizarre. The Assembly's about the size of a large Islington dinner party.' He can now bid goodbye to a job he increasingly disliked, as a backbench MP going nowhere. After Tony Blair's victory, he convinced - or deluded - himself that he had a chance of winning office, particularly after he had demonstrated that he was popular enough with Labour activists to beat Peter Mandelson to a seat on Labour's National Executive. Then the rules for NEC elections were changed, and he realised that he was doomed to be a marginal figure in the Commons. Of course, none of this was his fault - at least not in Livingstone's eyes. Though he lacks the brazen arrogance of many members of his profession, he can be breathtakingly short of modesty. When asked, for instance, whether he will exercise one of his new mayoral prerogatives by appointing two full-time personal advisers, he says he probably will not, because 'no one is less in need of political advice than I am, and when I get it I usually ignore it'. No, the dreariness of his years on the backbenches was the fault of all the other MPs, not Livingstone. 'Tony Blair and I never spent time socialising - that's one thing we had in common,' he says. 'We had a job of work to do. We didn't hang around the bars. It wasn't an encouraging environment. So, no I didn't enjoy it. It became increasingly sterile, and with each election the intake of people who were just "yah-boo, your side is worse" increased and the number of characters with any spirit of independence reduced. I just got so used to being in this Parliament where everybody just advances by stabbing you in the back.' Additional reporting by Burhan Wazir

fields.headline: They said, he said
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: His finest hour...
fields.body:
His finest hour...

'I bear in mind the words of Winston Churchill that in victory there should be magnanimity...'
Ken Livingstone

And magnanimity in defeat...?

'The people of London have made their verdict clear and it's my responsibility to make sure it works for London.'
Tony Blair

I've got a lovely bunch of candidates...

'Who are you going to vote for? The sex maniac? The baboon? The communist? Or the Lib Dem Woman no one has ever heard of'
Lord Carrington

'Only in politics would Ken Livingstone appear to be an interesting man. Anywhere else he would be recognised as a bore.'
Sebastian Faulks

But it could have been worse. Honest...

'We should pay the unemployed to walk around in bowler hats and to carry umbrellas. It would improve the tourist industry and individuals could buy a load of shares in the bowler hat company.'
Socialite Sir Dai Llewellyn on his plans if he were mayor

And, lest we forget them...

'Your head did not turn if a black woman passed because they were badly dressed, probably overweight and had a lousy job.'
Jeffrey Archer

'Wishy washy'
Description of Frank Dobson by image consultants Colour Me Beautiful

'I'm a cringing coward. I always vote the way they tell me to vote. I'm a balls-achingly, tooth-grindingly, butt-clenchingly loyal apparatchik.'
Labour MP Stephen Pound

Kramer Can Do It!
Headline still at the top of Susan Kramer's website yesterday

The last word...

'Barmy'
The verdict, many years ago, on the idea of an elected London mayor. The speaker: Ken Livingstone

fields.headline: New £80m Channel ferry
fields.trailText: Brittany Ferries is to build a new superferry - the first cross-Channel passenger ship to be launched since the Channel Tunnel was opened in 1995. The £80 million ferry, which will carry 2,000 passengers, 600 cars and 175 trucks on the Portsmouth to Caen route, will be launched in 2002. At 36,000 tons it will be more than three times the size of the Duc de Normandie which it replaces and will be the largest ship on the Western Channel.
fields.body:
Brittany Ferries is to build a new superferry - the first cross-Channel passenger ship to be launched since the Channel Tunnel was opened in 1995. The £80 million ferry, which will carry 2,000 passengers, 600 cars and 175 trucks on the Portsmouth to Caen route, will be launched in 2002. At 36,000 tons it will be more than three times the size of the Duc de Normandie which it replaces and will be the largest ship on the Western Channel.

New features will include airline-style seat-back videos on reclining seats in a special lounge, a cybercafe offering the chance to surf the Internet and two cinemas.

But managing director Ian Carruthers was quick to stress that it would maintain the traditional French ambience of the Brittany Ferries fleet.

'We won't reflect any fads. We are constructing something for 10 or 15 years. There will be areas to relax and we will have the traditional brasseries and cafeteria,' he said.

Ferry companies, which have faced fierce competition from the tunnel, were further hit when duty-free sales were abolished last year. But Brittany Ferries announced a 4 per cent rise in turnover in the last financial year with an increase in profits of 27 per cent to £17 million. The company claims a 52 per cent share of the Western Channel passenger market.

webTitle: Any model you like - still won't work

fields.headline: Any model you like - still won't work
fields.trailText: I very much admired the way Martha Lane Fox stuck to her guns on the Today programme last week. When gently sautéed rather than grilled over the pricing of the flotation of Lastminute, she admirably stuck by the decision to float at that level.
fields.body:
I very much admired the way Martha Lane Fox stuck to her guns on the Today programme last week. When gently sautéed rather than grilled over the pricing of the flotation of Lastminute, she admirably stuck by the decision to float at that level and managed in the space of a two-minute sting to drop Morgan Stanley's name as adviser two or possibly three times. In of course the nicest possible way. A masterly piece of subterfuge - linking in the listener's minds the words 'Morgan Stanley' with 'overpriced offering'.

And who can blame her? We have had to listen to all sorts of blather from the banking community about the great revolution that is e-commerce and the Internet. To add massive insult to great injury we have also had to endure their production of endless 'new valuation models' for Internet companies.

These are largely predicated on taking the birth date of the founder's grandmother, dividing by a shoe size then multiplying by the wind speed (measured of course by a 'finger in the air').

Well, not quite, but in an excellent article published recently in the FT Professor John Kay proved that the new valuation models being touted by the likes of McKinsey and a couple of merchant banks can be instantly undermined by simply applying the maths to existing non dot.com, profit-making companies.

Now the fact that there is a divergence in philosophy over what constitutes a 'fair value' for new-economy companies is one thing, but the truly shocking caveat is that the banks and venture capitalists which espouse such convoluted algebra actually do not believe their own modelling. How else would one explain the nervous rush for the exit being made by exactly the same banks and funds who seek to reassure the investor with their own medicine-show calculations?

This week Boo.com, the over-hyped business in the US which was to be the dernier cri in 'urban sportswear' (and you wonder why it's failing?) will probably lose founders and two backers.

Also in the US, News Corp is allegedly writing off its investment in theStreet.com - though to be fair, Rupert Murdoch was one of the first to try to puncture the balloon of Internet valuations.

The Quantum fund is jumping out of e-commerce investment and more banks than you could shake a stick at are shelving IPOs or cutting investment .

This can only be because they don't in fact believe their own models, which look at a rate of return 10, sometimes 15, years into the future. The relaxed attitude to the production of profits has evaporated almost overnight. If there is no payback in year three, or no sign of a break-even, suddenly investors, notwithstanding their valuation models, are simply not interested. So despite selling the mug punters and the larger investors a story of long-term gains, the evidence mounts that as soon as the market sags, these selfsame salesmen abandon ship.

The idea behind boo.com has not changed since day one - neither have the basic dynamics and assumptions about the retail market. Similarly World Online, another famous disaster story which recently hit our screens as Europe's largest Internet flotation crashed and burned.

What changed? Simply matters of personnel or implementation of strategy. Which, if you are truly taking the long view, must surely be factored in to any 10-year development plan. All companies suffer bad times, which is why the 'old-economy' companies carry premiums or discounts for such old-fashioned concepts as 'good management' or 'duff strategy'.

Putting a price on the future cannot work, because in a world where companies stand or fall by human decisions, we cannot know what the long-term future holds. We can look only as far as the next set of results and a sketchy forecast for the following year.

Banks may have changed their computer models, but they certainly haven't changed their investment philosophy. And if they haven't, why should we?

emily.bell@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: A breath of fresh heir
fields.standfirst: There is no row. Liz Murdoch has left Sky but it's business as usual. Emily Bell reports
fields.trailText: The bind about being a 'family business' is that too often the family and the business cannot be separated. So when Elisabeth Murdoch announced last week that she was leaving her post at BSkyB, which is 37.5 per cent owned by her father Rupert Murdoch's News International, there was the inevitable rush to read the tea leaves both for the company and the dynasty.
fields.body:
The bind about being a 'family business' is that too often the family and the business cannot be separated. So when Elisabeth Murdoch announced last week that she was leaving her post at BSkyB, which is 37.5 per cent owned by her father Rupert Murdoch's News International, there was the inevitable rush to read the tea leaves both for the company and the dynasty.

But the bald truth is less interesting, if a great deal more charming, than either a corporate or a family feud. Liz is pregnant - and due to give birth after Madonna but before the turn of the year. And, as pregnant women are wont to do, she decided to reassess the future. Rather than giving up on the television industry altogether, she is leaving to set up her own production company, which will generate content for both television and new media ventures.

It is lamentable that the TV industry is losing one of its highest-placed and highest-profile women executives. But then the Murdoch moniker guarantees, if nothing else, an ongoing interest in any of your doings. Settled now in the UK with her partner, PR man Matthew Freud, the lack of a role at Sky will not necessarily dim interest in her public or private activities.

When she told BSkyB chief executive Tony Ball nine days ago that she was leaving, his reaction was one of genuine regret but not total surprise. 'We had an extremely good working relationship, and we were very much singing from the same hymn sheet on what we were trying to achieve for the channels - more original and better programming,' says Ball.

According to colleagues of the pair at Sky, these are not just warm words: Murdoch's relationship with Ball was markedly better than with either of his predecessors, Mark Booth and Sam Chisholm. And it seems entirely possible that Liz Murdoch's new company will crop up as a potential supplier to Sky.

Equally, says Ball, the fact that Elisabeth has left Sky does not dent the broadcaster's relationship with its News Corp proprietor: 'I don't necessarily agree that Liz going lessens our perception as a News Corp company, and I'm sure that Mr Murdoch's interest in what we are doing will not be diminished either.'

What it does mean is that there will not, for the foreseeable future, be a Murdoch at the top of Sky, but then the appointment of Ball just over a year ago, was seen as confirmation of this.

With 62 per cent of Sky shares in the hands of other investors and with its own stock market quotation, to have placed a family member in the top slot would always have been questionable in the eyes of the City, whatever their merits.

The fact that Murdoch's departure was made for personal reasons and of her own volition appears clear cut. She is unlikely to be replaced, in title at least, as managing director of Sky Networks.

Ball says: 'Since I arrived, I've done quite a lot of restructuring, and while we obviously have good people who will look after the programming side, I don't think I'll be looking for a straight replacement for Liz.'

But Murdoch's departure also comes at a challenging time for the company. Next week the f-word raises its ugly head - bids for the next lot of TV rights to Premiership football have to be submitted by 10 May.

Sky is just one of 74 parties who have requested the tender document, and whoever else bids will be hell bent on spoiling its monopoly over top football.

It is not a subject Ball either can or will discuss. It seems unlikely that with more than 3 million homes now receiving Sky through digital dishes, the complex new package of Premiership rights will entirely leave the company, but its monopoly over screening fixtures is likely to come to an end.

In addition, News Corp is busy rearranging its satellite TV portfolio into one company, which it has hinted it will float off in order to unlock its value. Sky's position in this spin-off could be crucial, in that it is by far the most successful pay-TV operation within the overall News Corp operation.

Fox chief Peter Chernin will make an announcement within the next three months as to how the deal will be structured. The most likely outcome for Sky is that News Corp's stake in the company will be warehoused in the new company, but again the impact on Sky's destiny will be minimised.

Instead, Ball is focusing on what will happen next. BSkyB's progression to digital is going well: the third-quarter results are likely to reveal that the company has around 3.5 million digital viewers. And, says Ball, its target of 5 million in five years target is entirely achievable, though he also hints that Sky will eventually move away from being a company tied to doing dishes.

'I think it's inevitable that we are moving towards platform neutrality. We've experimented with ADSL [the new telephone technology] which is one way into the future, and there are others. But it is the general opinion that what the industry will be about is offering as much to your customers as possible,' he says.

However rivalry in the television industry is not yet dead. Ball says of Sky's main rival, OnDigital: 'I can see its attractions for some people, but they are still very constrained by what they can offer and they have an uphill struggle to get to the 2 million subscribers they originally needed to break even.'

Ball's next Big Decision, once the painful process of bidding for football is over, is what to do about switching off the analogue Sky signal. He says he will decide next year; the most likely option seems to be to dish the old satellite system as soon as possible.

'We are finding that digital customers do on the whole spend more than analogue customers. They are more frequent users of the pay-per- view services, for instance, and they seem prepared to pay more for the extended choice,' says Ball.

So is he happy with the programming line-up of the station? 'I'm never happy - if I were happy I wouldn't be doing this job. Things can always be better but I think the commitment Liz and I both had to air both the best of imported programming and to spend more on originated programming remains and is stronger than ever.'

Ball told the Royal Television Society recently that the landmark UK-made drama The Strangerers, which Sky commissioned, was something which 'didn't quite work'. That was 'not necessarily what I meant to say, but the point is that every schedule is always work in progress. Rather like my old school reports, it is a case of "could do better".'

Perhaps Liz Murdoch will oblige with a string of hit shows. Strangerer things have happened.

So is he happy with the programming line-up of the station? 'I'm never happy - if I were happy I wouldn't be doing this job. Things can always be better but I think the commitment Liz and I both had to air both the best of imported programming and to spend more on originated programming remains and is stronger than ever.' Ball told the Royal Television Society recently that the landmark UK-made drama The Strangerers, which Sky commissioned, was something which 'didn't quite work'. That was 'not necessarily what I meant to say, but the point is that every schedule is always work in progress. Rather like my old school reports, it is a case of "could do better".' Perhaps Liz Murdoch will oblige with a string of hit shows. Strangerer things have happened.

webTitle: Restorers' subtle touch brings Piero's genius to glorious life

fields.headline: Restorers' subtle touch brings Piero's genius to glorious life
fields.standfirst: Restoring the famous frescoes in Arezzo's church of San Francesco took eight years longer than planned.  Caroline Boucher flew to Tuscany for a close-up view - and found it well worth the wait
fields.trailText: There's really only one reason people go to Arezzo: fifteenth-century artist Piero della Francesca. His fresco cycle, The Legend of the True Cross, which decorates the choir of the church of San Francesco is one of the high points of early Renaissance art.
fields.body:
There's really only one reason people go to Arezzo: fifteenth-century artist Piero della Francesca. His fresco cycle, The Legend of the True Cross, which decorates the choir of the church of San Francesco is one of the high points of early Renaissance art.

But over the past few years, visitors have been met with varying degrees of scaffolding and inaccessibility as a huge restoration project unfolded very slowly, Italian-style. Due finish in 1992 to celebrate the five-hundredth anniversary of Piero's birth, the project actually took 15 years and was completed only this month. The damage, as with many Italian frescoes, was caused by a combination of leaks, earthquakes, vandalism (in this case from Napoleonic troops, who shot at the figures with their muskets - a similar fate to that of the Elgin marbles on the Parthenon) and earlier restorations that started an unforeseen chemical reaction.

But now the project, described by some as the most complex, difficult and problematic restoration of great fresco cycles that our generation has had to face - and that includes the Sistine Chapel in Rome - is finished and the complete cycle is visible on the three walls around the altar. When I was there last autumn, the northern wall was accessible only to those who bought a ticket and climbed the scaffolding with a guide. To be within touching distance of these important paintings, to be able to see the brush strokes, was profoundly moving. And it was immediately apparent that the restorers were doing a very sympathetic job, rather than overpainting and colouring, as their colleagues have been accused of doing in the Sistine chapel.

Close up, the majestic figures assume personalities: they look out from lively eyes, die expressive deaths. Their greasy hair tails off into thin, single brush-stroke strands. Many of the figures become quickly familiar because Piero used the same model over and over again. You feel ready to greet one dark-haired bearded local as he variously fights, marches and blows a trumpet, and it is with regret that you realise there is no way, 500 years later, of finding out who he was.

Also visible are the charcoal dots pricked through paper on to the walls by Piero's apprentices as a way of transferring the preliminary drawings on to the walls, and the restoration has not been so heavy-handed that the daily division of Piero's work has been obliterated. Fresco work should be done on wet plaster, otherwise it flakes off. The apprentices had to gauge daily which area might be used and wet the plaster accordingly: the resultant small variations in colour have helped art historians learn about the artists.

Piero was famously slow. He started work on the frescoes in around 1452. Born in nearby Borgo San Sepolcro (now Sansepolcro) where he is recorded as a town councillor in 1442, he had started work on the Madonna della Misericordia there in 1445 and his reputation would have come to the attention of the Bacci family in Arezzo, who commissioned him to decorate San Francesco.

As was common practice at the time, Piero included his patrons in the cycle, in pious poses in the presence of the true cross. The story he chose to decorate the church choir was the medieval 'Golden Legend' by Jacopo de Voragine, a tale of redemption through the burial and subsequent rediscovery of the true cross, which starts with Adam's original sin. Piero chose to depict the story artistically rather than chronologically, making best use of the vaulted shape of the building.

On the northern wall is a great battle scene showing the Byzantine Christian emperor Heraclius defeating the Persian king Chosroes. The ferocious and bloody battle is primarily arranged in an early version of perspective, using several rows of foreground figures distinct from the background landscape. It is an extraordinary tour de force that contrasts sharply with the more pastoral scenes above (one of which depicts the walled city of Arezzo as Jerusalem). Piero wrote two treatises on perspective and mathematics, and like his Florentine contemporary Uccello, experimented with architect Alberti's recent theories on perspective and vanishing points.

Arezzo has a few other things to look at: there is a small Piero Magdalen on the wall of the duomo, an imposing church at the town's summit. Vasari, a late Renaissance artist (taught by his distant relation, Signorelli), who wrote The Lives of the Artists (probably the most important source work on Renaissance artists in their context) designed and lived in a house not far from the duomo.

Arezzo is a lovely place to walk around, steep like all Tuscan towns, with beautifully decorated buildings and a shady park at the summit. However, unlike Lucca, where the car is discouraged and everybody rides bikes, cars roar about Arezzo's narrow streets and you often have to jump into doorways. There are two distinct sections: the old walled part on the hill surrounded by ramparts and imposing gates, and the new bustling development below. Hotel rooms go fast, and local hoteliers and restaurateurs show, on the whole, an indifference to their customers which is unusual for the region. The town gets crowded every month for the antiques fair, and shops in the old town stock a wonderful collection of things - particularly ecclesiastical candlesticks, extraordinary telescopes, astrolabes and silver. But although Arezzo is also famed for its gold merchants, there are few bargains to be had.

Florence is the nearest airport to Arezzo, but flights can be overbooked and expensive. We flew from Stansted to Pisa by Ryanair (£54 one way) and hired a car. This airline also flies to Rimini.

Trains: Italy has a superb rail system and Arezzo's station is in the new part of the town, about 10 minutes' walk from the sights.

webTitle: Home is where the class is

fields.headline: Home is where the class is
fields.standfirst: Last week two 13-year-olds who had never been to school won a national story competition. So are more parents teaching their children at home? Maureen Freely investigates
fields.trailText: Take children out of school and you are going to handicap them socially, and probably intellectually, too. That is the line most people in this country take and presumably why there was such a fuss last week about two cousins who won a nationwide story contest sponsored by the Disney Channel.
fields.body:
Education, education, education. League tables and early learning targets. The National Curriculum and performance-related pay. Ofsted inspections. Numeracy hours. Literacy hours. SATs. These are just a few of the tools the Government is using to 'raise standards'. Not everyone is happy about them, but most of us continue to believe that an imperfect school is better than no school at all.

Take children out of school and you are going to handicap them socially, and probably intellectually, too. That is the line most people in this country take and presumably why there was such a fuss last week about two cousins who won a nationwide story contest sponsored by the Disney Channel.

Gus Harris-Read and Arran Vidal-Hall, who live in Devon and are both 13, have never seen the inside of a school. 'I have been given the option,' Arran says, 'but it is something I would never, ever do. I cannot see the point of sitting in a classroom when you could be enjoying yourself learning about things you want to learn, rather than learning only what they decide to teach you.'

It was, one of the boys' fathers claims, an excellent way of producing excellence. 'The children get one-to-one contact and they have huge resources at their disposal. The advantages of home education are so huge that if the parents are properly committed, it cannot fail.'

According to Eileen Wilson, 'informal spokesperson' for Education Otherwise, there are 25,000 British families educating their own children - and the number is growing. The movement is even stronger in Canada, Australia and the United States. It even exists in countries where it is forbidden (Spain and Holland) or discouraged (Germany and Sweden). It is not, she insists, an 'anti-authority thing'.

Wilson says: 'School suits some children very well, but it doesn't suit everyone.' There is no such thing as a typical home-educating parent. 'We have the whole caboodle. We've got a duchess, and lawyers, solicitors and doctors, and we've got gypsies.'

In choosing to educate their children at home, they are exercising a right that most parents do not even know they have. The Education Act 1996 requires that the 'parent of every child of compulsory school age shall cause him to receive efficient full-time education suitable (a) to his age, ability, and aptitude, and (b) to any special educational needs he may have, either by regular attendance at school or otherwise.'

In other words, it is a parent's responsibility to make sure a child gets a proper education, but it is also up to parents to decide what shape that education takes. They do not have to seek permission to educate at home. Although they will probably be inspected once a year, they do not have to be in regular touch with the local education authority and they do not have to have degrees or qualifications. They do not have to follow the National Curriculum, observe the school year, follow a fixed timetable, give formal lessons, or make detailed plans in advance. However, many home-educating parents do.

Almost always, the decision to educate at home begins with what you might call a 'school trauma'. A child starts falling to pieces, and the school either fails to help or refuses to admit a problem exists. Things fell apart for Lucy Woodroffe's daughter, Alice, when she was in her second year at a village infant school. She was in a class of 20 boys and only six girls with a teacher in his first job, and she got lost in the shuffle.

'Every morning, I had to peel her arms off my neck,' Woodroffe recalls. 'At 3.15 I'd come back to a grey-faced child. She was disheartened, sidelined, and miserable. All my hard work building my lovely daughter was falling away.' So she deregistered her.

Seven years on, she is still home-educating Alice and her younger sister, as well as three other children who live in the same idyllic valley just outside Bath. The children have three intense hours in the morning and then less structured lessons in Spanish, music, drama, and science in the afternoon. They work with eight different qualified teachers. The day I went to visit they were with their philosophy teacher, who was about to take three of them on a nature walk. 'He can also teach them about birds, trees, hedge-lanes, flyfishing, history, Chaucer, Keats and even the Communist Party, of which he was once a member.'

It costs her about £12,000 a year to keep it all going. She doesn't ask the other parents to pay anything unless they can afford it. All the children are performing well above the standards they would be held to if they were in a formal school - Alice, now 13, will probably take her GCSEs a year early. They try to stick to the school year - this is partly because one of the other mothers is a teacher at a highly-regarded private girl's school. She insists her decision to take her son out of school was not ideological, but practical.

Home education suits him because 'he's a self-motivating boy who can sit down and draw for four or five hours and likes to write poems.' It would not, she thinks, suit his younger brother, 'who loves big social groups and parties and a busy lifestyle'.

For Naomi Ellis, homeschooling began as a temporary solution to a problem. Her family moved from London to Washington when her son was five. She did not think much of the local schools and decided to try homeschooling after she made friends with another woman who was already doing it. This same woman was her entrée to what turned out to be a vast and very unusual network. Some were schooling their children at home because they were fundamentalist Christians, others were from military backgrounds and rejected the school system because it did not require children to pledge allegiance to the flag.

Others were new age or, like her, professionals-turned-stay-at-home mothers. There were so many of them that they organised excursions and special classes. There was also a support group for mothers, which she found very helpful - and missed a lot when her family moved back to London.

In England there was not a big enough network but Ellis kept her son out of school for another year. Then she decided he was ready for formal education. If he's doing well, it is, she thinks, thanks to the grounding and the focused attention he got during two years he spent at home. 'I'm still not totally committed to the school system. Why should I be?'

If state education were her only option, she'd have removed him from school again in a flash. 'The state schools are doing so badly that it's hard to see how parents could achieve less. All they have to do is leave the television off. Even if all the children do is study the patterns in the carpet, they'll learn more.'

But for most home-educating parents in this country, questions of educational quality are secondary. Here we come to the ugly side of the story - Wilson says that in 99 cases out of a hundred, bullying makes parents take their children out of school.

The picture gets even uglier when you talk to Chris Smith, who runs Educate, an online service for home-educating parents, and who has counselled many home-educating parents in distress. His worst story is about a school that told one mother it was illegal for her to take her child out of school following the suicide of that child's brother, who had been bullied.

He has other stories about threatening inspectors, and education authorities that put home-educated children on the at-risk register. 'Most home-educating parents are worried that the right to educate their children will be taken away from them, so they do not like to stick their heads over the parapet.'

Smith is more confident - why would they meddle with a group of people who are getting excellent results? He was positively poetic when he described his daughter, who is so curious about the world and so at ease with all age groups; he takes so much more pleasure in her education than she would if she had to plod through the National Curriculum.

A proper education, says Lucy Woodroffe, should not be about turning children into obedient little soldiers, but teaching children to enjoy thinking, and to think independently to a high standard. Imposed standards and standardised tests reward narrow, rote thinking and so produce the opposite result. There are plenty of teachers who would agree with her.

Every time I go to talk to my children's teachers, I hear about the little things they are struggling to do above the National Curriculum, to try to get the children 'to think across the disciplines'. But so long as they are in that system, they have no choice but to obey the rules. It's the same with parents. Would they be more inclined to complain, I wonder, if they knew their rights?

www.education-otherwise.org www.educate.co.uk

fields.headline: Videos  by Philip French
fields.standfirst: The Sixth Sense | Kenneth Anger Volume 1, 2, 3 | Casablanca | eXistenZ
fields.trailText: The Sixth Sense | Kenneth Anger Volume 1, 2, 3 | Casablanca | eXistenZ
fields.body:
The Sixth Sense

(1999, 15, Buena Vista, VHS/Rental, DVD/Retail)

One of the two surprise runaway American successes of last year (the other was The Blair Witch Project ) M. Night Shyamalan's occult thriller gives Bruce Willis a fine role as a troubled Philadelphian child psychologist redeeming himself by helping a tormented eight-year-old lad. A scary, well-controlled story with a twist in its tail.

Kenneth Anger Volume 1, 2, 3

(1947-1980, 15/18, BFI, VHs/Retail, Rental)

The valuable BFI series of avant-garde classics continues with the near-complete works of the legendary gay underground director who started out as a three-year-old child actor in Reinhardt's 1935 A Midsummer Night's Dream , and burst onto the scene with his homoerotic film club classic Fireworks in 1947 aged 17, before compiling the classic work of Tinseltown gossip Hollywood Babylon . His bizarre life (well related in Bill Landis's frank 1995 biography) put him in touch with diabolist Aleister Crowley, Mick Jagger and the Manson Gang, and Mapplethorpe, Scorsese, Fassbinder and Lynch have acknowledged his influence.

Anger's three masterpieces are the monochrome sado-masochistic Fireworks ; the witty celebration of biker culture, Scorpio Rising (1964), which was prosecuted for obscenity because Anger cross-cut between gatherings of gay Hell's Angels and Christ's disciples; and Lucifer Rising (1973), a mishmash of Crowleyesque black magic and oriental religions, with Donald Cammell as Isis and Marianne Faithfull as Lilith.

Casablanca

(1942, U, Warner Bros, DVD/Retail)

Available on DVD for the first time in a sparkling new copy, this is one of the most magical pictures ever made, where the perfect actors, writers, director, composer and producer suddenly came together at a crucial moment of World War II- serendipity serving the Zeitgeist. Bogart's widow Lauren Bacall introduces an accompanying feature in which some happy survivors of the production recall the experience. She also presents extracts from TV attempts to revive Casablanca , and the Loony Tunes cartoon Carrotblanca starring Bugs Bunny as Rick.

eXistenZ

(1999, 15, Alliance Atlantis, VHS/Rental, DVD/Retail)

Canadian director David Cronenberg's SF horror flick continues his obsession with the human body's vulnerability to disease, decay, penetration, destruction and transformation. His queasy-making picture turns on a giant corporation trying out its latest virtual reality, interactive game on a panel of loonies. Jennifer Jason Leigh is the inventor, and this short, sharp Chinese box picture is designed to churn the stomach of the most detached viewer.

His queasy-making picture turns on a giant corporation trying out its latest virtual reality, interactive game on a panel of loonies. Jennifer Jason Leigh is the inventor, and this short, sharp Chinese box picture is designed to churn the stomach of the most detached viewer.

fields.headline: Done Roman - Ridley Scott
fields.standfirst: For the maker of Alien and Blade Runner, lionised by David Puttnam, the future seems to be in the past. Gladiator, the first Roman epic Hollywood has made in several decades, is a box-office sensation in the US.
fields.trailText: For the maker of Alien and Blade Runner, lionised by David Puttnam, the future seems to be in the past. His latest film, Gladiator, the first Roman epic Hollywood has made in several decades, is a box-office sensation in the US.
fields.body:
There's something not very English about doing everything on the grandest possible scale. But film-maker Ridley Scott - 'the greatest visual stylist working today', according to fellow director Alan Parker - has never worried about doing things the English way. And the 'grandest possible scale' is the only way to describe Gladiator, his new film which boasts a sweet $100 million budget.

Scott's epic, the first major Hollywood film about ancient Rome made in more than three decades, promises to be the biggest hit of the year. It's not subtle, but it is massively entertaining. Scott is an Englishman Hollywood loves. He has made three massively influential films: Alien, Blade Runner and Thelma and Louise, and is the walking refutation of François Truffaut's claim that the British are temperamentally unsuited to the aesthetics of film-making. (Directing aside, Scott is a producer, co-owner of Scott Free films and Shepperton Studios, and founder of the advertising production giant, Ridley Scott Associates.)

David, now Lord, Puttnam, who produced Scott's first feature, The Duellists, has no time for those who think that Scott allows style to overpower content. 'I remember someone criticising Ridley, saying "the images are too perfect". It's a bit like saying to Rembrandt "you paint too well". In the end he has a tremendous eye. What do you do, deny it? Pretend you don't have it?'

Despite the larger-than-life image - £20 Monte Cristos, pricey cars, expansive offices - Scott says he enjoys the fact that his films are more famous than his face. 'I like it that way. I do what I do.' And he once said 'as an Englishman, I am aghast at emotional intensity'. He describes himself as 'introspective', especially when compared with his brother, Tony, the director of Top Gun and Tinseltown playboy who once had an affair with Bridget Neilsen. 'Ridley is not one to open up and let you know what he really thinks or feels,' according to Alan Parker.

His private life - divorced, he now lives alone - remains largely under wraps. On the other hand, he mixes family and work. As well as nurturing his brother's career, his two sons and his daughter have followed him into the family business. Jake Scott made his feature debut with Plunkett and Macleane last year: the film shares a cinematographer and costume designer with Gladiator, and Jake made no attempt to hide his father's overwhelming influence.

Ridley Scott was born in South Shields in 1937. His father, who had worked in shipping, had a good war, rising to acting-brigadier and staying on in the Army. Scott himself considered joining the Marines when he was 19 - 'I like organisation' - but his father told him to go to art school instead. 'I was good at art, drawing and painting. Obsessed by it at 11 and 12.' His mother loved the movies, taking him to see such films as Gilda and - crucially - Citizen Kane. (One of the many films Scott planned and failed to direct was RKO 281, about the making of Kane, a story Scott described as 'art against commerce'. Eventually, Scott produced a cut-price version for the upmarket HBO cable network.)

After the war, the family lived in Germany before returning to the North-East: by the time he had done his A-levels, Scott had been to 10 schools. He went to the West Hartlepool College of Art and then to the Royal College of Art, where he made his first short film, Boy on a Bicycle, starring his younger brother, Tony, and his father. By the early Sixties he was working as a designer at the BBC, shifting to directing episodes of Z Cars and The Informer. But he felt restricted by television.

He switched to advertising. 'It was my film school,' he has said. 'The opportunity of making commercials was tremendous. I was able to be the insane perfectionist, controlling all the elements in one neat capsule.' He quickly made a name for himself, and in 1967 founded Ridley Scott Associates, still one of the major forces in ad production. Taking his inspiration from the US, he changed the way commercials were made. 'Most commercials were directed by feature directors who didn't give a shit about advertising. They thought that there was no art, no craft, no skill. I was the first of a new batch of directors who were determined to make it a craft.'

His main rival was Alan Parker. According to Tim Delaney, group chairman of advertising agency Leagas Delaney: 'If you had a dialogue thing you went to Alan, if you had a visual thing you went to Ridley. There were no other contenders.' Scott's nostalgic Hovis ads were classics, with feature-film production values. 'I always regarded commercials as films. It would irritate the ad agencies - it's a commercial and he's doing a feature, they'd say.'

By the time Scott came to direct his first feature, at the comparatively late age of 39, he was already powerful and living in a seventeenth-century house in Gloucester. But it took him several years to get a viable feature project. He came close with Ronnie and Leo, a violent black comedy that was going to star Michael York. Since Scott had never made a comedy, there's something intriguing about the idea.

Instead, he got his chance as an indirect consequence of Parker's success, as David Puttnam explains. 'I started working with Ridley to develop a couple of screenplays. We had what became The Duellists, and The Gunpowder Plot. Parker's Bugsy Malone was presented at Cannes and was an absolutely phenomenal success, and as I left the cinema the guy from Paramount, David Picker, said "This is an extraordinary talent. Do you know anyone else like him?" And I said, "A chap called Ridley Scott." So he said, "I'd like to meet him."

'I went straight from the cinema, phoned Ridley at home, told him to jump on a plane first thing tomorrow morning. Lunchtime the following day we were on the beach - this is a Cannes story par excellence - making a deal. When we got to the crux of what film we were going to do (we had the two scripts) I said one will cost two million and one we can make for 1.2 million and Picker said, "I'll take the cheaper one." We both nodded. Six months later we were making The Duellists.'

Based on a Joseph Conrad story about two French officers who continue their personal fights throughout the Napoleonic wars, The Duellists set the tone for Scott's career: it looked stunning. The casting also showed Scott's ambitions: British stars Albert Finney and Edward Fox played supporting roles to Americans Keith Carradine and Harvey Keitel. The film was well received at Cannes in 1977 but received only a seven-print release in the US.

But Scott was determined not to languish in the art-house ghetto. By then, a generation of advertising-bred British directors was emerging, led by Parker and including Hugh Hudson (Chariots Of Fire ), Adrian Lyne ( Flashdance ) and - shortly afterwards - Tony Scott. David Puttnam oversaw their rise. 'They had a visual sense which was a significant step on from the generation before them. Don't forget that there was not much of a gap between them and the Tony Richardson-Karel Reisz generation. I think the films just looked more handsome, because they didn't come from a documentary tradition. One of the reasons I didn't carry on working with Ridley was because I had a hankering to make films that were more gritty: Midnight Express, The Killing Fields. He wanted to make Alien - I had no interest in science fiction. I think on balance he was right.'

Scott has also said he had had no interest in science fiction before Star Wars, but his next two films fell into that bracket, and made his reputation. The first was Alien. Scott was drawn towards the film because 'the script was short, specific and unbelievably violent'. The design - by Swiss artist H.R. Giger - might have been the film's obvious strength, but Scott took great care to induce tension and fear amongst the cast, telling them as little as possible about the chest-burst scene and filming their shocked faces in one take. David Puttnam insists that Scott is much better director of actors than he is given credit for. He was very tough on Sigourney Weaver, but the film made her both a star and an icon. The film was a huge success.

Blade Runner wasn't. Again, Scott's perfectionism - or obsessiveness - caused problems with the crew, and the American unions, who wouldn't let him operate his own camera. 'Ridley brought out the best in people, but he was difficult,' production designer Lawrence Paull said. The production company decided that the film was too confusing, and insisted on a voiceover and a tacked-on happy ending that Scott hated. But the film's vision of a broken-down future filled with linguistic chaos (plus smoke and neon) was enormously influential. It did badly at the box office, and critics, including the New Yorker's Pauline Kael, savaged it, but by the end of the Eighties academics were treating it as the decade's most important film, a benchmark of postmodernism. It also ran and ran in late-night showings.

In 1992, something approaching Scott's original edit was released as the 'Director's Cut'. Scott, naturally, still wasn't satisfied. By the time that opinions were revised on Blade Runner, Scott was being overshadowed by his brother, who had enormous box-office success with Top Gun and Beverly Hills Cop II. Meanwhile, Ridley had made the fantasy flop Legend (1985) - with a young Tom Cruise - an excellent romantic thriller, Someone To Watch Over Me (1987), and Black Rain (1989) with Michael Douglas, which seemed largely designed to prove that Japanese cities looked just like the LA of Blade Runner.

Scott's next film came as a surprise. The fact that most of the action takes place in the daytime was enough to set Thelma and Louise apart from previous films, before you even got into the sexual politics of the piece. It is also warmer, funnier and more focused on character than any of his films, bar Someone To Watch Over Me. Scott even cast Harvey Keitel against type as a nice cop. It seemed to promise Scott a way out of his own straitjacket, but of the films that followed - 1492: Conquest Of Paradise (1992), White Squall (1996) and GI Jane (1997), in which Demi Moore screams 'Suck my dick!' - the less said the better.

All the while, Scott has continued to make ads - including a 1984-inspired promotion for Macintosh which was only shown once (to create the sense of an event) and is a legend in the advertising world, and the first of the BT 'It's good to talk' commercials with Bob Hoskins.

This was one of the things perceived as setting the Scott brothers apart from the British film establishment. Their lack of a theatrical background might have been the secret of their success as film-makers, but - Soho wisdom had it - it made them different. They were too Hollywood, even if Scott lives much of the time in Hampstead when not on location. But as Alan Parker now is the British film establishment, the Scotts can hardly be considered outsiders. In any event, there was a great fanfare when the Scott brothers bought Shepperton Studios in 1995. At times, Scott has seemed as interested in business as films. 'I think he likes business,' David Puttnam says. 'But I don't think his best friends would call him a particularly good businessman. I always thought that if Ridley had concentrated solely on making movies he would have a clutch of Oscars under his belt, because he certainly has the talent. He has just allowed himself, all too often, to get distracted. I just wish he devoted more time to his film-making because along the way there have been films that didn't do his talent justice.' Ridley Scott is currently working on Hannibal, the sequel to Silence Of The Lambs. Both Jodie Foster and Jonathan Demme passed on it, Demme because he found the book too lurid. But Thomas Harris's books have been excellent movie material - Michael Mann's Manhunter is probably better than Silence Of The Lambs - which gives Scott a chance to enter the most consistent period of his career.

And finally, in his sixties, fulfil his potential. David Puttnam argues: 'In his oeuvre, there are half a dozen really great movies. All I'm saying is, that there should have been a dozen, because he had it in him.'

Ridley Scott

Born: South Shields, 30 November 1937

Studied: West Hartlepool College of Art, Royal College of Art

Job: Film director, ad maker

Previous jobs: Television designer and director ( Z Cars, The Informer, Adam Adamant Lives )

First film: Boy on a Bicycle (starring his brother, Tony, and his father)

Notable films: The Duellists, Alien, Blade Runner, Black Rain, Thelma and Louise

Latest film: Gladiator (shot in Malta)

Next film: Hannibal

Notable ads: Hovis, BT's It's Good to Talk

fields.headline: Pulp Fiction II
fields.standfirst: Hollywood's sleaze-meister is back with a new potboiler
fields.trailText: Hollywood's sleaze-meister is back with a new potboiler
fields.body:
Joe Eszterhas is making something of a comeback. But it's not because the notorious screen hack needs the money. The screenwriter penned a succession of lurid scripts which sent studio heads into a bidding frenzy and made him very rich. Even before Hollywood madam Heidi Fleiss threatened to write her memoirs, Eszterhas's scripts proved LA folk were truly interested in the written word.

After hits such as Jagged Edge, Flashdance and Basic Instinct, which he sold for a then record $3 million, he earned $4m for his explicit tale of yuppie adultery, One Night Stand. Eventually director Mike Figgis radically reworked the script. Eszterhas was unperturbed, though; he was a screenwriter able to command huge fees and a percentage of box-office revenue.

After burning brightly for over a decade, Eszterhas's star waned following a succession of disappointments: Jade, Burn, Hollywood, Burn and Showgirls. The latter, a rites of passage sleaze-fest, aimed squarely at top shelf moviegoers, was absymal. As one critic quipped: 'It contains so much nudity that the sexy parts are when the girls put on their clothes.' For a while his scripts still sold for ludicrous amounts, but the stench of Showgirls, not the sweet smell of success wafted from the pages and they were not filmed. Since 1997 Eszterhas, previously one of the industry's most quotable figures, has shunned the limelight, telling Variety in 1998: 'I began to feel my public persona had overwhelmed what I did for a living, which is to sit at my desk writing scripts.'

Now the former journalist has returned with a non-fiction book, which has already attracted Hollywood interest. Not surprisingly, American Rhapsody promises to be a racy read. It deals with the confluence of Hollywood, politics and the Monica Lewinsky scandal.

Eszterhas's return is unlikely to lead to a repeat of his halcyon years. The potboiler plots and two-dimensional ballsy women he favoured are now an anachronism. And yet, his popular touch and showbiz acumen are unquestionable.

And Hollywood always needs pulp movies. Basic Instinct 2 is in the works and while Sharon Stone has declined, Eszterhas could be tempted. Maybe he could ask Monica to play the leading role.

fields.headline: Chaos theory hits LA
fields.standfirst: On-set misery is Hollywood's latest fashion, as high-profile productions, from  Charlie's Angels to  Mission: Impossible 2, are beset with feuds, fights and stars going AWOL. But, why worry, asks  Mark Morris. On-set flaps often produce great films
fields.trailText: On-set misery is Hollywood's latest fashion, as high-profile productions, from Charlie's Angels to Mission: Impossible 2, are beset with feuds, fights and stars going AWOL. But, why worry, asks Mark Morris. On-set flaps often produce great films
fields.body:
For anyone who likes to see the chinks in the Hollywood publicity machine, the last two weeks have been bliss. There have been stories of fighting on the set of Charlie's Angels, feuding between Samuel L. Jackson and the director and crew of Shaft, plus the news that shooting has finally finished on the crisis-plagued Town And Country and that Mission: Impossible 2 (pictured) needs to be completely re-edited.

As gossip, these stories are great. As a chance to indulge in a little Schadenfreude at the expense of the rich and beautiful, they are priceless. But for publications covering these stories, there is a justification that puts printing this stuff slightly above mere scandal-mongering. Call it the Heaven's Gate defence, or the Waterworld exemption. Tales of the raging egos of Jackson or Town And Country star Warren Beatty are fair game because chaos in production often equals critical and commercial disaster later on.

This is sober business news. That theory might actually work with Town And Country. A comedy about two husbands leaving their wives, the budget has swollen to $82 million, making it hard to see how the film will ever turn a profit. And the fingers pointed to Beatty, who finds it almost impossible to just star in film - he has to make decisions. But Michael De Luca from New Line pictures has accepted the blame.

The problem began when De Luca decided to push shooting ahead to fit the schedules of his chosen cast - Beatty, Diane Keaton and Garry Shandling. The hitch? The script wasn't ready. The film went ahead anyway, with an ending nobody liked. The film wrapped in April 1999, but preview audiences hated it so much that the cast - who had finished their next films - were called back a year later to reshoot the ending and various other scenes. All this - including emergency rewrites by Buck Henry and Pleasantville director Gary Ross - has doubled the budget.

The Charlie's Angels stories are juicier. Ally McBeal star Lucy Liu and Bill Murray (who plays Bosley) shut down production for a day with an argument which according to some (denied) reports ended with Liu hitting Murray. Liu had a problem with the script, although which one might be a fair question since they have reached the 30th draft. Murray tried to defend the writers and Liu turned on him. There have also been suggestions that she was annoyed by the difference between her wage and those of her more famous fellow Angels, Drew Barrymore and Cameron Diaz. All of which was tough on Barrymore, who has been understandably tearful since her boyfriend, MTV comedian Tom Green, discovered he had testicular cancer.

It came as almost incidental news that the three original Angels had turned down $100,000 apiece to do the customary cameo in the film. Jaclyn Smith just said no, Kate Jackson wanted to play a villain, and Farah Fawcett reportedly wanted to do a love scene with the never-seen Charlie. The producers turned down both ideas. But at least Smith, Jackson and Fawcett got offers, which is more than can be said for replacement Angels Cheryl Ladd and Tanya Roberts.

Over on the reactivated set of Shaft, they have been shooting a sex scene with out the presence of the star, Samuel L. Jackson. Jackson has a good excuse: he's busy with his next film, and it is not his fault that test audiences felt that the film had forgotten the part about Shaft being 'a sex machine with all the chicks'.

But the rumours have it that the crew were glad it was a body double and not Jackson doing the new title sequence of two shadowy figures in bed. The New York Post has an unidentified source saying: 'Nobody could stand the idea of having to work with him again. So they found a way to do it without having him back. Him, his entourage, and his private planes.' The story goes that Jackson kept slipping off to the golf course.

Meanwhile, director John Singleton (Boyz N The Hood) was nipping into his trailer with a variety of extras. And feuding with producer Scott Rudin about the lack of black faces in the crew. Jackson, in turn, has suggested that he will be back for the sequel but Singleton won't.

And then there is Mission: Impossible 2, scheduled for release at Christmas last year, but delayed because Tom Cruise was trapped on Eyes Wide Shut. Now editor/director Stuart Baird has been hired, at an estimated cost of $750,000, for three weeks' work, to cut the $180m film into shape. All this hasty last-minute fixing suggests that M:I-2, like Charlie's Angels, has the doomed aura of the next Waterworld to it, right?

Not necessarily. In spring and summer 1997, there was a film that seemed certain to follow in the footsteps of Kevin Costner's folly. Like Waterworld, it was set at sea, which always causes production nightmare. The stars - especially the leading actress - were publicly feuding with the director. One night, the whole crew fell ill after eating lobster chowder that had been spiked, possibly with PCP (angel dust). There were rumours of near-drownings. The Screen Actors Guild sent a team to the set to investigate what was being done to its members. The sprawling running time was hopelessly uncommercial, which was troubling because the budget had spiralled into record territory: just to break even, it would have be one of the most successful films ever. To spread the pain, Fox had sold the US rights to Paramount for $65m. The press gleefully reported each new crisis. The massive waste of money was the angle until a couple of weeks before Titanic was released, at which point the whole story changed swiftly.

There's nothing unique about the Titanic saga. In any business textbook, Gone With The Wind would be a great example of how not to make a film. It started shooting without a finished script or a female lead. George Cukor, the first director, was fired - reputedly on the orders of Clark Gable, uncomfortable with Cukor's homosexuality. His replacement, Victor Fleming, had a breakdown and Sam Wood finished the film. Ben Hecht was able to pick up $10,000 for a single week's work on the script. It was, inevitably, the most expensive film that had ever been made.

And if Town And Country has had problems with its ending, that might be the only thing it has in common with Casablanca, which was driven ahead even though no one knew how the story would finish. Ingrid Bergman was driven to distraction, not knowing who her character was going to end up with. The team scriptwriters somehow stumbled towards the right answer. With Titanic or Gone With The Wind, success had the effect of gently relegating the struggle of making the film to a footnote.

With Apocalypse Now, the legend of the making of the film and the film itself are complementary. Coppola had already survived The Godfather, which he himself was convinced was a disaster until it was released. There is squabbling to this day over who was responsible for the final edit. But that turned out to be a mere taster for the horrors of Apocalypse Now. It started with the sacking of Harvey Keitel and continued with Martin Sheen's heart attack, the massive drug abuse, the storm-smashed sets, the arguments with the Philippines air force over the use of helicopters that were fighting a real war, the three years it took to make the film, Brando, the budget that tripled and, yes, the fumbling towards an ending when most of the film had been shot.

At the time, Coppola looked to have been outmanoeuvred by Michael Cimino, whose The Deer Hunter was as ambitious but much cheaper, released much sooner and got better reviews. But as time goes on, the myth of Apocalypse Now has given it the edge: because Coppola really had hauled his cast, crew and family up river, into the heart of darkness.

And famous flops have emerged without long foreshadowings of what was to happen. It's hard to cut through the bland interview ritual where stars insist that working on a film has been fun, but here's Ewan McGregor promoting the Danny Boyle miscue A Life Less Ordinary: 'It's a fucking cracking movie. Let's talk about it, as long as we can stress how fucking great Cameron Diaz is. She the best!' For a few months, McGregor and Diaz were a ubiquitous pair, to emphasise the incredible screen chemistry they had. However much fun they were having, it didn't show in the film.

Or how about Airplane director claiming South Park creators Trey Parker and Matt Stone were 'as good as the Jim Carreys and Eddie Murphys' when they starred in his comedy BASEketball. The film was grounded in the mutual admiration between director and stars, but despite being released at the height of South Park mania it was a box-office disaster and went straight-to-video here.

And while everyone decided that Waterworld was going to be one of the biggest flops in movie history while it was being made, no one talked much about The Postman until the trailers appeared and provoked audience hysterics. Not made at sea, it didn't have the production traumas of its predecessor. It was, however, an even worse film. While Waterworld probably broke even in the end, The Postman never will. It certainly seems like the film that didn't cause fights on set, because no one was allowed to challenge director and star Costner's vision. Punch-ups, rows, reshoots: all these things at least suggest that someone is trying to save a film. With The Postman, no one realised until it was too late that the film was in trouble. Get all the voyeuristic kicks you can from stories of on-set nightmares, but politely ignore anyone who tells you they are portents of doom for a film.
