fields.headline: The trouble with Carrey
fields.standfirst: Jim Carrey's excellent as Andy Kaufman, but at the end, we still don't know what made the comic tick
fields.trailText: Philip French: In Jim Carrey's bravura performance, Kaufman is always performing. The movie is a single, extended turn that incorporates smaller ones on and off stage
fields.body:
After fleeing from Nazi Germany, Fritz Lang spent two years travelling the United States, steeping himself in the culture before making his first Hollywood movie, the very American Fury in 1936.

Milos Forman did something similar when he quit Czechoslovakia after the Russian tanks rolled into Prague in 1968. He'd become the leading light of the Czech new wave with his quirky celebrations of non-conformity and eccentricity - Black Peter, Loves of a Blonde and The Firemen's Ball. Three years later, though pursuing similar themes, he emerged as an American director with Taking Off, his comedy of life on both sides of the generation gap produced by the emergence of the 1960s counterculture. It remains one of the best films on that turbulent period.

Since then, Forman has been at his best dealing with anti-authoritarian outsiders in America, such as the rebellious Randall P McMurphy leading the asylum inmates of One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest and the libertarian porn-merchant defending free speech in The People v Larry Flynt. He's been least good revisiting Europe to direct the staid costume movies Amadeus and Valmont.

Forman might well have made Ed Wood, but instead he engaged the authors of its screenplay, Scott Alexander and Larry Karaszewski, to write Man on the Moon, a movie about Andy Kaufman, the oddball comedian whose true aims are as difficult to pin down as Larry Flynt's.

Kaufman emerged from a middle-class Jewish home on Long Island to puzzle, amuse and disturb America for a decade before dying of a rare form of lung cancer in 1984 at the age of 35. He is best known outside America for his role as Latka Gravas, the syntactically-challenged immigrant engineer, one of the regular blue-collar eccentrics in the cult sitcom Taxi, which ran from 1978 to 1983.

This delightful piece of character comedy endeared him to the general public, but his significance resides in the way he set out to provoke, annoy and alienate both his audience and his colleagues. Kaufman invented an alter ego, or rather an alter id, called Tony Clifton, a slobbish, racist, third-rate Las Vegas club performer, usually played by himself but occasionally by his partner and fellow provocateur, Bob Zmuda, and they even managed to get Clifton ejected from the Paramount lot.

Kaufman deliberately got up the nostrils of women and Southerners by staging bouts of all-in wrestling between himself and female challengers in Memphis. He emptied an auditorium of student fans in Arizona by refusing to reprise Latka Gravas for them and instead reading the whole of The Great Gatsby in a fruity English accent. He booked Carnegie Hall for a concert, but confronted those who came to be outraged with a kitschy version of a Radio City Music Hall Christmas show complete with Rockettes and Santa Claus. Eventually, he achieved his ambition of estranging most of his followers and failing to be believed when he said he had cancer.

Kaufman was a role player in the tradition of that archetypal American figure, the chameleon confidence trickster and, in Jim Carrey's bravura performance, Kaufman is always performing. The movie is a single, extended turn that incorporates smaller ones on and off stage.

Forman uses his formidable skills as a documentarian and a director of actors to recreate TV appearances, club acts and stage shows. They're indistinguishable from the real thing and, in fact, the scenes involving Taxi are performed by Carrey with Christopher Lloyd, Marilu Henner, Judd Hirsch, Carol Kane and other members of the original cast. Of course, Danny De Vito can't play himself in Taxi as he's been cast as George Shapiro, Kaufman's devoted but constantly exasperated agent.

Shapiro, De Vito and Bob Zmuda have co-produced the film, with Kaufman's live-in girlfriend, Lynne Margulies (played on screen by Courtney Love), as 'creative consultant'. But either these friends are determined to preserve Kaufman's central mystery or they don't know what makes him tick.

'That kid is totally meshugga,' Andy's father says, using an affectionate Yiddish term for madness. 'You're insane but you might be brilliant,' says Shapiro after signing him up. 'I don't do jokes; I don't know what's funny; I'm just a song-and-dance man,' says Kaufman.

We're left to make up our own minds and to me Kaufman seems a descendant of two figures from the 1950s - Guy Grand, the malevolent practical joker in Terry Southern's The Magic Christian and Lenny Bruce - satirists who were obsessed with the essential absurdity of life who ventured beyond the realms of morality and reason.

Certainly, Kaufman denies people the traditional consolations of humour, though when he engaged in transcendental meditation, was he seeking something or sending it up? And when he took a sentimental turn, was he exposing American sentimentality or embracing it?

Observing the proceedings, incidentally, is Victor Schiavelli, a curious, very un-American-looking actor with a long, thin face, high forehead and piercing eyes, who has recurred in Forman's movies since he appeared in Taking Off as the supercilious hippie who instructs members of the Society for the Parents of Fugitive Children on the etiquette of pot-smoking.

Here, he's a TV executive, variously infuriated, baffled and amused by Kaufman and, one suspects, he's reflecting Forman's own response. I'd have to say, though, that Kaufman, whose Tony Clifton persona is close to Sir Les Patterson, is a good deal less funny than his postmodern contemporary, Barry Humphries.

fields.headline: Who minds the credibility gap?
fields.trailText: America's editors think they have an incredible problem: Joe Public doesn't find the stories they write credible any longer. Fifteen years ago, 55 per cent of their readers thought that newspapers got their facts right 'most of the time'. Now that figure hovers wanly in the mid-thirties.
fields.body:
America's editors think they have an incredible problem: Joe Public doesn't find the stories they write credible any longer.

Fifteen years ago, 55 per cent of their readers thought that newspapers got their facts right 'most of the time'. Now that figure hovers wanly in the mid-thirties. And if you're not believed, the editors cry, you don't count.

What has gone wrong? Several layers of hair-shirt promptly feature: inaccurate reporting, perceived bias, sensationalism - and the exaltation of profit above the public interest. Yet it's what the papers are trying to do about it that is most fascinating to a British visitor surveying the scene at last week's International Press Institute Conference in Boston.

The $1.2 million campaign called Project Credibility looks, at first sight, like a crash course in civics: open-access columns for readers to criticise their papers anonymously; community meetings; accuracy check lists; content audits; and standing invitations to the public to come in and proof-read for a day. No worthy or earnest notion is left unturned - except the big and obvious one.

The American Society of Newspaper Editors has no code of practice or hint of self-regulation. Raise that prospect with otherwise distraught editors and they dive for cover, citing the First Amendment.

The press councils which grew in the Fifties remain in only a couple of states. Newsroom autonomy is absolute. The big chains allow no outside meddling in their ethical patch.

You couldn't have a greater contrast with Britain. Our press has its own credibility gaps, of course (though the trust statistics are rather better here), but the newspaper industry did at least join forces to agree a code that covers everybody - and an independent commission to supervise it.

This may not make for an altogether purer world, but in terms of joint action and effectiveness, we are light years ahead.

Does credibility matter? In one way, not as much as you'd suppose. There is no evident correlation between sales figures and reader trust. Indeed, rather the reverse. The least trusted papers are often the biggest sellers, whatever the punters tell the pollsters. Human hypocrisy always rules OK - and some of the American wittering often seems, to be frank, more concerned with chumminess in the country clubs than anything more elevated.

The argument, though, has suddenly become more complex and urgent. Joseph Nye, director of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, put it starkly to one IPI session.

In the information age, he said, the staple, precious diet of newspapers down the ages - information itself - had turned from a scarce resource into a torrent of facts. Now the shortage was 'attention time'. If newspapers wanted to survive the Internet, they had to be trusted guides to their readers, sources of wisdom and knowledge which could sift out the information that matters.

Credibility, in short, is about to become the essential ingredient that separates successful news websites from the rest. Will the American industry get that point quickly enough? Don't bet on it. The lessons of Monica Lewinsky haven't exactly bulwarked reporting of Elián González these past two weeks. Time-Warner's open row with Disney over cable TV access has put the profit motive up in lights. Any real move on ethics appears further away than ever.

Could British newspapers, just down the road, come to bless the PCC for helping them clean up their act? It's an unlikely thought when you remember the fear and loathing surrounding the commission's birth, but not an incredible one.

Meanwhile, the old debates about press freedom are taking on a new Net dimension, too. The World Times and big US research company IDC have just published their latest Information Society Index, the international league table of the information revolution.

They take 23 different indicators - from installed PCs to e-commerce volume - and apply them to countries around the world. Good news for Tony Blair. Britain is up two places to number 12 as one of the six fastest-improving nations on Earth - handily ahead of Germany, France, Italy and Spain. A first division performance.

The less euphoric news is that we still trail far behind the US and the four Scandinavian countries (Sweden is the new top of the shop, with Finland, Denmark and Norway all in the first five). Fifteen years ago, 55 per cent of their readers thought that newspapers got their facts right 'most of the time'. Now that figure hovers wanly in the mid-thirties. And if you're not believed, the editors cry, you don't count. What has gone wrong? Several layers of hair-shirt promptly feature: inaccurate reporting, perceived bias, sensationalism - and the exaltation of profit above the public interest. Raise that prospect with otherwise distraught editors and they dive for cover, citing the First Amendment. The press councils which grew in the Fifties remain in only a couple of states. Newsroom autonomy is absolute. The big chains allow no outside meddling in their ethical patch. You couldn't have a greater contrast with Britain. There is no evident correlation between sales figures and reader trust. Indeed, rather the reverse. The least trusted papers are often the biggest sellers, whatever the punters tell the pollsters. webTitle: Corus: No UK plant is safe

fields.headline: Corus: No UK plant is safe
fields.trailText: The jobs of 3,000 workers at steelmaker Corus's flagship Llanwern plant in south Wales are threatened this weekend by the deepening crisis in British manufacturing.
fields.body:
The jobs of 3,000 workers at steelmaker Corus's flagship Llanwern plant in south Wales are threatened this weekend by the deepening crisis in British manufacturing.

There is a 'very real threat' of it closing, said one union leader. And the company, formed from British Steel and the Dutch firm Hoogovens, warned Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers last week that none of its UK plants was safe.

In a series of urgent talks, the unions and Corus told Byers and other Ministers of the devastating impact of the strong pound and the Rover and Ford crises on the future of UK steel manufacturing.

Sir Ken Jackson, head of the Amalgamated Electrical and Engineering Union, told The Observer: 'Llanwern is on the brink.'

The problems are spreading to core sectors of Britain's industrial base. Ministers now fear that manufacturing could drop below 20 per cent of the gross domestic product, bringing disaster to Labour's heartlands.

Rover and Ford account for 400,000 tonnes a year of Corus' strip steel, which comes from UK plants.

A Corus spokesman said production was likely to switch to its Continental plants when Ford's new Fiesta model was produced only at the car firm's mainland factories from early next year. The current Fiesta is made at Dagenham, too, and the east London plant may stop making cars altogether.

The AEEU's national officer for metals, Bob Shannon, met Corus excutives last Thursday and was told that Llanwern was in imminent danger. Other Corus plants are also under threat, including another Welsh strip mill at Port Talbot, which employs 3,200 people.

Jackson warned Byers: 'Llanwern is on the brink. There is a very real threat of closure. The fallout from Rover has been underestimated, and the strength of the pound is causing Corus to haemorrhage profits.'

Other senior union figures, including John Monks, general secretary of the Trades Union Congress, also fear Llanwern is in grave peril.

Byers also met Corus' joint chief executives, John Bryant and Fokko van Duyne, on Friday. They told him the high pound coupled with government measures such as the climate change levy was having a disastrous impact on the industry.

UK workers have feared the pound would lead to a switch of production to the Netherlands since Corus was formed last year. If the company's UK market share falls below 50 per cent from the curent level only three points higher, a widescale restructuring - certain to include closures - will be triggered.

Chancellor Gordon Brown, who met members of the ISTC steel union last Thursday, promised to look into ways or relieving pressure on the industry.

fields.headline: Beware the lurkers in cyberspace
fields.standfirst: Breaches in Internet security are outgrowing controls, says  Jamie Doward
fields.trailText: He was called Maxus, hailed from Russia and earlier this year came close to topping the FBI's most wanted list. Not bad for a 19-year-old.
fields.body:
He was called Maxus, hailed from Russia and earlier this year came close to topping the FBI's most wanted list. Not bad for a 19-year-old.

Maxus's crime was to break into the computer system operated by US online retailer CD Universe, and steal 300,000 credit card numbers. With a precocious penchant for blackmail, Maxus demanded a £62,000 'Christmas present' from CD Universe - otherwise he would start publishing the credit card details on the Web.

Maxus is the latest, but by no means the last, hacker to have raised concerns over the security of the Internet.

Each month it seems a new threat to security on the Internet emerges. In February, Internet retailers had their sites bombarded by hackers with techno dross and online consumers were unable to buy what they wanted. This 'denial of service' attack was estimated to have slowed down Internet traffic by as much as 20 per cent.

Ominously, Internet experts predict the next attack could be on financial institutions. Given how quickly the hacking community is growing (35,000 hackers worldwide two years ago; today three times that at least), this seems a safe bet.

Only 2 per cent of credit card transactions are made over the Internet, according to the Association for Payment Clearing Services. And only 2 per cent of credit card frauds are committed using the Internet. But this percentage is predicted to grow dramatically. Last year consumers in Western Europe spent £2.6 billion online. By the end of 2002, this is predicted to rise to more than £7bn, according to analysts at Datamonitor.

And online banking, too, is set to explode. Datamonitor estimates that 1.05 million people banked online last year. This figure is predicted to rise to 5.35 million by 2004.

The APCS states in a guide to online transactions that if consumers follow some simple guidelines (see below) buying and banking over the Internet should be no different from using the phone or a mail order catalogue. But Internet security experts have reservations. 'There isn't any real regulation,' said Phil Ryan, head of information security at Peapod, an electronic security consultancy. 'The credit card companies are at fault: they haven't set rigid regulations. I have been to websites where I know no steps have been taken to protect data in transit.'

When information is recorded within a computer system, it opens the possibility of a third party hacking the network and obtaining your information. Big banks employ a wide range of security and encryption methods, but retailers with limited budgets may find it difficult. The real threat lies with employees. There is little to stop staff walking out of the office having downloaded reams of data.

Online retailers tend to store personal information about you indefinitely, giving hackers (or staff) plenty of time. This opens the possibility that your credit card details end up being swiped on to another credit card's magnetic strip, a process known as 'skimming'.

Credit card companies are trying to offset this problem by introducing 'smart' chips. But one hacker in France has already managed to crack smart card technology.

The latest attempt to outwit hackers comes from the Marbles credit card, available from September, which will mean users no longer have to send their credit card number over the Internet. Instead users will request a 16-digit number for each online purchase, valid for that transaction only.

Online tips

 Set your browser to the highest level of security notification.

 Enter only into transactions with companies that use encryption certificates. These should be displayed on the company's website.

 Telephone the company beforehand if you are worried about making a transaction online.

 Check bank and credit card statements as soon as you receive them. If you find discrepancies contact your card issuer immediately.

 Never send your Pin over the Internet.

For a comprehensive list see www.apacs.org.uk

fields.headline: Boo.com backers demand shake-up
fields.trailText: The founders of Boo.com will this week be given a dramatic ultimatum by their financial backers: cut your involvement with the company and accept sweeping management changes, or have the plug pulled on further funding.
fields.body:
The founders of Boo.com will this week be given a dramatic ultimatum by their financial backers: cut your involvement with the company and accept sweeping management changes, or have the plug pulled on further funding.

The move comes as the ailing online fashion retailer seeks a £20 million cash injection. The attempt to raise further funding highlights how quickly the company has been haemorrhaging cash after raising nearly £100m of financing last year.

City sources say JP Morgan and Goldman Sachs, two of the company's high-profile backers who participated in the first round of financing, have ruled out making any further investments. Both banks refused to comment on their involvement with Boo.

The sources say the remaining backers - which include the investment arms of luxury goods giant LVMH and the Benetton empire - are prepared to stump up more money, but only if the company's Swedish founders, chief operating officer Ernst Malmsten and chief marketing officer Kajsa Leander, relax their grip on the business.

'You can expect some management changes to be announced in the next few days,' a source said last night.

It is thought that Boo's backers are pushing for the duo to follow the example of their co-founder Patrik Hedelin, who resigned as the company's executive chairman in February 'to spend more time with his family' in Sweden.

Worries about Boo's future have been circulating for several months.

In a bid to expand its market share, Boo earlier this year slashed prices. However, efforts to revive the company's flagging fortunes have been unsuccessful, despite the fact it has spent nearly £15m on advertising in the past few months. Recently Boo laid off 70 staff as part of its restructuring programme.

Boo's backers may look to sell the company to a trade buyer. Analysts have suggested interested parties could include Marks & Spencer and Kingfisher.

webTitle: If e-friendly is as e-friendly does, who's a right e-jit?

fields.headline: If e-friendly is as e-friendly does, who's a right e-jit?
fields.trailText: Six years ago, someone (identity unknown) opened an Internet account with Prodigy, a US Internet services provider, in the name of 'Alexander Lunney'. Having registered, this person then posted vulgar messages on bulletin boards and sent a threatening e-mail message to another individual.
fields.body:
Six years ago, someone (identity unknown) opened an Internet account with Prodigy, a US Internet services provider, in the name of 'Alexander Lunney'. Having registered, this person then posted vulgar messages on bulletin boards and sent a threatening e-mail message to another individual. The recipient was not amused and summoned the cops.

The fuzz promptly descended upon one Alexander Lunney, who at that time was a 15-year-old Bronxville high school student. Shortly after that, young Lunney received a letter from Prodigy's lawyers, informing him that the company had decided to terminate his account 'due to the transmission of obscene, abusive, threatening and sexually explicit material'.

The only problem was that the lad was not, and never had been, a Prodigy customer and it was rapidly established that whoever had opened the account in his name was an impostor. At this point, Lunney sued Prodigy, and matters passed into the hands of m'learned friends.

A succession of local and district courts then ruled that the service provider was not legally culpable for either the objectionable e-mail or the bulletin board message.

'Prodigy was not a publisher of the e-mail transmitted through its system by a third party,' was the unanimous judgment of the New York Court of Appeals. 'We are unwilling to deny Prodigy the common-law qualified privilege accorded to telephone and telegraph companies.'

The judgment said that Prodigy could not be treated as publisher of the electronic bulletin board message and concluded that 'the public would not be well served by compelling an Internet service provider to examine and screen millions of e-mail communications, on pain of liability for defamation'.

The Lunney case eventually reached the US Supreme Court. On Monday last, the court upheld the ruling of the lower courts.

So the position is that, under US law, Internet service providers cannot be held legally liable for material that is published by third parties through their servers.

Given the nature of the Internet, and the key role played in it by ISPs, that is an eminently sensible state of affairs.

Now spool forward a few years, and cross the Atlantic to a small island off the shores of continental Europe. The rulers of this quaint kingdom know about as much about the Internet as the average trouser press, but this doesn't stop them being most awfully keen on it.

Their leader continually gushes about 'the Net' and they even declare on their gleaming new website (called e-commerce@its.best.uk, if you please) their goal of 'developing the UK as the best place in the world for e-commerce by 2002'.

A resident of this ancient land, one Laurence Godfrey, complained to an ISP called Demon Internet that some messages posted about him on Internet discussion groups carried by Demon (and thousands of other ISPs worldwide) were defamatory.

Demon declined to remove the offending newsgroups from its circulation system, and Mr Godfrey sued for libel. In the end, Demon decided not to fight the case and settled out of court, paying Mr Godfrey substantial damages and costs.

As a result, the legal position in the UK is that ISPs are legally responsible for the stuff that passes through their servers.

Are the country's Internet-savvy rulers wringing their hands over this and planning to revise the law of libel to protect ISPs from actions for defamation?

Are they hell. Au contraire: they are gleefully proposing (through the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Bill currently being railroaded through Parliament) to impose on them the enormous costs of the large-scale surveillance of private e-mail that the Bill requires ISPs to facilitate.

So here's your starter for 10. Which country - the US or the UK - is more e-friendly? Do not write on both sides of the paper at once.

John.Naughton@observer.co.uk www.briefhistory.com/footnotes/

fields.headline: Family upset at 'Joyce the foul-mouth'
fields.trailText: James Joyce's work may have outraged the Catholic Church with its graphic accounts of sex and defecation - but, in person, he was always the model of good manners. So say relatives of the Irish writer who are unhappy with actor Ewan McGregor's rough and ready portrayal of Joyce in a new film.
fields.body:
James Joyce's work may have outraged the Catholic Church with its graphic accounts of sex and defecation - but, in person, he was always the model of good manners. So say relatives of the Irish writer who are unhappy with actor Ewan McGregor's rough and ready portrayal of Joyce in a new film.

In one sequence, McGregor, who made his name in the violent and drug-ridden hit Trainspotting, is shown threatening a rival for his wife's affections with physical violence and using obscene language.

'He would never, never have done that,' said Ken Monaghan, Joyce's nephew and the director of the James Joyce Cultural Centre in Dublin.

'The film shows him shouting "fuck off" on a bridge near their home in Trieste and, despite his reputation for using foul language in his work, he would not have done that.'

The film, called Nora after Joyce's wife Nora Barnacle, is based on Brenda Maddox's 1998 biography about the tempestuous relationship between Joyce and his uneducated Galway bride.

In addition to the screenplay's emphasis on swearing, it uses explicit sex scenes to communicate the sensual basis of the Joyce marriage. The character of Molly Bloom, the sexually liberated wife of Leopold Bloom in Ulysses, is said to have been largely inspired by Nora Barnacle.

The film was first screened last month at the Dublin Film Festival, to critical acclaim. Irish scholars and relatives of Joyce, who died in 1941, have accepted the high sexual content as defensible. Many also praised actress Susan Lynch, who plays Nora.

'Theirs was certainly a very sexual relationship,' said Monaghan. 'It had to be because there was not much else they had in common. I think Susan Lynch is exactly what Nora should be. I never met her because she left Dublin for the last time before I was born, but obviously I heard a lot about her. She thought my mother, May, James's sister, disapproved of her for being lower class.'

Maddox herself recognises that the film is distinct from her book and told The Observer she was broadly pleased with it. The film's main detractor is Stephen James Joyce, Joyce's grandson and the sole executor of the literary estate. He has always been opposed to Maddox's book and is renowned for his sensitivity towards biographical interest in his family. He has accused film-maker Pat Murphy of permanently damaging the reputation of his grandparents.

Two years ago he took unsuccessful legal action against Picador which brought out a populist Reader's edition of Ulysses. It attempted to regularise the erratic spelling and punctuation in the epic which annoyed the author's nephew along with Joyce academics. McGregor knew that he would be putting his neck on the block by playing the part.

'Everyone will have a different idea of who he was, but what really impressed me was Nora was not a script about Joyce the writer. It was a love story. I liked that because you don't get vast waves of his writing pushed down your throat.'

Murphy, who also co-wrote the screenplay with Gerry Stembridge, said, 'I wanted it to touch on all the darker parts of their relationship but also to have moments that reflect Nora's sense of humour.'

In one sequence, McGregor, who made his name in the violent and drug-ridden hit Trainspotting, is shown threatening a rival for his wife's affections with physical violence and using obscene language. 'The film shows him shouting "fuck off" on a bridge near their home in Trieste and, despite his reputation for using foul language in his work, he would not have done that.' The film, called Nora after Joyce's wife Nora Barnacle, is based on Brenda Maddox's 1998 biography about the tempestuous relationship between Joyce and his uneducated Galway bride. In addition to the screenplay's emphasis on swearing, it uses explicit sex scenes to communicate the sensual basis of the Joyce marriage. The character of Molly Bloom, the sexually liberated wife of Leopold Bloom in Ulysses, is said to have been largely inspired by Nora Barnacle. The film was first screened last month at the Dublin Film Festival, to critical acclaim. Irish scholars and relatives of Joyce, who died in 1941, have accepted the high sexual content as defensible. Many also praised actress Susan Lynch, who plays Nora. 'Theirs was certainly a very sexual relationship,' said Monaghan. 'It had to be because there was not much else they had in common. I think Susan Lynch is exactly what Nora should be. I never met her because she left Dublin for the last time before I was born, but obviously I heard a lot about her. She thought my mother, May, James's sister, disapproved of her for being lower class.' Maddox herself recognises that the film is distinct from her book and told The Observer she was broadly pleased with it. The film's main detractor is Stephen James Joyce, Joyce's grandson and the sole executor of the literary estate. He has always been opposed to Maddox's book and is renowned for his sensitivity towards biographical interest in his family. He has accused film-maker Pat Murphy of permanently damaging the reputation of his grandparents. Two years ago he took unsuccessful legal action against Picador which brought out a populist Reader's edition of Ulysses. It attempted to regularise the erratic spelling and punctuation in the epic which annoyed the author's nephew along with Joyce academics. McGregor knew that he would be putting his neck on the block by playing the part. 'Everyone will have a different idea of who he was, but what really impressed me was Nora was not a script about Joyce the writer. It was a love story. I liked that because you don't get vast waves of his writing pushed down your throat.' Murphy, who also co-wrote the screenplay with Gerry Stembridge, said, 'I wanted it to touch on all the darker parts of their relationship but also to have moments that reflect Nora's sense of humour.'

fields.headline: Our 20 best Italian holidays
fields.standfirst: Marjorie Yue  offers a selection of trips from top ... to Toe
fields.trailText: Marjorie Yue offers a selection of trips from top ... to Toe.
fields.body:
1 Exotic gardens Lake Maggiore's most elegant resort, Stresa, is also home to some of Italy's finest gardens. Villa Taranto's park has become a botanical garden containing some of the richest collections of exotic plants such as the giant Amazonian water lilies. The barren rock that was Isolla Bella on one of the three Borromean Islands dotting the lake was transformed into a beautiful garden by a seventeenth century nobleman. Thomson Lakes and & Mountains (0870 606 1470) features a seven-night half-board stay at the resort's turn-of-the-century Hotel Regina Palace starting at £585 including flights and transfers.

2 Past perfect A privileged journey to see a very modern archaeological dig has been arranged by Page & Moy (0870 010 6457). The excavation of the amphitheatre in Grumentum in Basilicata, dating from the first century BC, is the main subject of a week-long tour to this little-known area of southern Italy. Other archaeological sites on the itinerary include Metaponto, the town where Pythagoras settled after his expulsion from Croton, and Matera, one of southern Italy's most fascinating towns with houses and churches carved into the cliff face. Guided by Dr Karina Mitens, the tour departs on 17 September and costs £899 including flights from Gatwick and half-board accommodation.

3 Floral hunt The dramatic castellations and towering pinnacles of the Dolomites in north-eastern Italy are the backdrop for Naturetrek's eight-day botanical holiday. The hunt is on for orchids, from military to marsh species, in the fertile meadows of the valleys, as well as limestone-loving plants such as the edelweiss and mountain avens. Departing on 24 June the tour costs £895 including flights from London to Verona and full-board accommodation in the Fasa Valley. Call 01962 733051.

4 Florentine luxury On 15 May a new luxury hotel opens in a turn-of-the-century building in Florence. The Savoy, Sir Rocco Forte's latest property, is set in a prime position on the Piazza della Repubblica in the heart of the city. It is decorated in traditional Italian style using distinctive Florentine colours and furniture, and many of the original features have been restored. Kirker Holidays (020 7231 3333) offers three-night breaks this summer from £762 including return flights, hotel transfers and breakfast.

5 Class acts The green shoots of Italy's rural tourism project have grown rapidly over the past decade. A newcomer to Sunvil Discovery's Farm Holidays programme is the Fattoria Lavacchio farm in Tuscany. Set on the top of the Florentine hills of Montfiesole, surrounded by typical rolling landscape between Rufina and Pontassieve, this working farm produces its own excellent wine such as Chianti Rufina and Cortignano, as well as olives. Other activities range from horseriding to pottery classes on the techniques of classical Tuscan ceramics. A seven-night fly-drive holiday in June starts at £611 including flights, breakfast and car hire. Call 020 8758 4722.

6 Easy pedalling Take a leisurely view of Venetia country on two wheels. Headwater Holidays (01606 813367) has introduced a nine-day independent cycling tour of the quiet back roads around the easygoing Venetian plains. The route passes through a string of charming villages at the base of the Berici hills. Time out of the saddle includes a boat trip down the Brenta canal from Padua to Venice, taking in a succession of some 50 world-famous Palladian villas. Accommodation ranges from a former Doge's residence to a vineyard. Prices start at £467 per person half-board, based on four travelling together by car, including ferry crossings.

7 Island hopping The Riviera D'Ulisse is a virtually undiscovered region south of Rome. The Villa Irlanda is five miles from the old town of Gaeta which lies behind the remains of fortress walls, jutting out into the Tyrrhenian Sea. Originally built by Earl Stembock, a cousin of the Russian tzar, part of the villa was once used as an Irish Papal College. It has now been converted into a four-star hotel with 15 acres of gardens - a convenient base to explore the little known Pontine islands. A three-night B&B stay costs from £416 including Heathrow flights and car hire. Call Italiatour! on 01883 621900.

8 War memories The Allied landings on the beaches of Anzio and Salerno provide the emotive theme of a special 10-day battlefields tour featured by Leger Holidays (01709 839839). Led by an expert guide, there are excursions to the site of Beach Head, Commonwealth War Cemeteries and a visit to the mountain-top abbey of Montecassino. The splendours of ancient Italy are not forgotten with trips to ancient Pompeii and the option of a full day in Rome. The break costs £399 per person (based on two sharing) including coach travel, half-board accommodation and excursions. Departures are in June and September.

9 Outdoor life Canvas Holidays' wide range of camping locations offer a flavour of Italy al fresco with sites at Tuscany, Lake Garda, Florence and Venice. For a 12-night stay at Campegglo la Rocca at Lake Garda expect to pay £353 if you arrive between 5 and 8 June for a family of two adults and up to four children. The price includes ferry crossings and tent accommodation. Reservations on 08709 022022.

10 Walker's reward The protected area of the Corno alle Scale Regional Park is exceptionally rewarding for the wealth of its wildlife, trees and flowers. Inntravel (01653 629010) has put together a week's independent walking in the Apennines, the mountains between the magnificent cities of Florence and Bologna. Luggage is transported ahead daily, so walkers can follow woodland paths, passing through traditional villages, and find a welcome en route at inns selected for their regional cuisine. Prices start at £527 half-board with four picnic lunches and include return flights from Heathrow to Bologna, and rail travel.

11 Opera extravaganza Independent gay and lesbian tour operator, Man Around (020 8902 7177) has arranged a seven-night musical extravaganza for opera lovers from 22 July, when the internationally renowned Verona Opera begins. Tickets for performances of La Traviata and Nabucco, staged in the city's ancient arena, are included, with accommodation at the nearby resort of Lake Garda. Departing from Gatwick, the holiday costs from £953 per person half-board at the Sport Olympio Hotel (based on two sharing a twin room) and a half-day tour of Verona.

12 Medici house Villa specialist Italian Life (0113 281 8811) has a fifteenth-century farmhouse once owned by the Medici family. Now restored and transformed into a splendid country house, the Villa Tagliafune is situated in a peaceful position in the Chianti hills, with its own olive grove and swimming pool. Florence is a comfortable 22km day-trip away and it is only 50kms to Siena. A seven-night stay in the villa, which sleeps eight, costs £3,656 in the first two weeks of June including ferry crossing for one car and passengers (add £104 for a second car).

13 Weigh anchor With just 312 passengers, the Windstar cruise from Rome to Venice has the feel of a private yacht. It sets sail from Civitavecchia, and ports of call include Sorrento, Taormina - Sicily's most picturesque town - and Corfu before cruising up the rugged Croatian coastline to Dubrovnik en route for Venice. The seven-night cruise departs on 18 September and 16 October and costs £2,539 per person based on two sharing a stateroom cabin (all cabins have seaviews). The price includes all meals and watersports (except diving). Bookings through Magic of Italy on 0990 462442.

14 Tuscan walks For many walking aficionados, the heart of the Garfagnana is where you can get close to the 'real Tuscany'. With the Apennines to the east, the Alpi Apuane to the west, and the Serchio river flowing in between, there is ample variety for walkers, from scaling the slopes of Mount Prado to exploring one of Europe's longest cave systems. Exodus (020 8675 5550) has an eight-day group tour with prices from £498 including flights and B&B accommodation on a farm at Braccicorti.

15 Tee off Knowledgeable golfers will head for the foothills of Lake Garda, to the Palazzo Arzaga. This beautifully restored fifteenth-century monastery is surrounded by two golf courses, both of which have the accolade of being the only courses in Italy endorsed by PGA Europe. The hotel's superb Saturnia spa and swimming pool with views across the landscape will keep non-golfers occupied. A four-night break, booked through Scott Dunn Mediterranean (020 8767 6090) starts at £675 per person including flights and breakfast; green fees for the 18-hole course from £24.

16 Fish dish Fish is the predominant catch of a learn-to-cook week based on the Amalfi coast. After helping to prepare such dishes as salmon marinated with orange, lemon and juniper berries and panna cotta with grappa, guests can sit down and enjoy the fruits of their labours over a glass or two of one of the region's fine wines. The Italian Cookery Week costs £1,199 including return flights from London, accommodation, tuition, excursions and food and wine. Call 020 8206 0112 or visit www.italian-cookery-weeks.co.uk.

17 Singles game If tennis is the name of your game, Solo's, the singles specialist, is serving up a seven-night holiday in the Dolomite mountain village of Fai della Pagnella. Aimed at intermediate players, daily morning coaching is combined with friendly tournaments in the afternoon. There are also sporting facilities for volleyball and mini-football. The cost of £699 and £769 for 10 June and 10 September departures respectively includes return flights from Gatwick and full-board single room accommodation at the Sport Hotel Panorama. Call 020 8951 2800.

18 Housing heritage Designated as a World Heritage site, the Trulli houses are quite a curiosity in Cisternino, in the Puglia region. The distinctive conical-roofed stone houses are featured in Long Travel's southern Italy brochure and include the tour operators' own Trullo Azzurro, a three bedroomed, three-bathroomed restored whitewashed building. There are child-friendly beaches eight miles away. One week's rental starts at £450 rising to £630 in mid-August. Flights can be arranged to Brindisi, Bari or Naples. Call 01694 722193.

19 Booze cruise Arblaster and Clarke's innovative wine cruise guides enthusiasts through a journey of discovery both at sea and on land to taste the classic yet little known wines of the Aeolian Islands, from the full-blooded Sicilian reds to the crisp fresh whites of Ischia. The three-masted barquentine Lili Marleen will sail from Fiumicino to Salina, Palermo and take in the remote island of Pantelleria, just off the Tunisian coast, known for its unusual domed houses of volcanic rock. The seven-night cruise departing 23 August starts at £2,999 per person in a twin cabin, including flights from London and most meals. Details on 01730 893344.

20 Opera feast Opera buffs can stay near the centre of the historic Tuscan town of Lucca, birthplace of Puccini, for the Torre de Lago opera festival. JMB Travel (01905 425628) is offering special breaks during the festival's duration (28 July to 19 August) starting at £538 for two nights at the three star Hotel Rex, including Heathrow flights to Pisa, breakfast and opera tickets.

Getting there

By air

British Airways

Contact: 0845 77 333 77 or www.british-airways.com

Flights: Birmingham, Gatwick, Heathrow and Manchester to Rome (Fiumicino), Milan (Malpensa and Linate), Genoa, Naples, Pisa, Verona, Bologna and Venice.

Good deal: Rome from £141 or Venice from £142

Alitalia

Contact: 0870 600 4343 or www.alitalia.it

Flights: 20 daily to Italy. Heathrow to Milan (Linate and Malpensa) and Rome (Fiumicino); Gatwick to Rome (Fiumicino), Venice and Bologna

Good deal: Milan, Rome, Bologna, Venice from £143

Buzz

Contact: 0870 240 7070 or www.buzzaway.com

Flights: Stansted to Milan (Linate)

Good deal: From £80 return; flights subject to availability; minimum two-night stay

Ryanair

Contact: 0541 569 569 or www.ryanair.com

Flights: Stansted to Ancona, Brescia, Genoa, Lamezia, Pisa, Rimini, Turin,Venice

Go

Contact: 08456 054321 or www.go-fly.com

Flights: Stansted to Milan, Venice, Bologna, Rome

By coach

Eurolines

Contact: 01582 404511 or www.eurolines.co.uk

From Victoria Coach Station, London, to more than 20 destinations.

Good deal: From £69 return to Rome, Florence, Milan and Turin. Two weeks advance booking.

By train

Rail Europe

Contact: 0990 848 848 or www.raileurope.co.uk

TGV to Turin, Milan, Rome, Naples, Venice. Also train services (Eurostar Italia, InterCity, Night, regional and local) linking to destinations throughout Italy. Apex return London to Milan via Paris from £131.

Motorail

Contact: 08702 415 415 or www.raileurope.co.uk

Services direct to Italy have been suspended. Alternative route is Motorail from Calais to Nice and drive into Italy. (Brive, Toulouse, Narbonne and Avignon are also served).

Good deal: From £259 one-way (Calais to Nice). Based on two-berth sleeper. Sunday - Thursday departures.

webTitle: ICC action on match fixing must be sustained

fields.headline: ICC action on match fixing must be sustained
fields.standfirst: They could start by reducing the number of pointless one-day matches, says Vic Marks
fields.trailText: They made the right noises and there was an unusual air of unanimity at the conclusion of this ICC meeting. The message was that they were going to get tough with match-fixers and anyone who consorts with bookies, though I suspect that shady Bombay bookmakers are not yet enduring sleepless nights.
fields.body:
They made the right noises and there was an unusual air of unanimity at the conclusion of this ICC meeting. The message was that they were going to get tough with match-fixers and anyone who consorts with bookies, though I suspect that shady Bombay bookmakers are not yet enduring sleepless nights.

Listen to the words of ICC's chief executive, David Richards: 'Any person found guilty of match fixing can expect to be put out of the game for a very long time, if not altogether. We have a serious problem, but the view of the [ICC] board is that it is not rampant throughout the game. This meeting has given the ICC teeth.' But that was Richards speaking in Christchurch after the special meeting held over two days in January 1999 in the wake of the revelations that Shane Warne and Mark Waugh had taken money for providing information to bookmakers.

So what's new? In 1999, post-Christchurch, the ICC set up an independent investigation into allegations of betting and match fixing - the Code of Conduct Commission - which would call on national boards to uncover cases of corruption. In 2000 we also have the announcement of an independent anti-corruption investigation. After the next scandal will another investigative panel be formed?

To examine what the ICC Code of Conduct has turned up recently Wisden's Crime and Punishment section comes in handy. Here's a flavour: 'N Hussain. Excessive coloured piping on pads. Fined 10% of match fee by PL Van Der Merwe (England v NZ, 1st Test at Birm ingham).' Or 'G.D McGrath. Spat on pitch near batsman. (Aus v WI 4th Test in Antigua). Previously suspended fine imposed.' There's no mention of any illicit dealings with bookmakers being uncovered or punished.

This is not to belittle the ICC's commitment to cleansing the game, but it does emphasise how powerless they are until they find some proof. Then, it seems they will act. Sarfraz Nawaz, the former Pakistani opening bowler and never one to take the middle line, once advocated the death penalty for offenders.

But the absence of proof stymies the best intentions. What is essential is that the cricket boards around the world and the latest body of ICC investigators not only liaise with the relevant police authorities but come to an agreement with them that evidence can be handed over to the cricketing authorities at the conclusion of the investigation. In certain cases there may not be sufficient evidence to justify criminal proceedings, but there may be enough for a disciplinary board to take action.

Access to police information is crucial, something which has been made clear to me by Somerset's chief executive, Peter Anderson. Earlier in his career Anderson was assistant director (operations) of the Independent Commission against Corruption in Hong Kong and spent four years investigating jockeys there. It would seem foolish not to use some of his expertise now, if only in an advisory capacity.

On paper this is a formidable deterrent. Whether it would ever be used is another matter. It may fall into the same category as the penalties that were available for the preparation of poor pitches in English domestic cricket; until this year they were so severe that the ECB dare not impose them.

Clearly this decision was made with a view to encouraging Pakistan finally to release the Qayyum report, which was delivered to the Pakistan Cricket Board on Friday. It is expected to incriminate the likes of Salim Malik - who continues to profess his innocence - Mushtaq Ahmed and Wasim Akram. The PCB have been waiting a year for the report to arrive. Once it has been seen by their lawyers it will be handed over to the ICC, probably this week.

Presumably suspension could apply to South Africa if their inquiries into the Cronje affair are dilatory. (Incidentally, but for Cronje and the Delhi police we would probably still be rumbling along blissfully complacent without ever giving a thought to the Commission's progress). That threat of suspension from international cricket must be sustained.

Conspicuously absent from the ICC was any discussion about the proliferation of meaningless one-day matches. This is not so surprising. The ICC president, Jagmohan Dalmiya, whom we now know is innocent of any shady dealings with TV companies, has nonetheless been a prime mover in the establishment of a multitude of one-day tournaments in the East. These have generated a lot of money, but have debased the game and - unwittingly - they have opened the doors to the illegal bookmakers.

It seems absurd that the international game of cricket is so unstructured. Compare cricket with soccer, which has an international calendar based on the World Cup and the European Cup with a few friendlies tossed in. Given the unanimity springing from last week's meeting, this might have been a good time to discuss the formation of an internationally agreed schedule.

I have always thought, with my conservative hat on, that an Ashes series, for example, could stand alone. Tradition and history lend it significance. But it is crazy that countless one-day games with no inherent meaning take place worldwide each year. Surely it is possible in an age of easy and quick air travel, to create a coherent international one-day league that could dovetail with the World Cup. A solution for Test cricket, which would be trickier to accommodate, could follow in due course. While the ICC wait for some hard evidence on match-fixing so they can nail the offender(s), they would be well advised to address the nuts and bolts of a one-day international schedule that might help deter the cancer of match-fixing.

fields.headline: Sun, surf, and Chardonnay
fields.standfirst: California's dreaming if it thinks it can still sell its wine at over-inflated prices
fields.trailText: California's dreaming if it thinks it can still sell its wine at over-inflated prices
fields.body:
'We've got a kindred-soul thing going with Australia,' a Californian winemaker told me recently. 'In both cases, our winemakers wear shorts, drink lots of beer and get quite rowdy.' Superficially, these two New World countries appear to have a lot in common: sun, surf and a lapping ocean of oak-flavoured Chardonnay.

But the more you look at their respective wine industries, the less valid the comparison seems. The most obvious difference is that California makes more than three times as much wine as Australia and consumes most of its own production. But there's also a small matter of identity. Australia is happy to be described as a New World country, whereas California is equivocal about the tag. The best Napa Valley producers want to compete with Bordeaux and Burgundy, not the Barossa or Stellenbosch.

Such a desire is laudable and, in one sense, justifiable. California produces some stunning stuff at the top end. The likes of Ridge, Saintsbury, Au Bon Climat, Kistler, Bryant Family, Newton and Harlan Estate deserve to be judged against the Old World's finest. Often their prices are comparable, too. Napa Valley Cabernet Sauvignon starts at £10 and disappears into the ether.

The problem with this state of affairs, at least as far as the consumer is concerned, is that fine wine is a tiny part of the West Coast's total production. The Napa and Sonoma Valleys - or Sonapanoma, as I like to call them - are famous names, but together they account for only 5 per cent of California's wine. The remaining 95 per cent contains some pockets of very good stuff, especially in Santa Cruz, Mendocino, Santa Barbara and the Anderson Valley, but most of it is snoozily uninispiring.

More to the point, it is usually over-priced. As the local vernacular would have it, California sucks in value-for-money terms, especially when set against Chile, Australia, Argentina, Portugal, Italy and even France. Finding an interesting bottle under £8 is hard enough; finding one under £5 is like hunting for a contact lens in an Olympic-size swimming pool.

What are you talking about, the marketing guys will ask? Sales of Californian wine were up 39 per cent in the UK last year. Most of this was thanks to Gallo, the company responsible for two-thirds of what the West Coast sends us. There's nothing wrong with what Gallo produces, but it's not exactly thrilling. I've had better times at barn dances than I have drinking Turning Leaf or Garnet Point. Take away the awful Blossom Hill, another big seller in the UK, and you're not left with very much. Mondavi's cheaper wines are mediocre (Woodbridge, or Pont du Bois, as a mate of mine calls it, is a rip-off), as are those sold under the Sutter Home, Arius and Paul Masson labels. The only California producer whose wines I would recommend with any confidence under £8 is Fetzer.

If Fetzer can do it, why can't its competitors? Answering such a question will become increasingly urgent over the next five years. The world is facing a significant over-supply of wine, much of it emerging from California. (Merlot plantings increased by 38 per cent on the West Coast last year.) Americans can't, or rather don't want to, drink all that extra wine, so someone else will have to. Or perhaps not. As the worldwide surplus grows, California will face a choice: improve its basic quality or drop its prices by at least £1. Otherwise, people will go elsewhere. Beer-swilling winemakers in shorts are all very well, but as the Australians realised some time ago, it's the stuff in the bottle that really matters.

fields.headline: Grater love
fields.standfirst: Showering freshly shaved Parmesan over even the simplest dish will turn it into a feast fit for a king
fields.trailText: Nigel Slater:Showering freshly shaved Parmesan over even the simplest dish will turn it into a feast fit for a king
fields.body:
There is one throw-it-together midweek supper I make year in year out. It consists of nothing more than a few handfuls of pasta tossed with olive oil, parsley and Parmesan. It is instantly satisfying and ready before I have taken off my coat or even poured myself a drink. The meal generates only a pan, a colander, a bowl and a fork in terms of washing up (unless you are the sort of person who washes their cheese grater rather than tapping it on the kitchen counter as I do), and is as cheap as chips. True, it relies on a bottle of decent olive oil, a bunch of vivid green and perky parsley and a generous hand with the Parmesan, but it is hardly much of a shopping list. Yet it is the meal I make most often, though in truth I usually throw a bit of salad in a bowl to eat afterwards.

This is not a meal that knocks your socks off with its originality. Neither is it a recipe for impressing your neighbours. It is just a nice, straightforward and somewhat understated supper. I suppose I should point out that it works best if you have stopped at Oddbins on the way home for a bottle of glorious Icardi. Yet its simplicity can be its downfall. This is one of those recipes that stands or falls entirely by the quality of its (very few) ingredients. Few recipes so perfectly illustrate what I have been banging on about for years - that the integrity of the ingredients is more crucial than the ability of the cook. In other words, shopping is more important than cooking.

All the parts of a recipe such as this are as important as one another. The pasta needs to be a decent Italian brand, the olive oil should be your favourite (it does not matter whether it is a creamy, peppery, fruity or rasping oil, so long as it is one you truly like) and it goes without saying that the parsley needs to be bright and fresh. But none of this will make one jot of difference if the cheese comes ready-grated in a little cardboard drum. The Parmesan you grate for yourself from a great craggy lump is altogether different from one bought ready-ground. The way I look at it is this: if we were really meant to buy the stuff that comes in a little cardboard drum, then how come it smells like vomit?

A whole wheel of Parmesan is a wonderful sight - as big as a coffee table and three times as heavy, it takes more than one to lift it and an experienced hand to cut it into manageable lumps. When I say manageable, I am talking about price as much as size. Good Parmesan does not come cheap. In Italy, I have seen it labelled Grana, which is in fact a general name for all of their very hard, grainy cheeses used for grating, but the sort that is particularly worth seeking out is one with a hard shell that is covered with little dots bearing the words Parmigiano Reggiano.

I found out the other day that the Parmesan I have been buying recently is about two years old, which is not especially ancient for this particular cheese. The older it gets, the harder and more tangy it becomes. (I don't really like the word 'tangy', but it does seem perfect to describe the after-notes of an old Reggiano.) The younger cheeses you come across in the supermarket are not to be despised, though. Their damp softness makes them easy to slice with a vegetable peeler to scatter over a salad of, say, cos lettuce and walnuts. But they lack the finesse and the deep, long-lasting savour of an older cheese. For grating, you will need more than you would from a bolder, older one.

Whenever I am asked one of those 'what ingredients do you always have in your kitchen' questions, then a lump of Parmigiano is never far behind the Illy espresso, tiny Ligurian olives and Evian. (We don't have to go much further down the list before we bump into Smarties.) Try adding a handful of Parmesan to your next green salad. With a copious and mustardy dressing, the cheese will make a flimsy salad substantial enough to call itself a light lunch.

Broken off in lumps, it is a surprisingly good cheese to eat with fruit - especially luscious pears (the cold juice of the fruit and the salty, sharp tang of the cheese is indescribably good), and then there is the strange-sounding pairing of peas and cheese. Yes, I know, odd and unimaginable - but it works. Boil and strain the peas, then toss them with a thin coating of melting butter and a sizeable shake of Parmesan.

How I grate my Grana depends very much on the maturity of the cheese. I have a natty little grater I bought in Milan (you can get them in any kitchen shop - I am just showing off) which has sharp, square teeth. It seems to produce just the right size gratings for melting. Any larger, and the cheese seems to stay in shape, like cheese-flavoured gravel. I use this small hand-grater for soft, young Parmesan. For older, more interestingly flavoured cheeses, I tend to get out the food processor, first grating the cheese on a coarse setting, then swapping it for the large blade to get it really fine. Disliking drawers full of bits and bobs, I have not yet fallen for one of those old-fashioned barrel graters where you hold the cheese down against a revolving drum. I have met those who swear by them.

I should mention that this cheese is no different to any other when it meets the heat, and you should avoid at all costs overcooking it. Grated Reggiano should turn a sumptuous pale gold; any darker and it may turn bitter. Which means you have to keep an eye on it under the grill. It will burn faster than you can say hard cheese.

Parmesan biscuits

Tiny, crumbly biscuits to eat with drinks. They take barely 10 minutes to make and not much more than that to bake. Makes about 20.

125g plain flour
100g cold butter
80g finely grated Parmesan
1 egg yolk
a little ground chilli powder

Put the flour into a mixing bowl and add the butter cut into small chunks. Rub the butter into the flour with your fingertips until it looks like fine, fresh breadcrumbs. It is essential that you don't go too far with this, and that you stop rubbing in as soon as the flour and butter look crumb-like.

Add the grated Parmesan, the egg yolk, a pinch of chilli powder and very little salt. Now gently bring the dough together with your hands, squeezing and softly kneading it till it looks like coarse pastry.

Twist the dough in two and roll each into a fat cylinder about the diameter of a £2 coin. Slice each roll into thick discs, about 0.5cm thick - less than the thickness of your little finger. Place each slice on a baking sheet and bake at 170°C/gas mark 3 for 18-20 minutes. They are ready when pale gold and crumbly. Lift them carefully from the baking sheet - they will be very tender - and allow them to cool on a rack.

The biscuits are best eaten an hour or less after baking, though you can keep them for a day or two in an airtight container.

Penne with Parmesan and parsley

Those who find this treatment for pasta a little abstemious may like to sneak in some melted butter - about 50g, a good thick slice. Serves 2.

300g penne rigate or other short, tubular pasta
a generous handful of chopped parsley
extra-virgin olive oil
80g finely grated Parmesan

Bring a large, deep pan of water to the boil. Add a generous amount of salt and then the pasta. Cook until it is tender but still has a bit of bite. Most dried pasta takes about nine minutes to reach this toothsome yet tender stage.

Drain the pasta quickly but not especially thoroughly. A little excess moisture is a good thing here. Return the pasta to the pan, throw in the chopped parsley, a generous drizzle of your favourite extra-virgin oil and then the Parmesan. Put a lid on the pan for a minute, then remove and toss the hot pasta with the softening cheese.

Baked plaice with Parmesan crumbs

I have never really gone along with the pairing of cheese and fish, yet it works here. This recipe, incidentally, is something I first made a couple of years ago and comes from Real Food. Serves 2.

2 large plaice fillets, skin on
4 gently heaping tbsps fine white breadcrumbs
6 level tbsps finely grated Parmesan
4 tbsps melted butter
2 tbsps olive oil

Lay the fish skin-side down in a buttered ovenproof dish. Mix the breadcrumbs, Parmesan, melted butter and oil and grind over a little salt and black pepper. Spread the seasoned crumbs loosely over the fish, then bake for 20 minutes in an oven preheated to 220°C/gas mark 7.

 Real Food is just out in paperback (Fourth Estate, £12.99)

fields.headline: Knickers - who needs 'em?
fields.standfirst: Why are women so obsessed with underwear? The time has come, writes  Germaine Greer, to burn our Wonderbras and slip into something more comfortable
fields.trailText: Why are women so obsessed with underwear? The time has come, writes Germaine Greer, to burn our Wonderbras and slip into something more comfortable
fields.body:
Lingerie is a fancy French name for underwear. Underwear is any garment that is not meant to be seen in public; the category includes, from the skin out, pants, singlets, brassieres, corsets, girdles, suspender-belts, vests, slips and petticoats. Under each of these headings could be marshalled dozens of variations; pants, for example, include briefs, Y-fronts, jockey shorts, boxer shorts, knickers, cami-knickers, drawers, bloomers, panties, pantettes, panty-girdles, panty-shorts, pant-slips, scanties, bikini briefs and thongs.

Who wears all this stuff? And why is our culture increasingly obsessed by it? British people spent £1.6 billion on lingerie last year, 25 per cent more than in 1991, influenced no doubt by the images that proliferate everywhere. Underwear is used to sell anything from Citroën cars to the Vogue website. There is even an exhibition of underwear, Inside Out, organised by the British Council, opening in London next month.

When I was growing up, certain kinds of women's underwear were called 'foundation garments'. If your clothes were to look good you had to underprop them with foundation garments, so at 14 or so you were packed off to be 'fitted' with your first bra and girdle. The bra fitter was usually a deep-voiced, whiskery female of what seemed horrifyingly advanced years and she measured your budding breast by (horribly) spreading her hand over it.

The girdle was (and still is) a garment so repellent that you had to dash to take it off in the toilet and stuff it down behind the cistern before foreplay reached the revelation point. Nowadays, firmness of the rear end is supposed to be achieved by working out, and no more covering needed than a thong. But thongs can be repellent on certain bodies. My hairdresser confided to me the other day that, though his wife is a beautiful woman he finds the sight of her buttocks surrounding a thong deeply off-putting. The very thought of Cherie Blair's mythical thong is mind-boggling.

One function of underwear is to provide an extra layer of insulation from the cold. Princess Diana thrilled her adoring public when she admitted that she wore Thermolactyl smalls under her evening gowns so that she could stand still for hours in draughty halls without succumbing to hypothermia. However, the undergarment as defence against the cold is becoming unnecessary as indoor temperatures rise; though, outside, people might need sheepskins in winter, indoors it is usually so hot they have to remove all insulation and work in shirt-sleeves. Skiers and mountaineers might wear spencers and longjohns; the rest of us do not.

Most Englishmen do not wear vests under their shirts any more; many Englishmen who do wear vests wear nothing over them. Sensible underwear, it seems, is either being worn as outerwear or being phased out. In fact underwear has always shown a tendency to transmigrate and appear as outerwear. Corsets have as often been worn outside dresses as inside them. However, neither Superman nor John Major succeeded in popularising the wearing of Y-fronts over instead of under trousers. In the days when she was still ambulatory my mother used to thrill beholders by flaunting herself in ancient, threadbare and virtually transparent men's longjohns.

If underwear was meant to keep you warm you would expect that in hot countries people wear less of it - and by and large that is true. People who pass their lives naked except for a few strings of beads and a penis sheath are unlikely to go a bundle on underwear, but as soon as the missionaries get to work on them they adopt not only European styles of outer dress but also underwear.

Aborigine women living in the broiling heat of Australia wear gathered skirts with slips under them made of hot, clingy synthetic material trimmed with cheap lace, which rapidly becomes tattered. When both skirt and slip become unbearably dirty and brittle they are thrown away, thus becoming genuinely disposable unlike the mad paper pants we used to wear that fell to pieces while you were still in them. Throughout outback Australia the traveller will encounter long lines of discarded clothing, and sometimes hillocks of it.

The wearing of slips in aboriginal culture implies decency; it is a response to the long history of abuse of aboriginal women by white men and then by demoralised black men. A largely futile assertion of propriety is now part and parcel of the rationale of clothing where, for 400,000 years, there was no clothing together with a fierce sense of bodily propriety.

Naked peoples associate modesty not with covering but with demeanour; only after they have been made aware of their bodies as object of prurient interest on the part of intrusive strangers do they feel a pressing need to hide parts of them. Missionaries, only too aware of their own lechery, used to insist on the wearing of clothes and underclothes. A mission-educated native who cast aside his clothing was considered to have reverted to savagery.

The association of underwear with decency runs deep. All the year round except for high summer my Tuscan housekeeper wore an astonishing array of underwear - knickers, a brassiere, a woollen vest, a girdle, a petticoat and stockings knotted above her knees. Whenever she bent over to cull a mushroom or gather wild salad, an extraordinary panorama of elastic and cheap lace was revealed.

Even in the hottest weather Lisa retained under her print dress and overall an essential minimum of underwear: bra, petticoat and knickers. As I had no secrets from her she knew that I did not so much as possess these articles; she also knew that I slept naked, but I never knew what she thought of this loucheness on my part. My Italian lover made his feelings plain; he would pull at the top of my dress, peer down it, and curse a blue streak when he saw me standing naked inside it.

My housekeeper's body was a white tender kernel protected from the cruel sun and the glacial mountain breezes alike by multiple wrappings like the skins of an onion. She firmly believed that if she worked up a sweat she must absolutely not remove any of her layers, for if the sweat cooled on her body she would fall ill. In her case, too, it seemed to me that her layers of underwear conferred decency. She had lived close to destitution all her life; when she married her husband, who was a carbonaro, poorest of the peasant poor, she had not even a coverlet to her bed. Her edifice of unnecessary raiment was the testimony that, though she was still illiterate, she had become a person of substance, una persona seria.

Lisa told me how it was in the old days, before the girls wore pants or shoes, when they wore just shifts, petticoats, full skirts and bodices. The discharge of menstruation was soaked up by the petticoats which the women wiped between their legs whenever necessary. For Lisa, acquiring pants and bras was part of modernisation, along with sanitary napkins and her husband's motorcycle truck.

When Lisa was a girl, everyone in our part of the Tuscan hills urinated and defecated out of doors. To the end of her life Lisa had misgivings about doing one's bisogni in the house, a practice which seemed to her unhygienic. Because a husband did not accompany wife or daughter as she went out to empty bowels or bladder last thing at night, it was the best opportunity for a woman to meet her lover or encounter a sexual predator. (Judges then had as much difficulty distinguishing between the two as they do today.) The last thing she needed was knickers which, pulled down around her ankles, would be very likely to be soiled and certain to impede her flight if she should be disturbed. She did as all women used to do before the invention of drawers, bundled up her skirts or threw them over her head to keep them clean, and squatted with her legs sensibly apart.

My mother used to say, as all Australian mothers proverbially said, that I must put on a clean pair of underpants every day in case I got knocked down by a car. For a while I collected briefs in fancy colours, mildly amused to think that under my regulation beatnik black glowed briefs of electric blue, fluorescent yellow or hot magenta. This phase came to an end when, after I gathered in my multi-coloured collection from the washing line in the sudden darkness of a Sydney summer night I discovered that someone had cut the crotch out of every pair. Thereafter I was more likely than not to leave my knickers off; as we left the house my man would run his thumb down my flank to see if he could feel a panty ridge; no ridge and I had to go back in and get some pants on. He was more concerned about my pants than I was, but why?

Years later when I wrote about going without, I got hundreds of nagging letters. Knickers protected me from catching infections or infestations (eg crab lice) off train seats and the like, didn't I know? Conversely they would prevent the pollution of the environment by noxious liquids emanating from me. I thought then and I think now, better a bidet than a panty-liner. For 'heavier days' there were beautifully made Italian thongs lined with rubber latex. Otherwise, nothing. In those days I did not even wear panty-hose, but stockings that I knotted above the knee as Lisa had taught me (to avoid the obscenity of a suspender belt). And no bra, natch. Not very erotic, you will be thinking. Quite.

It was a part of my feminist battle against pornography that I would not tackle up. A century ago randy little boys would pore over the corsetry advertisements in women's magazines and as the pornography industry has grown up it has elaborated this voyeuristic fixation. The passivity and vulnerability of the female subject of male erotic interest is accentuated by her being captured, as it were, as she undresses.

The viewer of most commercial pornography is still hiding in a woman's wardrobe, peering through the keyhole as she pops her suspenders and pushes her stockings languorously down over her legs. Corsets are uncomfortable; lace is supremely uncomfortable; suspender belts are ridiculous; most brassieres fake rather than control the bosom. There are men who secretly yearn to wear all this kit. We may ask even of the men who do not, is it us they love or these fetishistic garments?

The great undergarment success story of our time is the Wonderbra, which does not simply lift and separate, as did the brassieres of old, but literally tips the breasts into the face of the beholder, creating ebullient cleavage where otherwise there was none. The Wonderbra is clearly meant to allure but it is also bound to disappoint. Once a woman's Wonderbra has enticed a man into her arms she is faced with the dilemma of when to take it off.

Every Wonderbra I have ever seen was padded; there is no half hemisphere corresponding to the half that is so impressively exposed. The Wonderbra removed, the bosom shrinks, the cleavage disappears as the released breasts obey the call of gravity and sag away from the sternum.

The Wonderbra is one undergarment that must have been meant to stay on during sex, along with suspender-belts and black stockings and the rest of the tackle. Underwear is now sportswear.

One of the mysteries of the twentieth century is how the brassiere conquered the world. You might think it was the great manufacturers who convinced women that they would not be real women until they tipped their breasts into a harness, but the dusty bras I've seen on display in the shopping lanes of ancient towns from China to Peru are locally made. The shape of the breasts might be international but the brand names are not.

There is now no country in the world where women do not think it appropriate to strap their breasts into an immobile shape. The transformation of the useful breast into fetish object was accompanied by the marketing of synthetic babyfood, lipstick and high-heeled shoes, as the awesome imagery of the mother retreated in the face of the onward march of prostitution.

 Inside Out is at the Design Museum, London SE1, from 1 June
