fields.headline: Sharp hedges
fields.standfirst: Whether it's planned as a boundary or an informal divide, a flowering hedge will transform your garden
fields.trailText: Whether it's planned as a boundary or an informal divide, a flowering hedge will transform your garden
fields.body:
Hawthorn hedges run like flowering rivers across the whole of England, breaking into thousands upon thousands of blossoming tributaries. I've said it before, and I'll say it again, but I think there's nothing on earth more beautiful than the May blossom and cow parsley in full sail on a sunny May morning. What, you might well ask from your much-loved but small urban back garden, has that got to do with anything other than my own good fortune in being in the countryside? A lot. For a start, most of us try to capture an essence of the country within the confines of our gardens, be they never so urban and never so small.

As a culture, we are receding from the countryside. More and more people see it as something to visit, like a theme park, rather than as a living, working environment. I suspect that most people are closer to their gardens than they are to any broader landscape around them. By observing what is happening at any season in the countryside, we can distil that and improve our gardens. That improvement will, of course, be subjective and largely emotional. I am all for this. Any intelligent harnessing of our feelings will improve the quality of both garden and gardening. A flowering, informal hedge immediately places the looseness and fecundity of open countryside within the strict limitations of our gardens. It implies a confidence and freedom of spirit and is, I think, profoundly liberating.

Another point of looking at what is flowering around you is to do with timing. The television and journalism I am involved in tends to be driven by what the viewer/reader can do now, this weekend, and has to be topical and relevant. In this flurry of perfectly sensible relevance, it is easy to pass by one of the most important aspects of gardening, which is just looking. But it is not enough merely to see - you have to connect brain, eye and emotion.

The images remain as part of an internal picture library that you can draw upon perhaps years later. This is why a lot of gardening is best done up to a year ahead.

So, go and look for flowering hedges over the coming few months. Make notes, albeit mental ones, and plan for next year. What might you be looking for? Over the past few months, you might have seen a hedge of forsythia like a streak of mustard left on a plate, or ribes, which is an abuse on both eye and nose, or even - God forbid - both forsythia and ribes together, looking like one of those malevolent cakes lurking under a bell jar in a provincial tearoom. Flowering quince (Chaenomeles) is much better, as is the rampantly flamboyant kerria, or even horrid rhododendron, of which more anon. But do not think that a flowering hedge has no part in a formal garden. Think of lavender, rosemary, santolina or hyssop. All make good outline hedges, marking paths, geometric shapes and borders while also acting as a good foil for blowsy summer flowers, such as roses.

As a rule, a flowering hedge is not a good idea for the back of a border. It would be too busy and distracting from the border itself. Anything other than a low hedge with flowers is best used as a boundary or to divide informal spaces such as the edge of an orchard.

Roses, of course, make one of the best flowering hedges of all. You must use shrub roses and feed them well so they establish a good thick shape. Rosa rugosa is the one that is usually called in to perform this task, and does perform it superbly, being tough and fast growing. It is beautiful in flower and produces spectacular hips.

Of the many rugosas, the pure-white 'Blanc Double de Coubert' is the most beautiful and best scented, with R rugosa var alba hard on its heels. R 'Roseraie de l'Hay' is the thickest and most floriferous, while the dark foliage and bright red flowers of 'Hunter' make for an almost holly-like contrast. 'Alba' roses are equally tough and also make good hedges, although they are not so free flowering, and Hybrid musks can be kept quite ordered. But centifolias, which include some of the loveliest flowers of all, will never be less than a bosomy, buxom hedge. Any rose hedge, however much you try and restrain it, always adds a softness to the garden, which is psychological as much as visual.

Trim your hedge at the wrong time, though, and it will look neat but have no flowers. As a general rule, you are unlikely to go far wrong if you cut the hedge immediately after flowering, whenever that is. This does mean that by flowering time you will have a full year's growth, so a hawthorn or blackthorn hedge will be distinctly shaggy for half the year.

As a non-floral diversion, you can make fabulous effects with form and space by growing yew or box hedges much wider than their mature height. There is a really good example of this outside the Van Gogh museum in Amsterdam. Evergreen hedges are aesthetically more difficult, and I am not sure that I feel very keen on any of them. I think the wires get crossed. An evergreen hedge is a permanent barrier, whereas a flowering hedge is valued for the way it transforms itself and usurps the preconception of a hedge. If you want evergreen (and I do) why try to go beyond the best - namely yew, box or holly?

Any late-flowering hedge has the advantage of remaining neatly trimmed throughout the winter. I agree that Osmanthus delavayi and O burkwoodii have wonderful fragrance and think they make good shrubs, but I cannot see why you would choose an osmanthus hedge over a holly one in the same situation, unless you were hooked on that particular scent. Choisya ternata can make a good hedge with delicious white flowers and is really tough.

I would stick to the basic plant and avoid the yellow hybrid 'Sundance' on account of it being horrid en masse. If you have lots of space and your tastes incline that way, you can pick innumerable versions of rhododendron hedge, all smothered with flower. I am told that some people like this. If I go beyond my knee-jerk rejection of the whole ericaceous plant world, I think that what I miss in all flowering evergreens is that sense of uncontained wild exuberance that a flowering deciduous hedge somehow brings into the back garden.

Perhaps you need to go to the foothills of the Himalayas and see the rhododendrons flowering there to appreciate their magic fully. For the moment, I shall have to be content with wallowing in the flowering hawthorn hedges outside my window.

Anything other than a low hedge with flowers is best used as a boundary or to divide informal spaces such as the edge of an orchard. Roses, of course, make one of the best flowering hedges of all. You must use shrub roses and feed them well so they establish a good thick shape. Rosa rugosa is the one that is usually called in to perform this task, and does perform it superbly, being tough and fast growing. It is beautiful in flower and produces spectacular hips. Of the many rugosas, the pure-white 'Blanc Double de Coubert' is the most beautiful and best scented, with R rugosa var alba hard on its heels. R 'Roseraie de l'Hay' is the thickest and most floriferous, while the dark foliage and bright red flowers of 'Hunter' make for an almost holly-like contrast. 'Alba' roses are equally tough and also make good hedges, although they are not so free flowering, and Hybrid musks can be kept quite ordered. But centifolias, which include some of the loveliest flowers of all, will never be less than a bosomy, buxom hedge. Any rose hedge, however much you try and restrain it, always adds a softness to the garden, which is psychological as much as visual. Trim your hedge at the wrong time, though, and it will look neat but have no flowers. As a general rule, you are unlikely to go far wrong if you cut the hedge immediately after flowering, whenever that is. This does mean that by flowering time you will have a full year's growth, so a hawthorn or blackthorn hedge will be distinctly shaggy for half the year. As a non-floral diversion, you can make fabulous effects with form and space by growing yew or box hedges much wider than their mature height. There is a really good example of this outside the Van Gogh museum in Amsterdam. Evergreen hedges are aesthetically more difficult, and I am not sure that I feel very keen on any of them. I think the wires get crossed. An evergreen hedge is a permanent barrier, whereas a flowering hedge is valued for the way it transforms itself and usurps the preconception of a hedge. If you want evergreen (and I do) why try to go beyond the best - namely yew, box or holly? Any late-flowering hedge has the advantage of remaining neatly trimmed throughout the winter. I agree that Osmanthus delavayi and O burkwoodii have wonderful fragrance and think they make good shrubs, but I cannot see why you would choose an osmanthus hedge over a holly one in the same situation, unless you were hooked on that particular scent. Choisya ternata can make a good hedge with delicious white flowers and is really tough. I would stick to the basic plant and avoid the yellow hybrid 'Sundance' on account of it being horrid en masse. If you have lots of space and your tastes incline that way, you can pick innumerable versions of rhododendron hedge, all smothered with flower. I am told that some people like this. If I go beyond my knee-jerk rejection of the whole ericaceous plant world, I think that what I miss in all flowering evergreens is that sense of uncontained wild exuberance that a flowering deciduous hedge somehow brings into the back garden. Perhaps you need to go to the foothills of the Himalayas and see the rhododendrons flowering there to appreciate their magic fully. For the moment, I shall have to be content with wallowing in the flowering hawthorn hedges outside my window. webTitle: Stressed out in an exotic hotel

fields.headline: Stressed out in an exotic hotel
fields.trailText: Stressed-out holidaymakers may fly to ever more exotic destinations but more than a quarter of them choose to stay in their rooms rather than explore their surroundings, according to a survey published last week.
fields.body:
Stressed-out holidaymakers may fly to ever more exotic destinations but more than a quarter of them choose to stay in their rooms rather than explore their surroundings, according to a survey published last week. Some just watch TV and videos while others catch up on the romance that they have no time for in their busy lives at home. One in 10 actually go on holiday to find romance.

The holiday itself creates stress with more than half of the sample interviewed by NOP Solutions for the website All-Hotels.com finding the journey the most difficult part. Men find booking the holiday more stressful than woman, which may explain why the poll shows that the Internet has not changed the common practice of woman taking responsibility for booking a household's holiday.

A quarter of all respondents spent more money on their holiday than on going out, cars, household bills and health insurance while one in 10 never took a holiday, either at home or overseas.

One statistic that will not appeal to All-Hotels, a site that features 55,000 hotels worldwide, is that 63 per cent visited travel agents to get brochures before booking their holiday.

• Even postcards are not safe from the reach of Internet sales. A new website, sendacardhome.com, gives a choice of 3,500 postcard views from 1,000 locations in more than 50 countries. You choose your card, write the message and opt for internet despatch or old-fashioned mail. An e-mail costs 10p per address while a posted card is 15p plus local postage.

fields.headline: Shelter from an operatic storm
fields.standfirst: Claudia Pritchard offers an insider's guide to the pleasures and pitfalls of music in the open air
fields.trailText: Claudia Pritchard offers an insider's guide to the pleasures and pitfalls of music in the open air.
fields.body:
The foot soldier perched high above the audience at Verona's great Arena could take it no longer. Perhaps it was the heat, or the altitude, but for whatever reason, he crumpled silently to his knees, toppled gracefully to one side and, while his fellow infantrymen of the Egyptian army belted out a great chorus from Aida, was simply stretchered away, like any casualty of war.

In the cheapest seats at Verona you may need binoculars, cushions and advanced powers of endurance, but you are rewarded with little vignettes such as the occasional collapsing swordbearer, or the snack salesman who slips in a quick rendition of Nessun Dorma between the acts. There is a pecking order at this great open air festival of opera: opera-goers on a tight budget in the towering gradinata tiers need to check in early to get the best, most central positions in their price bracket. Leave it until the last few minutes and you are nearer the celestial stars than the singing ones, and languishing around the edges.

It is a different story in the top price poltrone (literally, 'armchairs') or poltronissime - 'very armchairs?' - at ground level. You get to make a grand entrance through a curtained archway, possibly in the wake of a diva on her night off, whose arrival will be greeted with a great cheer from the crowd already assembled. There is plush red seating, and in the event of rain, the chance of shelter. For it does rain in Verona, and mightily, as storms break operatically over the hills outside the city. One drop, and the orchestra packs up its instruments in mid-bar and makes for cover.

Outside the Arena, the street sellers know a thing or two about meteorology. If they stop selling ices and start selling emergency rainwear half an hour before curtain up, you can be sure of rain. A performance may be interrupted a dozen times before it is abandoned - refunds from the box office need to be avoided. As the storm abates, ticketholders reveal their nationalities: the Italians chuck their plastic macs away, as litter; the British fold them up and take them home.

Opera in the open air is in many ways a mad concept: even the astounding acoustics of Verona's Arena are at full stretch in a solo aria. But in their hearts, the audience have come for the massive choruses - Aida furnishes most, with Carmen a close second - and the theatrical permutations of people-moving.

In smaller auditoria such as the one at Torre del Lago near Puccini's villa, the composer's music is more audible, wafting across the lake where he shot wildfowl con brio. Here too, the elements bring their hazards. There is nothing a well-bred mosquito likes better than a nice succulent opera-goer on a hot, summer's night. Wear your dandiest outfit, certainly, but take your seat without anointing yourself from head to toe in insect repellent and you will be scratching away as rhythmically as the second violins for days to come.

fields.headline: Ken's capital opportunity
fields.trailText: Savour this delicious paradox served up by the mayoral elections in the capital. Ken Livingstone, the old leftist who Tony Blair did not want, is now presented with the challenge of fulfilling New Labour's promise of a new politics.
fields.body:
Savour this delicious paradox served up by the mayoral elections in the capital. Ken Livingstone, the old leftist who Tony Blair did not want, is now presented with the challenge of fulfilling New Labour's promise of a new politics.

London has the chance to be a fascinating laboratory for a consensual, more pluralistic way of governing. That will be the only successful way to run the capital. It has an independent as mayor, and we think, having been elected as an independent, Livingstone should not be rushing back into the Labour Party, even if it will have him. No party is in overall control in the Assembly, thanks to the proportional voting system that Mr Blair insisted on. Mayor and Assembly will work together - or they will hang together.

Livingstone has made the right sort of noises so far, asking members of the Assembly to 'leave the party whip at the door' and spraying job invitations at his opponents. The voters have broken tribal habits; the politicians will have to follow. What is required from him is to create a government for the capital drawn from all available talents and parties. Livingstone fashioned an extraordinary rainbow coalition to win this election; he now needs to do the same in power.

The Government's responsibility is to help make London an advertisement for new politics. Having been slapped in Wales and now stung in the capital, Tony Blair surely must have finally and painfully absorbed the lesson that you can't be both a devolver and a control-freak. Each time New Labour has tried the fix or the meddle, yellow, sticky, runny stuff has exploded all over the Prime Minister's face. So let us hear no more about Ministers shackling and neutering Livingstone. It would be wrong. It would also be stupid.

That would simply give an excuse to Livingstone to return to the indulgent politics of continual opposition, when his energies should be devoted to improving the quality of London life. He has the right and the obligation to pick fights with the Government in pursuit of the capital's interests. The financing of the Tube is the obvious first combustion point. We do not want to see him using his new platform to attack the Government on issues that have nothing to do with the capital.

The opportunity is there for London to be the harbinger of a thrilling revival of civic politics and a refreshing experiment in a new politics. Blair and Livingstone, both of whom would like a second term, have a common interest in seizing that opportunity.

webTitle: Help the aged, don't penalise them

fields.headline: Help the aged, don't penalise them
fields.trailText: Katharine Whitehorn argues that 'it's the people who stop work but having nothing to put in its place who are most unhappy'. And this applies particularly to successful business and professional people whose lives have been focused on their careers.
fields.body:
Katharine Whitehorn argues that 'it's the people who stop work but having nothing to put in its place who are most unhappy'. And this applies particularly to successful business and professional people whose lives have been focused on their careers.

However, even in these ageist times when being over 50 can make getting a job interview almost impossible, the expertise of such people can still be much in demand by the voluntary organisations throughout the UK. Jobs are unpaid, apart from expenses, but can offer great satisfaction. And with nearly 1,000 vacancies, there's a good chance of finding just the appointment which will make best use of a lifetime's expertise. The volunteer gets a renewed sense of purpose in a life after work and the voluntary organisation gets much-needed help it couldn't otherwise afford. A true win-win situation.
Sue Evans
Chief executive, Reach
London SE1

Katharine Whitehorn's article last Sunday says it all about the ever-ageing population, many of whom, like her, can still do useful work well after what used to be normal retiring age. But much worse is the waste of those forced into retirement in middle age.

But she failed to make a vital point. This is happening alongside the cult of overwork, which is ruining the lives of many younger people and those of their families. This combination is at one profoundly antisocial and unbelievably stupid.
J Denza
London NW3

From the view of a dweller in the affluent south, Katharine Whitehorn is probably right. However, about 40 million live outside that area. Many for reasons such as redundancy or poor health have to retire early with little savings, Government policies between 1979 and 1997 being the cause. If she can bring more jobs to the North and Midlands, as a pensioner, who is aware of people who are not self-motivated, I wish her good luck.
J Holden
Bury
Lancs

Katharine Whitehorn greatly exaggerates the extent of changes in the life expectancies of retired people (Comment, last week). It is not true that 'before the war, a pensioner lived for about two or three years after retirement'. In those days nearly all pensioners would be men and on reaching age 65 in the mid-1930s a man had a life expectancy of just over 11 years; if the argument is that many worked until they were older, the fact is that even those men reaching age 75 could expect to live for another five years.
John Craig
Woking
Surrey

fields.headline: Don't waste the phone windfall
fields.trailText: The decision to use the windfall profits from mobile-phone licences to reduce the national debt is a prudent one, but prudence unconnected with generosity can become avarice. Would it be too much to ask that we should devote nine-tenths of the sum to reducing our national debt in the form of the money which our Government owes to our own citizens, and one-tenth of it to reducing the burden of debt of low-income countries owed to governments and international institutions?
fields.body:
The decision to use the windfall profits from mobile-phone licences to reduce the national debt is a prudent one, but prudence unconnected with generosity can become avarice. Would it be too much to ask that we should devote nine-tenths of the sum to reducing our national debt in the form of the money which our Government owes to our own citizens, and one-tenth of it to reducing the burden of debt of low-income countries owed to governments and international institutions?

We cannot do everything ourselves, but at least we could complete the work of remitting bilateral debt owed to UK by low-income countries which Gordon Brown has courageously begun. He has remitted half of this debt - £2 billion out of the £4 billion owed to the UK. The remaining £2 billion pounds is owed by Nigeria, which is a low-income country now under democratic rule, but which has been omitted from the list of 41 Heavily Indebted Poor Countries by the World Bank for specious reasons. We owe it to all low-income countries to help them to escape from the burden of unpayable debt.
Martin Dent
Co-founder, Jubilee 2000
Keele University

Clare Short (Letters, last week) castigates The Observer for not making a clear distinction between 'emergency aid' and 'long-term development assistance'. Do Ethiopians appreciate the distinction; cuts she admits to will punish the poor, regardless of what sort of aid has been cut? The distinction is spurious.
Gail Warden
Eastbourne
E Sussex

fields.headline: Gay parity
fields.trailText: Richard Ingrams's columns may have a lively, entertaining style but are all too frequently sullied with sexism and homophobia. Last week's snide reference to gay people as The Gays is offensive and out of touch. Millions of gay people reject marriage.
fields.body:
Richard Ingrams's columns may have a lively, entertaining style but are all too frequently sullied with sexism and homophobia. Last week's snide reference to gay people as The Gays is offensive and out of touch. Millions of gay people reject marriage.

But, far more important, is the right to simple, legal parity for partners in a relationship whether gay, straight, married or unmarried.
Joanna Walters
London EC1

Populist demand

Andrew Marr (Comment, last week) uses the word 'populist' six times (and your leader on the same page uses it twice) to denote any kind of unprincipled vote-catching. But 100 years ago the American People's Party, or Populists, were mounting a principled and complex challenge to conventional politics.

Starting as a small-farmers' organisation against the 'middlemen', the Populists became an all-round anti-monopoly movement, focusing on the banks and railroads. The anti-trust laws that are giving Bill Gates so much grief stem from the moment Populism crossed over into conventional politics. Were William Hague, Ken Livingstone and Steven Norris really Populists we would be on the verge of radical change.
DBC Reed
Northampton

Get rail on track

It was reassuring to know that we will soon be travelling in new levitating trains at 300mph (News, last week). Most of us would settle for old BR rolling stock being replaced. Perhaps we need to re-assign the engineering brains and powers of invention to repairing what we have before we let them loose on these futuristic projects.
A Robertson
Maidenhead
Berks

Recall Gallipoli

On 25 April, with other relatives of those who fought and died at Gallipoli, we attended the eighty-fifth anniversary of the 1915 campaign. We visited many of the cemeteries of our 21,000 dead and marvelled at their bravery in that disastrous and badly led campaign.

Imagine our dismay at the international service held at the Turkish Memorial where our soldiers and sailors had no official voice to honour them. While the Prime Ministers of Australia and New Zealand gave eloquent speeches, our Government sent a junior Defence Minister, John Spellar, whose rank did not merit an invitation to speak.

When asked for an explanation, Mr Spellar told us that Gallipoli was a long time ago and a long way off. Furthermore, the Prime Minister is a very busy man. He should know that those who fought are still in living memory and 85 years ago were busy dying for our country. They deserve our respect and remembrance.
Ann E Varley and others
Gastard
Wilts

Perverse priority

Last Monday, in Birmingham, a black man was sprayed with inflammable liquid and set on fire. On the same day, in London, a statue and some stones were daubed with paint. Which incident brought forth thunderous denunciations from press and politicians alike?
Tom Paterson
Whitley Bay
Tyne and Wear

Nato too silent

Neither reviewer Peter Beaumont nor author William Shawcross ask whether 'humanitarian intervention' over Kosovo need have taken the form it did (Books, last week). There was, to paraphrase Sherlock Holmes, the curious incident of the Nato watchdog that did nothing in the night-time.

Imagine the impact on Ulster if the Irish Republic had briefly descended into anarchy with all of its armouries looted, enabling the IRA to take control of the border areas. Yet the equivalent occurred in Albania and was tolerated. Worse still, the KLA was eventually recognised as a legitimate party to the dispute without meeting the requirements demanded of the IRA, who had to participate in elections, win seats, stop the armed struggle, and cease setting up no-go areas.

If only Nato had acted in Albania, the 'terrorist' KLA would not have supplanted the 'pacifist' Rugova. It would also have reinforced diplomacy's refrain that Yugoslavia's territorial integrity was inviolable.
Yugo Kovach
Twickenham
Middx

Euro-trash

Last week I bought a jumper from Gap for £34. The price tag also gave the price as FF325 and DM79. Then I read Will Hutton on the euro. At the exchange rate quoted of £1=DM3.36 I could have saved £10.50. The sooner we join the euro the more £10.50s we will have to pay for the cars that are now going to be manufactured abroad. Perhaps Mr Byers has not even been successful in controlling Rip Off Britain. The jumper is in no sense transparent!
Raymond Maher
Harrow
Middx

Last week's snide reference to gay people as The Gays is offensive and out of touch. Millions of gay people reject marriage. But, far more important, is the right to simple, legal parity for partners in a relationship whether gay, straight, married or unmarried. Joanna Walters London EC1 Populist demand Andrew Marr (Comment, last week) uses the word 'populist' six times (and your leader on the same page uses it twice) to denote any kind of unprincipled vote-catching. But 100 years ago the American People's Party, or Populists, were mounting a principled and complex challenge to conventional politics. Starting as a small-farmers' organisation against the 'middlemen', the Populists became an all-round anti-monopoly movement, focusing on the banks and railroads. The anti-trust laws that are giving Bill Gates so much grief stem from the moment Populism crossed over into conventional politics. Were William Hague, Ken Livingstone and Steven Norris really Populists we would be on the verge of radical change. DBC Reed Northampton Get rail on track It was reassuring to know that we will soon be travelling in new levitating trains at 300mph (News, last week). fields.headline: Time for better childcare
fields.trailText: You report that Childcare Commission chair Harriet Harman MP hopes findings from a recent childcare research review will help working mothers 'break through the guilt barrier' (News, last week).
fields.body:
You report that Childcare Commission chair Harriet Harman MP hopes findings from a recent childcare research review will help working mothers 'break through the guilt barrier' (News, last week).

In our experience, mothers and fathers do not so much feel guilty about going out to work as miserable at the lamentably low levels of quality childcare provision to which this Government has yet to make a significant difference.
Dr Jacqueline Barnes
Senior lecturer, Royal Free and University College Medical School
London
Eva Lloyd
Chief Executive, National Early Years Network
London N7

Your article on working mothers confirmed facts I have long known. Twenty years ago I was the first person to take maternity leave from my job as biomedical scientist in a hospital pathology laboratory.

I have two well balanced children, one studying medicine at university, the other in full-time employment. My income allowed my family to benefit from an enhanced lifestyle.

I, on the other hand, am clapped out at 49! The years of working long hours in a stressful job and juggling family commitments have taken their toll. In particular I suffer from chronic insomnia. I would be ready to retire at 50, let alone have to struggle on to 65.

I hope my daughters have the choice not to work if they have children.
Penelope Elsey
Crawley Down
W Sussex

webTitle: Leading lights in line for London's cabinet

fields.headline: Leading lights in line for London's cabinet
fields.trailText: Nicky Gavron
fields.body:
Nicky Gavron

Nicky Gavron, a senior Labour local authority figure, has been a Haringey councillor since 1986. She is also a millionaire, having once been married to a printing tycoon .

Described as a 'quango queen' who sits on a multitude of public bodies - including the London Planning Advisory Committee, which she headed - she has made her name with innovative environmental initiatives. She introduced a successful waste recycling campaign in the capital with £12 million from then Tory Environment Secretary John Gummer and angered the car lobby by proposing that drivers in central London should face tolls.

As Haringey councillor she voted to sell off the education authority. She came top in the Labour primaries for the Greater London Assembly and angered Lord Harris of Haringey for choosing his turf as her constituency. She was married to Lord Gavron, who recently donated £500,000 to Labour and was chairman of the Guardian Media Group. They have two daughters but were divorced in 1987.
Antony Barnett

Lee Jasper

Lee Jasper, secretary of the National Assembly Against Racism and director of the 1990 Trust, a think-tank specialising in policing, equality and immigration, is an outspoken critic of the Metropolitan police. The 42-year-old father of five gave evidence to the Stephen Lawrence inquiry and led calls for the resignation of Sir Paul Condon.

Politically active since the late Eighties, he came to prominence in 1996 during riots in Brixton that followed the death of a young black man, Wayne Douglas. Jasper organised the main rally and made angry speeches. Three police officers were injured and £1 million worth of damage was done to local buildings. Jasper was accused of inciting the crowd but was not charged.

The son of a Jamaican-born father and English mother, he studied social science at Manchester Polytechnic. He is a full-time father and supports himself by giving lectures on race relations to police officers around the country.
Tony Thompson

webTitle: Be moderate or be a loser, senior Tories warn Hague

fields.headline: Be moderate or be a loser, senior Tories warn Hague
fields.standfirst:
Elections 2000: special report
Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Tory euphoria over last week's elections has been punctured by warnings from moderate members of the party that the results cannot be seen as an endorsement of William Hague's lurch to the right.
fields.byline: by Anthony Browne and Andy McSmith
fields.body:
Tory euphoria over last week's elections has been punctured by warnings from moderate members of the party that the results cannot be seen as an endorsement of William Hague's lurch to the right.

Tory politicians have warned Hague that the elections demonstrate that the party is still deeply unpopular, with one former Tory Minister saying it shows the country still 'hates us'. Tory heavyweights have warned Hague he must keep to the centre ground if he is to have any chance of winning the general election.

The Conservatives gained almost 600 seats in the local elections, but dramatically lost the Westminster seat of Romsey to the Liberal Democrats. One of their strongest performances was in London, where the unsuccessful mayoral candidate Steve Norris did unexpectedly well after publicly distancing himself from many of Hague's policies on issues such as asylum-seekers and gays.

Former Tory Foreign Secretary Sir Malcolm Rifkind will warn Scottish Conservatives today of the need to strike a 'moderate' tone if they are to regain electoral support.

In what is likely to be seen as a public rebuke to Hague, Rifkind will urge his party in Scotland: 'To win support will require effort, attractive policies and moderate rhetoric.'

But he will warn: 'That is also the task of the Conservative Party as a whole, as we approach the general election.'

The intervention from moderate Tories is likely to be seen as a warning to Hague, who has been accused by party critics of shifting from the centre ground to the right. The former Tory Deputy Prime Minister, Michael Heseltine, suggested the elections showed Norris had as much support for his moderate policies as Hague did for his.

He told The Observer: 'Steve Norris did commendably well in London. It could be said Norris took a different message than Hague. Both could claim their message delivered success.'

The former Tory Minister David Curry MP said the results showed his party was still deeply unpopular: 'The electorate still hates us as a parliamentary party. The electorate hasn't changed its opinion of us since '97 - it has not forgiven us. It is absolutely clear the country still thinks of us as a grim lot.

'Steve demonstrated in London that you've simply got to be inclusive in order to be able to appeal. The essential thing for Tories is that we must reinvent one-nation Conservatism. The former Tory Science Minister Ian Taylor said: We need to be a party that stands for something, rather than just being against things,' he said.

'We are against the euro, asylum-seekers and criminals, but we don't appear to have much concern for people who feel themselves to be socially excluded.'

fields.headline: Treble whammies all round
fields.trailText: Although they were quite good at whacking people in the old days, the Jesuits never taught us about the 'double whammy'. It was left to Chris Patten, a Benedictine, to introduce the phrase into English parlance.
fields.body:
Although they were quite good at whacking people in the old days, the Jesuits never taught us about the 'double whammy'. It was left to Chris Patten, a Benedictine, to introduce the phrase into English parlance.

For some time I have had a nagging feeling there may be some kind of link between Labour's current economic policies and the concept of the double whammy. But when I have asked users of the term what it means, they have, as it were, been lost for words.

The wonderful Information Resource Center at the United States Embassy has come to the rescue: a double whammy is 'a double portion of something, especially something troublesome'. It appears in dictionaries of American slang, and Al Capp's Li'l Abner, the cartoon strip, is cited as a source.

The pound has risen so high that in itself it constitutes a double, or perhaps triple whammy. The mass redundancies threatened at Longbridge, Dagenham and, now it seems, Llanwern (the steel industry), are caused by a number of factors, but few people now disagree that a common factor is the high pound.

Despite the Government's attempt to blame it on the euro, the fact of the matter is that the Government has not conducted economic policy in a way that makes avoidance of an overvalued pound a serious objective. Intervention in the exchange markets has been eschewed; and, for all the Chancellor's brilliance in producing a fiscal surplus, one is reminded of the days when fiscal surpluses were cited as a reason why taxes should not be raised to curb a consumer and house price boom, and too much reliance was placed on the 'single club' of interest rates, during the Lawson boom of the late Eighties.

But there is another, separate whammy exacerbating these industrial troubles: it is New Labour's embrace of the nearest it can get to US-style labour laws. The Government espouses free markets and an easy hire-and-fire approach. When multinationals make their decisions in response to, say, overcapacity in the car or steel industries, it is easier to fire and shut down in the UK than it is in most Continental countries.

Thus from the point of view of the likely social distress and political trouble to come from plant closures in the Labour heartlands, the free-market approach to the value of the pound, and the much-vaunted 'flexible labour market' in Britain can be seen as a multiple whammy.

At a superficial level, the Government resembles Labour governments of old. Indeed, some siren voices have been raised recently warning Messrs Blair and Byers of the follies of contemplating a return to the bad old days, when uneconomic firms were almost routinely propped up by the Government in time of crisis.

But the problem with the overvalued pound - and it now seems to be every bit as overvalued as it was in the sado-monetarist period of 1980-81 - is that it affects not only uneconomic, so-called 'sunset' or 'old economy' industries: it affects every manufacturer. Last week, for example, Toshiba, not widely known for producing uneconomic coal, described the level of sterling as 'unbearable'.

There is accumulating evidence that firms are surviving by re-sourcing their supplies from abroad, and the Confederation of British Industry warns it is not only investment by foreign firms that is threatened by present uncompetitive pound.

The Bank of England's monetary policy committee (MPC) was clearly alive to fears that sterling might rise even higher when it left interest rates unchanged last week.

The MPC has been much praised for its achievement of the 2.5 per cent inflation target, yet the Treasury warns us wage earnings are rising at 6.2 per cent per annum and 'real earnings' are shooting up at rates reminiscent of the Lawson boom. Try as they will, the official statisticians cannot find the underlying productivity improvements to justify this trend.

The truth that can only just dare to speak its name is that it is the overvaluation of sterling that has enabled the MPC to achieve the inflation target. Eddie George can hardly appear in public now without warning that a devaluation of sterling would probably force the MPC to raise interest rates. This would be in order to offset the inflationary impact of a devaluation. I sniff another double whammy lurking here somewhere.

Last week the Prime Minister declared: 'The worst thing we could do is to try artificially to devalue the currency.' Yet the currency is artificially high, and causing serious damage.

What it boils down to is that the Government has not been nearly as successful with the economy as the conventional wisdom has supposed. The pound in your pocket has not yet been devalued, but it will have to be if Britain is to retain a viable industrial sector.

The control freaks are now at the mercy of events and the markets. I have lost count of how many whammies we have here...

webTitle: Trust the key as guns fall silent

fields.headline: Trust the key as guns fall silent
fields.standfirst:
Mary Holland says all sides may now have realised that there is no alternative to compromise

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: At Hillsborough on Friday night Tony Blair and Bertie Ahern both looked exhausted.
fields.body:
At Hillsborough on Friday night Tony Blair and Bertie Ahern both looked exhausted.

There was no talk of the 'hand of history' on Blair's shoulder, nor of 'seismic shifts' in the positions of the conflicting parties. Instead the British Prime Minister described his involvement in the peace process as 'deeply fulfilling but also deeply frustrating.'

Most people who have watched the years of violence in Northern Ireland and the long task of bringing an equitable political settlement to the province would agree.

Blair is right to stress the progress that has been made. Peace on the streets, a power-sharing government up and working - albeit only for a brief period - the overwhelming desire of the majority of the people in Northern Ireland to secure a lasting peace through political compromise. A very cautious optimism is in order.

There have been so many false dawns. The statement by the two governments on Friday raises as many questions as it answers. The IRA's statement yesterday which pledges 'a process that will completely and verifiably put arms beyond use' and offers to allow 'the contents of a number of our arms dumps' to be inspected by third parties is a major step forward.

The process that led to yesterday's announcement began with a phone call on 12 February when the Northern Ireland Secretary called Dublin's Foreign Minister Brian Cowen with the outline of a plan aimed at breaking the decommissioning deadlock. At its heart was the concept that the IRA should be allowed to control the process of their arms being put beyond use for ever.

Mandelson's idea was that this would remove the impression in republican minds that decommissioning was tantamount to surrender.

But will it win over David Trimble, without alienating republicans who may see it as the IRA 'dancing to the Unionists' tune'. Will Trimble be able to sell it to his party's governing body on 20 May, just two days before the proposed restoration of the executive? The Unionist leader's position has become even more embattled since March when he appeared to soften his stance on 'no guns, no government'. Many of his supporters will reject the IRA's statement because it falls short of delivering the 'actual product'.

Is the IRA merely playing for time, hoping to wring more concessions?

The suspension of the political institutions by Mandelson on 10 February was done to save Trimble's skin, but it enraged Sinn Fein and the Irish government. The republicans never really believed that suspension would happen and underestimated Mandelson's view that it was necessary to rescue not only Trimble, but the dwindling band of unionists who continued to support the Belfast Agreement.

Mandelson, for his part, failed to understand how crucial the existence of the power-sharing executive and cross-border bodies were to Gerry Adams. Sinn Fein needs to show its supporters that politics can work and that the Belfast Agreement has the potential to deliver concrete political gains.

Many unionists suspect it is a plot to water down Northern Ireland's links with Britain and move the province, slowly but surely, into a united Ireland. Their fears were exacerbated last week by a leak of a Northern Ireland Office document which described Brian Cowen as demanding that 'there should be no further evidence of Britishness in the governance of Northern Ireland'.

On the nationalist side, particularly in Republican areas such as South Armagh, there are complaints that the Agreement has changed nothing. There are still British soldiers on the ground, the RUC is still the RUC, few of the pledges in the 'equality agenda' have translated into reality.

The statement by the prime ministers addresses these issues. But at the heart of the peace process is a darker problem - how do you build trust between two communities who have feared each other for generations and have both suffered appalling violence and grief?

Many people outside Northern Ireland find it difficult to understand why decommissioning has been such an obstacle. After all, the guns are silent. Well, relatively so. Why not build on this and hope the whole problem will fade away?

The idea of arms being put beyond use rather than surrendered was first mooted by Dublin officials two years ago. But the first republican to amplify the view was Danny Morrison, the former Sinn Fein publicity director, IRA prisoner and now writer. He suggested the IRA put their arms into sealed dumps in an article in The Observer last December.

The demand for the handover of guns is hugely symbolic to both sides. The republican movement sees it as a demand for surrender. Many of its political leaders - Adams and Martin McGuinness for example - were themselves active in 'the armed struggle'. One Sinn Fein spokesman said: 'Handing over guns would be a betrayal of all we fought for and of those who died. It would mean admitting that we had been wrong all along, that Bobby Sands and the other hunger strikers were criminals.'

Unionists do not see decommissioning in the same light. Many suspect that the IRA is holding on to its weapons for use at some future date, when Sinn Fein has extracted maximum gains from the Government. They are already bruised by concessions that have been made. Others think no nationalist can be trusted and that Sinn Fein's involvement in politics is solely to bring about a united Ireland.

There are more hopeful factors. Monica McWilliams of the Women's Coalition, long a generous and constructive voice, put it well last week. She said that the peace process would get back on track: 'Have you ever seen a politician who had tasted power and did not want it back?'

The brief weeks when the Executive was running, when old enemies showed that they were able to work together, offered a tantalising glimpse of how things could be. People liked what they saw. At a practical level, they preferred dealing with local politicians. At a more emotional level, the Executive and the Assembly seemed to show that it was possible to move away from violence and division and to operate normal, democratic politics.

A negotiator in the talks to end apartheid in South Africa once said that there is a moment in every peace process where both sides finally accept that they have nowhere else to go. There has to be compromise because the only alternative is a return to violence. We may, at last, have reached that point in Northern Ireland. David Trimble and his supporters know that they have cut the best deal on offer to the unionist community. Nationalists have accepted that there will be no change in the constitutional position of Northern Ireland until a majority of people want it. If this deal fails the alternative will be moves towards joint authority and the erosion of the link with Britain.

Politicians and secretaries of state come and go, but what is happening here is an attempt to lay to rest the legacy of a centuries-old history of division. There are still difficulties ahead and we will see more days of doom and gloom. Slowly but surely, though, the people and the politicians are moving towards what everybody wants, a secure peace.

Last week was a bad one for Tony Blair. There were cracks that he had fled to Northern Ireland to escape all that. But Blair's commitment to achieving peace for the next generation cannot be faulted and, if he succeeds in solving the Irish problem, that is what history will remember.
fields.bodyText: At Hillsborough on Friday night Tony Blair and Bertie Ahern both looked exhausted. There was no talk of the 'hand of history' on Blair's shoulder, nor of 'seismic shifts' in the positions of the conflicting parties. Instead the British Prime Minister described his involvement in the peace process as 'deeply fulfilling but also deeply frustrating.' Most people who have watched the years of violence in Northern Ireland and the long task of bringing an equitable political settlement to the province would agree. Blair is right to stress the progress that has been made. Peace on the streets, a power-sharing government up and working - albeit only for a brief period - the overwhelming desire of the majority of the people in Northern Ireland to secure a lasting peace through political compromise. A very cautious optimism is in order. There have been so many false dawns. The statement by the two governments on Friday raises as many questions as it answers. The IRA's statement yesterday which pledges 'a process that will completely and verifiably put arms beyond use' and offers to allow 'the contents of a number of our arms dumps' to be inspected by third parties is a major step forward. The process that led to yesterday's announcement began with a phone call on 12 February when the Northern Ireland Secretary called Dublin's Foreign Minister Brian Cowen with the outline of a plan aimed at breaking the decommissioning deadlock. At its heart was the concept that the IRA should be allowed to control the process of their arms being put beyond use for ever. Mandelson's idea was that this would remove the impression in republican minds that decommissioning was tantamount to surrender. But will it win over David Trimble, without alienating republicans who may see it as the IRA 'dancing to the Unionists' tune'. Will Trimble be able to sell it to his party's governing body on 20 May, just two days before the proposed restoration of the executive? The Unionist leader's position has become even more embattled since March when he appeared to soften his stance on 'no guns, no government'. Many of his supporters will reject the IRA's statement because it falls short of delivering the 'actual product'. Is the IRA merely playing for time, hoping to wring more concessions? The suspension of the political institutions by Mandelson on 10 February was done to save Trimble's skin, but it enraged Sinn Fein and the Irish government. The republicans never really believed that suspension would happen and underestimated Mandelson's view that it was necessary to rescue not only Trimble, but the dwindling band of unionists who continued to support the Belfast Agreement. Mandelson, for his part, failed to understand how crucial the existence of the power-sharing executive and cross-border bodies were to Gerry Adams. Sinn Fein needs to show its supporters that politics can work and that the Belfast Agreement has the potential to deliver concrete political gains. Many unionists suspect it is a plot to water down Northern Ireland's links with Britain and move the province, slowly but surely, into a united Ireland. Their fears were exacerbated last week by a leak of a Northern Ireland Office document which described Brian Cowen as demanding that 'there should be no further evidence of Britishness in the governance of Northern Ireland'. On the nationalist side, particularly in Republican areas such as South Armagh, there are complaints that the Agreement has changed nothing. There are still British soldiers on the ground, the RUC is still the RUC, few of the pledges in the 'equality agenda' have translated into reality. The statement by the prime ministers addresses these issues. But at the heart of the peace process is a darker problem - how do you build trust between two communities who have feared each other for generations and have both suffered appalling violence and grief? Many people outside Northern Ireland find it difficult to understand why decommissioning has been such an obstacle. After all, the guns are silent. Well, relatively so. Why not build on this and hope the whole problem will fade away? The idea of arms being put beyond use rather than surrendered was first mooted by Dublin officials two years ago. But the first republican to amplify the view was Danny Morrison, the former Sinn Fein publicity director, IRA prisoner and now writer. He suggested the IRA put their arms into sealed dumps in an article in The Observer last December. The demand for the handover of guns is hugely symbolic to both sides. The republican movement sees it as a demand for surrender. Many of its political leaders - Adams and Martin McGuinness for example - were themselves active in 'the armed struggle'. One Sinn Fein spokesman said: 'Handing over guns would be a betrayal of all we fought for and of those who died. It would mean admitting that we had been wrong all along, that Bobby Sands and the other hunger strikers were criminals.' Unionists do not see decommissioning in the same light. Many suspect that the IRA is holding on to its weapons for use at some future date, when Sinn Fein has extracted maximum gains from the Government. They are already bruised by concessions that have been made. Others think no nationalist can be trusted and that Sinn Fein's involvement in politics is solely to bring about a united Ireland. There are more hopeful factors. Monica McWilliams of the Women's Coalition, long a generous and constructive voice, put it well last week. She said that the peace process would get back on track: 'Have you ever seen a politician who had tasted power and did not want it back?' The brief weeks when the Executive was running, when old enemies showed that they were able to work together, offered a tantalising glimpse of how things could be. People liked what they saw. At a practical level, they preferred dealing with local politicians. At a more emotional level, the Executive and the Assembly seemed to show that it was possible to move away from violence and division and to operate normal, democratic politics. A negotiator in the talks to end apartheid in South Africa once said that there is a moment in every peace process where both sides finally accept that they have nowhere else to go. There has to be compromise because the only alternative is a return to violence. We may, at last, have reached that point in Northern Ireland. David Trimble and his supporters know that they have cut the best deal on offer to the unionist community. Nationalists have accepted that there will be no change in the constitutional position of Northern Ireland until a majority of people want it. If this deal fails the alternative will be moves towards joint authority and the erosion of the link with Britain. Politicians and secretaries of state come and go, but what is happening here is an attempt to lay to rest the legacy of a centuries-old history of division. There are still difficulties ahead and we will see more days of doom and gloom. Slowly but surely, though, the people and the politicians are moving towards what everybody wants, a secure peace. But Blair's commitment to achieving peace for the next generation cannot be faulted and, if he succeeds in solving the Irish problem, that is what history will remember.

fields.headline: DNA tests to identify rioters
fields.trailText: Half-eaten hamburgers stolen in the attack on McDonald's during last week's anti-capitalist demonstrations are enabling those involved to be identified.
fields.body:
Half-eaten hamburgers stolen in the attack on McDonald's during last week's anti-capitalist demonstrations are enabling those involved to be identified.

DNA readings from saliva samples are expected to produce several names. Further DNA evidence has been collected from blood on the restaurant's windows - a number of protesters cut themselves while smashing panes. Everyone arrested in the capital is now required to submit a DNA sample. The fast-growing database has led to hundreds of arrests.

The violent nature of the protests has sparked infighting among rival groups. Reclaim the Streets is furious that anarchists disrupted a peaceful day of action by attacking the Cenotaph and vandalising a statue of Winston Churchill. 'It was an act of stupidity which damaged our image. There are times when criminal damage is useful - as with the destruction of genetically modified crops - and times when it is useless,' said John Jordan, of Reclaim the Streets.

Jordan said the anti-capitalist group would continue to mount days of action - the next is planned to coincide with a meeting of the International Monetary Fund in Prague in September - but would learn to control them more tightly. 'We want to stop the nutters taking over.'

Assistant Metropolitan Police Commissioner Ian Johnston said between 500 and 1,000 hardcore protesters were estimated to be behind the trouble. He defended police 'softly, softly' tactics. 'There were officers in standard uniform outside McDonald's before the attack. They were forced to retreat when missiles were thrown and were replaced by officers in full riot gear. If those in riot gear had been there from the start, they would have been accused of inciting a riot.'

webTitle: Mayor Ken recruits top race radical

fields.headline: Mayor Ken recruits top race radical
fields.standfirst: Appointment of outspoken black activist set to unnerve Downing St.
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone yesterday underlined his determination to bring a new kind of politics to London by appointing a radical black activist to his mayoral Cabinet. Lee Jasper, a Brixton community leader, has been given responsibility for race relations and liaison with the Metropolitan Police.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone yesterday underlined his determination to bring a new kind of politics to London by appointing a radical black activist to his mayoral Cabinet. Lee Jasper, a Brixton community leader, has been given responsibility for race relations and liaison with the Metropolitan Police.

The capital's first elected Mayor has also told Tony Blair he will be apply to rejoin the Labour Party this year.

The appointment of Jasper was made within hours of a friendly 20-minute telephone conversation between Livingstone and the Prime Minister, in which both promised to work together.

Blair promised Livingstone co-operation from Labour, despite a hard-fought election campaign in which the Prime Minister repeatedly warned voters that the left-winger was unfit to be Mayor.

Livingstone repeated his wish to be allowed back into the party, having been expelled for a minimum of five years for running against Labour's official candidate, Frank Dobson.

Speaking exclusively, Livingstone told The Observer: 'I said I would be applying to join, but I didn't want to embarrass him. I'd wait, and clearly he'd want to wait and see how I'd perform as Mayor. We'll think about it after the summer. I know a lot of people in the party want me back in, and I'm sure there'll be some sort of debate about this at the party conference.'

Several London Labour constituency parties are expected to try to use the autumn conference to force through a vote ending Livingstone's exile. But party officials insist there is no prospect of Livingstone rejoining before 2005.

Livingstone's decision to turn to Jasper, rather than the better known former TV presenter Trevor Phillips, as the main voice of London's black community, will increase Labour's nervousness about whether they can work with the new Mayor.

A jokey comment by Jasper was one of the main weapons used by Labour against Livingstone during the campaign. When The Observer first reported the possibility of Jasper's appointment, he joked that it would have senior officers at Scotland Yard 'tearing their hair out'.

Livingstone said yesterday: 'Lee, like me, has learnt that having a sense of humour is not compatible with public life. I don't want people around me who don't have a sense of humour. He has been working with the Met as an adviser for years. They are very impressed with him.'

Livingstone will open negotiations this week with the nine Labour members of the Greater London Assembly over the appointment of a Deputy Mayor. Yesterday he offered the post to Labour assembly member Nicky Gavron.

Livingstone is upset that Phillips' former press officer Adrian McMenamin arranged for a complaint about Livingstone's £160,000 annual earnings from speeches and journalism to go to the Commissioner for Standards and Privileges, earning him a public rebuke.

Livingstone vowed yesterday never to use one of the Mayor's perks: a chauffeur driven car. He will travel to work by Tube. 'I renewed my season ticket,' he said.

fields.headline: Mugabe's army hands out guns
fields.standfirst:
Deaths spiral as Zimbabwe plunges into election war for votes

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: State-sponsored violence against Zimbabwe's opposition has reached the proportions of a war, with beatings and killings spreading to cities and remote rural areas.
fields.body:
State-sponsored violence against Zimbabwe's opposition has reached the proportions of a war, with beatings and killings spreading to cities and remote rural areas.

Supporters of President Robert Mugabe have killed more than 18 supporters of the new opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) since 1 April. A further increase in the violence looms with reports that 21,000 AK-47 rifles have been imported into Zimbabwe by the government for distribution to Mugabe's supporters.

There are fears the seizure of properties by government supporters may move into the cities, with the news that a block of flats in Bulawayo has been taken over by Mugabe's supporters.

Members of the Affirmative Action Group (AAG), which supports Mugabe, broke into the apartment building and allocated flats to their members. It had been vacant for several months awaiting redevelopment by its owner, a businessman of Asian descent. The AAG had threatened to take over the building, claiming it was 'under-utilised'.

A letter threatening Zimbabwe's small but prosperous Asian community has also circulated in Harare and Bulawayo. The letter, purportedly from the AAG, warns Asian businessmen they will meet with 'harsh measures' if they do not support Mugabe's Zanu-PF party in the coming elections, due by August. Zanu-PF is facing its strongest challenge in its 20 years in power from the MDC.

The invasions of nearly 1,200 white-owned farms by Mugabe's supporters is Zanu-PF's campaign strategy to win votes in the rural areas, where 65 per cent of Zimbabwe's 12 million people live. 'Land is the economy, the economy is land,' is Zanu-PF's slogan for the elections. The farm invaders have concentrated on stamping out support for the MDC among white farmers and their workforce, who are estimated to number about 500,000 out of a total of 5.2 million registered voters.

Violence by Mugabe's supporters has created turmoil on the farms. Now it has spread to the nearby rural areas where peasant farmers live and to the townships of the country's cities. Gangs of Zanu-PF supporters, including veterans of the war against Rhodesian rule, members of the army and the Central Intelligence Organisation (CIO), have beaten, tortured and killed those suspected of supporting the opposition MDC.

There have been more than 50 cases of political violence in Harare's townships since April.

'Mugabe's supporters threatened to take the country back to war if Zanu-PF lost the elections. In fact, they have already unleashed that war. We are for all intents and purposes living in a war zone,' said Iden Wetherell, deputy editor of the Zimbabwe Independent. 'The levels of violence and intimidation in the rural areas are as high as they were during the war years. This is what happens when you allow rule of law to break down in one area; it spreads to other areas. These are obviously not circumstances in which free and fair elections can be held.'

The invasions of Zimbabwe's white-owned farms have continued unabated, despite a highly publicised agreement between the war veterans and the white farmers. Last week 46 new farms were occupied and many reported violent attacks upon their farm workers. Leaders of the Commercial Farmers Union (CFU), which represents the country's 4,500 white farmers, have finally had enough of trying to appease Mugabe and on Friday the CFU launched an outspoken attack accusing him of encouraging the invasions.

'We have a situation developing to what looks like major insurrection. The war veterans can do what they like. It's total anarchy,' said CFU deputy director Jerry Grant.

The invasions of white-owned farms have been planned and carried out by the Zimbabwe National Army and the Central Intelligence Organisation, according to reports in the Zimbabwe Independent, which details how several army units have been transporting and feeding the thousands of blacks who are occupying the farms. It also reported that 21,000 AK-47 automatic rifles were imported from Russia to Harare's Manyame air force base recently.

'It is likely that these weapons will be distributed liberally to farm squatters, thereby giving the police commissioner another excuse not to enforce the law and kick them out,' said an army source.

fields.headline: @large
fields.trailText: Things look set to turn very ugly in the battle of the artists formerly known as Radio One DJs. In the blue corner we have Peter Powell, ex-squeeze of Anthea Turner, with his dot.com offering. In the other we now have pint-sized spinmeister Bruno Brookes who is, erm, another ex-squeeze of Anthea.
fields.body:
Jockeys getting in a spin

Things look set to turn very ugly in the battle of the artists formerly known as Radio One DJs. In the blue corner we have Peter Powell, ex-squeeze of Anthea Turner, with his dot.com offering. In the other we now have pint-sized spinmeister Bruno Brookes who is, erm, another ex-squeeze of Anthea. Bruno is launching Storm Radio, 'the world's first celebrity-led Internet-only radio station'. Top celebs featuring on the new station include Joe Absolom (Matthew from EastEnders) and Jo Guest (Jo Guest from the world of glamour modelling). And there's a welcome back to Kim Appleby, formerly of pop duo Mel & Kim. Blimey.

What's the beef?

Mind you, the Brookes-Powell feud is nothing compared with that set to break out in cyberspace between Burger King and McDonalds. BK is launching an online advertising campaign which neatly sidesteps broadcasting restrictions on comparative advertising. Distinctly unchuffed at not being able to reveal that its range of Doubles burgers are 26 per cent beefier than the Big Mac in its TV ads, BK is launching an Internet campaign to show 'the truth' at www.burgerking.co.uk. That spluttering sound you're hearing? That's the sound of lawyers licking their lips.

Lost letters

A big hello to Mooov.com, an online service that purports to 'guide the consumer through the mad wonderful world of moving home'. Philip Orwell, boss of this company, which hopes to 'inject a bit of pleasure into the house-buying process', has an interesting CV. Philip 'grew up in Hampstead and was briefly excluded from school in 1976 for reading E.E. Cummings' we are told in a press release. [ A pedant writes: I think you'll find that should be e e cummings .] Honestly, these dot.com people. One minute they're changing capitals into little letters; now they're going the other way. The barbarians are truly at the gate.

Ether alcohol

Online wine retailer rouge-blanc.com reports that the average price of an Internet purchase in the UK is £30, compared with £50 in France and Germany. Apparently, wine and spirits accounts for eight per cent of web purchases in the UK, compared with nine per cent in France and 12 per cent in Germany.

fields.headline: Anger at Kosovo mines contract
fields.standfirst:
Firm accused of human rights abuses wins million-pound Government deal

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: A private military company accused of human rights abuses has been awarded lucrative Government contracts to clear unexploded mines and cluster bombs in Kosovo,  The Observer can reveal.
fields.body:
A private military company accused of human rights abuses has been awarded lucrative Government contracts to clear unexploded mines and cluster bombs in Kosovo, The Observer can reveal.

The decision, taken by International Development Secretary Clare Short, has infuriated MPs, charities and anti-arms trade campaigners.

Since the end of the Kosovo conflict, the Government has awarded two mine-clearance contracts worth more than £1 million to Defence Systems, a London-based firm, founded by former senior SAS officer Alistair Morrison, which has been involved in a spate of human rights controversies.

United Nations' special rapporteur, Enrique Ballesteros, stated in a 1998 report that it was concerned about DSL's alleged 'mercenary' activities in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

DSL's activities in Colombia, where it has been employed by BP to protect its multi-billion pound interests, have long been a concern to human rights organisations. In 1998 it was expelled from Angola for alleged 'illegal activities'.

DSL also recommended Sandline International - the firm involved in the arms-to-Sierra Leone scandal - to the government of Papua New Guinea when it needed mercenary help.

Labour MP Ann Clwyd, a member of the House of Commons International Development Select Committee, will raise questions in Parliament this week. 'Why are we giving taxpayers' money to a firm with a record like DSL so that it can make a profit out of clearing mines in Kosovo?' said Clwyd. 'I want to know what checks were done by the Government.'

Since April 1997, DSL has been owned by US security giant Armor Holdings, which sells body armour and riot control equipment.

Richard Lloyd, director of the UK working group on land mines, is concerned that firms like DSL are using land mine clearance as a way to gain respectability.

Lloyd said: 'The operation in Kosovo is highly sensitive. Aid organisations and charities are experienced and well-equipped to deal with this, but questions have to be asked about whether the same can be said of a militaristic private company with a dodgy track record.'

The Campaign Against the Arms Trade will also protest against the DSL contract.

DSL has used former British servicemen to offer protection against kidnapping, espionage and terrorism to multinationals operating in 'risky' regions.

Nigel Woof, Armor's vice chairman of marketing, dismisses allegations of human rights abuses against DSL.

He said DSL is not only used by private corporations but by the UN, human aid groups and Western governments to protect embassies.

Woof said: 'We have never, and will never be involved in mercenary activities. We are proud of what we do and operate a disciplined and ethical operation.'

However, accusations of human rights abuses have been hard to shake off.

It was alleged that DSL trained Colombian police in counter-insurgency techniques using ex-SAS personnel and fed intelligence on anyone opposed to BP to Columbia's 14th brigade - a group of soldiers with a record of atrocities including the massacre of 43 people in 1988.

A report by the Parliamentary Human Rights Group entitled 'The Business of Killing' said the main concern was that DSL passed on information on environmentalists and community leaders.

Both DSL and BP claimed the only training they gave was defensive. But documents obtained by the Guardian showed that a senior DSL employee, Roger Brown, was in charge of security for the 520-mile Ocensa oil pipeline in Colombia, in which BP is a major shareholder.

Brown was a key figure in a proposed pipeline protection project with the 14th Brigade and Israeli security company Silver Shadow, involving attack helicopters and the 'direct supply of anti-guerrilla special weaponry'. When this came to light, BP suspended Brown, who until recently continued to work for DSL.

DSL is one of five companies to be awarded mine-clearance contracts worth £13.5m in Kosovo.

A spokesman for the International Development Department said: 'We deplore the use of and training of mercenaries, but there was no evidence that DSL should not be granted the contract.'
fields.bodyText: A private military company accused of human rights abuses has been awarded lucrative Government contracts to clear unexploded mines and cluster bombs in Kosovo, The Observer can reveal. The decision, taken by International Development Secretary Clare Short, has infuriated MPs, charities and anti-arms trade campaigners. Since the end of the Kosovo conflict, the Government has awarded two mine-clearance contracts worth more than £1 million to Defence Systems, a London-based firm, founded by former senior SAS officer Alistair Morrison, which has been involved in a spate of human rights controversies. United Nations' special rapporteur, Enrique Ballesteros, stated in a 1998 report that it was concerned about DSL's alleged 'mercenary' activities in the Democratic Republic of Congo. DSL's activities in Colombia, where it has been employed by BP to protect its multi-billion pound interests, have long been a concern to human rights organisations. In 1998 it was expelled from Angola for alleged 'illegal activities'. DSL also recommended Sandline International - the firm involved in the arms-to-Sierra Leone scandal - to the government of Papua New Guinea when it needed mercenary help. Labour MP Ann Clwyd, a member of the House of Commons International Development Select Committee, will raise questions in Parliament this week. 'Why are we giving taxpayers' money to a firm with a record like DSL so that it can make a profit out of clearing mines in Kosovo?' said Clwyd. 'I want to know what checks were done by the Government.' Since April 1997, DSL has been owned by US security giant Armor Holdings, which sells body armour and riot control equipment. Richard Lloyd, director of the UK working group on land mines, is concerned that firms like DSL are using land mine clearance as a way to gain respectability. Lloyd said: 'The operation in Kosovo is highly sensitive. Aid organisations and charities are experienced and well-equipped to deal with this, but questions have to be asked about whether the same can be said of a militaristic private company with a dodgy track record.' The Campaign Against the Arms Trade will also protest against the DSL contract. DSL has used former British servicemen to offer protection against kidnapping, espionage and terrorism to multinationals operating in 'risky' regions. Nigel Woof, Armor's vice chairman of marketing, dismisses allegations of human rights abuses against DSL. He said DSL is not only used by private corporations but by the UN, human aid groups and Western governments to protect embassies. Woof said: 'We have never, and will never be involved in mercenary activities. We are proud of what we do and operate a disciplined and ethical operation.' However, accusations of human rights abuses have been hard to shake off. It was alleged that DSL trained Colombian police in counter-insurgency techniques using ex-SAS personnel and fed intelligence on anyone opposed to BP to Columbia's 14th brigade - a group of soldiers with a record of atrocities including the massacre of 43 people in 1988. A report by the Parliamentary Human Rights Group entitled 'The Business of Killing' said the main concern was that DSL passed on information on environmentalists and community leaders. Both DSL and BP claimed the only training they gave was defensive. But documents obtained by the Guardian showed that a senior DSL employee, Roger Brown, was in charge of security for the 520-mile Ocensa oil pipeline in Colombia, in which BP is a major shareholder. Brown was a key figure in a proposed pipeline protection project with the 14th Brigade and Israeli security company Silver Shadow, involving attack helicopters and the 'direct supply of anti-guerrilla special weaponry'. When this came to light, BP suspended Brown, who until recently continued to work for DSL. DSL is one of five companies to be awarded mine-clearance contracts worth £13.5m in Kosovo. A spokesman for the International Development Department said: 'We deplore the use of and training of mercenaries, but there was no evidence that DSL should not be granted the contract.'
