webTitle: Angry Lockerbie relatives demand to hear testimony

fields.headline: Angry Lockerbie relatives demand to hear testimony
fields.standfirst:
Lockerbie: special report
University of Glasgow Lockerbie trial briefing
Lockerbie trial documents (Libyan site)
fields.trailText: Relatives of victims of the Lockerbie disaster are locked in a dispute with lawyers prosecuting the two Libyans accused of the bombing after they turned down requests for advance notice of when key witnesses will be giving evidence.
fields.body:
Relatives of victims of the Lockerbie disaster are locked in a dispute with lawyers prosecuting the two Libyans accused of the bombing after they turned down requests for advance notice of when key witnesses will be giving evidence.

Three days into Scotland's biggest ever murder trial, in a specially constructed court at Camp van Zeist in the Netherlands, some relatives have accused prosecutors of ignoring their needs with a deci sion effectively denying them the opportunity to hear crucial testimony.

The prosecution team has listed more than 1,000 witnesses in its case against Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed al-Megrahi, 48, and Al-Amin Khalifa Fhimah, 34, who deny charges of murder, conspiracy to murder and breaching airline security legislation. Their counsel have listed 119 witnesses and have told the court they will present evidence showing Palestinian terrorists were responsible.

All 259 passengers and crew on board Pan Am Flight 103 from London to New York were killed when a bomb concealed inside a radio cassette recorder exploded on 21 December 1988. A further 11 people died in Lockerbie as wreckage landed on the town.

Relatives, spread around 16 countries, have repeatedly asked family liaison officials for advance notice of witnesses to allow them time to get to the court or to one of four remote sites set up in the US and Britain to offer them closed circuit viewing. They have been told two days notice is required before they can attend the remote sites.

The Crown Office, the prosecuting authority, insists that advance notice of the witness schedule would be a security risk. Members of US and British intelligence services and witnesses with links to Middle East terror organisations are expected to be called.

British relatives have not become involved in the dispute, but Rosemary Wolfe, an American whose 20-year-old daughter Miriam was a victim, told The Observer : 'We are seriously concerned about this and have repeatedly asked for more information but it is just another one of those issues left hanging in the ether.'

Marina de Larracoechea, a Basque whose sister Nieves was a stewardess on Pan Am 103 said: 'It is ridiculous that we will not be told when witnesses are going to appear. I have a right to be here to hear the important witnesses.'

Officials are working on a compromise that will allow the relatives to be given gen eral information on which broad areas of evidence are coming up. There is also a secure website and a telephone hotline for families providing updates from the prosecution, the court service and the police.

fields.headline: 'Softie' punk finds life's no riot
fields.standfirst: Al McAlavey looks just the part of an anarchist - and he was duly jailed for 90 days for his May Day antics. But looks can be deceptive, writes John Sweeney
fields.trailText: This is a tale of two Mohican hairdos. The first is the green curl of turf plonked on Winston Churchill's statue in the midst of Whitehall's May Day mayhem; the second a dark tuft of hair riding the tattooed bonce of Al 'The Dog's Bollocks' McAlavey.
fields.body:
This is a tale of two Mohican hairdos. The first is the green curl of turf plonked on Winston Churchill's statue in the midst of Whitehall's May Day mayhem; the second a dark tuft of hair riding the tattooed bonce of Al 'The Dog's Bollocks' McAlavey.

The second got The Dog's Bollocks into trouble with the law. That, and the spider web tattoo on his left elbow, his T-shirt depicting the aforesaid canine private parts, his earrings and nose-rings and his daft-as-a-brush manner.

No old or young Etonian he, the 38-year-old punk rocker pleaded guilty to using threatening words and behaviour towards the police. The stipendiary magistrate, Rosamond Keating, gave him 90 days, saying: 'It is violence for violence's sake and it ruins the chances of other people having a peaceful protest, partly because it encourages others to commit violence.'

McAlavey looked the part of the mad dog anarchist better than the well-spoken housewife, the clothes designer and the Spanish shop assistant who went into the dock in the same court session. He got by far the longest sentence for punching a line of police riot shields. But the story behind his anarchism and his life is sadder and a touch more sympathetic than the tabloid headlines of 'you shamed us' and 'riot thug'.

His address given in court was Prince's Street, Rochester, Kent - a modern council flat in a block that looks like something out of a Polish new town. No black flags, no hissing bomblets, no busts of Kropotkin: only the kettle bubbling, Jemima Puddle Duck in the lavatory and a fluffy rabbit called Toulouse being fed a carrot by six-year-old Sheri. Her mother, Rachel 'Wolf' Jolley, poured the tea and bemoaned the reporters who had dogged her. She had been quoted in the Mirror as saying: 'He was well tanked up. I knew there would be trouble. They were looking for it. He's been an anarchist all his life and has got an appalling record, drunk and disorderly, fighting, you name it...'

Now she seemed rueful about that tongue-lashing and did her best to put the other side of The Dog's Bollocks: 'He's a big softie, really, and he's brilliant with the kids,' - Rikki, 12, Sheri, and Dexi, three, who are not, she added, his.

Jolley told the story of McAlavey's downfall: 'We were at The Sweeps, which is a May Day festival with morris dancers and the like in Rochester, and his mate Garry turned up and said, "There's a riot in London, let's go".'

McAlavey hesitated because he had to work the next day, but then said he would go up to Carnaby Street to buy Dr Marten boots. According to Jolley, he only left Rochester around 4pm, giving him little time to punch police riot shields before he was banged up. The desecration of the Cenotaph took place before he arrived.

He was as much a victim of his love affair with punk as a villain, she reckoned. 'He's got all the LPs, Rattus Norvegicus by The Stranglers, the lot.' She was upset that he was to spend 90 days in prison because she suffers from panic attacks outdoors and Al goes to the supermarket with her.

She was not alone in standing up for The Dog's Bollocks. His boss, Terry Rowe, personnel manager at the Nestledown Bed factory in Strood, said: 'I was gobsmacked when I heard the news. He can have his job back any time. He has not had one day off sick.' The image of rioting scum was beginning to melt in front of my eyes.

The initial May Day protest was - according to Albert Beale, one of the editors of Non-Violence Action Newsletter, 'an incredibly laid-back, fluffy kind of action.' They had reclaimed the streets. But not for long.

The affectionate (and easily removed) wit behind Winnie's green hairdo was knocked flat by what followed: the vandalism of shops, the defacing of the Cenotaph in black spray paint and the arrival of others, including The Dog's Bollocks, hungry for a bit of action. In a knife slash of time the mood changed, and the riot police and the mob danced their unlovely foxtrot around the streets of London.

On Friday Churchill's statue looked as solid as ever, though its granite plinth was swaddled in plastic sheeting after corrosive treatment to attack the graffiti sprayer's moronic disdain 'Dead Twat'. In Whitehall, Sir Walter Raleigh in front of the Ministry of Defence was still badly stained, as if by nicotine. The statue of Bill Slim - the soldiers' general who forged defeat into victory in Burma - had been cleaned of the graffiti of 'Fat Boy', a reference to the pop star who didn't have to fight the fascistic Japanese Imperial Army. At the back of Slim's plinth fag packets, rubbish and a McDonald's carton were strewn. And still the Far East Prisoners of War have not been compensated for their agony, as Martin Bell MP reminded the Commons: 'British heroes every one. Is not the best answer to those who would deface our monuments to the dead to give this kind of gesture to the living?' Not yet, it seems.

In the middle of Whitehall, the Cenotaph was ringed with red poppies, left by members of the Danish anti-Nazi resistance in memory of the British soldiers and airmen who gave their lives for their country's freedom. Close up, the soft porous sandstone of the Cenotaph still clearly bore the scrubbing marks of the repairers, who had failed to rub out the indelible stains of 'Why glorify war?' and other dull-witted squiggles on the nation's monument to the dead of two world wars.

The satire on corporate power - the oil majors, the banks, the info giants, the rule of the motor car - had imploded into an ugly, defiling mess. John Jordan, a sociology lecturer at Sheffield University, stepped into the limelight to make a rare statement on behalf of Reclaim the Streets: 'We respect and celebrate all those people who are, and have been, prepared to stand up to fascism, imperialism and dictatorship.

'That said, we do not necessarily celebrate the generals and the ruling class that send these people to their deaths in order to protect the privileges and control of the few. The abhorrence of sending millions of men to their deaths in the trenches dwarfs the stupidity of any possible slogan on any possible piece of stone.'

Beale, the non-violent activist, moaned: 'I saw a headline in the Sun, appropriately lying in the gutter, exclaiming: "If you vote for Ken, you vote for this", showing a picture of masked rioters smashing windows. It's frustrating but in some ways inevitable. This movement is not as well-organised as it ought to be.'

Not far from The Dog's Bollocks in Kent live Pat Moran and Ken Stamp of the Burma Star Association. Stamp, who flew Lysanders behind enemy lines in a monsoon, and Moran, who worked as an orderly in a 'M*A*S*H' hospital just behind the front line, were both angered at the insult to their comrades.

But Stamp added: 'I have a sympathy for their ideals.' And Moran said: 'The big corporations have got to the stage that they are so powerful ordinary people cannot control them.' And then they stood in front of their Burma Star memorial and quoted the legend:

'When you go home,

Tell them of us - and say

For your tomorrow

We gave our today.'

webTitle: 'I never want to blot out the horror of that night'

fields.headline: 'I never want to blot out the horror of that night'
fields.standfirst:
After 11 years of political wrangling, two Libyan suspects are in court for the mid-air bombing of Flight 103 and 270 deaths. For the relatives this ordeal seems never-ending, reports Stuart Millar in Camp van Zeist

Lockerbie: special report
University of Glasgow Lockerbie trial briefing
Lockerbie trial documents (Libyan site)
fields.trailText: After 11 years of political wrangling, two Libyan suspects are in court for the mid-air bombing of Flight 103 and 270 deaths. For the relatives this ordeal seems never-ending.
fields.body:
Marina de Larrocoechea did not sleep a wink on Tuesday night. Understandable perhaps, after the discomfort of a flight from New York to the Netherlands, but it was not jet lag that kept her awake. It was the anxiety of knowing that within a few hours, after 11 years of grief, struggle and disappointment, two men would go on trial for the murder of her sister, Nieves.

On 21 December, 1988, the Basque air stewardess was killed along with 269 others when a bomb concealed inside a Toshiba radio cassette recorder tore through a Pan Am jumbo jet and sent the blazing wreckage raining down on Lockerbie.

In the full glare of the world's media, the trial of the two Libyans accused of the bombing finally got under way last week in a specially constructed Scottish court in Holland, but behind the legal manoeuvrings and the enormous quantity of coverage generated by Scotland's biggest-ever murder case are bereaved relatives like De Larrocoechea.

After more than a decade of shunning media attention to concentrate on battling to have those responsible brought to justice, she agreed last week to give The Observer an insight into how it felt to sit in court and listen while the full horror of a loved one's death was reconstructed in graphic detail.

'The only thing worse than having to go through all this now is the fact that the bombing happened in the first place,' she said. 'I wish things could be as they were on 20 December 1988 but this is my reality now and I have to see it through.'

Like other relatives of the victims, the 52-year-old designer arrived at Camp van Zeist, a former US air base eight miles from Utrecht, early on Wednesday morning for the opening of the trial which kicked off a little after 10.30 am.

Like the other relatives, she sat in silence in the public gallery as the two Libyans, Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed al- Megrahi, 48, and Al-Amin Khalifa Fhimah, 34, pleaded not guilty to murder and conspiracy to murder. And like the other relatives it was the first time she had seen in person the accused, who were dressed in their national costume of white robes and dark skullcaps. But De Larrocoechea is not like the other relatives in at least one crucial respect: she has grave doubts that the Libyans were involved at all.

'I am having great difficulty accepting these men as the bombers, and I'm having an even harder time believing they were acting alone if they were in it at all,' she said. 'One of the American relatives turned to me and said, "I finally know what a mass murderer looks like." But I can't make such hard statements about them. They are two guys in the middle of this enormous international intrigue.'

Nor does she have much confidence in the prosecution. She has tried and failed to get the court to allow independent legal representation for the relatives in the trial because she fears that the prosecution will be prevented by considerations of national interest from bringing out the full story of Flight 103's destruction. She also fears that it will not address allegations that the US government failed to make public the warnings from terrorist groups in the run-up to the tragedy that an American airline would be targeted.

'If my sister had told me that there had been bomb threats but she was going to get on the plane because she didn't take them seriously, then things would be completely different. At least she would have had the choice, she would have been in control of her own life. Instead she and the other people on the plane were allowed to be massacred.'

Despite her misgivings, however, she was relieved when the trial got under way after months of delay. 'It is absolutely necessary. If nothing else it is the only thing we have left out of all the original scenarios. At last we can see what the Crown have come up with and how far they are prepared to go with it.'

For her and the other relatives - mainly American - the evidence of the first three days was hard. Slowly and in painful detail, the Lord Advocate, Colin Boyd, has reconstructed the events leading up to the explosion on Flight 103 and the horrific aftermath as it fell on Lockerbie.

On Wednesday afternoon a palpable chill ran through the public gallery as the court silently watched on television screens the moment when the plane disappeared off the radar to be replaced by traces of wreckage spreading over south-west Scotland. One American, Susan Cohen, whose 20-year-old daughter Theodora was killed, was so upset by the image that she left the room uncertain whether she would be strong enough to return at all.

But De Larrocoechea found the image easier to deal with. Not only had she seen it at the Scottish fatal accident inquiry but she has made herself face far more graphic evidence since, like the terrible police photographs she still has of the carnage on the ground. Indeed, hardened by the ordeal of the last decade, she came to Camp van Zeist convinced that nothing could still get to her. It took just one word to undermine those defences.

On Thursday morning the court was hearing from eyewitnesses who, one by one, outlined in ghastly simplicity the fireball, the mushroom cloud and the other details of the devastation which hit Lockerbie. The prosecution case was cleverly constructed, starting with an eyewitness over the border near Carlisle and steadily focusing closer and closer to the town and the evidence of witnesses on streets where the wreckage fell.

Jasmine Bell, a social work assistant at the time, had been delivering Christmas food parcels in the Rosebank area of town when a piece of fuselage hit the streets she was in. Wading through the debris on the pavement with her son shortly after one of them had stumbled, she told the court. 'We looked down and my son said, "What is that, mum?" and my first reaction was, "It's OK, it's just meat." Then it registered that it wasn't meat.'

'It was such a brutal description, the word meat,' said De Larrocoechea. 'I didn't expect to be upset by anything, but my stomach just shrank when she said that. My entire system wrenched. In a way that is good though. I don't want to blot out the horror of that night. This was a horrendous massacre and it must be discussed as such.'

There were other traumatic moments. On Friday afternoon the court listened for a full hour as the complete list of victims was read out. Each of the relatives reacted differently as their loved ones name was read; De Larrocoechea bowed her head and clasped her hands. 'That was difficult, but not as difficult as living with it every day,' she said as she left the court afterwards.

The prosecution's meticulous reconstruction of the tragedy has angered some relatives. Bruce Smith, a retired airline pilot who lost his wife Ingrid, emerged from the court after listening to the crash evidence and complained: 'I know that to find diamonds you have to go through a couple of tons of gravel, but today we have gone through three tons of gravel and we've only found a couple of tiny diamonds.' De Larrocoechea is willing to be more patient. 'The American relatives better fasten their seatbelts, because this is going to be a very long ride. The Crown has to set up the case, and there is a real contradiction with some of the relatives. They know that this could take at least a year and they have accepted that, but it just to seems to make them more anxious and impatient on a day-to-day basis.'

Already, however, there have been the first glimpses of the real battleground upon which this case will be fought. The prosecution has yet to get to the nub of the evidence against the Libyans, but William Taylor QC, for Megrahi, and Richard Keen QC, for Fhimah, have started to show how they plan to fight the case as they have cross-examined senior police officers involved in the recovery operation and the subsequent investigation. With each one, the defence has raised the activities of American federal operatives, including FBI and CIA members, at the scene in the days immediately following the tragedy.

'I get a very good sense that the prosecutors mean well,' said De Larrocoechea. 'But I still fear they are going to have a big dilemma at some point over who they are representing, the public interest or the interests of the victims and the relatives. They can't do both. And the defence lawyers seem extremely good, especially Taylor. I get the feeling he has a deadly touch.'

With the first week over, she remains cautious about how much the trial can possibly achieve until the question of the US government's actions has been dealt with. 'This week has been very important for us, because it is a big step forward that a criminal trial is finally happening. But even if the prosecution comes up with a case that convinces me the Libyans really are guilty, and even if they are then found guilty, we will still only be one step closer to justice.'
fields.bodyText: Marina de Larrocoechea did not sleep a wink on Tuesday night. Understandable perhaps, after the discomfort of a flight from New York to the Netherlands, but it was not jet lag that kept her awake. It was the anxiety of knowing that within a few hours, after 11 years of grief, struggle and disappointment, two men would go on trial for the murder of her sister, Nieves. On 21 December, 1988, the Basque air stewardess was killed along with 269 others when a bomb concealed inside a Toshiba radio cassette recorder tore through a Pan Am jumbo jet and sent the blazing wreckage raining down on Lockerbie. In the full glare of the world's media, the trial of the two Libyans accused of the bombing finally got under way last week in a specially constructed Scottish court in Holland, but behind the legal manoeuvrings and the enormous quantity of coverage generated by Scotland's biggest-ever murder case are bereaved relatives like De Larrocoechea. After more than a decade of shunning media attention to concentrate on battling to have those responsible brought to justice, she agreed last week to give The Observer an insight into how it felt to sit in court and listen while the full horror of a loved one's death was reconstructed in graphic detail. 'The only thing worse than having to go through all this now is the fact that the bombing happened in the first place,' she said. 'I wish things could be as they were on 20 December 1988 but this is my reality now and I have to see it through.' Like other relatives of the victims, the 52-year-old designer arrived at Camp van Zeist, a former US air base eight miles from Utrecht, early on Wednesday morning for the opening of the trial which kicked off a little after 10.30 am. Like the other relatives, she sat in silence in the public gallery as the two Libyans, Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed al- Megrahi, 48, and Al-Amin Khalifa Fhimah, 34, pleaded not guilty to murder and conspiracy to murder. And like the other relatives it was the first time she had seen in person the accused, who were dressed in their national costume of white robes and dark skullcaps. But De Larrocoechea is not like the other relatives in at least one crucial respect: she has grave doubts that the Libyans were involved at all. 'I am having great difficulty accepting these men as the bombers, and I'm having an even harder time believing they were acting alone if they were in it at all,' she said. 'One of the American relatives turned to me and said, "I finally know what a mass murderer looks like." But I can't make such hard statements about them. They are two guys in the middle of this enormous international intrigue.' Nor does she have much confidence in the prosecution. She has tried and failed to get the court to allow independent legal representation for the relatives in the trial because she fears that the prosecution will be prevented by considerations of national interest from bringing out the full story of Flight 103's destruction. She also fears that it will not address allegations that the US government failed to make public the warnings from terrorist groups in the run-up to the tragedy that an American airline would be targeted. 'If my sister had told me that there had been bomb threats but she was going to get on the plane because she didn't take them seriously, then things would be completely different. At least she would have had the choice, she would have been in control of her own life. Instead she and the other people on the plane were allowed to be massacred.' Despite her misgivings, however, she was relieved when the trial got under way after months of delay. 'It is absolutely necessary. If nothing else it is the only thing we have left out of all the original scenarios. At last we can see what the Crown have come up with and how far they are prepared to go with it.' For her and the other relatives - mainly American - the evidence of the first three days was hard. Slowly and in painful detail, the Lord Advocate, Colin Boyd, has reconstructed the events leading up to the explosion on Flight 103 and the horrific aftermath as it fell on Lockerbie. On Wednesday afternoon a palpable chill ran through the public gallery as the court silently watched on television screens the moment when the plane disappeared off the radar to be replaced by traces of wreckage spreading over south-west Scotland. One American, Susan Cohen, whose 20-year-old daughter Theodora was killed, was so upset by the image that she left the room uncertain whether she would be strong enough to return at all. But De Larrocoechea found the image easier to deal with. Not only had she seen it at the Scottish fatal accident inquiry but she has made herself face far more graphic evidence since, like the terrible police photographs she still has of the carnage on the ground. Indeed, hardened by the ordeal of the last decade, she came to Camp van Zeist convinced that nothing could still get to her. It took just one word to undermine those defences. On Thursday morning the court was hearing from eyewitnesses who, one by one, outlined in ghastly simplicity the fireball, the mushroom cloud and the other details of the devastation which hit Lockerbie. The prosecution case was cleverly constructed, starting with an eyewitness over the border near Carlisle and steadily focusing closer and closer to the town and the evidence of witnesses on streets where the wreckage fell. Jasmine Bell, a social work assistant at the time, had been delivering Christmas food parcels in the Rosebank area of town when a piece of fuselage hit the streets she was in. Wading through the debris on the pavement with her son shortly after one of them had stumbled, she told the court. 'We looked down and my son said, "What is that, mum?" and my first reaction was, "It's OK, it's just meat." Then it registered that it wasn't meat.' 'It was such a brutal description, the word meat,' said De Larrocoechea. 'I didn't expect to be upset by anything, but my stomach just shrank when she said that. My entire system wrenched. In a way that is good though. I don't want to blot out the horror of that night. This was a horrendous massacre and it must be discussed as such.' There were other traumatic moments. On Friday afternoon the court listened for a full hour as the complete list of victims was read out. Each of the relatives reacted differently as their loved ones name was read; De Larrocoechea bowed her head and clasped her hands. 'That was difficult, but not as difficult as living with it every day,' she said as she left the court afterwards. The prosecution's meticulous reconstruction of the tragedy has angered some relatives. Bruce Smith, a retired airline pilot who lost his wife Ingrid, emerged from the court after listening to the crash evidence and complained: 'I know that to find diamonds you have to go through a couple of tons of gravel, but today we have gone through three tons of gravel and we've only found a couple of tiny diamonds.' De Larrocoechea is willing to be more patient. 'The American relatives better fasten their seatbelts, because this is going to be a very long ride. The Crown has to set up the case, and there is a real contradiction with some of the relatives. They know that this could take at least a year and they have accepted that, but it just to seems to make them more anxious and impatient on a day-to-day basis.' Already, however, there have been the first glimpses of the real battleground upon which this case will be fought. The prosecution has yet to get to the nub of the evidence against the Libyans, but William Taylor QC, for Megrahi, and Richard Keen QC, for Fhimah, have started to show how they plan to fight the case as they have cross-examined senior police officers involved in the recovery operation and the subsequent investigation. With each one, the defence has raised the activities of American federal operatives, including FBI and CIA members, at the scene in the days immediately following the tragedy. 'I get a very good sense that the prosecutors mean well,' said De Larrocoechea. 'But I still fear they are going to have a big dilemma at some point over who they are representing, the public interest or the interests of the victims and the relatives. They can't do both. And the defence lawyers seem extremely good, especially Taylor. I get the feeling he has a deadly touch.' With the first week over, she remains cautious about how much the trial can possibly achieve until the question of the US government's actions has been dealt with. 'This week has been very important for us, because it is a big step forward that a criminal trial is finally happening. But even if the prosecution comes up with a case that convinces me the Libyans really are guilty, and even if they are then found guilty, we will still only be one step closer to justice.'

fields.headline: Chasing an £8bn dream
fields.standfirst: A computer for every pupil? Jamie Doward meets the man who is sure he can swing it
fields.trailText: Professor Henry J. Beker often stresses how much he loves life. Given that the company he founded and chairs, Baltimore Technologies, is worth around £3 billion, which means his personal stake in the business is worth more than £30 million, this is not altogether surprising.
fields.body:
Professor Henry J. Beker often stresses how much he loves life. Given that the company he founded and chairs, Baltimore Technologies, is worth around £3 billion, which means his personal stake in the business is worth more than £30 million, this is not altogether surprising.

But you suspect the real reason the former president of the Institute of Mathematics oozes enthusiasm is that he is afforded a unique opportunity. The former academic now has the chance to put his manifold ideas into practice: the ultimate empirical test of his hypotheses.

'It's just real good to be alive,' Beker says. 'There's a lot of fun to be had. It's exciting because there's a lot of opportunity around. I feel privileged to be in the IT industry at this time.'

In addition to Baltimore, which provides online security solutions to businesses - a market with huge growth potential - Beker has recently accepted the chairmanships of two other fledgling Internet companies. In both cases he has pumped in his own money. Several other investments lie ahead.

And, on top of his ever-expanding portfolio of companies, Beker, 48, is to launch the e-Learning Foundation, a a charity that aims to give every pupil in the UK access to a portable computer at school. Beker's back-of-the-envelope calculations suggest the project will cost a minimum of £8 billion.

Beker's career path has been an unusual one. One day he was happily ensconced in academia; the next, Sir Ernest Harrison,former chairman of Racal Electronics, plucked him from the ivory towers and set the mathematician on the path to becoming an entrepreneur.

Beker's interest in maths emerged at Kilburn Grammar School in London. He later won the University of London prize for best student, which convinced him to go on to do a PhD in mathematics. His first post was as a research assistant in Swansea.

'It was meant to be a two-year post, but after a year I was headhunted by Racal. They were getting more and more into military and security systems. They decided they needed a mathematician, but didn't know how to find one. So they employed a professor from Bath University to look for one.'

Beker didn't know what to think of the offer at first. 'I'd never really thought about moving into industry. I was absolutely focused on academia, churning out research papers. As far as I was concerned, this was art.'

But Racal dangled a large carrot and Beker quitted the groves of academe. Colleagues suggested he was selling out. 'To an extent I was, but it was such a great opportunity - to build a maths department in industry - that I couldn't refuse.'

There was one small problem. Beker was a mathematician working with electronic engineers. He didn't understand what his colleagues were going on about. He found the solution by studying for an engineering degree at night school.

Beker rose through the Racal ranks, ending up as managing director of security firm Chubb, but by 1988 he wanted to do something himself. 'I believed there was going to be a huge opportunity created by people doing business electronically. They would need security. This was in pre-Internet days, but the signs were there.'

Beker called his company Zergo and initially the omens looked good. Several big banks signed up for the company's services and an injection of cash from a venture capital firm allowed Zergo to buy up a smaller rival.

And then came the recession. 'It was all about survival. We were working incredibly hard to stay alive.'

Then the Internet emerged as the good times returned and Zergo was faced with a massive dilemma. Should it tear up its business plan and take a bet on becoming an Internet player?

A subsequent acquisition made Zergo the biggest security player in Europe and Asia, but the US market still had to be cracked. A small Irish company called Baltimore had started to carve out a name for itself in the US. The acquisition was completed at the start of last year, only a few months after Zergo floated on the London Stock Exchange and the new company kept the Baltimore name. A Nasdaq listing followed last November.

Earlier this year, Baltimore Technologies entered the FTSE 100, startling many observers, who had never heard of it and saw the rise of new-economy companies, many with highly inflated values, is a sign of market mania. But Beker argues that Baltimore is now one of the best companies of its type in the world, a claim the City enthusiastically endorsed until March of this year. Between January 1999 and January 2000, Baltimore's share price soared from just under 500p to more than 13,200p, a move that valued the company at close to £6 billion.

The recent slump in the value of technology stocks has cut Baltimore's value in half, although the share price has started to rise again. Beker is now looking to turn two other companies into businesses the size of Baltimore. ProtX is a company that does away with the need for credit card details in online transactions. OverNet Data designs wireless e-commerce services. Too many pies perhaps?

'The good and bad of me, if you like, is that I do have a tremendous amount of energy. I enjoy being involved with things.'

Indeed his most recent project, the details of which have yet to be fully revealed and are still being fleshed out, represents a colossal undertaking: the e-Learning Foundation, which Beker is to spearhead.

'In its broadest sense its aim is to promote and support technology and education. Within the next five years, I would like to see every pupil in the UK with a portable computer of their own, such that they can take from lesson to lesson so that IT becomes just like maths and English, a fundamental enabler. I believe that could put the UK at the forefront of the world.'

Microsoft has given the project some seed capital, but winning the Government around will prove crucial to the project's success. The two sides are in discussions.

'The discussions have been positive, but the Government does have some very justifiable reservations. It needs to ensure there will be equity of access, and it needs to ensure that any funds they put in will be used in the right way.'

Beker says the project will cost something like £8 billion, a sum he acknowledges 'is non-trivial, to put it mildly'. His financing solution is either one of the most enlightened pieces of thinking to have emerged from the dot.com sector, or one of the most naïve, depending on how cynical your view of human nature is.

'I want to see all the new IT companies that are being founded donating a small part of their equity to the e-Learning Foundation. I would claim it's in their interest to do so, because it would make their companies more successful in the future. The equity may not be a lot today, but somewhere there'll be the next generation of Microsofts and Baltimores.'

The established players would be asked to pay into a fund which would work in conjunction with local subsidiaries. Beker says that several companies have already signed up to offer the Foundation equity stakes.

It is a herculean undertaking, but Beker is convinced he can help make it happen.

'No project of this size is going to be without issues and problems. But if you spend all your time thinking of those you're not going to do anything.'

Not a concept widely endorsed in academia.

webTitle: You can argue about who won, but Hague is the biggest loser

fields.headline: You can argue about who won, but Hague is the biggest loser
fields.standfirst:
Tony Blair finally stands exposed as a politician like all the rest. But if the Conservatives think council wins will breed Commons seats, they're wrong. Andy McSmith and Peter Kellner report

Elections 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair finally stands exposed as a politician like all the rest. But if the Conservatives think council wins will breed Commons seats, they're wrong.  Andy McSmith and  Peter Kellner  report
fields.body:
Tony Blair always seemed to rise above party and politics and speak for the nation. Now, the voters see him as a politician. The shocks administered to Labour and the Conservatives last Thursday made it a bad day for politicians.

Not that Blair will shrug off the disappointments. Like many driven people, he is perennially thinking the worst can happen. He is one of few people well-informed about British politics who takes seriously the possibility that the Tories might win the general election.

When William Hague chose to make an election issue out of asylum seekers and the jailing of farmer Tony Martin, even those appalled by his decision feared it might be a winner. One liberal Tory told The Observer, with a visible shudder: 'You have to remember that the last two occasions that we brought down a Labour Government were in 1970, after Enoch Powell's river of blood speech, and 1979, after Margaret Thatcher had played the race card.'

On Thursday night, as it became apparent that the Tories were heading to gain over 600 seats, it appeared that the Hague strategy had worked. But the next day, all the shine was taken off his success by the stunning Liberal Democrat victory in the Romsey by-election. By Friday, the young and relatively little-known Charles Kennedy was the only one of the three main party leaders entitled to go to bed feeling pleased.

As well as passing his first big electoral test by collecting 28 per cent of votes - the highest for the third party since the days when people remembered a Liberal government - Kennedy has earned himself respect in Downing Street.

His relationship with Tony Blair has never been anywhere near as close as the one his predecessor, Paddy Ashdown, enjoyed. Kennedy was seen as less pro-Labour and a bit of a lightweight who did not seem to stand for anything. Even people in his own party moaned that Kennedy 'needed to find his Kosovo' - a reference to Ashdown's ability to speak with authority during the Balkans conflict.

But when Hague raised the asylum-seekers issue, Kennedy seemed to find his 'Kosovo'. He took the fight directly to the Tory leader's doorstep, attacking him for being an opportunist. This tactic obviously worked in Romsey, where Labour voters switched to the Liberal Democrats in large enough numbers to humiliate the Tories.

The scale of that humiliation has yet to sink in. The last time an opposition party lost one of its own seats in a by-election was in 1987, when Labour lost Greenwich, just before losing a general election by more than 100 seats.

No Tory opposition leader in 100 years has presided over a worse result in one of his party's own seats. Hague can at least congratulate himself on his shrewdness in choosing 4 May as the date for the by-election. Had it happened on its own, unleavened by Tory success in other places, the Romsey result would almost certainly have triggered another debilitating round of speculation about Hague's future as party leader.

On Friday, Hague argued that the result was unimportant, as it reflected local factors. His disdain is implausible. Romsey may have been a disaster, even by the standards of the past few years - but it follows a pattern of the Tories failing to recover the ground they lost between 1992 and 1997. Much has been written about Blair's 'heartland' problem; Hague also has his.

Even the Tory argument that the Romsey result was down to tactical voting by Labour supporters is no real comfort to them. Part of Hague's recovery strategy depends on his party recapturing most of the 30 seats they lost to the Lib Dems in 1997. If Labour supporters are willing to switch to the Lib Dems in these seats to keep the Tories out, Hague will be thwarted. Indeed, if only one Labour voter in Tory-Lib Dem marginals switched to the Lib Dems, Charles Kennedy could expect to have another eight MPs in the Commons.

Caught up in Irish politics, Blair has scarcely had time to absorb the results, apart from the unwelcome but unsurprising humiliation of his candidate for the London mayoralty. Labour's poor showing appears to be due to their supporters being far less motivated to vote than the core Tory voters. For the first time since 1992, the Tories had the largest projected share of the national vote. The shock will mean Blair will face a less docile party in Parliament than before, as Labour MPs in marginal seats face the prospect of unemployment. On Tuesday, rebels will put up a spirited opposition to John Prescott's proposed privatisation of air traffic control. The results were described by Labour MP Peter Kilfoyle, who recently resigned as a junior Defence Minister, as a reminder that 'people will not be taken for granted'.

However, in terms of the next general election, the results provide much less encouragement. The Tories' projected national vote share, 37 per cent, was well below the 42-45 per cent an opposition party needs at this stage of a Parliament to stand a real chance of victory at a subsequent general election.

That is not all. The Tories gained less ground than average on Thursday in a number of the areas where they lost seats to Labour in 1997 - such as Exeter, Reading, St Albans, Welwyn Hatfield, Stevenage, Chester, Hastings and Gloucester. This is one reason why two projections of Commons seats made on Friday - one for Sky News, the other for Channel 4 - both showed Labour ahead of the Tories.

If Labour can persuade a reasonable number of its supporters who stayed at home on Thursday to make the journey to the polling station at a general election, then Blair would win comfortably.

Perhaps the most telling comparison is with the Eighties. Then, Labour regularly 'won' mid-term local election contests - and went on to lose the subsequent general elections heavily. One reason was that Labour local councillors were generally more popular than the party's national leadership. The Tories are in much the same position today. Many councillors have escaped the opprobrium heaped on the party nationally for sleaze, incompetence and broken promises. Hague cannot rely on everyone who voted Tory locally on Thursday doing the same at a general election.

Perhaps the most telling comparison is with the Eighties. Then, Labour regularly 'won' mid-term local election contests - and went on to lose the subsequent general elections heavily. One reason was that Labour local councillors were generally more popular than the party's national leadership. The Tories are in much the same position today. Many councillors have escaped the opprobrium heaped on the party nationally for sleaze, incompetence and broken promises. Hague cannot rely on everyone who voted Tory locally on Thursday doing the same at a general election.

webTitle: French fume as British take EC's top jobs

fields.headline: French fume as British take EC's top jobs
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: The culture of the European Commission is changing and the battle lines are being drawn. Just as Britain once talked of 'new' and 'old' Labour, so people are starting to talk of 'new' and 'old' Commission types.
fields.body:
The culture of the European Commission is changing and the battle lines are being drawn. Just as Britain once talked of 'new' and 'old' Labour, so people are starting to talk of 'new' and 'old' Commission types.

Last week Romano Prodi ditched his own spokesman and replaced the EC's most senior civil servant in the name of efficiency. The same reshuffle saw changes in three of the top jobs. A Briton, Jonathan Faull, is set to become Prodi's spokesman and the EU's most senior spin doctor. The Italian President of the European Commission is ruffling feathers, particularly Gallic ones.

The reshuffle has resurrected wild talk of an Anglo-Saxon plot to subvert the EU and weaken its influence from within. The French, fearing their influence is on the wane, are fuming. But at last the ignominious collapse of the disgraced Jacques Santer Commission, which resigned en masse last March after a damning report into the way it was run, is making itself felt.

Carlo Trojan, as Secretary General, wielded enormous influence. Although not accused of impropriety, the Dutchman, who has been moved to Geneva, was felt to be too steeped in the old Santer ways. The Dutch government said it was 'unpleasantly surprised' when it learnt of his demotion.

The other victim of the reshuffle, Ricardo Levi, who was Prodi's spokesman, biographer and friend, was pushed out for different reasons. His faltering English and long-winded vague press briefings did Prodi no favours but he is not being thrown on the scrapheap. Instead he will head a Commission think-tank which will feed policy ideas to Prodi.

Trojan will be replaced by an Irishman, David O'Sullivan, currently in charge of Prodi's private office. O'Sullivan, in turn, will be replaced by Michel Petite of France.

However, Petite's elevation has not been enough to silence French complaints about the number of British officials coming through the ranks.

'Britain was not a founder member of the EU, it isn't in the euro and it's always sniping about Brussels; yet more and more UK officials are making it into high places,' one official said.

A glance at who has the top jobs shows Germany and France still have a stranglehold in the Commission; but Britain is catching up.

One British official offers this explanation: 'The French think the Brits are getting above their station. It's hard enough for them to stomach McDonald's on the Champs Elysées but to see Brussels - traditionally their own backyard - stuffed with Brits is more than they can bear.'

Adding to their misery is the fact that English has largely usurped French as the language of choice in the Commission.

Prodi, aware that the Commission cannot afford another public relations disaster, is doing what Tony Blair did to the Labour Party. He is saying 'modernise or die'. Ironically, Neil Kinnock, Commission Vice-President in charge of internal reform, is leading the charge.

webTitle: What price securing a kosher education?

fields.headline: What price securing a kosher education?
fields.trailText: Tony Blair and Jack Dee apart, we're an irreligious lot, we Brits. Even our Northern Irish branch. Many things have been said about the Queen, but no one's ever dared accuse the head of the Church of being particularly religious. Very, very few of us are regular worshippers. Those of us who are tend to be recent immigrants and favour Catholicism, Islam or those variations of Christianity which involve full immersional baptism and lots of singing. As a spiritual force, the mainstream Church of England is dead on its feet. As a social entity, though, it's becoming a player again - along with the Catholic Church and the Muslim and Jewish religious authorities.
fields.body:
Tony Blair and Jack Dee apart, we're an irreligious lot, we Brits. Even our Northern Irish branch. Many things have been said about the Queen, but no one's ever dared accuse the head of the Church of being particularly religious. Very, very few of us are regular worshippers. Those of us who are tend to be recent immigrants and favour Catholicism, Islam or those variations of Christianity which involve full immersional baptism and lots of singing. As a spiritual force, the mainstream Church of England is dead on its feet. As a social entity, though, it's becoming a player again - along with the Catholic Church and the Muslim and Jewish religious authorities.

This is because of two things: school league tables and parental choice. 'Results achieved by pupils in denominational schools are higher than the average for all schools,' commented a recent review by the Office of Standards in Education. Add parental choice to a theoretically comprehensive system and it was inevitable that parents would learn to work that system. Get tight with Jesus (or Mohammed or God), they figured, and their children would be bumped right on up the waiting list.

It used to be said that the Church of England was 'the Tory Party at prayer'. These days, it might well be described as 'anxious parents on their knees, praying' - that their children will get into the nice little church school just outside their catchment area. The one with a uniform. The one which sits high and mighty on the exam league tables. The one that all their friends' children go to. Parents will now do anything, it seems, to get their child in. Even going to service everybloodyweek. You could say this indicates that our belief in God has mutated into a faith in the redemptive powers of education. Or that we're hypocrites. Or realists. Or that it's 'a classic British compromise'.

There is a paradox at play here, you see. While Americans share an overwhelming belief in God, their laws forbid state funding of religious schools. The same is true in Australia and France. Yet we Brits - pragmatic atheists, by and large - see no problem with having denominational schools. The major attraction is that they're state-funded. Fully independent, fee-paying schools attached to the established religions are in long-term decline. State-funded religious schools, by contrast, are a clear case of getting a little extra something for free.

Take David, the father of two young girls, who moved to a Home County. 'I was very conscious of my desire to have my children educated well and free,' he explains. 'In London, I was stuck in a job I hated but couldn't leave because of the cost of school fees. I figure you either pay your dues to God or to Mammon. You either work harder to pay the school fees or you suck up to Jesus. So I suck up to Jesus.'

His country seat was chosen with school league tables to hand. He and his wife settled on a place with a church at the end of the garden. 'Somebody from the family goes to church at least three weeks out of four,' he says. Are you religious, David? 'God, no.'

Attendance is markedly higher at churches with associated schools than those without. There are the parents, smiling and nodding at the vicar like back-shelf dogs. After service in some parts of inner London, you can't get near the vicar for the press of parents - young-ish, affluent-ish, convinced that a cheery 'splendid sermon, vicar' will edge their child up the waiting list. In my area, some Jewish (well, Jewish atheist) parents have considered putting in the odd appearance to get their child into a favoured church school.

'Parents are simply liars,' laughed the Scouse head of a successful West London Catholic primary. She has a fair point. One of the mothers complaining so volubly about Kathryn Blair supposedly stealing her child's place at her Catholic secondary school turned out to be Greek Orthodox. 'Come the time parents are worrying about getting their children into the local Catholic secondary school, you get a sudden burst of religious fervour. You see them in the front row at Mass, making sure the priest notices them. The priest is on the interviewing committee, too. Tell him you're a fallen Catholic and he'll welcome you with open arms - and your child to the school.'

I know a parent of a child at this sought-after school. Let us call her Tina. Tina told me that to get a place you had to go to Mass every Sunday. 'No, that's not true,' confided the head, smiling softly. 'All I ask is that the parents are Catholic and show some support for the church. I don't insist that they attend every week. But don't you go telling any of them I said that.'

In Catholic circles, this is known as grace through observance - the conviction that, if you go through the motions long enough, you'll eventually develop faith. It's a charming notion - even to a non-believer like me. But does it work?

'I started off cynically; I wanted to get my child into the school,' said Tina. 'So I went to Mass every week. But my attitude towards it gradually changed. I started to believe again. My child has brought me back to the faith of my own childhood.'

As for me, I was born a Catholic atheist and intend staying that way. My wife is a Jewish atheist. Between them, our three children have attended 14 schools, including two religious ones. My half-Catholic, half-Jewish son became head boy of his Church of England primary school. Now he's given up eating pork. Grace through observance, kosher-style?

webTitle: The rising tide of 'sod them' politics

fields.headline: The rising tide of 'sod them' politics
fields.standfirst:
The metropolitan mafia misjudged the temper of the people. Self-denial is what Westminster needs now. Andrew Phillips explains why.

Elections 2000: special report
fields.trailText: The metropolitan mafia misjudged the temper of the people. Self-denial is what Westminster needs now.  Andrew  Phillips explains why.
fields.body:
If democracy was a currency it would be going through the floor. On Thursday, despite the brouhaha of the Mayoral and Greater London Authority elections, the turnout was 33.6 per cent. The established parties garnered little more than half those votes. Ken Livingstone was, par excellence, the 'Sod Them' candidate. Elsewhere the turnout was around 30 per cent.

The previous week saw a political demonstration directed against the only sacred cow we have left - capitalism. It was conducted in a riotous manner which threw up few examples of model citizenship. Maybe it was a straw in an ill wind we would do well to understand.

In May last year we had a catastrophic Euro-election, when a paltry 23 per cent went to the polls. The last general election produced the lowest turnout since before the war, with the young voter show-up reckoned at 40 per cent.

In this age of disparagement, public trust in - and allegiance to - democratic politics and parties are wearing thin. Fewer than one in 50 people belongs to any party - lower than the membership of several charities.

In a speech to the National Council for Voluntary Organisations in February, the Chancellor, Gordon Brown, talked of the need to restore 'civic patriotism', of the limits of 'big government' and big business, and recognised that 'you do not rebuild communities from the top down', enlisting Neil Kinnock's insight that the State must 'not be above our heads, but below our feet'. Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy has also staked this out as one of his themes.

Yet that is how Parliament feels to most people. The frenzied outpourings of government task forces, teams, committees and quangos is way beyond the ken of the 'ordinary' public. The extent of civic bemusement can never have been as profound.

Having been a legislator for a mere 20 months, my worst fears have been surpassed. The legislative process is out of control. Single party, mandate government, served by a stiflingly whipped Commons (the Government has 'won' every vote), encourages production-line legislation, give or take a hold-up in the Lords.

Reforms devised by politicians and civil servants, often with little experience of what they are reforming, are commonplace. Once on the statute book, the real-life impact of new law is rarely, if ever, assessed against the claims made for it.

The legislative overburden is startling. In 1998 Westminster spewed out 2,500 pages of primary, and more than 8,000 pages of secondary, legislation. The EU added around 10ft of shelfspace of regulations and directives.

Much legislation is of such complexity that only a handful can cope with it. Yet dependence on such expertise is dangerous, democratically speaking. The legal expert will be ahead of the public in his field but may well be far behind in general experience.

All this makes for a potentially resentful tension between Westminster/Whitehall and the public. Research by Professor David Buckingham at the Institute of Education confirms that most young people have turned their backs on conventional politics (as opposed to single-issue attachments), and are cynical about its practitioners.

As he puts it, 'this rejection of "official politics" stems not from apathy or ignorance, but from a sense of exclusion. Since they could not make any difference to what happened, why should they bother to find out about it?' David Blunkett's landmark reform in making school citizenship studies compulsory from 2002 is long overdue, but much more is needed.

Another source of public resentment is that politicians rarely show any real interest in what they think or feel except at election times. The problems of disconnectedness tend to get more acute the further one is from London. The country towns of England are still suffering from the succession of changes thrust on them over the last 30 years which have deformed their character and self-esteem.

In 1972 more than 350 borough towns lost self-governing status. By comparison, most of today's town councils possess piffling powers and do not easily lie down under the district councils they are inferior to.

Most former owner-occupied town centre businesses have closed or sold out to national multiples. The new entrepreneurs are invariably too pressured, or disinclined, to participate in civic affairs. Further, if a market town has a superstore on its periphery, it will suck even more of the life out of its centre, and put little back in return.

The steady shutdown of schools and hospitals, county and magistrates' courts, banks, government offices and rail links, has added to the demoralisation and loss of the professional elite. Thus the pool of independent proprietors and professional people, from whom many of the best councillors and civic leaders were drawn, has been steadily depleted.

The metropolitan mafia has misjudged the social politics, too. The ceaseless changes imposed from Westminster and Brussels too often inadvertently disadvantage the already disadvantaged, for whose benefit they are intended. It is so-called ordinary people who cling to communal recognition and identity and the significance it brings to their lives. At least the recent Policy Action Team report on community self-help got the message, concluding that 'self-sufficiency is about communities shaping their own destiny'.

Rebuilding effective democracy will call for unprecedented self-denial by Westminster, only achievable by committed collaboration across the political spectrum.

Lord Phillips of Sudbury is a Liberal Democrat peer and chairman of the Citizenship Foundation

fields.headline: A profession in crisis
fields.standfirst: The scandal of Bristol's paediatric surgeons, the fatal removal of the wrong kidney, and the horrifying trial of Dr Harold Shipman have all forced us to confront a reality we'd rather deny that doctors are not infallible. And yet we still except daily miracles. Maureen Rice reports
fields.trailText: The scandal of Bristol's paediatric surgeons, the fatal removal of the wrong kidney, and the horrifying trial of Dr Harold Shipman have all forced us to confront a reality we'd rather deny that doctors are not infallible. And yet we still except daily miracles. Maureen Rice reports
fields.body:
This is a story of something that happened in the middle of the night on an obstetrics ward at a large London hospital. It's a true story, told to me by a doctor who wants to remain anonymous, and who was then in the early stages of her career. Like all junior doctors, she was working ridiculously long hours. She had just one day off in every fortnight and was lucky if she cleared two hours sleep a night. She was overworked and sleep deprived. Completely standard, given the job.

On this night, the doctor - I'll call her Sarah Carter - was called to the labour ward. A woman in labour, with a history of complications, had developed worryingly high blood-pressure levels. Dr Carter prepared to administer a drug to lower the blood pressure. She gave instructions to prepare the drug to the nurse at the scene, who measured out and prepared the dose, then handed the drug to the doctor, which is the standard procedure. Dr Carter administered the drug And then all hell broke loose.

Dr Carter had asked for the recommended oral dose of the drug, but then administered it intravenously. The nurse who prepared the medicine had opened three pre-measured vials to fulfil the doctor's request. It was an unusually large amount to put in a syringe, but she said nothing. Who knows why? Maybe she was worried about contradicting a doctor. Dr Carter took the syringe without thinking - she hadn't seen the three vials being opened and hadn't realised that she'd automatically asked for an oral dose.

The patient's blood pressure dropped dramatically, and so did the baby's. The situation quickly became dangerous. It was by now 2am. Emergency telephone calls were made, the anaesthetist and registrar were woken up, dragged from their beds and rushed to the scene. The baby was in extreme distress and the ward was swarming with senior doctors. An emergency Caesarean was performed.

There was urgent work to be done helping the baby to breathe, but this time the outcome was a good one. The mother and baby were fine. Dr Carter was not. 'I was completely traumatised by the whole experience. I thought I would have to leave medicine, that I just couldn't take the possible consequences of a mistake. And I realised how easy the mistake had been to make.'

It has been estimated that as many as 33,000 people die in Britain every year as a result of medical errors or accidents. Nobody knows how many near misses there are - mistakes, like Dr Carter's, caught in time to prevent serious injury - but doctors themselves admit they are ubiquitous. Until very recently, these numbers were not acknowledged or discussed. Every accident was treated as an anomaly, a shocking and terrible one-off. The truth - that all doctors make mistakes, including the very best ones - is not what patients want to hear, but it was all that kept Dr Carter in medicine. 'I was upset and depressed about it for months, but I gradually came to realise that this was the kind of mistake that happens all the time. It wasn't a one-off caused by an incompetent - me - but the kind of everyday error that is rife throughout the whole medical system.'

That knowledge is only just hitting the rest of us. A recent spate of high profile and extraordinary cases has focused the full beam of public and media attention on medical mistakes as never before: the scandal of the paediatric heart surgeons at Bristol Royal Infirmary; the case of the surgeon in west Wales who removed the wrong kidney from his patient, causing the patient's death. Even Harold Shipman, the GP who killed at least 15 of his elderly patients deliberately rather than accidentally, exposed a reality we prefer to deny. According to Dr Ian Bogle, who is chairman of the British Medical Association, 'It's a very rare doctor who will get through his or her career without making serious mistakes. The conditions under which doctors work, and the very nature of medicine, means errors are inevitable.'

The nature of medicine means that doctors work under extreme pressure, situations are often urgent, and decisions have to be made in seconds. Under those conditions, what is an error? Removing the wrong kidney is pretty unequivocal, but medicine is an imprecise science. Sometimes we blame error for an unwanted outcome, when the error is an error of judgement, but then only with hindsight. Dr Nick Cheshire, a vascular consultant at St Mary's hospital in Paddington describes the daily judgement calls that may or may not turn out well. 'A patient presents with blocked arteries in his leg and a potential risk of developing gangrene. If we leave the patient as he is there may be a 20 per cent or higher risk to his life over the next year. If we operate, there may be a 5 per cent risk to his life - but that's tomorrow morning; 5 per cent may not sound like a high risk, but if you or a member of your family is one of those 5 per cent, that's 100 per cent as far as you're concerned.'

But there is one group of people, profoundly affected by the consequences of medical mistakes, being overlooked in this rush of reform: the doctors who make them.

Depression, breakdown, leaving the profession and even suicide are common responses among doctors to their own mistakes. It's a high price to pay for the risks we ask them to take every day. Of course, we need protection from bad or incompetent doctors. But what about the good doctors, whose split-second mistakes can have equally terrible consequences? There's no helpline for traumatised doctors, no on-site counselling service or 'buddy' system where they can deal with their guilt and shame. When Dr Carter made her mistake, her impulse was to apologise to the patient 'but there just wasn't any procedure for it. I was discouraged from talking about it at all. It was made plain that I'd made a mistake and that I wasn't to make it again, but beyond that it was kind of bad form to want to discuss it. By the next day, I was expected to be over it, and to just get on with it.'

The pressure on doctors to live up to impossible patient expectations is immense.

There isn't another profession where mistakes are so poorly tolerated or understood, or the price paid for them so high. We may live in a global age, but we're still applying Old Testament standards to doctors. In law, or the media, there's only one response to a doctor who makes a serious mistake: name them, shame them, take them to court and if possible get them struck off. Faced with the human suffering of a victim and their family, it may be a natural human impulse to need somebody to blame. But it won't stop the same mistake from happening to somebody else. We can reduce medical error, but it requires a process that doesn't just involve individual doctors and the health service, but a redefining of the whole culture of medicine and the unwritten contract between doctor and patient. According to Matthew Pitt, a consultant at Great Ormond Street Hospital, and part of the hospital's working group on clinical risk, blaming a doctor for errors ignores the fact that many - maybe most - mistakes are the result of a series of system errors that come together with potentially disastrous consequences. 'It's common for doctors to feel that errors are entirely their own fault. Cool reflection will often bring to light a system dysfunction that has placed the doctor at risk on the front line.'

System dysfunction can mean anything from a missing set of notes to a pharmaceutical company suddenly changing the colour of the label on a drug. In Dr Carter's case, the system allowed oral and intravenous doses to be easily mixed up. The nurse was only required to check that the dosage was accurate according to the doctor's instructions - there was no check that the instruction was accurate in the first place. She was failed again by her working conditions. According to Pitt, 'The mistake when the junior doctor has been up for 24 hours is an obvious example. Instead, it acknowledges that all human beings are fallible, and will sooner or later make mistakes, so systems must be designed that prevent these mistakes from having disastrous consequences. fields.headline: Welcome the wandering tribes
fields.standfirst:
As Britain and the rest of Europe are convulsed by panic over illegal immigration, Jeremy Harding, author of a highly acclaimed new book on the asylum crisis, here argues that far from threatening jobs and draining resources, immigrants are vital to our future growth

Asylum: myths and realities - Observer special
fields.trailText: As Britain and the rest of Europe are convulsed by panic over illegal immigration,  Jeremy Harding, argues that far from threatening jobs and draining resources, immigrants are vital to our future growth
fields.body:
Entering Europe illegally is a dangerous business for asylum seekers and so-called 'economic migrants', whether they come from Iraq, Turkey, Sri Lanka or China. But for the growing numbers of Africans prepared to cross the Sahara in search of a job, the journey is a nightmare.

Williams Osunde grew up in Lagos, Nigeria. He was 20 when he abandoned his studies for lack of funds. He set out north with a group of friends. Their goal was Ceuta, the Spanish enclave tucked into Morocco's Mediterranean coastline - a hike of about 2,000 miles. They each paid £50 for a place on a lorry to the border with Niger. More money changed hands at the frontier. For weeks Williams and his friends were stranded, trying to raise enough cash for the next leg of the journey. A six-day march, and a few rides in trucks, brought them within range of Algeria. Here they hired the services of a trafficker, who took their money, put them in a lorry but dumped them well short of the border. They walked the remaining 50 miles.

While they waited for an opportune moment to cross, one of their party died of thirst. From then on, Williams lost track of the place names and the stages of the journey. It was over 1,000 miles. They did some of it on foot and as far as he knew - he was delirious for much of the time - it took around two months, with occasional lifts in trucks allowing them to strike an average of 20-25 miles a day. By the time they had crossed the desert and reached Ceuta, four more people had died.

I met Williams in a holding camp for illegal sub-Saharan migrants and Algerian asylum-seekers in Ceuta. The territory is one of the European Union's frontline defences against clandestine migration. Since decolonisation in North Africa, Spain has hung on to Ceuta and its twin enclave, Melilla. And so, on Spain's entry into the European Union in 1986, two forward posts of the EU came into existence in Africa. The trickle of people like Williams began in the mid-1990s. In 1997, about 700 'illegals' came up through the Sahara and entered Ceuta from Morocco. By 1998, the figure was nearer 1,000. Last year it was 7,000. A year-on-year increase projected on these figures alone is worrying, to both the Spanish authorities and the EU.

Ceuta is one of several vulnerable flanks of Fortress Europe - a tempting point of transgression where migrant pressure has to be opposed. In 1993 the EU approved funding for a defensive wall round the enclave. It has two high parallel wire fences running for five miles round the territory, a roll of razor wire, a line of electronic sensors and 33 closed-circuit cameras. The cost was estimated at $25 million. The game was on: a contest between the low technologies of willpower and mutiny, and the hi-tech security skills of the rich world.

Last year, as the figures for illegal migrants to Ceuta rose sharply, the authorities began to beef up the defence with better surveillance and some redesign. But officials in the Governor's Office in Ceuta argue privately it will only thin numbers down or drive migrants to take the more dangerous option of fishing boats from the coast of Africa to mainland Spain via the Straits of Gibraltar. One official in the Governor's Office is working on the assumption that, by 2015, between 15 and 20 million migrants will have made a bid for Western Europe via Spanish territory.

No one knows how many 'irregular' migrants are in the EU. Since the early 1990s, tens of thousands have entered from the remains of the Eastern Bloc. And the manner of their entry, aided and often abused by traffickers, means many remain caught in a world of illegality or exploitation.

By the middle of the decade, the Dutch police estimated 75 per cent of Amsterdam's prostitutes were non-nationals. Of these, they believed, 80 per cent were in the country illegally. According to a recent study in the Netherlands, a Dutch prostitute earning $300 a day would see between half and two-thirds of those earnings. But a newcomer from Ukraine, who could earn $500 in a day, could expect $25 in hand at the end of it. Traffickers and crime rings pocket the difference. In 1997 a court in Brussels convicted nine members of a Nigerian prostitution ring. The women recruited in West Africa had been promised asylum to entice them to Europe. They could buy their freedom for $25,000.

But what is the bigger issue here - the presence of illegal migrants or the crimes of indenture and ransom, and insatiable demand in the marketplace? These are not the fault of the illegal migrant herself. Like most people at a disadvantage, she can only collude. Dealing with clandestine migration is high on the EU's agenda. When Austria held the EU presidency two years ago, it suggested in a draft paper on asylum and migration that 1.5 million migrants entered the wealthy European states every year and that 'every other migrant in the "first world" is there illegally'. There is no knowing the truth of this assertion, but one thing is sure: the muddier the conjecture, the better it sticks, and the association with illegality is hard for large numbers of non-nationals in EU countries to shed.

Last week in Romsey, Tory leader William Hague hammered it home shamelessly in the closing stages of the by-election campaign, accusing the Government of being soft on crime and soft on asylum seekers. But it is not surprising asylum seekers take clandestine routes to safety in the West. Britain and other EU members have put a host of exclusionary measures in place, including draconian visa regimes and the penalisation of airlines carrying refugee passengers, to keep them at bay.

For many, illegal entry with the help of traffickers is the only option. Indeed, the traffickers are their lifeline. The Chinese gangs known as snakeheads, who induct women into a life of semi-slavery in the US and Britain, were also the people who ran dissidents to safety in the retreat from Tiananmen Square. Refugees have always kept strange company in seeking sanctuary. Nowadays, they share their routes to safety with disadvantaged 'economic migrants' to whom national borders are simply barriers to prosperity - people like Williams Osunde, who will walk many hundreds of miles for a job.

For most of this year in Britain, asylum seekers have been the object of a tough-talk competition between the parties. But as the last political capital is wrung from their misfortunes, a bigger question is coming into focus: how is it possible to restrict freedom of human movement across borders in a world where the falling price of airline fares and the spread of digital communications encourage the taste for access?

And is it right to restrict it? There are few constraints now on the movement of capital and goods. Yet often the very people who think it a sin to tamper with the self-expression of the markets are the first to call for lower immigration from poorer countries, even though it would take decades of inward immigration to bring about the kind of social change a brisk downsizing or a liquidation by a large corporation like BMW can inject into a social landscape in a year.

Illegal migrants in Western Europe are a tiny minority of the 200 million people worldwide now residing outside their country of origin. They and their legal counterparts account for nothing like the number of immigrants that wealthy countries such as Britain will require in future. 'Very high volumes of migration would be needed,' the OECD reported in 1998, 'to change the trend in ageing populations' in prosperous countries.

The analogy might be a basin of water with the plug out and the tap running. The first gurgling sounds are audible from 2010 onwards, when the ratio of citizens between 15 and 64 to citizens over 65 is no longer sustainable. The shortfall in the first group is so large that, by 2020, according to the OECD, tens of millions of people will be required to restore the ratio in Australia, the US and Britain.

Whether the rich world is deeply confused or simply too single-minded for its own good depends on how you see it. Williams Osunde was in no doubt. While he was in Ceuta waiting to be processed out of the detention camp for illegals as a casual labourer in mainland Spain, a young woman from West Africa was caught on the perimeter. She was in the eighth month of her pregnancy. She committed suicide in a cell before she could be transferred to the camp.

Though Williams had never met her, he insisted on attending the funeral. At the graveside, he read from Ephesians: 'For we wrestle not against the flesh and blood but against principalities - against spiritual wickedness in high places.' The way Williams saw it, there were two domains, that of the rich and that of the poor. And there was a conspiracy to ensure that those from the second who needed to reach the first were kept from doing so.

fields.bodyText: Entering Europe illegally is a dangerous business for asylum seekers and so-called 'economic migrants', whether they come from Iraq, Turkey, Sri Lanka or China. He was 20 when he abandoned his studies for lack of funds. He set out north with a group of friends. Their goal was Ceuta, the Spanish enclave tucked into Morocco's Mediterranean coastline - a hike of about 2,000 miles. They each paid £50 for a place on a lorry to the border with Niger. More money changed hands at the frontier. For weeks Williams and his friends were stranded, trying to raise enough cash for the next leg of the journey. A six-day march, and a few rides in trucks, brought them within range of Algeria. Here they hired the services of a trafficker, who took their money, put them in a lorry but dumped them well short of the border. They walked the remaining 50 miles.
